webTitle: Rebels make the rules in ravaged Sierra Leone

fields.headline: Rebels make the rules in ravaged Sierra Leone
fields.standfirst:
A rare look into the interior shows neither the government nor UN in charge

Background: Sierra Leone's troubled times
fields.trailText: Just outside the little town of Lunsar, less than a hundred miles inland from Freetown, there is a roadblock where the rule of President Tajun Kabbar ends, and that of the rebel leader Foday Sankoh begins.
fields.byline: Robin Denselow in Makeni, rebel-held Sierra Leone
fields.body:
Just outside the little town of Lunsar, less than a hundred miles inland from Freetown, there is a roadblock where the rule of President Tajun Kabbar ends, and that of the rebel leader Foday Sankoh begins.

From here on in, right through to the diamond fields in the east of the country, Mr Sankoh's Revolutionary United Front is in charge. In the shade by the road, armed men of the RUF - and a few armed children scarcely big enough to hold their weapons - sit guarding the piece of string that marks the start of their territory.

In theory, the government and its RUF rivals are no longer in conflict, having signed a peace pact in the Togolese capital of Lome in July last year. Under that deal, there would be an amnesty for everyone involved in the atrocities - including the machete amputations of hands and arms - inflicted during Sierra Leone's eight years of fighting. The RUF would join a new government of national unity, take part in elections next year, and disarm en masse.

But at the string barrier outside Lunsar, national unity looked a pretty notional concept. A little further along the road, the RUF was still firmly in control of the little market town of Makeni, as it has been since seizing the place two years ago. There were RUF gunmen and gun-children in the streets. The RUF still runs its own prison (to which access is denied, even to United Nations observers) and its own military police.

Police war dance

At RUF headquarters in Makeni, local commander Colonel Augustine Bao encouraged the police to demonstrate the RUF war dance, "Hungry Lion". They threw themselves around the office, clawing like lions with their hands, and shouting "Sankoh, our leader".

The government and UN hope, desperately, that these men will start giving up their weapons once a disarmament centre opens in the town in about five weeks. Those who disarm here are promised training, a pardon for any past crimes, protection by UN forces, and a total of £190 to ease their return to civilian life.

Such centres are already operating elsewhere. So far, 17,000 combatants from rebel and pro-government groups have handed in weapons, but only 4,000 from the RUF. It is estimated that at least 15,000 RUF fighters remain in Makeni and the rebel heartland.

UN pushed back

Col Bao insisted that they would give up their weapons, but then added that the needs of his fighters had to be met. He suspected that President Kabbah's camp would deny ex-RUF men their place in the new national army. What if UN troops tried to seize the weapons? He laughed: "You can guess what will happen."

It's a strange scenario. The UN - in need of some good news in Africa after its failures in Somalia, Rwanda and Angola - finds itself watching over a peace deal that depends on whether rebels who have already been granted an amnesty actually give up their weapons.

So far, 6,000 troops have arrived for the Unamsil peace force, and by July the target 11,000 could be in place - the largest UN force currently deployed. The annual cost is estimated at $310m (£195m). For the moment, the UN troops are "sensitising", letting local people get used to them, looking at the terrain - as far as they can - and helping with the "demobilisation" of child soldiers.

The UN troops are not removing roadblocks, however, or taking guns from fighters. In fact, in one notable case confiscation worked the other way round: a Guinean contingent on its way to join Unamsil was relieved of a large quantity of weapons, including machine guns and mortars. There has already been one incident in which UN troops trying to deploy further east, towards the diamond fields, were forced back by RUF men. General VK Jetley, Unamsil's Indian commander, agreed, "We do get stopped, because those are areas that are sensitive, and as you know there is a lot of digging going on".

Lieutenant-Colonel Joe Puraj Wilcznski from Britain's Parachute Regiment, serving as a UN military observer, drove through the town and pointed down a side street. "There are weapons here allocated to every crossroads, with the potential to turn them into check-points. When a child was killed by an explosion we saw people tumbling out of their houses with weapons, AK47s and RPGs. [rocket-propelled grenade launchers]."

Using force, he said, "is not an option" for Unamsil. "These people spilled blood to occupy this territory and they won't give it up" until they trust the peace deal. Foday Sankoh can carry on mining diamonds and keep guns back in case the election goes against him. Mr Sankoh angrily denied he was digging for diamonds - "that's rubbish and nonsense" - and said he had already instructed his men to disarm. "Did you see arms in Makeni?" he demanded. Indeed I had. "Those are military police, they have to be armed because people are travelling with arms."

Later he changed tack and said he was about to disarm. "It's just a matter of time. We should not be pushed".

 Robin Denselow reports on Sierra Leone for Newsnight, BBC2, tonight at 10.30 and tomorrow.

fields.headline: A Long Way From Chicago
fields.trailText: It is 1929 and Joey and his sister travel from the Chicago of Al Capone to the hicksville town of their gran on what is to be the first of a yearly summer visit. Here in her parlour they see their first dead body
fields.body:
A Long Way From Chicago
by Richard Peck
Published by Hodder Children's Books
£3.99

It is 1929 and Joey and his sister travel from the Chicago of Al Capone to the hicksville town of their gran on what is to be the first of a yearly summer visit. Here in her parlour they see their first dead body.

A series of interlinked short stories that telescope in time to 1942, Peck's brilliant book has the polecat reek of authentic American fiction, filled with characters such as Shotgun Cheetham, a gran who behaves with the recklessness of a frontier-town outlaw.

Seen entirely through the eyes of the child, this is a great book about the way you grow up slower than you want and much faster than you ever realise.

fields.headline: The Dare Game
fields.trailText: This sequel to The Story of Tracey Beaker is not in the same league as Wilson's The Illustrated Mum, which scooped this year's Guardian children's award
fields.body:
The Dare Game
by Jacqueline Wilson
Published by Doubleday
£10.99

This sequel to The Story of Tracey Beaker is not in the same league as Wilson's The Illustrated Mum, which scooped this year's Guardian children's award. But, as always with Wilson, the prose is as feisty as her heroine, the armour-plated Tracey, a girl with a hard attitude and the softest of hearts.

Now out of the children's home and living with her foster mum, Cam, Tracey hasn't given up hope of being reunited with her mother. But only as the dares that she sets herself and her friends get wilder, does Tracey finally face up to reality. Wilson tackles subjects that other writers shy away from and this meaty read will win her more fans.

fields.headline: Amber's Secret
fields.trailText: A beautiful, quiet book about faith, miracles and the kindness of strangers, which evokes the lumpy-mince misery of childhood and the sense of being utterly alone
fields.body:
Amber's Secret
by Ann Pilling
Published by Collins
£9.99

"Did you know," said Amber one day to her friend Sally, "that if you pick up the phone and ring Appleford 616 you can talk to God?" It is the 1950s; Sally's dad is abroad and her mum has been taken into hospital. When Sally accidentally shatters her mother's beloved grandfather clock and the mending of the clock becomes mixed up in her mind with the mending of her mother. Desperate, she rings God.

This is a beautiful, quiet book about faith, miracles and the kindness of strangers, which evokes the lumpy-mince misery of childhood and the sense of being utterly alone. Not action-packed enough to appeal across the board, but plenty will fall for its reflective charm.

fields.headline: Heaven Eyes
fields.trailText: Erin, January and Mouse run away from the children's home where they live and set sail on a raft down the river. They are rescued by Heaven Eyes, a girl with webbed hands and feet who believes they are her lost siblings.
fields.body:
Heaven Eyes
by David Almond
Published by Hodder
£10

Erin, January and Mouse run away from the children's home where they live and set sail on a raft down the river. They are rescued by Heaven Eyes, a girl with webbed hands and feet who believes they are her lost siblings.

Set largely in a dilapidated warehouse, Almond's story is a beautiful, eerie tale in which the living and the dead find comfort in each other. What's it about? Who knows? But perhaps about daring to go as far as death and having the bravery to come back again, or about discovering that you don't have to go as far as you think to find yourself. Like Almond's brilliant Skellig, this is a a book about love and faith - particularly faith in yourself and others.

fields.headline: The Famous Adventures of Jack
fields.trailText: A girl walks into a cottage and asks for Jack. "Which Jack did you want?" asks the old woman inside. "They're 10 a penny, Jacks are." Ten a penny - but all extraordinary.
fields.body:
The Famous Adventures of Jack

by Berlie Doherty
Published by Hodder Children's Books
£10.99 hb, £3.99 pb

A girl walks into a cottage and asks for Jack. "Which Jack did you want?" asks the old woman inside. "They're 10 a penny, Jacks are." Ten a penny - but all extraordinary.

Clever Jacks, daft Jacks, Jacks who kill giants. . . Familiar and not so familiar Jacks all turn up in this clever weaving together of a series of short stories. Then there are the talking cats, disappearing castles - and don't forget the magic beans.

Ingeniously splicing the old and the new, this is a book that plays on children's familiarity with fairy tales and which celebrates our need to hear old stories in a new ways.

fields.headline: My First Elmer Joke Book
fields.trailText:
What do elephants talk in their sleep?

Mumbo jumbo
fields.body:
My First Elmer Joke Book
by David McKee
Published by Red Fox
£4.99

What do elephants talk in their sleep? Mumbo jumbo.

What do you give an elephant with big feet? Plenty of room.

I never used to see the point of the cute patchwork elephant: his only purpose seemed to be cute. Maybe that's why babies seem to love him so much. But this little book is incredibly daft and full of joy. The vivid pictures have real wit, which is more than you can say about the jokes, which are all as old as an elephant.

You and your one-year-old will love the colourful pictures, while your four-year-old will wet herself at the sublime silliness of the jokes and wear you out repeating them.

fields.headline: Little Pig Figwort
fields.trailText: The final book from ace kid's writer Branford, who died last year, is a high-spirited tale about a little pig who likes to have fun - so much so that he can't get to sleep.
fields.body:
Little Pig Figwort

by Henrietta Branford, illustrated by Claudio Munoz
Published by Collins
£10.99

The final book from ace kid's writer Branford, who died last year, is a high-spirited tale about a little pig who likes to have fun - so much so that he can't get to sleep. But when he goes to the bottom of the sea the mermaids are sleepy and at the north pole the polar bears growl at him to go home. It is only on the moon that he finds his soulmates, the moon pigs, who play all night.

The I-can't-get-to-sleep picture book is genre in children's fiction, and frankly some of them are a yawn. But Branford's humorous text and Munoz's expressive pictures ensure that this one won't send you to sleep while you are reading it.

fields.headline: Grandma Chickenlegs
fields.trailText: Parents are often so hung up at this stage on getting their children to decipher text that they forget the importance of pictures. But there is nothing babyish about this re-telling of the Baba Yaga story.
fields.body:
Grandma Chickenlegs
by Geraldine McCaughrean, illustrated by Moira Kemp
Published by Doubleday
£9.99

Parents are often so hung up at this stage on getting their children to decipher text that they forget the importance of pictures. But there is nothing babyish about this re-telling of the Baba Yaga story. The poetry of the text is perfectly in tune with colourful pictures that evoke the inner turmoil of little Tatia: when her mother dies, her father marries a woman "with eyes as sharp as needles and a soul as thin as thread".

There is something pleasingly theatrical in the way the pictures show Tatia as a tiny figure and her persecutors as huge presences until the final pages, when the newly confident Tatia soars in the air on a swing over her sleeping father.

fields.headline: Brown - don't underestimate us
fields.trailText: Scotland manager Craig Brown admits the French team operate at a level above his own players every week - but he has warned the world champions against taking his makeshift side too lightly.
fields.body:
Scotland manager Craig Brown admits the French team operate at a level above his own players every week - but he has warned the world champions against taking his makeshift side too lightly.

Brown is more than willing to offer credit to France before tonight's friendly at Hampden Park. But despite the Scots being badly depleted he refuses to accept it may prove a one-sided affair.

After Jackie McNamara became the latest probable starter to withdraw from the squad because of injury, Brown has been left painfully short of numbers against the talented World Cup holders. Celtic wing-back McNamara's hamstring problem means a call-up for Coventry's Paul Telfer, while another uncapped player, Hearts defender Steven Pressley, comes in for Matt Elliott.

The Leicester defender withdrew last night because his three-week-old son Alfie is seriously ill in hospital, joining the likes of Tom Boyd, Craig Burley and Paul Lambert on the sidelines. But a defiant Brown, who must now decide whether to draft any of his newcomers straight into the side, points to occasions in the past when Scotland have been underdogs as reason for hope.

He said: "We haven't got any players in Serie A and fewer in the Premiership than the French have. We have got to show massive respect for the standard of the France team. "They are playing at the top level, the real top level. They're world champions and when you look at the leading clubs they play for you can see why. "If you looked at the transfer value and wages of their players compared to ours you might say we shouldn't be on the same park, but I don't want to be disrespectful to our guys.

"We played against Brazil in the World Cup's opening game in France who are all big, big hitters as individuals and we didn't show an inferiority complex then. "I honestly don't think the French really have a weakness as a side so perhaps all we can hope for is a bit of complacency creeps in if they see we have a weakened team."

Brown insists he has learned to be "philosophical" about the call-offs which have now prompted him to add four names to his original squad after Russell Anderson and Gary Naysmith's introductions yesterday.

Telfer was contacted this morning via a telephone call to Highfield Road manager Gordon Strachan after Brown established the player was keen to play for his country. The player was involved in a horrific car accident earlier in his career when at Luton as a youngster, but Brown has been assured by all concerned that the incident has been consigned to the past.

He added: "Paul was surprised when he found out he was being drafted in, but was very keen to join us. I have wanted to promote him for some time, but every time he has been injured. "Gordon tells me Paul has excelled of late and I think everyone in England knows his quality. After what happened at Luton he just wants to get on with his life now."

Brown accepts his gameplan has had to be altered several times this week and hinted he may now be forced into a less attack-minded approach with a change of formation from 3-4-3 into 3-5-2.

He said: "We have got to balance the team out. It is not quite damage limitation, but we do have to be solid against the French. We have to perform as a very compact unit. "Archie Knox (Scotland assistant coach) is quite surprised at all our withdrawals and cannot believe it, particularly as we looked in good shape when the squad was announced. "The only player I couldn't select who I wanted to last week was Paul Lambert so we have to be disappointed at how many we've lost since then, but we just have to hope now the replacements can do a job for Scotland.

"I know from experience not to pick a team until I see everyone is fully fit. I was probably going to start with Jackie McNamara and Matt Elliott, but now I have to think again." With Colin Cameron looking a probable starter, Brown's main poser appears to be whether to offer either Pressley or Telfer the awesome challenge of an immediate and unexpected debut.

webTitle: If only they had let the man stick to leg-breaks

fields.headline: If only they had let the man stick to leg-breaks
fields.trailText: Walsh plays not for the posh Kingston Cricket Club at Sabina Park but for Melbourne down the road. It was here, where his mother Joan still dishes up stewed peas and the men play dominoes with an extraordinary passion that one thought was reserved for cricket and Appleton rum, that sages in flannels put arms round Walsh's youthful and slender shoulders and persuaded him to be quick instead.
fields.body:
Courtney Walsh really wanted to be a leg-spinner and now there are batsmen all over the world who would like quietly to lynch the man responsible for the damn-fool suggestion that he should bowl fast.

As a confused youngster, at Jamaica's Excelsior High in 1979, Walsh took all 10 wickets for 43 runs against Camperdown High; he took five with pace and five with twirl.

Even as an established Test player he tried to persuade his captain Richie Richardson to let him bowl wrist-spin on a turning pitch. Richardson refused and Walsh's face still turns sour at the memory.

Walsh plays not for the posh Kingston Cricket Club at Sabina Park but for Melbourne down the road. It was here, where his mother Joan still dishes up stewed peas and the men play dominoes with an extraordinary passion that one thought was reserved for cricket and Appleton rum, that sages in flannels put arms round Walsh's youthful and slender shoulders and persuaded him to be quick instead.

Michael Holding, who played for Melbourne at the time, helped. "My first memory of big cricket was when Mikey took 14 wickets against England at the Oval in 1976 and Melbourne decided to mark his return. We raised a posse to go to the airport with banners and flags saying 'Hurricane Holding - welcome home'."

Because of Melbourne and Holding, Walsh became a fast bowler. And today he has a world-record 435 Test wickets. The man is a marvel.

In Jamaica he has not quite matched the greatness of Holding or the notorious aggression of such pacemen as Roy Gilchrist, who was sent home from India for bowling beamers, and Leslie Hylton, who in 1955 was executed for murdering his wife, despite a well supported plea for mercy.

Walsh does not have the aggression even for a good sledge. Jamaica made him an ambassador and gave him a special passport.

"He sledges with his eyes," says Derek Hodgson in his book Courtney: Heart Of The Lion. It was published last year and is already screaming for an updated reprint.

Colin Croft, the man Walsh replaced in the West Indies team in 1983, places his successor "sixth or seventh" in his list of Caribbean quicks, behind Wes Hall, Holding, Joel Garner, Curtly Ambrose and Andy Roberts.

This is a strange order, not only because there is no mention of Malcolm Marshall, undoubtedly the best West Indian fast bowler of all, but also because it underplays the intelligence and professionalism of Roberts, who did so much to build the great side of the 70s and 80s.

Walsh, though, is surely the fittest and most hard-working of them all. Everyone thought Roberts was capable of breaking all records when he reached 100 Test wickets in 19 matches; and Pakistan's Waqar Younis sprinted to 150 in only 27 Tests before his true age, his back and more vigilant umpires slowed his remarkable strike rate. Hall took his wickets quickly enough but was burned out at 30.

Walsh will be 38 this year. His pace - and he was genuinely rapid at times - has slowed but he will still be in England this summer to torture with his deadly ability to move the ball away from the right-hander from wide of the crease and a change of pace which is so well disguised that some have questioned the purity of his action.

England should pick a left-hander or two, for "Cuddy" does not like bowling round the wicket. But in truth nothing will stop him. It never has, just as nothing has stopped him dancing to his vast collection of salsa CDs.

He played, of course, for Gloucestershire too, appearing for them first in 1984 and last in 1998, when he took 106 championship wickets at 17 apiece. His last four matches produced 34 wickets.

He was one of the most successful of all overseas signings. But then he was told, by fax, that he would not be required last season. Gloucestershire, unhappy that he would not be available during the World Cup, and that he had been talking to other counties, even though out of contract, signed Australia's Ian Harvey instead.

"I was astonished that my association with Gloucestershire should be terminated as abruptly and brutally as that," said Walsh. The men at Bristol, one senses, will never be ambassadors.

fields.headline: Scotland 0 - 2 France
fields.trailText: Teams
fields.body:
Teams

Scotland: Sullivan, Ritchie, Dailly, Hendry, Telfer, B Ferguson, Hutchison, Cameron, Davidson, Gallacher, Dodds. Subs: Anderson, Gould, Pressley, Naysmith, Johnston, Burchill, N McCann.

France: Rame, Thuram, Desailly, Blanc, Lizarazu, Giuly, Deschamps, Petit, Djorkaeff, Dugarry, Henry. Subs: Vieira, Pires, Wiltord, Leboeuf, Micoud, Letizi, Djetou.

Referee: Rune Pedersen (Norway)

The home of Scottish football welcomes world champions France for what is the official opening of the renovated Hampden Park. A giant white ribbon draped over one side of the pitch was ceremoniously snipped by an assortment of past Scotland greats shortly before play got underway.
1 Scotland kick off and play the ball wide before being dispossessed. Thuram makes an early break down the right for France but soon runs into trouble.
2 Scotland respond by almost opening the scoring. A nifty flick by Dodds rolls to Gallacher and he urges the ball in to the back of the net without apparently touching it, but the ref knows all and Gallacher is deemed to have handled the ball in.
6 France are attempting to drive the game from midfield with Henry patrolling up front.
8 A long ball by Blanc allows Dugarry to get behind Telfer on the edge of the six-yard box. The Frenchman has a good stab at an awkward shot but puts wide.
10 Dugarry is at the centre of things when he again gets the better of Telfer and tries to release Henry in the penalty area, but Hutchison reads the pass and intercepts
11 Scotland have the best chance of the match so far when Cameron runs on to a long ball played down the middle by Telfer. Momentary confusion between Blanc and Desailly allows Telfer to fluff his moment of glory and shoot wide.
13 Scotland again come close to ending France's run of 12 away games without defeat when a whipped-in cross by Hutchison causes confusion in front of goal and is cleared for a corner. Telfer takes and Petit clears, almost knocking out Dugarry in the process.
19 After an opening spell in which France looked to be establishing an early advantage in terms of movement and possession, Scotland have temporarily won back the initiative and are attempting to take the game to the world champions.
21 Good movement by Djorkaeff deep on the left wins a free-kick for France. Djorkaeff takes but misses everyone.
25 France now getting back into gear. A deep centre misses Djorkaeff on the edge of the six-yard box by inches before Dugarry whips in the return from the left. Henry gets up well to head straight into the hands of 'keeper Sullivan.
29 Dugarry unleashes a blistering right-foot shot from 20 yards after cutting in from the left, but it flies wide of the right-hand upright.
32 Scotland, after a good run of play, are now finding it hard to get out of their half as France, spurred on by their near-misses, push up.
34 France are happy to tease Scotland over the half-way line before knocking it around comfortably in midfield, releasing Dugarry down the left wing and fashioning a break out of nothing. Dugarry looking lively on the left, creating space and putting in good crosses as Scotland continue to defend too deeply.
39 Scotland enjoy a rare excursion upfield. Dailly releases Telfer on the right but his cross is blocked and cleared easily.
43 Craig Brown's men are manage to hold their own despite a flurry of chances for France, the latest of which is nipped in the bud by the referee's whistle. A floated cross by Thuram finds Djorkaeff on the edge of the Scotland. He fluffs an overhead kick and the ball falls kindly for Henry before he can get back on-side.
45 Half-time. Both sides have had chances but Scotland will have to take the game to France as they did at the beginning of the half if they are to achieve a result.

46 Substitutions Wiltord on for Djorkaeff, Micoud on for Giuly, Pressley on for Ritchie, McCann on for Cameron. Scotland come out flying compared to the first half and immediately try to work the ball through midfield.
48 McCann, on for the second half, is doing a good job of restoring order in the middle of the park.
50 Deschamp delivers a centre to Henry on the edge of the Scotland area and the Arsenal striker lays the ball off for Wiltord to shoot over the bar.
51 France begin to reassert their authority as Wiltord proves capable company for Henry.
54 Goal: Scotland 0 - 1 France Micoud picks up the ball near the half-way line, and runs through the middle before finding Wiltord on the right of the penalty area. He looks up, shoots with his right foot and beats Sullivan at the far post.
59 France begin to carve up the midfield and leave Scotland exposed with some outstanding passing and movement.
60 Substitution Vieira on for Deschamps.
63 Gallacher gets into a good position on the left but his cross is too weak and fails to find a head in the six-yard box.
65 France again build from the back when Petit makes a diagonal run from deep and attempts to slide through a pass to the advancing Henry.
67 Micoud does his bit to advance the cause with a probing run from midfield before finding Dugarry on the right. His cross falls to no one but Scotland are unable to clear quickly and another corner results. Comes to nothing.
69 Substitution Johnston on for Telfer.
71 Lovely passing again exposes Scotland. Henry, 20 yards out, passes right to Wiltord who in turn finds Vieira, but the Frenchman fails to to open his international account when he puts his shot wide.
72 Substitution Pires on for Dugarry.
74 Micoud passes for Pires to cross from wide on the right, but Henry can only shoot over from 10 yards.
79 This half appears to be going the way of the first - some bluster at the start from Scotland before France demenstrate to any doubters the qualities that helped make them world champions. Scotland are restricted to playing on the break and firing in long-range shots as France continue to take the game beyond them.
80 Substitution Burchill on for Gallacher. Dodds, massively outnumbered, finds himself on edge of the France area and has a crack from 20 yards.
83 Scotland win a corner and the crowd of 48,157 sense the chance of an honurable draw. McCann takes but Rame gathers cleanly.
88 A late chance for Scotland. Hutchison finds Burchill deep on the right, but he dwells on the ball and allows Desailly to close him down.
90 Goal: Scotland 0 - 2 France Vieira breaks from midfield and the ball is laid back for Henry to slot home a beautiful right-foot shot from 20 yards out. France wrap up the match and Scotland give up all hope. Understandable. Full-time: Scotland 0 - 2 France

webTitle: Healy's pace and poise leave McIlroy purring

fields.headline: Healy's pace and poise leave McIlroy purring
fields.standfirst: Malta 0 - 3 Northern Ireland Hughes 13pen, Quinn 15, Healy 41
fields.trailText: David Healy, the Manchester United striker, played a decisive role in Northern Ireland's comprehensive victory in this friendly here last night.
fields.byline: Malcolm Brodie at the Ta' Qali Stadium
fields.body:
David Healy, the Manchester United striker, played a decisive role in Northern Ireland's comprehensive victory in this friendly here last night.

Healy, who scored twice on his debut in last month's 3-1 win over Luxembourg, again demonstrated his potential with superb pace and running off the ball, crowning his night with a third international goal.

"He is something special, a real find for us, but we must be careful not to put undue pressure on him or expect too much," said the Irish manager Sammy McIlroy.

Northern Ireland have suffered for years from the lack of a proven goalscorer but Healy, aged 20, looks as if he could provide the answer.

In general there is a new vibrancy and passion in the side since McIlroy took over in January, though the real tests are yet to come: against Hungary in Belfast next month and, possibly, Yugoslavia in August. McIlroy is confident he can find a settled side by then for the World Cup qualifiers.

Healy engineered the opening goal after 13 minutes. He swept the ball wide to Michael Hughes, who cut in from the left but was brought down by David Carabott. The Wimbledon winger converted the penalty.

Two minutes later Healy laid off a clipped pass for his striking partner James Quinn to drive over the line. To cap a superlative performance he scored the third five minutes before half-time. Hughes found him with a perfect through-ball and he timed his run to beat the offside trap before pushing his shot under the keeper into the far corner.

Healy almost had another, hitting the post midway through the second half as Malta became demoralised. They have not won a competitive fixture since defeating Estonia 1-0 in 1993 and, thanks to Healy, can now add this result to their pitiful record.

 The substitute Maurice Harkin scored an 89th-minute winner on his debut to give Roy Millar a 2-1 winning start to his reign as the Northern Ireland Under-21 manager. The Hearts striker Andy Kirk gave Northern Ireland the lead after five minutes in Corradino before Michael Galea equalised for Malta 17 minutes later.

Malta (4-4-2): Barry (Muscat, h-t); Said, Buttigieg (Turner, h-t), Debono, Chetcuti; Carabott (Ifeanyi, h-t), Busuttil, Vella, Cutajar; Nwoko (Mallia, 76min), Agius (Mifsud, h-t).

Northern Ireland (4-4-2): Carroll (Wigan; Taylor, (Fulham, h-t); Griffin (St Johnstone), Murdock (Preston; Sonner, Sheffield Wednesday, h-t), Williams (Watford), Nolan (Sheffield Wednesday); Gillespie (Blackburn Rovers; Johnson, Blackburn, 62), Lennon (Leicester), Lomas (West Ham, capt), Hughes (Wimbledon; Horlock, Man City, 77); Quinn (WBA; Coote, Norwich, 69), Healy (Manchester Utd).

Referee: M de Santis (Italy).

fields.headline: Fast and loose
fields.standfirst:
The glossy mag Fast Company is their bible, the all-night photocopy shop is their shrine, the net their lifeblood. Oliver Burkeman meets Britain's Free Agents, who work for whom they like, when they like (and hope they don't get ill)

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: The glossy mag Fast Company is their bible, the all-night photocopy shop is their shrine, the net their lifeblood. Oliver Burkeman meets Britain's Free Agents, who work for whom they like, when they like (and hope they don't get ill)
fields.body:
Karen Meador, John Howitt and Graham Cooper wouldn't claim to be revolutionaries. Karen runs a one-woman professional coaching agency from her Brighton home. John is an internet programmer who works in London during the week and returns to his family home in Nottingham at weekends. Graham was made redundant from a major IT company last September, and now makes a living working as a marketing specialist from his attic.

But there are those who believe that they are in the vanguard of a revolution. They are, in the adrenaline-wired terminology of the heralds of change, "free agents". They know no fixed company loyalties; they work where and when they choose. They aren't employed in organised departments - instead, they come together for months, weeks or even mere days at a time to collaborate on specific projects, pooling their complementary skills before dispersing and moving on to the next challenge. And, unlike the standard-issue freelances, they may prefigure a transformation in the nature of companies and the way all of us relate to them.

"It's liberating, and humanising, in two ways," says Meador. "My previous, employed work involved considerable travel with someone else determining the pace and scheduling. And this is more value-based: I can choose to do only work that fits with my interests and values. I can better target my skills and gifts, and I can say 'no' if I don't think the results of my work will be carried forward."

There are millions like her: 25m in the US alone, according to Dan Pink, the hyperactive self-styled guru of the free-agent lifestyle and editor of the website FreeAgentNation.com, one of a proliferating number of sites springing up to oil the wheels of the new economy. (In the UK, their numbers remain mysterious: the office for national statistics doesn't recognise freelancing as a category, lumping all forms of casual work together.) For Pink, their historical soulmates are the condottieri of medieval Europe - "soldiers fighting on behalf of any sovereign who could pay them and lead them into a worthy battle": the original free lances.

Despite the medieval parallels, though, free agency is only now gathering pace again, Pink argues. "There has long been a social contract of work, in which the individual would give the organisation loyalty, and the organisation would give the individual security. That bargain started breaking down in the 1970s and disappeared in the 1990s. So now individuals are saying: 'I can be more secure with five clients than one boss'."

Free agents are perhaps best defined by what they are not. His antithesis is the "organisation man", as characterised by the sociologist William Whyte in his 1956 book of the same name - loyally conformist corporate employees who gave their life to the company: "A man," Whyte wrote, "who is so completely involved in his work that he cannot distinguish between work and the rest of his life - and is happy that he cannot." But decades of downsizing and outsourcing have changed all that. And technology, champions of the free-agent concept argue, has rendered the efficiencies of the centralised megabusiness all but obsolete.

Nobody's quite sure where the idea of the free agent came from. But the academics who are championing the cause trace it to a 1998 Harvard Business Review article, by Thomas Malone and Robert Laubacher, which coined the phrase "the E-Lance economy" and looked forward to "a world in which business is not controlled through a stable chain of management in a large, permanent company [but] carried out by independent contractors connected through personal computers and electronic networks". Pink, when he's not likening free agents to 15th century hired swordsmen, sees its origins in the US baseball players of the 1970s who refused to be traded between teams and pioneered the idea of the sportsman as independent star.

In better-off pockets of the United States, free agency is fast becoming a religion: its bible is the glossy magazine Fast Company; its shrine is the 24-hour photocopy store, an on-tap business infrastructure where free agents can send faxes, and, in some stores, participate in videoconferences. But it is the internet which is the movement's lifeblood. On the web - at sites such as FreeAgent.com, Guru.com and Workexchange. com - they can pitch for work through "reverse auctions" where clients offer projects and contractors bid for them. On any given day at FreeAgent.com, find almost any kind of work with a hot internet start-up, or get hired as a session musician for a rock band.

That's also the plan for Freelancers.net, a UK equivalent run out of a home office in Berkshire by Dan Winchester and Andy Stowell. "People are beginning to use us as a way to source partners for jobs," says Winchester. "Say I'm a designer and my clients want their website e-commerce enabled. I can use Freelancers.net to track down someone to do it."

For those whose skills are in big demand work is plentiful, and prices high. But much of the work on offer lacks any such glamour. You can, for example, try your hand writing greetings cards verses, on spec - "$10 for anything we use". Or a night shift in data entry for a personnel firm, pay unspecified. Postcards in the windows of newsagents have offered more exciting opportunities.

And it is by no means always a lifestyle freely chosen for the purposes of liberation and self-expression. Graham Cooper - now a marketing consultant after a career in defence technology - found himself on the labour market again in his 50s. "I felt there was little choice than to go alone," he recalls. He wouldn't quite call it a forced decision."One of my former colleagues is on a building site mixing cement - that's what I'd call necessitous."

It can be an isolated lifestyle, too. "You miss the chat around the coffee machine; you can't work flat out for eight hours a day."

And it's difficult, listening to the rhetoric of the new economy's prophets, not to find in the "free agent revolution" an attempt to glamorise temping and insecurity - an illusion in which the workers and the employers are complicit, the former keen not to think of themselves as second-rate, and the latter only too willing to disguise their efficiency drives as the liberation of their former employees.

Whatever the downsides, though, Dan Pink reckons we may not have much choice. "Companies aren't going to go away - it's not as if everybody is going to wake up tomorrow and say 'I'm a free agent'. But companies aren't lasting long: Netscape, a paragon of the new economy, was created in 1993 and had disappeared by 1998, and I don't know how you're expected to have job security in a company that's only alive for four years. Most of us are going to outlive any organisation we may work for."

John is an internet programmer who works in London during the week and returns to his family home in Nottingham at weekends. Graham was made redundant from a major IT company last September, and now makes a living working as a marketing specialist from his attic. But there are those who believe that they are in the vanguard of a revolution. They are, in the adrenaline-wired terminology of the heralds of change, "free agents". They know no fixed company loyalties; they work where and when they choose. They aren't employed in organised departments - instead, they come together for months, weeks or even mere days at a time to collaborate on specific projects, pooling their complementary skills before dispersing and moving on to the next challenge. And, unlike the standard-issue freelances, they may prefigure a transformation in the nature of companies and the way all of us relate to them. "It's liberating, and humanising, in two ways," says Meador. "My previous, employed work involved considerable travel with someone else determining the pace and scheduling. And this is more value-based: I can choose to do only work that fits with my interests and values. I can better target my skills and gifts, and I can say 'no' if I don't think the results of my work will be carried forward." There are millions like her: 25m in the US alone, according to Dan Pink, the hyperactive self-styled guru of the free-agent lifestyle and editor of the website FreeAgentNation.com, one of a proliferating number of sites springing up to oil the wheels of the new economy. His antithesis is the "organisation man", as characterised by the sociologist William Whyte in his 1956 book of the same name - loyally conformist corporate employees who gave their life to the company: "A man," Whyte wrote, "who is so completely involved in his work that he cannot distinguish between work and the rest of his life - and is happy that he cannot." webTitle: Brief encounters: an employment tribunal lawyer writes

fields.headline: Brief encounters: an employment tribunal lawyer writes
fields.standfirst: Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: "It's a good offer. We won't do better if we go into the tribunal."
fields.body:
"It's a good offer. We won't do better if we go into the tribunal."

Jane, my client, is looking at me with a look I see every few months. It's the look you wear when you've steeled yourself to leave the job where the jokes are always about slappers or blowjobs or your tits, and you're never going to get promoted. And you've taken your courage in your hands and brought the claim, and listened for months to your solicitor's equivocations and forebodings. And you've come to the tribunal in the smartest of the suits you used to wear to work and your boyfriend has taken the day off to hold your hand. And you realise the trade-off for all the anger and the pain is a company cheque and a bland reference.

She shakes her head. "I know you said the tribunal couldn't order them to do anything about Mr P or Mr M, but if other people from the company saw what they were like, if they heard my story ... "

She stops because she knows what I'm going to say. I've said it already: that the tribunal can't undo what's been done, can't change the men she worked with, can't really give her the justice she wants.

The boyfriend is looking anxious. They've spent a lot on this case and settlement is the no-risk option. "Do you want me to leave you two alone for a little while to talk about it?" I go outside and walk down the windblown Croydon streets, uniformly grey under the white winter sky, and wish I still smoked.

When I get back to the waiting room, Jane is crying soundlessly into some loo paper and trying to smile. I ask if she knows what she wants to do. "Well, I thought about it and about how maybe I'd feel better seeing them suffer a bit. But Simon and I talked, and we can't really afford it and I'm not sure men like that suffer anyway."

"I think you're doing the right thing. I'll go and tell their counsel and we'll just have to draw up the agreement. Then we go into the tribunal briefly and it'll all be over."

As we're leaving, Jane puts a white hand on my arm and says: "It's not your fault it's like this." Which makes me wonder what my face was doing.

Back in chambers, barristers who are not in court are eating their lunchtime sandwiches in the conference room. One of the silks is telling a "humorous" story about a feminist solicitor who stopped instructing him after he referred to her as a lady. Everyone laughs at this and someone remarks it's a good thing there are no "ladies" in chambers. Whatever that means.

I suddenly can't be bothered to go "Heh heh" at this. I put my sandwiches back in their bag and eat them at my desk.

fields.trailText: Subtlety isn't a prized approach when it comes to revenge, hence the success of 30 staff at a brick factory in the West Midlands, whose parting gesture when they were fired is growing in legend. It wasn't the actual dismissal that provoked them. It was the way in which bosses at the Ibstock Brick Himley plant, near Dudley, told them to make sure their last batch of bricks was up to scratch before leaving. Nursing injured pride, they made one quick adjustment to the machinery and 30,000 bricks came out with the word "Bollocks" imprinted on their surface, to wing their way across the county.
fields.body:
Subtlety isn't a prized approach when it comes to revenge, hence the success of 30 staff at a brick factory in the West Midlands, whose parting gesture when they were fired is growing in legend. It wasn't the actual dismissal that provoked them. It was the way in which bosses at the Ibstock Brick Himley plant, near Dudley, told them to make sure their last batch of bricks was up to scratch before leaving. Nursing injured pride, they made one quick adjustment to the machinery and 30,000 bricks came out with the word "Bollocks" imprinted on their surface, to wing their way across the county. "There was a problem with an amount of bricks," confirmed a factory spokesman understandably keen to point out that they were primarily for use in decorative features and unlikely to be seen from the street. When the prank was discovered managers hastily dispatched sorry notes to their customers, but it was too late. The bricks were already changing hands on the black market and letters from Speechless of Dudley were flying in.

It's easy to laugh at other people's hobbies, so here goes. Keith Herrmann, the director of a company called Exide Electronics in North Carolina, collects (snigger) autographed business cards. He started writing off to the heads of America's biggest companies in 1997 because, he says, he admired their success and didn't think that asking them for autographs would identify him as a crank and rule out his chances of ever working for them. Three years later, he has 200 autographed cards, including the CEOs of three big car-makers and two airliners. His journey hasn't been without controversy, either. There was the time when William Wrigley, head of the gum empire, sent him six packs of Juicy Fruit but no signature, and when he asked JB Foster, CEO of the Newfield Exploration Co, what value he would put on his autographed business card. Foster estimated that his card had a street value of one cup of coffee, which Herrmann chuckled at as self-deprecation and everyone else read as wishful thinking.

webTitle: Freeserve deals will cut Dixons stake

fields.headline: Freeserve deals will cut Dixons stake
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Freeserve, Britain's biggest internet service provider, wants its main shareholder Dixons to cut its stake from 80% to 20%, and it intends to dilute the store's holding by making share-based acquisitions.
fields.body:
Freeserve, Britain's biggest internet service provider, wants its main shareholder Dixons to cut its stake from 80% to 20%, and it intends to dilute the store's holding by making share-based acquisitions.

Nicholas Backhouse, Freeserve's chief financial officer, said yesterday that the "correct long term shareholding" for Dixons would be something like 20%.

After a briefing at the SG Cowen global technology conference in Cannes, he said Freeserve was looking at a number of deals that could dilute the Dixons stake. Last week Freeserve announced its first all-share acquisition of Intracus for £60m.

Intracus is a community website where various groups get together to organise events.

Mr Backhouse said Freeserve would prefer dilution of the Dixons shareholding to one of the other options, the sale of part of the Dixons holding to outsiders.

"Expect to see us doing a lot more deals like that [Intracus]. We will acquire all the things we need to acquire to significantly grow our market share and we will dilute them down."

One route for Dixons to cut its Freeserve stake would be to offer shares in the ISP to its own shareholders. It sold 20% of Freeserve last July.

However Mr Backhouse said this path would not see Dixons "make the most of the value" out of Freeserve. The surge in Freeserve's share recently - they hit a peak of 920p in March and closed at 545.5p yesterday - has finally given it the ability to use its stock to do deals.

Mr Backhouse said Dixons had the right to sell 40% of its Freeserve shareholding from August and the remainder 12 months later.

Freeserve has grown to be the largest internet service provider with about one third of the 7.8m estimated internet users in Britain. Mr Backhouse said it was "perfectly realistic" that Freeserve could come to dominate 50% of the British internet users market, but refused to give a time frame for this target.

The company is transforming itself from an ISP to a web portal similar to Yahoo! It is driving this strategy by seeking content deals and acquisitions.

This week it announced it had collaborated with Bar clays, Britain's second biggest bank, to offer financial services online to small business.

Freeserve last week reported a loss of £2.3m in the quarter ending February 5, while advertising revenue increased and subscriptions grew 50%. It is not expected to turn a profit until 2002.

Total revenue in the quarter was £5.1m, with 55% of that coming from e-commerce and advertising.

It signed 126 advertisers in that period. The company has also counted on increased revenue from telephone tariffs but fierce competition has caused Freeserve to give up its share of those revenues from telephone calls by offering a flat monthly internet access fee which starts next month.

This means it is faced with the battle of finding other ways of substituting that revenue which may come from the boom in online retailing in the next few years.

Fletchers Research predicts that British online retailing business will grow from €350m in 1999 to €5.9bn in 2004.

fields.headline: Tricks of the trade
fields.standfirst:
Interviews by Cayte Williams

Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: Stephen Pyke, 32 editor
fields.body:
Stephen Pyke, 32 editor

I worked for a small publishing company where everyone was very sociable and I got on really well with the boss. My job involved a lot of proofreading which wasn't my strong point but I thought charm would get me through. My boss did try to discuss work problems with me, but I always got her off the subject. Eventually she went away on business and her deputy fired me. I was quite young and vain, but I learnt that no matter how much you ingratiate yourself, unless the boss gets his or her money's worth, your job just isn't going to work out.

Jenny Bates, 35 marketing consultant

I stupidly took a job I knew was an office politics minefield. Part of my brief was to force out another employee but I couldn't, I'm too nice to be Machiavellian. The whole thing was a disaster: I was really unhappy, I lost all self-confidence and my work went downhill. In the end, my colleague left and I got fired for underachieving. My advice is to leave a job as soon as the rot sets in. The next time I felt things weren't working out with a company, I left. It gave me so much confidence to know I'd made the decision to move on.

Kate Reynolds, 26 management consultant trainee

At a consultancy where I worked, I asked my superior if it was OK to send external emails. She said it was and that she sent them all the time. Over the next few months, it became painfully clear we didn't get along. Eventually I was fired for abusing the company email system, which was rich considering everyone else was doing it. I protested but it was no use: if someone is looking for an excuse to fire you, they'll usually cite misuse of company tools or time. I've learnt that when it comes to personal calls and emails, you've got to see company policy in writing.

Craig Harris, 38 IT consultant

I worked for a small company that expanded quickly and became more corporate. I'd been there since day one and was part of a more easy-going culture, and the management consultant they brought in clearly saw me as surplus to requirements. I was no longer involved in decision-making and was offered another job with longer hours but no more money. The bosses wore away at me and eventually I was forced out. I was bitter for a long time; if it ever happened again, I'd seek legal advice, know my rights and be confrontational all down the line.

Amanda Chaplin, 38 production manager

I had a boss who told me how awful my predecessors were, but how great I was. The job was a nightmare. I tried to point out potential problems but he ignored them and when things went wrong, I got the blame. When I reminded him of my warnings, he thought I was making trouble. One day I arrived to be told I wasn't allowed on the premises. In future, if I worked for someone who said all previous employees were rubbish, I'd hear alarm bells. It's false pride to think it's going to be any different for you.

fields.headline: Birthday Boulez
fields.standfirst:
Celebrating Pierre
South Bank Centre, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText: At Sunday night's final concert in the South Bank's weekend-long celebrations for Pierre Boulez's 75th birthday, the composer himself conducted a performance of his Pli Selon Pli with the soprano Valdine Anderson and the Ensemble Intercontemporain. The Festival Hall audience included a good dozen leading British composers, opera intendants and orchestral managers from two continents. The affectionate respect in which Boulez is held by those who have worked with him could not have been more fulsomely demonstrated.
fields.body:
At Sunday night's final concert in the South Bank's weekend-long celebrations for Pierre Boulez's 75th birthday, the composer himself conducted a performance of his Pli Selon Pli with the soprano Valdine Anderson and the Ensemble Intercontemporain. The Festival Hall audience included a good dozen leading British composers, opera intendants and orchestral managers from two continents. The affectionate respect in which Boulez is held by those who have worked with him could not have been more fulsomely demonstrated.

In one sense Pli Selon Pli, completed in 1962, said everything about Boulez's achievement as a composer. He's written nothing better since this five-movement portrait of Mallarmé, which sums up his remarkable orchestral mastery and exhaustively explores the ways in which music and text can cohabit.

Pierre-Laurent Aimard's dazzling piano recital on Saturday afternoon presented the early Boulez, the 12 Notations from 1945 and the First Piano Sonata written a year later. More recent works were featured in the London Sinfonietta's two programmes, conducted by George Benjamin and Pierre-André Valade. Benjamin's programme included the modest Dérive and the potent Eclat. Valade gave a second London outing to the 1998 Sur Incises, which takes a little piano piece and multiplies it into a huge (although over long) study in shimmering resonances for trios of pianos, harps and tuned percussion.

There was a British premiere too. Anthèmes II sets a solo violin (Clio Gould here) in dialogue with computer-transformed images of itself that are projected in real time around the auditorium. It's revealing that Boulez's explorations of new technology allow him to replicate electronically the same multiplicative ideas that he uses on paper in pieces like Sur Incises. Anthèmes contains gorgeous effects, but is protracted.

The South Bank had also arranged a special birthday present, inviting 12 composers to produce a set of piano pieces to mirror Boulez's own Notations. Only a few pieces - an aqueous flurry of figuration from Berio, a fractured melody from Birtwistle, sinewy lyricism from Elliott Carter - really stood out. George Benjamin's offering was naughty but nice, taking a series of chords from Boulez's Dérive and arranging to spell out the tune of Happy Birthday.

Rolf Hind's performance, a real tour de force, was recorded by Radio 3, and within an hour CD copies were being distributed to members of the audience - a wonderful initiative that has immense potential. A tireless educator and facilitator, Boulez himself would thoroughly approve.
fields.bodyText: At Sunday night's final concert in the South Bank's weekend-long celebrations for Pierre Boulez's 75th birthday, the composer himself conducted a performance of his Pli Selon Pli with the soprano Valdine Anderson and the Ensemble Intercontemporain. The Festival Hall audience included a good dozen leading British composers, opera intendants and orchestral managers from two continents. The affectionate respect in which Boulez is held by those who have worked with him could not have been more fulsomely demonstrated. In one sense Pli Selon Pli, completed in 1962, said everything about Boulez's achievement as a composer. He's written nothing better since this five-movement portrait of Mallarmé, which sums up his remarkable orchestral mastery and exhaustively explores the ways in which music and text can cohabit. Pierre-Laurent Aimard's dazzling piano recital on Saturday afternoon presented the early Boulez, the 12 Notations from 1945 and the First Piano Sonata written a year later. More recent works were featured in the London Sinfonietta's two programmes, conducted by George Benjamin and Pierre-André Valade. Benjamin's programme included the modest Dérive and the potent Eclat. Valade gave a second London outing to the 1998 Sur Incises, which takes a little piano piece and multiplies it into a huge (although over long) study in shimmering resonances for trios of pianos, harps and tuned percussion. There was a British premiere too. Anthèmes II sets a solo violin (Clio Gould here) in dialogue with computer-transformed images of itself that are projected in real time around the auditorium. It's revealing that Boulez's explorations of new technology allow him to replicate electronically the same multiplicative ideas that he uses on paper in pieces like Sur Incises. Anthèmes contains gorgeous effects, but is protracted. The South Bank had also arranged a special birthday present, inviting 12 composers to produce a set of piano pieces to mirror Boulez's own Notations. Only a few pieces - an aqueous flurry of figuration from Berio, a fractured melody from Birtwistle, sinewy lyricism from Elliott Carter - really stood out. George Benjamin's offering was naughty but nice, taking a series of chords from Boulez's Dérive and arranging to spell out the tune of Happy Birthday. Rolf Hind's performance, a real tour de force, was recorded by Radio 3, and within an hour CD copies were being distributed to members of the audience - a wonderful initiative that has immense potential. A tireless educator and facilitator, Boulez himself would thoroughly approve.

fields.headline: Opec prepares to raise production
fields.trailText: The world's biggest oil producers were last night poised to rubber stamp a deal which would raise production and reduce global crude prices despite a day of wrangling.
fields.body:
The world's biggest oil producers were last night poised to rubber stamp a deal which would raise production and reduce global crude prices despite a day of wrangling.

Venezuela said the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries had reached agreement and as news from the Vienna summit filtered out May Brent crude was marked down 33 cents to $25.35 (£16) on the International Petroleum Exchange.

Opec has been under intense pressure from the United States to relax output restraints, which sent Brent blend crude prices soaring from $10 to well over $30. The US fears further restraint will drive up inflation and slow economic growth worldwide.

But Opec price doves like Iran desperately fought for the smallest possible output increases, while the cartel's most powerful member Saudi Arabia argued to release an extra 1.7m barrels per day (bpd).

Increases would come on top of official limits for the 10 Opec nations of 22.976m bpd agreed in March last year.

Venezuelan oil minister Ali Rodriguez said Opec had finally reached a consensus arguing: "I believe we have an agreement."

Saudi oil minister Ali al-Naimi raised both thumbs when asked the same ques tion. But Algeria's energy minister Chakib Khelil felt there was still some way to go.

Saudi Arabia is keen to bring crude prices into the $25 to $27 a barrel mark demanded by the US where politicians have demanded legal action against Opec nations if restraints are not eased.

Iranian oil minister Bijan Zanganeh whose country is already under sanctions from the US, said he resented political interference.

fields.headline: Coach party heaven
fields.standfirst:
Sting
Royal Albert Hall, London
Rating: ****
fields.trailText: Sting vexes variously, from his tantrically toned thighs to his annual presence as Our Man at the Grammys, where he recently picked up a trophy for the album Brand New Day to add to his groaning mantelpiece. But where he might be expected to cause the most irritation, live performance - 90 minutes of sub-jazz diddling punctuated by stuff about the rainforest, right? - is his strongest suit.
fields.body:
Sting vexes variously, from his tantrically toned thighs to his annual presence as Our Man at the Grammys, where he recently picked up a trophy for the album Brand New Day to add to his groaning mantelpiece. But where he might be expected to cause the most irritation, live performance - 90 minutes of sub-jazz diddling punctuated by stuff about the rainforest, right? - is his strongest suit.

Maybe it's because, as he starts a 10-night Albert Hall run, he's found an identity that suits him. He's abandoned all pretence of musical exploration and settled into amiable croonerhood, allowing his voice and charm to carry the show. And they do, definitively. It's a long set, with too many solo "hits" (I'm So Happy I Can't Stop Crying, say, which soared to number 54 in 1996) and too few Police ones, but his insinuating drawl, still one of this country's most distinctive, and cocktail-lounge backing lull you into woozy contentment.

Sting's brought in the best talent around, including pianist Jason Rebello, pedal steel guitarist BJ Cole and a striking French rapper, who sketch melancholy fills that complement the dusky back-lighting. All very romantic, which is why we stop after Fields of Gold (properly known as Discs of Gold) to let a fan in the balcony pop the question to his girl friend. When she accepts, Sting breaks into a congratulatory Every Little Thing She Does Is Magic that has the place throbbing in communal mistiness. "I think they've mistaken me for Cilla Black," he says. What a good egg. Mick Hucknall would never have done it.

It helps that he's held on to his hair and figure, presenting a comely bit of eye candy to the ladies clustered up front, who seem to have come on a package tour, free black-and-yellow scarves thrown in. He sings Moon Over Bourbon Street directly to them in Satchmo tones dredged up from some rogue vocal repository he doesn't often visit. Winding up with Roxanne and Every Breath You Take - one can only imagine Puff Daddy's reaction to this desecration of his rap masterpiece - he sends you home feeling benignly entertained. Sting's ascent to good-egghood may put paid to any lingering memory of him in his sexpot prime, but there are worse ways to spend an evening.

 Until April 7. Box office: 0171-589 8212.

webTitle: Sainsbury's offers unsold food to charity

fields.headline: Sainsbury's offers unsold food to charity
fields.trailText: Sainsbury's aims to halt the widespread dumping of its supermarket food by donating 100,000 tonnes of it to homeless people through a newly created community resources manager.
fields.body:
Sainsbury's aims to halt the widespread dumping of its supermarket food by donating 100,000 tonnes of it to homeless people through a newly created community resources manager.

Martin Bowden, a former Hertfordshire store manager has been appointed by Sainsbury directors to take over national responsibility for coordinating food donation and the recycling of equipment. The company claims this role is unique in British firms despite the common deployment of general community affairs teams by other large groups.

The move underlines the way growing criticism of supermarket waste has forced a change in direction. Millions of tonnes of food annually are dumped in landfill waste sites which despoil the countrywide and create gases damaging to the ozone layer.

The food distribution is being organised in coordination with Crisis, the charity for homeless people. Sainsbury is working alongside Marks & Spencer, Pret a Manger and a handful of smaller sandwich shops to help distribute food to hostels run by Crisis FareShare.

Mr Bowden said his elevation to a full-time community resources post would allow him to reach ambitious targets. "For a company to donate and recycle on a large scale it has to be one person's responsibility.

Most companies throw everything away because it is the quickest and easiest solution."

Sachs Ghosh, the chief executive of Crisis, said the work with Sainsbury and a handful of other corporate givers was important. "Only three out of five homeless people get access to fresh food. This is bad for health reasons, for their self-esteem and because homeless people need energy to sort their lives out or to kick drugs."

fields.headline: Banks end ATM double charges
fields.standfirst: MPs keep up pressure on clearers
fields.trailText: Banks and building societies yesterday voted to ban double charging for cash machine withdrawals, ending the threat that customers could be forced to pay out up to £2.50 for taking out just £10.
fields.body:
Banks and building societies yesterday voted to ban double charging for cash machine withdrawals, ending the threat that customers could be forced to pay out up to £2.50 for taking out just £10.

But any hopes the banks may have harboured that this would defuse the row over charges were swiftly dashed with the launch yesterday of a new cross-party parliamentary group dedicated to fighting bank branch closures and excessive cash machine fees.

The decision to abolish double charging came at a meeting in Harrogate of the 34 members of the Link cash machine network. It means customers who use other banks' machines will not face both a "disloyalty charge" from their own bank and a surcharge from the institution owning the machine. Link members caused an outcry when they backed moves to introduce surcharges from January next year for customers of rival banks who use their machines.

While Lloyds TSB hailed the decision as "a victory for common sense" that ensures clarity for customers, there was no agreement on how much people might be charged. Barclays has suggested a charge of £1 while others have yet to declare their position. John Hardy, chief executive of Link, said: "We have to wait for the individual members to make their decisions."

And while Barclays and several other institutions will be dropping disloyalty fees from next year in favour of surcharges, there is no clear industry-wide policy on this, and disloyalty fees have not been abolished. However, it was decided that in a potential double charge situation, the surcharge will take precendence over the disloyalty fee.

The abolition of double charging takes effect from July 1 and affects all ATMs, including the several hundred so-called "convenience" machines, often located in remote areas and which already levy a user fee of typically £1.

The Link board also reaffirmed its commitment to ensuring that by the start of 2001, machines will carry on-screen warnings of any charges that will be imposed.

At the same time as the Link members were meeting, MPs from all parties joined forces to launch a parliamentary group aimed at fighting further cuts in branch networks and opposing exorbitant cash machine charges.

Barclays is closing 172 branches on April 7, and Lloyds TSB and NatWest also have closure programmes.

fields.headline: Jacqueline Wilson's top 10 children's books
fields.trailText: Jacqueline Wilson is the winner of the Guardian Children's Fiction Prize 2000 with The Illustrated Mum
fields.body:
Jacqueline Wilson is the winner of the Guardian Children's Fiction Prize 2000 with The Illustrated Mum
Buy The Illustrated Mum at Amazon.co.uk

1. Ballet Shoes by Noel Streatfield
I longed to go to ballet classes but my mother wouldn't let me, so I read Ballet Shoes again and again and pranced around our flat in my bedroom slippers pretending to be all three Fossil sisters at their stage school.

2. Little Women by Louisa M. Alcott
I loved this book (and I especially loved Jo) so it was a treat to go to Concorde to visit Orchard House where Louisa lived. It was like stepping straight into the book.

3. What Katy Did by Susan Coolidge
I was an only child so I loved reading about large families. I liked Katy best when she was naughty and wild and untidy at the beginning of the book.

4. The Family from One End Street by Eve Garnett
The Ruggles were another large family. I identified strongly with the second child, Kate. I even looked a bit like her, with wispy hair and a drooping hemline!

5. Nancy and Plum by Betty Macdonald
This was my all-time favourite children's book, though no-one else has ever heard of it. Nancy and Plum were two orphan sisters who ran away - it was very stirring stuff.

6. Where the Wild Things Are by Maurice Sendak
I've read this picture book with all kinds of small children and it's never failed. I think it's a masterpiece.

7. Lavender's Blue compiled by Kathleen Lines
My favourite nursery rhyme collection with Harold Jones' exquisite dream-like illustrations.

8. Out of the Dust by Karen Hesse
The only modern children's book that has ever made me cry.

9. The Midwife's Apprentice by Karen Cushman
I usually don't care for historical novels but Karen Cuchman's medieval girls are so real and spirited that they beguile you back into the past.

10. I Capture the Castle by Dodie Smith
Cassandra keeps a journal, writing about her life in a ruined castle. I know the first paragraph off by heart!

webTitle: Temps to ease pain of family leave

fields.headline: Temps to ease pain of family leave
fields.trailText: A nationwide army of highly qualified "supertemps" will be set up to help businesses cover key jobs when staff take maternity and parental leave under plans being considered by the government.
fields.body:
A nationwide army of highly qualified "supertemps" will be set up to help businesses cover key jobs when staff take maternity and parental leave under plans being considered by the government.

Ministers believe the scheme, under which the employment service would act as a giant temping agency, would help ease the burden on business of new family-friendly working regulations by bypassing recruitment costs.

The plan is also intended to provide flexible work opportunities for skilled professionals, particularly mothers who may have dropped out of full-time employment after having children.

The trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, is to examine the plan as part of his consultation on maternity pay and leave, announced in last week's Budget and launched with a meeting of Whitehall officials yesterday.

The review is certain to lead to improved rights, possibly including longer leave and more time off for fathers, potentially putting the government on a collision course with businesses already complaining of over-regulation.

The supertemp scheme would create a pool of skilled temporary workers in specialist fields such as accountancy, IT or management, whose details would be held by local employment service offices. Workers would be able to state their skills and the times they were able to work, perhaps stipulating school terms only.

Small and medium-sized companies needing cover when permanent staff took time off would be able to contact the service to find workers to match their needs, saving on the cost of advertising and recruitment.

Businesses complain that finding temporary workers is a key hidden cost of new rights such as parental leave, under which parents of children under five can take up to 13 weeks off work unpaid. BT estimates its recruitment costs at £1,350 per worker, while the Institute of Personnel and Employment calculates the cost of replacing a junior manager at £7,000.

The minister for women, Tessa Jowell, has commissioned the employment service to examine how the scheme will work, and is strongly backing the proposal. Ministers argue that it will kill two birds with one stone by providing practical help for businesses coping with the costs of improved parental rights, while offering flexible work options for parents who do not want to work full time.

Other workers expected to be keen to become supertemps are professionals who retire early and find they wish to keep in touch with the workplace, and mothers who wish to return to work once their children are older.

Ministers are also considering using the scheme as a gateway to training to help would-be temps update skills to match employers' needs precisely.

A government source said: "One advantage of this is that companies would be more predisposed to any extension of maternity leave if we have shown them beforehand that the government really does want to help them and not simply apply pressure. The intention is to make any changes easier for businesses to handle."

The British Chambers of Commerce last night welcomed the proposal as a "step on the way" to easing the potential burden for business of new maternity rights, but said more support would be needed to compensate small firms for extra costs.

Spokesman Andrew Parkinson said: "It's encouraging that the government is now thinking about the answers before proposing the problems in order to sweeten the pill - that is something that marks a change in the way government consults on these kind of issues.

"But this would not compensate businesses for the full cost of employing extra staff or finding cover for extended maternity leave."

Sarah Jackson, co-chief executive for the family-friendly pressure group Parents at Work, said the plan could help "the thousands of well-qualified people who are longing to work at a level that suits their skills but just don't want to work full time".

"The pressure professional people find themselves under is tremendous, and we know that people are bailing out, particularly in their 40s. This would give them a chance to work on their own terms."

fields.headline: Inspiring flinches
fields.standfirst:
The Ghost Train Tattoo
Royal Exchange Theatre, Manchester
Rating: ***
fields.trailText: Audiences like new plays. So it's heartening to find the Royal Exchange presenting a pair of premieres in rep on its main stage rather than shunting them into the studio. Equally surprising is that actor Simon Robson's contribution, The Ghost Train Tattoo, turns out to be a poetic study of middle-class family life of the kind Robert Bolt might have written in the 50s. Even if technically Robson has a lot to learn, his play has its own deeply felt truth.
fields.body:
Audiences like new plays. So it's heartening to find the Royal Exchange presenting a pair of premieres in rep on its main stage rather than shunting them into the studio. Equally surprising is that actor Simon Robson's contribution, The Ghost Train Tattoo, turns out to be a poetic study of middle-class family life of the kind Robert Bolt might have written in the 50s. Even if technically Robson has a lot to learn, his play has its own deeply felt truth.

He starts from the Tolstoyan assumption that each unhappy family is unhappy in its own unique way. In this case, we are in the comfortable Wiltshire home of an ex-naval officer, George, who over the years manages to destroy two marriages and the lives of his three children. Intending to do good, George causes irreparable harm by treating his offspring as if they were mutinous ratings who needed a touch of the lash; as a result, they are driven variously into flight, suicide and a loveless despair.

You could easily pinpoint Robson's faults. His structure is clumsy. He shifts the spotlight uneasily from one child to another. He is also woefully hazy on social detail: I longed to know how George was able to support two wives and a large family on a naval pension. But Robson's virtue is that he writes with burning indignation about the unthinking destructiveness of fathers: in one of the best scenes, George openly accuses his teenage son, Freddy, of having an affair with his piano-teacher, thereby killing both the boy's musical instinct and the teacher's career. George's first wife, ironically, works for the Swindon Samaritans; but Robson's point is that it is often the do-gooding middle classes who are the most dysfunctional and that we live still with the remnants of a ruined patriarchy where fathers are credited with a quasi-Biblical authority.

Flawed though the play is, it makes you flinch with recognition. Robson also has the gift of leaving scenes poetically suspended just before they reach the point of crisis: a reflection, I suspect, of his actor's instinct. Some parts are better written than others but, in Braham Murray and Sarah Frankcom's suitably mood-indigo production, Terence Wilton lends George exactly the right air of apologetic tyranny. There is incisive support from Joseph Murray as the introspective Freddy, Gabrielle Drake as his interventionist stepmother and Margo Gunn as the seductive piano teacher, whose resonant cry of "Fuck family!" I suspect Robson would endorse.  In rep with Fiona Padfield's Snapshots until April 15. Box office: 0161-833 9833.
