In this case, we are in the comfortable Wiltshire home of an ex-naval officer, George, who over the years manages to destroy two marriages and the lives of his three children. Intending to do good, George causes irreparable harm by treating his offspring as if they were mutinous ratings who needed a touch of the lash; as a result, they are driven variously into flight, suicide and a loveless despair. You could easily pinpoint Robson's faults. His structure is clumsy. He shifts the spotlight uneasily from one child to another. He is also woefully hazy on social detail: I longed to know how George was able to support two wives and a large family on a naval pension. But Robson's virtue is that he writes with burning indignation about the unthinking destructiveness of fathers: in one of the best scenes, George openly accuses his teenage son, Freddy, of having an affair with his piano-teacher, thereby killing both the boy's musical instinct and the teacher's career. George's first wife, ironically, works for the Swindon Samaritans; but Robson's point is that it is often the do-gooding middle classes who are the most dysfunctional and that we live still with the remnants of a ruined patriarchy where fathers are credited with a quasi-Biblical authority. Flawed though the play is, it makes you flinch with recognition. Robson also has the gift of leaving scenes poetically suspended just before they reach the point of crisis: a reflection, I suspect, of his actor's instinct. Some parts are better written than others but, in Braham Murray and Sarah Frankcom's suitably mood-indigo production, Terence Wilton lends George exactly the right air of apologetic tyranny. There is incisive support from Joseph Murray as the introspective Freddy, Gabrielle Drake as his interventionist stepmother and Margo Gunn as the seductive piano teacher, whose resonant cry of "Fuck family!" I suspect Robson would endorse.  In rep with Fiona Padfield's Snapshots until April 15. Box office: 0161-833 9833.

webTitle: A first for Giggs under friendly fire

fields.headline: A first for Giggs under friendly fire
fields.trailText: Cardiff will witness a piece of history tomorrow when Ryan Giggs plays his first friendly for Wales since his debut in 1991. And if the Manchester United winger shows the same attacking prowess on the pitch as he did off it yesterday, Finland may be in trouble.
fields.body:
Cardiff will witness a piece of history tomorrow when Ryan Giggs plays his first friendly for Wales since his debut in 1991. And if the Manchester United winger shows the same attacking prowess on the pitch as he did off it yesterday, Finland may be in trouble.

"When people say you don't want to play for your country it hurts," Giggs said. "Then you find people having polls asking fans whether I should be picked to play for my country in future, and that's just stupid because I always give 100% when I play for Wales.

"I hope that by playing on Wednesday it will finally kill off the thing about me not playing in friendlies for Wales."

Trinidad and Tobago are prepared to risk United's wrath by calling up Dwight Yorke for the second leg of their World Cup qualifier against the Dominican Republic. The striker has been excused from the first leg, which clashes with United's Champions League tie at Real Madrid. But Trinidad's coach Ian Porterfield says he may use him for the return on April 16 if the tie is in the balance.

Chelsea have signed Sebastian Kneissl, a 17-year-old German youth international striker, from Eintracht Frankfurt.

 Steve Guppy has been cleared of ticket-touting. The Leicester and England wing-back and Ian Andrews, the Leicester physiotherapist, have been been found not guilty by an FA disciplinary commission looking into the distribution of tickets for the Worthington Cup final last season. The other seven players and officials under investigation, including Andy Impey, Scott Taylor and Tony Cottee, must attend a meeting at a Heathrow hotel at lunchtime today to discover their fate.

webTitle: Hignett leads Barnsley onwards and upwards

fields.headline: Hignett leads Barnsley onwards and upwards
fields.trailText: Barnlsey 3 - 0 Grimsby
fields.body:
Barnsley's manager Dave Bassett had warned his side not to lapse into "survival football" after recent signs that their First Division promotion campaign was becoming lost in apprehension.

But to be disturbed by Grimsby would be an irrational fear to rank alongside chickens or deathly silences. Barnsley's victory was readily won and they went level on points with second-place Ipswich Town.

Confidence was not an issue as far as the inimitable Tommy Tyke is concerned. The match-programme's most famous cartoon character was revelling in the possibility that Barnsley can exchange places in the Premiership with Sheffield Wednesday at the end of the season. "It'd really put tin 'at on it nar, wouldn't it, if Reds went up as t'Owls cum darn?"

Grimsby did not immediately look like a side who would stand in their way: one of the worst away records in the division and a small gaggle of fans bawling "We only sing when we're fishing", which seems a persuasive enough argument for the reduction of North Sea quotas overnight.

Twenty minutes without producing an opening of note further prayed upon Barnsley's composure but then they might have scored twice in a minute, Mark Nicholls blocking Chris Morgan's shot after Matty Appleby had surged into the area, and Neil Shipperley driving an equally good opportunity against the legs of the goalkeeper Danny Coyne.

Eric Tinkler proved to be more clinical, the South African sweeping the ball into the attic of the net after Bruce Dyer had got to the by-line.

The second half began as inconsequentially as the first, al though the time could always be whiled away by deciphering the numbers on the Grimsby shirts, a task that would have led even Sherlock Holmes to exclaim: "You must be joking, Watson. Pass me my opium."

No matter. The Oakwell crowd were soon able to celebrate a second time. Shipperley turned Steve Livingstone nine yards out and, although Coyne managed some contact on the shot, the ball crossed the line and a routine victory became apparent.

The catalyst of this Barnsley side, though, invariably remains Craig Hignett. He played in fits and starts but when he is in full flow down the right, the team tend to prosper. He has never shown such verve and confidence as this season, and another crack at the Premiership would be a fitting reward.

In fact it was Hignett who collected Barnsley's third, exchanging passes with the substitute Nicky Eaden and applying a smooth finish.

webTitle: When even the rumour mongers stop, you're in trouble

fields.headline: When even the rumour mongers stop, you're in trouble
fields.trailText: A common explanation of those who voice doubt about Peter Reid is that supporters are fickle, but on Saturday fans were not reacting to a few months of frustration but to five decades of it.
fields.body:
Until Saturday, to the outside world the idea of the Sunderland boss Peter Reid being booed by home fans at the Stadium of Light probably seemed about as plausible as Steve Ogrizovic replacing Liz Hurley as the Face of Estée Lauder. In the north-east, however, the abuse came as less of a shock.

The north-east crackles with football gossip. You can barely step outside without somebody assailing you with a rumour, usually picked up on an intelligence network that apparently includes everyone from the brother-in-law of the chief constable to the bloke who fitted Juninho's satellite dish. Naturally, then, when Sunderland sold Michael Bridges to Leeds United during the summer I expected to hear something juicy. Possibly even an allegation so salacious that it might top the nonsense that follows whenever anyone from the region says, "Well, you know the real reason the Toon sold Andy Cole, don't you?"

When nothing emerged, I asked a long-time Sunderland season-ticket holder what lay behind the deal. His answer was in many ways more shocking than anything I could have imagined. The man simply frowned and said: "The fact that Peter Reid is totally clueless."

Behind this bald statement lay something even more worrying for the Sunderland manager. Because when fans in the north-east don't react to the selling of a star by concocting a justification for it involving a trio of Ukrainian lap dancers, an industrial quantity of vegetable oil and a trained goat, then whoever is responsible for the sale is on shaky ground indeed.

So it has proved, with Sunderland's poor start to the millennium rapidly bringing unrest. A common explanation of those who voice doubt about Reid is that they are fickle. This is to misunderstand the situation. At any club who have struggled to fulfil their potential for as long as Sunderland, the attitude of the rank and file to the management is always likely to mirror that at a TUC conference. On Saturday fans were not reacting to a few months of frustration but to five decades of it.

Sunderland were once one of England's most successful clubs. They have consistently drawn huge crowds. In the 1949-50 season, for example, the aggregate attendance at Roker Park topped the million mark. Founder members of the Football League, Sunderland and their supporters did not experience relegation until 1958. That debacle has left a bitter legacy.

Widely held responsible was the manager, a man whose name is still so commonly prefixed on Wearside that a visitor might think the Rokermen were once coached by someone named Thatclown Alan-Brown. Since then it has been an uphill struggle for anybody taking charge. And as the years of underachievement have gone by, the gradient has got steeper and steeper, taking a savage upturn during the mid-80s when Lawrie McMenemy arrived as the Saviour and left just in time to avoid being crucified.

Part of Reid's problem, then, is a common one to any manager of a club with Sunderland's history and support. The supporters are romantics. He, generally, is a pragmatist. They want Gone With The Wind, he leans more toward gritty, kitchen-sink drama.

On Wearside this situation is exacerbated by the close proximity of their bitter rivals Newcastle. That city has roughly the same population as Sunderland but somehow always seems bigger. The same is true of the football clubs. The Magpies appear to attract publicity almost effortlessly. The other clubs in the region feel they have to do the sporting equivalent of dancing naked on the table yelling "Look at me!" to merit even the most cursory attention. And just when Sunderland felt the flashbulbs turning their way, along came Bobby Robson and their own three-month spell without a win.

Sunderland's captain during the club's last great era was Raich Carter. He was a tough man, as anybody who grew up in a Durham pit village with the name Horatio would be. Recalling the crowds at Roker Park during the 30s, however, he was known to soften. "They sacrificed so much to come and see us," he once said. "We were their only hope." Nowadays people talk of the pressure created by the vast amounts of money that have flooded into the game. As Reid is no doubt aware, the old-fashioned burden of expectation is less tangible but a good deal heavier.

Australia win by six wickets
fields.trailText: Australia beat New Zealand by six wickets in Wellington yesterday to secure the series 2-0 with one to play and take their winning Test sequence to nine, an Australian record and only two short of West Indies' run between 1983 and 1985.
fields.body:
Australia beat New Zealand by six wickets in Wellington yesterday to secure the series 2-0 with one to play and take their winning Test sequence to nine, an Australian record and only two short of West Indies' run between 1983 and 1985.

Set 174 to win, Australia reached their target in fading light after tea. Their victory took them past the eight in consecutive Tests against England that Warwick Armstrong's 1920-21 team recorded.

If they win the third Test in Hamilton starting on Friday their chance to equal the world record will come against West Indies in Brisbane later this year.

Australia were in cool control yesterday. New Zealand, starting with a lead of 68, were looking to the first-innings centurion Chris Cairns and Stephen Fleming to extend their sixth-wicket partnership of 105. But Cairns added only eight and Fleming seven.

Shane Warne, with three second-innings wickets, moved his total on to 363, eighth highest in the world, as Courtney Walsh was straining in the Caribbean to go from second to first past Kapil Dev.

The New Zealand spinner Daniel Vettori will undergo a bone scan today to determine whether he is fit for Friday.

webTitle: Fans furious at Wembley seating plans

fields.headline: Fans furious at Wembley seating plans
fields.standfirst: New stadium creams off 15% for corporate hospitality and season tickets
fields.trailText: Almost 14,000 seats in the new Wembley stadium, which will have a capacity of 90,000, are to be set aside for corporate guests and wealthy fans in a move that has angered supporters' groups who claim it is a further sign of the game pricing out traditional followers.
fields.body:
Almost 14,000 seats in the new Wembley stadium, which will have a capacity of 90,000, are to be set aside for corporate guests and wealthy fans in a move that has angered supporters' groups who claim it is a further sign of the game pricing out traditional followers.

One of the most controversial aspects of the new seating arrangements is the plan to have 7,000 club seats which will allow those who buy them a guaranteed seat for every event at Wembley, including FA and Worthington Cup finals, all play-off matches, England internationals and rugby league finals.

The seats, which will be padded and slightly larger than those in the rest of the stadium, will cost £2,000 per season. Given that some who buy club seats may not wish to attend all events, certain matches could take place before rows of empty seats with fans of the teams involved unable to secure a ticket.

Wembley officials have said that owners of club seats will not be allowed to sell their tickets for events they do not wish to attend, in a move designed to prevent touts from buying them and selling them on a match-by-match basis.

Apart from the 7,000 club seats, another 4,000 are to be made available for corporate guests, where the ticket price will include a meal before the game. Around 1,000 seats are to be made available for sponsors and another 1,800 wealthy fans will be accommodated in executive boxes around the stadium.

Wembley officials have confirmed that the exclusive seating arrangements mean that there will be an increase of only 10,000 tickets for general admission. For events such as an FA Cup final this means that each club is at most likely to be 5,000 tickets better off in its allocation, raising concerns that the increased capacity of the new Wembley has not catered for genuine fans.

Members of the Football Supporters Association have voiced concerns over the arrangements, claiming that traditional, less well-off fans have again been overlooked.

Its spokesman Kevin Miles said: "A play-off game could be the biggest game in a devoted fan's life and yet seats could remain empty when it takes place because it might not be as glamorous to the well-heeled, part-time supporters who might buy the club seats.

"This is all part of a developing trend. Football feels that it's boom time, that it can overlook commitment, loyalty and devotion from fans in return for extracting the highest price for a seat.

"Football stadia should be packed with the people to whom the game means the most, not people who can afford to pay the most."

Wembley National Stadium Limited, the FA subsidiary company set up to oversee construction of the new stadium, denies that too much space has been set aside for corporate and wealthy fans. It claims only 6.4% of the new stadium is for corporate guests and that most Premier League clubs have at least double that of corporate hospitality.

Its spokesman Chris Palmer added: "The club seats are not corporate seats. We are confident they will not lead to rows of empty seats during some matches. We will make sure that they will be bought by genuine football fans and it will be illegal for anyone to sell them on.

"At the moment football is either champagne or Bovril. We have always said that we aim to provide a range of facilities in the new stadium."

Plans for the new Wembley are to be considered by Brent Council, the local authority, next month and, if permission is given, building work will start this year. The £350m project, led by Chelsea's chairman Ken Bates, will include conference facilities and a hotel.

Wembley officials remain confident that club seats will not be purchased by touts, who would view the £2,000 outlay as a sound investment given the guarantee of tickets for all events at Wembley, though Palmer refused to elaborate on how it would prevent touts getting in on the act.

Officials from Brent Council and WNSL have been locked in dispute recently over plans for the stadium. Council officials have threatened to refuse planning permission unless money is contributed to the cost of redeveloping Wembley Park underground station and surrounding roads.

The two sides are believed to be close to agreement, allowing work to begin on what has promised to be the best football stadium in the world.

fields.headline: Nic bashing, Cheque cashing and High fashion
fields.trailText: NIC SOLITO
fields.body:
NIC SOLITO

"Pido disculpas a la plantilla, al club y a todos los socios." They're the words everyone's been waiting to hear. Unfortunately, now that they've heard them, nobody knows what they mean. But the Fiver can exclusively reveal that the above statement is an apology to Real Madrid, the club, the board and the fans. Not only that, but it's an apology from the sizeable mouth of Lonely Nicolas Anelka.

Lonely Nic, in the middle of a 45-day ban imposed by the club for missing training (amongst other things), revealed his shame to the world today and asked for Real's forgiveness. Forgiveness which, coincidentally, would free him up to play for Real against Manchester United in Big Cup next week. "Debido a los próximos compromisos del club," read Nic from a prepared statement today, "Me pongo a disposición de este para lo que desee, y acepto la sanción que me sea impuesta."

Which basically means he is prepared to suck the bunions off Lorenzo Sanz's feet if he'll give him a game. Real will make their own statement on the situation later today, but it is thought that the club are prepared to give Lonely Nic the benefit of the doubt. This has everything to do with a sudden belief in the power of rehabilitation of course, and nothing to do with the fact that Fernando Morientes, Real's first choice striker, is injured.

NO FIVER? NO COMMENT

Forget the Mirror. Your number one stop for financial news should always be the Fiver. Today's briefing from the City concerns another torrid session for US equities as blue chip... hold on... no, it's all about Manchester United. Money Mart Edwards and chairman Sir Ronald Smith today announced that overall pre-tax profits at the half-year are up £1.2m before tax, that wages have gone up by £3m, and that transfer costs have increased by 28 per cent. But it wasn't all about money. No sir. Edwards and Smith love football nearly as much as ready cash, and to prove it, they both sat and talked about it for minutes and minutes.

Here's Martin on Fifa's great new proposals for a harmonised international calendar. "I can't see European clubs accepting all the Fifa proposals and Uefa is still not happy," spat Edwards, possibly spoiling for a power struggle with Sepp Blatter. "There's still a long way to go and we've got to go back to the drawing board." But before he could be asked to elaborate on why he doesn't like the idea of the February to November set-up, he had to nip off to cash a cheque.

Ah well, Sir Ronnie's still here. What about that David Beckham, eh? "Beckham's got three years left to go on his contract. He's certainly staying!" answered Smith with the boyish enthusiasm of a fan. So you'll keep hold of the fans favourite at all costs, then? "He's free to negotiate what he believes is fair and we will try to stretch to that," he snapped, suddenly serious at the sound of the c-word. "But if we can't reach an agreement, so be it and he will be put on the transfer market." And who exactly will you get to replace the second-best player in the wor... ah look, he's ran off clutching a bag of coins.

GETTING JITROIS

When you're a full-time Gallic charmer and hero of the French people, and you're waging a one-man Napoleonic war on English football, it's perhaps inevitable that something will give. And for He Is Emmanuel Petit, it's been his performances on the pitch this season. The usually tough-as-cowhide midfielder has confessed to the Sun that "some of my performances have not been very good" - and that Arsene Wenger's had words.

In a valiant search for answers to Manu's malaise, The Fiver turns to www.emmanuelpetit.com. At first nothing seems amiss, as Manu's fetish for all things leather thunders on unabated like an Argentinan bull ready to stud. "I've been fascinated by leather for a very long time and discovering the creations of Jean-Claude Jitrois was for me some kind of revelation," he announces proudly to the world. "I'm interested in Jean-Claude's work because he does exactly what fits me," he adds helpfully.

Fortunately for Arsenal fans everywhere, Petit quickly returns the talk to how much he enjoys getting smashed with the lads, going out on the pull... and his lack of a dress designer. "There are not many dress designers who manage to make me dream," he dolefully admits. "I rather take a pull-over here, a shirt there and some trousers elsewhere. I don't have a regular dress designer."

The man clearly needs help. So if you're a dress designer, pay a visit to the London branch of his boutique, Jitrois in Sloane Square. That's the one whose walls are covered with fur "creating a muffled and original atmosphere." Arsenal's Big Cup place could depend on it.

Leeds are prepared to match Everton's £3m valuation of Don Hutchison and are preparing a summer bid to take the Scotland international to Elland Road.

Liverpool look set to pay £1.5m to secure the services of teenage Millwall striker Cherno Samba. The 15-year-old was a guest of the club at Anfield on Saturday.

Derby manager Jim Smith is hoping to add Motherwell's Finnish international Simo Valakari to his midfield this summer.

Seven current and former Leicester players and staff have been found guilty of misconduct by the FA. Players Andy Impey, Tony Cottee, Arnar Gunnlaugsson, Scott Taylor and Graham Fenton, plus Academy director David Nish and chief scout Jim Melrose, were found to have handled tickets for last year's Worthington Cup final "irresponsibly". The guilty parties were fined and banned from receiving tickets for home internationals, cup finals or cup semi-finals.

NTL, through its subsidiary company Premium TV Limited, has taken a 5.585% stake in Middlesbrough for an undisclosed fee. The investment will make Premium the exclusive worldwide agent for certain media and commercial rights, excluding those negotiated by the FA Premier League, for five years. Boro becomes the third Premiership club to strike a deal with the cable giants.

Alex Ferguson has been named the greatest manager of all time after a poll conducted among the country's coaches by magazine FourFourTwo. Fergie beat Bill Shankly into second place, while former Tranmere coach John King beats Franz Beckenbauer into the top 20. Full list: 1.Sir Alex Ferguson; 2. Bill Shankly; 3. Brian Clough; 4. Sven Goran Eriksson; 16. Herbert Chapman; 17. Arsene Wenger; 18. Graham Taylor; 19. Joe Mercer; 20. John King.

Norwegian international striker John Carew will join Valencia in the summer, putting paid to potential bids from Arsenal, Spurs and Leeds. "Several clubs have been in the picture, but Valencia have always been my first choice," said Rosenborg's leading scorer. "I've seen them on television and I was impressed. They're among the best in Spain, and I have a good chance of a fixed team place."

Co Adriaanse has been named as the new coach of Ajax Amsterdam. The former Willem II coach will replace Jan Wouters.

Both Harry Kewell and Lucas Radebe will miss upcoming friendly matches with their respective national sides. The Leeds players have not been selected in the Australian and South African squads named today, to allow them to concentrate on Leeds' Uefa Cup tie with Galatasaray.

Greek international midfielder Theo Zagorakis will return home to AEK Athens this summer after a two-year spell at Leicester City.

webTitle: Winner of the Guardian Children's Fiction Prize 2000

fields.headline: Winner of the Guardian Children's Fiction Prize 2000
fields.trailText: The winner of the Guardian Children's Fiction Prize 2000 is The Illustrated Mum by Jacqueline Wilson (Transworld, £10.99/£3.99).
fields.body:
The winner of the Guardian Children's Fiction Prize 2000 is The Illustrated Mum by Jacqueline Wilson (Transworld, £10.99/£3.99).

Told through the eyes of Dol, younger daughter of Marigold, the highly tattooed "illustrated mum" of the title, this is the disturbingly perceptive and provocative story of how two sisters cope with their mother's increasingly erratic behaviour caused by mental illness. Marigold's love for her daughters, and theirs for her, shines through, despite the pain of a childhood full of anxiety and responsibility.

"The tradition in children's books was that there used to be a beginning, a middle and an ending and the ending was the happy bit. Now, real life isn't like that for most children. I try to end positively, but not necessarily happily. Things are usually slightly better in fiction than in the real world," says Wilson.

"I'm not a bossy person," Wilson says. "If there's any preaching in my books, it's saying, 'OK. Be what you are. You don't have to be like anyone else. You just have to like yourself'. "

Jacqueline Wilson is the author of over 60 books. She has won the Smarties Prize, the Whitbread Children's Book Award and the Federation of Children's Book Group's Award. She will receive £1,500 for the Guardian Children's Fiction Prize.

The shortlisted titles:

David Almond: Kit's Wilderness, Hodder Children's Books, £4.99
Bernard Ashley: Little Soldier, Orchard, £4.99
Susan Cooper: King of Shadows, Bodley Head, £10.99
Jan Mark: The Eclipse of the Century, Scholastic, £14.99
J. K. Rowling: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban, Bloomsbury, £10.99

The judges were:
Julia Eccleshare (chair), Keith Gray, Elizabeth Laird and Susan Price.

fields.headline: Trial by paper
fields.standfirst: Donald MacLeod and  Lee Elliot Major report on growing concern at the new academic bureacracy
fields.trailText: Donald MacLeod and Lee Elliot Major report on growing concern at the new academic bureacracy
fields.body:
Moves to head off a simmering revolt by academics over the mounting burden and costs of of bureaucracy will be announced next month by the funding councils and the quality watchdog for higher education.

Complaints that each university department was having to produce "truckloads of bumpf" when teaching was assessed were valid, admitted John Randall, chief executive of the Quality Assurance Agency. But he did not accept claims that a teaching quality assessment for a single department costs £250,000. He insists a new, lighter-touch inspection system - to be published in April and put into effect in Scotland later this year - will ease the burden for lecturers and administrative staff. Academics remain sceptical and, among some of the older universities, downright hostile.

At the same time, the Higher Education Funding Council for England is about to publish a report on the growing bureaucratic demands on universities and colleges not only from teaching and research assessments, but also student records and complaints and the increased number of bids they have to make to secure funding. Sir Brian Fender, the council's chief executive, is known to be enthusiastic about the potential for reducing duplication.

A pilot study of Leeds University and Leeds Metropolitan has been looking at the costs of "accountability" - quality audits, subject reviews, funding and student returns, and bidding. It is understood the cost of a subject review, including the opportunity costs of lost teaching and research, were estimated at £250,000.

Fed up to the back teeth with the huge amount of documentation, academics have become increasingly vocal in their protests. University College London threatened to refuse to take part in the new quality assessment system unless it was modified. Vice-provost Michael Worton said other universities were rallying to their call. "We are calling for discussion, negotiation, treaty - we are also preparing for war. For all the emphasis on outcomes and qualifications, there is no let-up on the remorseless concentration on process and paper trails." He is still awaiting a response from the agency to UCL's ultimatum.

The Oxford Magazine, a forum for academics at that university, called on colleagues to follow UCL's lead. "We have reached a sticking point. It is time for [the funding council] to realise that auditing academics as if they were potential malefactors and embezzlers was a misconception from the start," said its editor Jim Reed.

Many in the new universities, however, feel the agency's quality assessments have allowed them to demonstrate high standards of teaching. At Central Lancashire, Eileen Martin, dean of the nursing faculty, which gained the maximum 24 points, said the visiting panel looked at teaching and clinical practice and spoke to employers and students. "They gave us a thorough going over, but the score accurately reflects the quality of nursing and midwifery provision."

Randall said criticism by Alan Ryan, Warden of New College, Oxford, of "truckloads of supporting bumpf" was valid. The system the agency inherited, which would operate in England until December, involved assembling large quantities of documentary evidence to be placed in the team's "base room".

Taking a snapshot of academic provision, or of overall academic management, over a short period of three or four days meant information had to be assembled artificially and for no other purpose, and kept at hand in case it was required. Much of it was not required, giving rise to complaints of wasted effort.

The new method being introduced by the agency would avoid this problem, said Randall. "The time spent on review will no longer be concentrated into a single week, but spread intermittently over a longer period. Reviewers will deal with naturally arising, rather than artificially assembled, evidence. They will time their visits to coincide with internal events for which the institution has to assemble evidence for its own purposes (for example its own internal review of provision)."

But Randall is scornful of some of the criticism, saying universities need much of this information anyway to monitor their degree standards. A well-run department should be able to produce a lot of the information required by the agency without massive extra costs. "I think it will prove possible for good institutions for assessment to be significantly lighter than it is at the moment. There will be regard to an institution's track record. How much effort do you need to establish that Imperial is good at engineering? However, a research reputation does not always trickle down to the teaching."

But even if lighter-touch audits work in practice, a whole series of pressures will only aggravate the long-standing complaint that academic life has become one long paperchase. Various government agencies - all in the name of standards and accountability in teaching, research and financial activities - are adding to the burden.

Administrative loads are also on the rise in the research world. The race for research ratings in the Research Assessment Exercise is only a headache for departments every four years or so. More troublesome is the government's penchant for a plethora of competitions for research grants. The university challenge scheme, the university enterprise scheme and joint infra structure fund are among the new initiatives. Most carefully prepared bids from academics are rejected. The JIF scheme, for example, has so far received £3bn of proposals for new and updated laboratories, but will only support a tiny fraction.

Tighter controls are also being planned for academic spending. University departments will produce annual accounts detailing academic staff time spent on research and teaching duties, following the transparency review of funding. The review was instigated as part of a deal which saw more research money for universities in the last government spending review.

More performance indicators are also in the pipeline. Last year saw academics scrutinised on numbers of student drop-outs. Now the government wants universities to return figures on numbers of graduate jobs secured by university leavers.

Taking a snapshot of academic provision, or of overall academic management, over a short period of three or four days meant information had to be assembled artificially and for no other purpose, and kept at hand in case it was required. Much of it was not required, giving rise to complaints of wasted effort. The new method being introduced by the agency would avoid this problem, said Randall. "The time spent on review will no longer be concentrated into a single week, but spread intermittently over a longer period. Reviewers will deal with naturally arising, rather than artificially assembled, evidence. They will time their visits to coincide with internal events for which the institution has to assemble evidence for its own purposes (for example its own internal review of provision)." But Randall is scornful of some of the criticism, saying universities need much of this information anyway to monitor their degree standards. A well-run department should be able to produce a lot of the information required by the agency without massive extra costs. "I think it will prove possible for good institutions for assessment to be significantly lighter than it is at the moment. There will be regard to an institution's track record. How much effort do you need to establish that Imperial is good at engineering? However, a research reputation does not always trickle down to the teaching." But even if lighter-touch audits work in practice, a whole series of pressures will only aggravate the long-standing complaint that academic life has become one long paperchase. Various government agencies - all in the name of standards and accountability in teaching, research and financial activities - are adding to the burden. Administrative loads are also on the rise in the research world. The race for research ratings in the Research Assessment Exercise is only a headache for departments every four years or so. More troublesome is the government's penchant for a plethora of competitions for research grants. The university challenge scheme, the university enterprise scheme and joint infra structure fund are among the new initiatives. Most carefully prepared bids from academics are rejected. The JIF scheme, for example, has so far received £3bn of proposals for new and updated laboratories, but will only support a tiny fraction. Tighter controls are also being planned for academic spending. University departments will produce annual accounts detailing academic staff time spent on research and teaching duties, following the transparency review of funding. The review was instigated as part of a deal which saw more research money for universities in the last government spending review. More performance indicators are also in the pipeline. Last year saw academics scrutinised on numbers of student drop-outs. Now the government wants universities to return figures on numbers of graduate jobs secured by university leavers.

webTitle: Second secret service laptop went missing

fields.headline: Second secret service laptop went missing
fields.trailText: An urgent inquiry was under way today when it was revealed an MI6 officer mislaid a laptop computer containing classified material after a drinking session at a tapas bar near the secret service's headquarters in central London.
fields.body:
An urgent inquiry was under way today when it was revealed an MI6 officer mislaid a laptop computer containing classified material after a drinking session at a tapas bar near the secret service's headquarters in central London.

The incident is the second such loss in the last month. Just days ago - on March 4 - it was revealed that an MI5 laptop computer containing classified information on Northern Ireland had been stolen from Paddington underground station.

The Foreign Office confirmed that the MI6 laptop was lost on March 3, the loss reported to the Metropolitan police, and, following a police investigation, was recovered on March 16.

"We were assured by the police that the laptop was not compromised," a Foreign Office spokeswoman said last night. The department, which has responsibility for MI6, is preparing a report.

A mini-cab firm boss today revealed another string to the agencies intelligence-gathering activities when he said he was contacted by MI6 agents about the laptop.

MI6 used an anonymous newspaper advert to try and track down the laptop claiming an academic had lost "vital research notes" stored on the machine.

"It was all a bit odd," said Frank Henry who runs a mini-cab firm near the tapas bar. "I got a visit from two smartly dressed men, I think they were wearing suits, at the beginning of March. They said they had lost a briefcase with something important in it which they thought they might have left in a taxi, and asked if we had found anything.

"They had been the worse for wear that night. One of the men said they couldn't remember what cab firm they had called because they were in such a state."

Tom King, chairman of the parliamentary intelligence and security committee which will review the Foreign Office report, said they would be asking some "tough questions" about security at both agencies.

"The fact that people working in the agencies are taking laptops around in public which may have intelligence information on it, even if it is encrypted, is a very serious matter.

"I don't think sufficient thought has been given to what the impact of this new technology is," he added.

fields.headline: The final cut
fields.standfirst: You might think recent scare stories would have put people off leaving their bodies to science. Far from it - there's a nationwide surplus. As  Oliver Burkeman  finds out, donating your corpse is far from straightforward
fields.trailText: You might think recent scare stories would have put people off leaving their bodies to science. Far from it - there's a nationwide surplus. As Oliver Burkeman finds out, donating your corpse is far from straightforward
fields.body:
There are many different ways of dealing with the prospect of death - a belief in karma, angels with harps, or a painless nothingness - but the thought that one's corpse might end up being picked over by medical students for educational purposes has never been a particularly comforting one.

Recent events have rendered it even less so: last September, the University of California at Irvine fired Christopher Brown, director of its medical school's "willed-body program", amid allegations that he had sold the spines of six donated bodies to a private research firm for $5,000 (£3,000). (He denies the accusations.) And a lawsuit filed in 1996 accused the authorities at the University of California at Los Angeles of having cremated 18,000 donated bodies alongside dead laboratory animals and dumping them in rubbish skips from 1950 to 1993.

But the unease is justified over here, too. In 1998, the artist Anthony Noel-Kelly was jailed for nine months for paying a trainee lab technician to steal body parts from a mortuary at London's Royal College of Surgeons to use as moulds for his sculptures. And urban folklore teems with macabre tales of limbs going missing from anatomy departments and turning up at drunken student parties.

You might have thought scare stories like these would have deterred potential donors from signing over their corpses, but nothing could be further from the truth: there's a nationwide surplus.

"If anything, we're declining offers rather than encountering a shortage," says Roger Searle, head of Newcastle University medical school's anatomical and clinical skills centre. "The citizens of the north-east are very generous, very public-spirited." The same seems true across Britain - many universities receive hundreds of approaches each year - even if generosity isn't necessarily the only motive: the University of California's website encourages potential donors with the hint that "some individuals leave their bodies to a [medical] school they always dreamed of attending".

The exploding popularity of body donation is all the more surprising considering the administrative palaver involved in actually assigning one's cadaver to an anatomy department. Write to the university of your choice and you'll first receive an extensive information pack detailing the legal documentation that must be completed for your decision to be officially valid. Then you'll need to persuade your next of kin of the merits of your decision, since, when you die, it will be they who have the ultimate power to decide what happens to your corpse. (If you have signed a donor card for organ transplants as well, this will normally take precedence if the circumstances are appropriate.) Finally, once you're gone, your immediate family will need to sign still more documentation allowing the university to arrange for you to be transported and refrigerated until your remains are required.

Even if you fill out all the right forms, though, the chances are that your corpse won't be accepted. "I'd say I send out up to 10 letters a week in response to requests for information, but probably I only accept around one in three bodies," says Roger Soames, deputy head of the school of biomedical sciences at Leeds University. Infectious diseases - HIV, say, or tuberculosis - will rule you out, because you may endanger staff and students. If you die of a cancer that has spread throughout your body, you will not display normal anatomical structures, and consequently won't be much use for general teaching. Obesity can be a problem, too, and if you die in suspicious circumstances, necessitating a postmortem examination, donation won't be possible. Even timing your death badly might pose difficulties: outside term time, universities may often be unable to collect and refrigerate you within the five-day time limit imposed by law.

However, says Soames, the popular belief that you need to die relatively young is incorrect: "We get a lot of enquiries asking 'Am I too old?', but the answer is no."

There is, of course, no opportunity for a conventional burial or cremation, so Searle encourages relatives to pay their last respects before a body is admitted to the university. Cremated ashes can eventually be returned to the next of kin, but it may be a long wait: the law entitles universities to retain bodies for up to three years, and they are often stored for a year before they're required. Instead, most medical schools - following Home Office recommendations - now hold regu lar collective memorial services attended by relatives of donors, medical students and faculty staff.

Strenuous efforts are being made to produce simulation technology that could render the use of real bodies in teaching obsolete, but it hasn't succeeded yet. "There are other methods, CD-roms and all that, but they just don't give you the same 3D image that you can touch and see that this runs here, that connects there," Searle says. "When former students come here as demonstrators in anatomy, there's a tremendous difference between those who did dissection at medical school and those who used plastic models."

Happily, there is little evidence to suggest that medical students will behave improperly with your cadaver, and the entire system is tightly regulated in the UK by Her Majesty's inspector of anatomy, operating under the provisions of the Anatomy Act of 1984 - the present-day successor to the law hastily introduced after Burke and Hare murdered at least 15 people in 19th-century Edinburgh in order to supply bodies for dissection to the anatomist Dr Robert Knox. (These days, no payments can be made.)

Much of the archetypal medical student's black humour is probably more reasonably seen as a coping mechanism for the somewhat grim task of dissection. And, for the record, there is no established source for the urban legend about the medical student who spends a year dissecting various parts of her assigned cadaver before, towards the end of her course, rolling back the cover to study the head - only to discover that the body is her uncle's.

fields.headline: Body fascism
fields.standfirst: In his continuing battle for the body beautiful,  Stephen Moss  develops a disturbing contempt for weaklings
fields.trailText: In his continuing battle for the body beautiful, Stephen Moss develops a disturbing contempt for weaklings
fields.body:
The fitness report is a little slimmer this week - two columns instead of three. This is either a clever typographical joke - as I get smaller, so does the space - or a reflection of the fact that I have less and less to say. I leave you to decide which.

If this was the London Marathon, I would be passing the Isle of Dogs. Now it becomes a slog and the reps become truly repetitious. I have just come from a one-hour "boxercise" class - a bit of boxing and lots of circuit training - where I was probably the least fit person in a group of 20. There is a lesson here: as you get fitter and look for new ways to exercise, you continually come across people who are even fitter than you. This could be inspiring or depressing; at present, I plump for the latter.

It is odd to be an interloper in this world of the fit: lithe people in lycra who inhabit mechanised subterranean caves and watch MTV (is there any gym in Britain tuned in to the BBC or ITV?) Training, the effort to keep up, takes over your life: each week I try to work out with Sam, my trainer, three times, run three times and do two boxercise classes. I am left with mountains of laundry and virtually no time to do anything else, yet it doesn't seem enough. I'm still bottom of the class.

I am also worried about the dehumanising effect of working out. I saw an overweight, disconsolate-looking man on the train the other evening drinking a little bottle of gin and tonic, and had an urge to remonstrate with him for this public display of weakness. In my quest for physical and mental perfection, for manifest purpose, I am becoming intolerant of the messiness and inconsequentiality of life. This may be how fascism begins.

Back in the gym, I am transformed (OK, showing moderate improvement). I can now run on the treadmill for 20 minutes without collapsing in a wheezing heap; do pull-ups on that infernal machine (a hang-over from the Spanish Inquisition?) that makes you lift half your weight; do press-ups for the first time in my life. Believe you can do it and you can. "Mind over matter", as Sam says ad nauseam (nausea sometimes being the operative word).

My back has been objecting, so I had a massage from Jo, head therapist at the health club. Most of the regulars have a weekly massage, which eases aches, strengthens muscles and leaves you feeling relaxed. Jo said my shoulders were knotted from sitting in front of a screen, but that regular massage could rectify the problem. Hence forth I may try to sneak in without Sam seeing me and head straight for the massage room.

Another benefit of my posh gym is that you get to see the in-house doctor, who, if you can bear to know the results, will subject you to a "biological terrain assessment". Dr Bannock puts samples of urine, blood and saliva into test tube-type containers which are connected to a laptop. The computer whirs and bleeps (I panic but Dr B says it always does this) and prints out a diagram of how your cells are performing - a kind of ordinance survey map for your biological terrain.

My results were mixed. Dr Bannock said I had a biological age of 33, which is encouraging since I am 42 (in Gymworld, clocks and calendars can be conquered, time can be tamed). But there were valleys as well as peaks: body too acidic; digestive system stressed (he says I eat too fast and don't eat enough fruit and veg); kidneys stressed (drink more water!); adrenal glands stressed (so I lack energy); circulatory system stressed. My body is having to work too hard to keep the show on the road: the terrain needs a little landscaping.

Dr Bannock has several key principles, which I offer here with no consultation fee:

 Eat like the French: take your time, digest it well, relax. Don't eat and drink at the same time.

 Graze rather than gorge.

 Eat like a king at breakfast, a prince at lunchtime and a pauper in the evening.

 Don't just drink lots of water, drink good water: he suggests Volvic.

 Eat lots of fruit (especially first thing), veg, fibre, soluble oats, and other grains and seeds. Get protein from fish or white meat. Eat organic foods. Eat brown bread, rice and pasta, rather than white.

 With alcohol, worry more about frequency than quantity: the occasional blowout is OK; drinking every night is not. Red wine is better than white, and avoid rubbish.

 Drink herbal tea rather than tea and coffee where possible.

 Exercise frequently to keep the heart, muscles and bones in good order - use it or lose it!

 Stephen Moss is spending three months working out at Matt Roberts at One, 1 Aldwych, London WC2 (020-7300 0600).

webTitle: A father's search for the truth

fields.headline: A father's search for the truth
fields.standfirst: When his son was diagnosed with autism, David Thrower was astonished to learn that there was no official data available on how common the disease was. So he decided to find out for himself - with extraordinary results.  Melanie McFadyean reports
fields.trailText: When his son was diagnosed with autism, David Thrower was astonished to learn that there was no official data available on how common the disease was. So he decided to find out for himself - with extraordinary results. Melanie McFadyean reports
fields.body:
David Thrower has photos, as any parent does, of his son Oliver as a toddler, a bright little fellow. Then he produces a photo of Oliver at 15 months and something is wrong: the child's eyes are blank. That was when David and his partner first noticed their boy's decline, one that coincided with a measles vaccination. Then at the age of four Oliver had the measles, mumps and rubella (MMR) jab, after which all his skills, says Thrower, "dissolved". He screamed, became destructive, and attacked his parents and other children.

Now aged 12, he has no speech at all, can't feed or dress himself, and is hyperactive. Oliver had become autistic, one of a growing number of children diagnosed with this condition. But Thrower did not invite me to his house in Warrington to talk about immunisation. Although he thinks vaccinations may be one cause of autism, he suspects there are other environmental and genetic factors that could play a part - and he wants to know what they are. It may be too late for Oliver, but he hopes he can make a difference for other children.

"The point is to find out the truth, to get to the heart of it. There's a terrible reluctance to look into the prevalence and causes of autism, but science isn't advanced by closed minds," he says.

Three years ago, Thrower gave up his job as a transport planner to look after Oliver and be a "house husband" while his partner continued to work full time. Aged 49, he is remarkably fit and energetic for someone whose son's hyperactivity ensures that he rarely gets an uninterrupted night's sleep. He spends all his spare time researching the causes of autism and its prevalence after discovering, to his amazement, that there was almost no official data.

"Don't make it a sob story," he says genially: he doesn't want this to be a sentimental tale of a broken-hearted man. Looking at the yards of files in his office, you marvel that he managed to research and write the meticulous 90-page document on the possible causes, treatment and rates of autism that he presented to the health select committee of the House of Commons last summer.

Since the outset of his research, Thrower has been writing to ministers and officials at the Department of Health. At first they responded at length. "All propaganda and sales talk," says Thrower. But as his questions became more probing, the replies became more evasive, and now he doesn't get replies at all.

Undeterred, he ploughed on, and earlier this month produced his latest findings, which expose dramatic rises in autism and the shambolic state of data collection in the UK. As psychiatrist Dr Lorna Wing, an expert on autism, made clear in a recent report for the National Autistic Society: "There is no central recording by the UK government and very few epidemiological studies on which to make informed predictions. The available studies into this population are infrequent, expensive and problematic."

Thrower, alone in his study, in his own time and at his own expense, has made a start. Last year, he wrote to 161 organisations - every health authority in this country and a number of other bodies - asking them whether they collected data on rates for autism spectrum disorders (ASD - the technical term for wide-ranging autistic diagnosis) and what the data showed.

Just over half replied. Thrower doesn't pretend that his monitoring was perfect. It was a trawl providing "interesting" snapshots. "Interesting" is his word: many people would say alarming.

Of the half who replied, only 17% had any detailed data at all, 38% had very limited data or were just beginning to think about setting up monitoring systems and the remaining 45% had no data whatsoever and no plans to gather it. Thrower's research reveals that rates in some districts are far higher than the already high national prevalence rate of one in 100. In East Surrey, for example, where an audit was taken of all three-year-olds in a health trust district, autism amongst three year old boys was running at 1 in 69.

Several authorities were uncertain as to whether the climb in reported cases of ASD was due to better diagnosis or greater prevalence, but a significant number believed it to be the latter. Thrower's analysis of statistics from Bromley Autistic Trust shows that in the 80s they had a 120% rise, with latest figures - for the early 90s - showing that rise continuing.

In the Birmingham Children's Hospital NHS trust there was an average annual increase of 37% of children under five during 1991-6. In Shropshire, the health authority figures show that while numbers are small they are rising, from 1-2 new cases per year in 1991 to 4-5 in 1999.

In North Staffordshire, the health trust does has not have exact data but "has noted a bulge of younger cases in a local school", and in South Staffordshire the "special school for autistic children has had to expand provision and is still bursting at the seams".

Of the health authorities that have made the effort to collate information on autism rates, there is a huge variation in the effort made: West Surrey concluded that autism was very rare on the basis of a week-long survey in 1998; while Ealing Hammersmith and Hounslow uses data from hospital admissions.

fields.headline: This won't hurt a bit...
fields.standfirst: Well it will, actually, whatever your doctor says. And a new study suggests routine injections may be surprisingly painful.  Ed Walker  reports
fields.trailText: Well it will, actually, whatever your doctor says. And a new study suggests routine injections may be surprisingly painful. Ed Walker reports
fields.body:
It's a fact of life that if you're admitted to hospital, you're probably going to have a needle stuck into you. And, of course, the mother of them all is the spinal needle. That's used to suck out the fluid that surrounds your central nervous system. Which has got to really hurt, right? Except that it doesn't, apparently.

At least not anywhere near as much as other injections, according to a study in this week's Lancet, which not only shows that spinals have an undeserved reputation, but also that so-called "routine" jabs hurt a lot more than doctors and patients might imagine. In the Italian study, 83% of patients thought a spinal injection would be most painful, while 80% said an intramuscular (IM) would hurt least. But after they had actually experienced them, nearly 90% said either IM or intravenous (IV) injections were most unpleasant, with only 11% rating the spinal as most painful.

If you push a sharp piece of metal through skin, it will hurt, but there are ways of reducing the pain. Probably the most common sort of injection is the IV, which often involves inserting a cannula (a short length of plastic tubing) into the vein to give drugs or fluids. Dr Bruno Simini, who carried out the Italian trial, says that patients should be anaesthetised before a cannula is inserted. He's right, but it doesn't always happen. You can apply anaesthetic cream which numbs the skin, but it takes about 20 to 30 minutes to work, and in an emergency there may not be time. It's usually reserved for children, although it can be used just as well on adults. The effect is never complete, and even if you prevent actual pain, the patient still feels the "pushing" sensation, which many children will interpret as pain.

The alternative is to inject a tiny blob of local anaesthetic just under the skin. Many doctors still argue that having a local injection is just as painful as the other injection, so why bother? But having had IV cannulae myself both with and without local, I can confirm that a tiny injection of local does not hurt anywhere near as much as having a 2mm diameter needle shoved into a vein.

The problem is that even a tiny amount of fluid under the skin can make its successful puncture afterwards more difficult. If you have to make two attempts instead of one, it rather defeats the object of the exercise. I always use local for anything other than the very smallest cannula, but some doctors are not comfortable with it.

Then there are IM injections. It's an easy way of giving drugs, but painful and unreliable. Simini states that "IM injections should belong in the past". Here, it is not the puncture of the skin that causes most pain, but the forcing of fluid into muscle fibres. The absorption from muscle into the bloodstream can be erratic, particularly in a shocked patient. On the whole, drugs are far better administered by the IV route, where their effects are immediate and predictable.

Generally speaking, doctors don't impale people just for the sake of it. But my advice is that if you're about to have a large drip put in and your physician says, "It'll only hurt a bit," ask if she's ever had one. Then ask for some local first.

 Dr Walker is an accident and emergency specialist in west Yorkshire.

fields.headline: Dear doctor
fields.trailText: Is this folic folly? | Dealing with Parkinson's | Sperm counting
fields.body:
Is this folic folly?
Q: A visiting friend had an early morning ritual of gobbling a handful of vitamins, minerals and supplements while I had toast and cornflakes. The one she set most store by was folic acid, to prevent heart disease. I took it in the early stages of pregnancy, then stopped. Should I take it too?

A: Cornflakes with milk, toast and some fresh fruit or orange juice is a nutritionally sound way to start the day. Folic acid (folate) lowers blood levels of a chemical called homocysteine, which we get from our normal diet. Very high homocysteine levels - brought about by a rare genetic disorder - are linked to increased risk of heart disease, strokes and possibly dementia, so lowering homocysteine levels ought to reduce those risks. However, proof that high levels actually cause these ailments is still awaited - the presence of homocysteine may reflect other risk factors, such as poor diet and smoking. There's no harm in eating lots of green veg which are rich in the substance anyway.

Dealing with Parkinson's
Q: My elderly father has been told he has early Parkinson's disease. He has slowed down considerably, his hands shake and he has lost a lot of his zest for life. The pills his GP has given him, carbidopa, don't seem to be making much impact. Is there anything else we can do?

A: Parkinson's is common in older people. Brain nerve cells that control movement and contain the chemical messenger dopamine deteriorate. The pills your father is taking contain a dopamine-like drug called levodopa, which can be very helpful. His lack of improvement could be because the diagnosis is wrong (he could be depressed and have a harmless tremor), the dose might need adjusting or he may need a different drug. New drugs that boost dopamine levels in the brain, such as ropinirole (ReQuip), appear to work as well as levodopa but with fewer side effects. The Parkinson's Disease Society (tel: 020 7931 8080) could recommend a neurologist if your father wants to be referred to a specialist.

Sperm counting
Q: My partner wants us to try for a baby now. I'd rather wait, as I'm only 21. He's 25 and reckons that sperm counts are falling all the time because of environmental poisoning, so we shouldn't hang around. Will four to five more years make any difference?

A: No. Tell him that men today produce just as many sperm as their grandfathers did, according to a US study completed in 1997 and comparing samples from a 1951 study. If he is worried about his own sperm count, he can get a semen sample analysed at the local hospital lab. At 25, if he hasn't had chemotherapy or serious illness or surgery that may affect his fertility, he shouldn't worry unduly.

Dosage disorders
Q: I contracted a severe urinary tract infection last July, requiring five days in hospital. Since then, I have had recurring infections. Last October a urologist prescribed long-term low-dose antibiotics (Trimethoprim), but now I have three weeks or so clear, then the pain returns, followed by nausea and dizziness. I am then prescribed another antibiotic then told to resume the low dose. Tests and scans have detected no under lying problem. I am 53 and had a hysterectomy at 37.

A: Constant antibiotics are clearly not a satisfactory long-term solution. It may be that your vagina has become dry, sore and susceptible to infections since you went through the menopause. HRT in the form of oestrogen pessaries or vaginal creams often helps. You could try HRT as oral tablets or patches. If you can't take HRT, antiseptic pessaries such as Aci-Jel are worth a try.

 These answers are intended to be as accurate and full as possible, but should never be used as a substitute for visiting a doctor. If you have a question for Dr Robinson, email drann@dircon.co.uk or write to her c/o The Health Editor, The Guardian, 119 Farringdon Road, London EC1R 3ER. She regrets that she cannot enter into personal correspondence.

webTitle: New website slashes car prices by £3,000

fields.headline: New website slashes car prices by £3,000
fields.trailText: In a symbolic blow against "rip-off" Britain, the Consumer Association today launched carbusters.com as part of the organisation's campaign against overpriced cars.
fields.body:
In a symbolic blow against "rip-off" Britain, the Consumer Association today launched carbusters.com as part of the organisation's campaign against overpriced cars.

Car buyers could save thousands of pounds on new vehicles by buying direct through the website, bypassing high prices in car showrooms. To mark the launch, Dr Tony Lewis, a GP from Budleigh Salterton, Devon, and his wife Penny, took delivery of two Ford Focus cars purchased through the new website.

The couple, who both selected Ford's 2.0 Ghia five-door model with extras, saved themselves £6,500 by importing the cars through carbusters.com. Dr Lewis said: "Ordering online was very easy. It took around three minutes from beginning to end. We have had to wait a couple of months to receive the car - but the saving more than makes up for the wait." His wife added: "From a woman's point of view, ordering online was excellent, and very easy. There was no hassle, no salesmen making you feel small or intimidated."

The most popular cars ordered through carbusters.com were the VW Golf, Ford Focus and VW Passat. The website has been extensively tested by the CA over the past three months. But the site is of limited scope as it bought only 83 cars with full UK specification. The order, worth more than £1.5 million, has realised savings of around £270,000 - an average of £3,000 to £4,000 per car.

The CA will not be making a profit selling the cars, but will charge an administration fee to cover the costs of running the scheme. Sheila McKechnie, director of the CA, said: "At last year's motor show thousands of people welcomed our decision to establish a scheme to help them get a fair price for new cars. Carbusters.com is a straight challenge to the car manufacturers in the UK to stop treating the UK as 'Treasure Island'. The scheme will deliver new UK specification cars to your door at thousands of pounds off the manufacturers' official list price."

Carbusters.com offers guaranteed right-hand drive cars, full UK specification, a price guarantee for 30 days, and home delivery of cars. The CA's move came amid reports that the government plans to force manufacturers to cut UK prices after the competition commission concluded that British car buyers are being ripped off.

The Telegraph reported that the commission was particularly critical of the fact that private motorists subsidised lucrative discounts for business customers. Trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers received the commission report at the end of January and the DTI is scheduled to publish its own report when it has reached its own conclusion.

In February, the European commission found that Britain remained by far the most expensive country in the EU to buy a new car, despite recent price cuts by some manufacturers. It found that the average price gap between the cheapest and most expensive markets for all car models it examined was 19.5% in the six months to November 1 among the 11 euro zone countries.

If Britain, which is not a member of the single currency, was included, the average price differential across the EU rose to 35%, it said. Consumer groups in Britain want an end to the car industry's exemption from EU competition rules and have called on consumers to hold off buying new cars until prices fall.

Under the so-called "block exemption" from EU rules, cars may only be sold through designated dealers. Critics say this gives manufacturers considerable price control. A survey by mortgage bank Alliance & Leicester said that despite a fall in prices since last year, registrations by private car users were down by 10.6% in January with little indication that demand would have picked up in February.

"With the price differential where it is at the moment and the uncertainty over the investigation, it's leaving the way open for internet and other operations to ship cars in from Europe where they are cheaper," said a spokeswoman for the Retail Motor Industry Federation.

fields.headline: Do they mean us?
fields.standfirst: As Tony Blair strives to reclaim the concept of Britishness, foreign affairs specialist Simon Tisdall examines perceptions of nationality around the world
fields.trailText: As Tony Blair strives to reclaim the concept of Britishness, foreign affairs specialist Simon Tisdall examines perceptions of nationality around the world.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's speech today on the nature of "Britishness" may seem a little unnecessary to non-Britons. Everybody abroad knows that there are two types of Britons and that both groups are, well, rather odd.

One lot wears bowler hats, carries umbrellas, attends garden parties with the Queen, drinks tea, hunts foxes, and regards almost everything "foreign" with polite loathing. The other lot drinks too much beer, eats fish 'n' chips, misbehaves at football matches, goes bright red and peely on Spanish beaches, and likes wearing Union Jack underpants. The Household Cavalry and the Spice Girls - two cultures, one rather strange nation.

Mr Blair's predecessors have done little to dispel these risible national stereotypes. Conservative prime ministers have regularly wrapped themselves in the flag, Mrs Thatcher being the prime example. She perpetuated the myth of Britain's dislike of foreigners, particularly by being beastly to the Germans. Labour once even used a Churchillian-style, John Bull-type bulldog as a PR prop. Cool Britannia - the attempt to portray Britain as an international cultural trendsetter - was, in contrast, a rather pathetic and embarrassing attempt to boost a modern British identity at home and abroad.

All this indicates a degree of British uncertainty about who they are and what they stand for. This is usually explained by the fact that the 1707 union between England and Scotland, for example, is a relatively recent event; that Wales and Ireland were conquered by force (and haven't forgotten it); and that Britain, having built a global empire, painted the map red, and ruled the waves just about everywhere, now finds itself in drastically reduced circumstances.

But Mr Blair's initiative today is more about rebutting accusations that Labour's devolution of power to Scotland and Wales is breaking up Britain, and answering those who argue that England, too, should enjoy a greater degree of national self-determination. The prime minister is also anxious to assert what he sees as the special aspects of "Britishness" in the context of European integration.

Such a debate is hardly unique to Britain. France has long been struggling with perceived threats to "Frenchness", ranging from American movies and fastfood restaurants to the anglicising of the French language. It also faces regional pressures in places such as Brittany, Alsace, and Corsica. Spain, on the other hand, seems to have managed to remain happily Spanish while decentralising government to a considerable degree (although not enough for some Basques and Catalans).

The United States runs on a federal basis in which the 50 states all have their own, often very powerful, governors and legislatures. The Americans have resolved problems of "American-ness" by profligate hyphenation: thus we have African-Americans, Irish-Americans, Cuban-Americans and so on. China. on the other hand, takes a less flexible approach to its nationalities question. Beijing basically views everybody as Chinese (including Tibetans, Taiwanese and Uighurs, for example); there will be no argument, thank you.

Once they were Celts, Romans, Angles, Normans and Saxons. Now they include many people of African and the Caribbean descent as well as Bengalis, Kurds, Sikhs, Indians, Turks and Greeks. This multicultural diversity has developed without any help from, and perhaps despite, politicians. And it will continue to evolve, whatever Mr Blair says.

Britain and "Britishness" are, as always, a work in progress.

webTitle: What is Britishness? Tories dream while Labour defines

fields.headline: What is Britishness? Tories dream while Labour defines
fields.standfirst:
Blair will today deliver a speech on an issue that most divides the parties

Devolution in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: Blair will today deliver a speech on an issue that most divides the parties.
fields.body:
For Conservatives, Britishness has the delicacy of a Fabergé egg or, better, a Wedgwood figurine. It's an infinitely precious thing, of which they are the only reliable custodians. They polish it, place it behind glass, check it daily for violations. As a party, they've lived off their unique stewardship of this display-piece for many decades: the party of crown, constitution, nation and Union Jack, ranged against the party of the people, the international and the Red Flag.

Though this always was a false antithesis, these are recognisable party silhouettes. From Attlee to Thatcher, that was how things were seen to be. But the obvious cliché contained a latent paradox, which has burst unanswerably to the surface in the time of William Hague. On the one hand, he says, the British are uniquely strong, their history especially to be admired, their political system a wonder of the world, their national character proof against the alien hordes. On the other hand, apparently, their national identity is so fragile that it faces imminent destruction at the hands of foreigners and Scotsmen, abetted by Tony Blair.

Today, Mr Blair knifes this charge, in a speech that has been prepared for weeks and leaked for days. Several colleagues are billed to follow, in an important pre-election campaign that's supposed to reclaim Britishness for Labour. It's another epic moment in Labour's long march through the centre ground of politics. What's most striking about it, however, is that the message has become irrefutable. The campaign is all but redundant. Mr Hague may have lost his last issue.

The Hague view of Britishness is dominated by enemies and nostalgia. He gave a speech about it a year ago, which was incorrigibly narrow and defensive, glorying above all in the need to resist every European advance. The sacred exhibit, national identity, could never be moved. Labour's entire constitutional programme was cracking the Wedgwood. The third way was not the British way. Devolution and Lords reform were violating the very heart of Britain. The country itself, set in the silver sea, could not be relied on to survive.

Mr Hague is not alone. Vapourings about the future of Britishness have produced speeches and books on a prodigious scale in the past few years. What has mostly characterised those from the right is not inquiry but anxiety. With the absorption of Indians and the separation of Scots, is Britain not already dead? Though Hague has moved on from the ideal of ethnic homogeneity, his version of Britishness is marked with the vulgar untruth espoused by Enoch Powell and Margaret Thatcher: that "Britain" lives only by the unchanging nature of its political arrangements.

When Mr Blair came to power, he didn't have a worked-out idea about "Britain". It's been a persistent argument against his constitutional programme that there was, in fact, no programme, merely a set of ill-connected initiatives answering different political demands. But what he has done so far is the opposite of a threat to Britain.

Take devolution. Yes, the early days of the Scottish and Welsh assemblies have been difficult. They challenge the pattern of politics we have come to know as British. Sometimes they've been quite a mess. The entire political formation of all concerned, the men in Downing Street as much as those outside, has received a nasty assault which few of them were ready for. The psychology as well as the politics of centralism takes a lot of shifting.

But to talk about this as the end of Britain is the hyperbolic nonsense of desperate minds. It's merely a new, confederal kind of Britain, stumbling towards a model that arises by popular regional demand, and provides the possibility of Britain reconciling the power of global economic forces with the desire to preserve identity. Devolved institutions, when they've had time to bed down and be understood as normal, will say that Britain flourishes as a land of multiple identities. While Hagueism stands for an inward exclusiveness, Blairism feels its way to the world of porous truths.

It has more to do, if Britain is not to wither. Britain can't survive if England remains the centralised and dominant sub-state. Whether English devolution is driven through via local government or regional government will be a serious debate. But the reactionaries who would destroy Britain had better prepare for a painful discussion. Likewise, that other Hagueite icon, the House of Lords. Whatever may or may not happen to the membership of the second chamber, the notion that "Britain" can exist only if the ranks and titles of lordship are sustained for another century would be the grossest trivialising of national identity.

In a Downing Street lecture not long ago, the historian Linda Colley proposed an end to these debates about identity. They had got us nowhere, she said. Instead, she advised her audience of the great and good to address what they could do something about: citizenship. Let people stop worrying about such neuralgic questions as losing British identity or buying into European identity. All these identities could co-exist: would, indeed, be largely dependent on the image of themselves that individual citizens preferred to have. What politicians could affect was how their citizenship was made real.

Professor Colley urged that we should know, whichever patch of the islands we came from, what defines us as a citizen and what our rights are. She wasn't in favour of a republic, but suggested a monarchy that swore a solemn oath of service to the people - rather than being either swathed in anachronistic pomp or reduced to riding bicycles. As well as diffusion of power from the centre, a citizen's Britain would do more to engage its ethnic minorities as well and truly British - as being, indeed, the salient proof that, unlike Englishness, Welshness or Scottishness, Britishness is a concept "with no necessary ethnic or cultural overtones".

Finally, she suggested the British should know more history. If they did so, they would discover not only that Britain had much to be proud of that did not entail the brutalities of imperialism, but that it co-existed with social and political change. When India achieved independence there were many Tories who believed that Britain, having begun to surrender its empire, had undermined its own raison d' être. It should now be clear that they misread history in the same way the terrified anti-reformers of modern Conservatism, invoking their static view of what nation means, have elicited from Mr Blair the speech he is making today.

I hope he, in his turn, is not defensive. He has plenty to do to make the political mechanics of the new devolved and European Britain work better. But the reinventions he has begun have reversed the roles history once assigned to these two parties. Now it is Conservatism for dreams, Labour for reality.
