webTitle: Labour tries to reclaim the flag

fields.headline: Labour tries to reclaim the flag
fields.standfirst:
Ministers launch debate on modern Britishness to resolve party's problem and put pressure on Hague

Hugo Young: What is Britishness? Leader comment: What is Britain for?
Competition winners: design a new flag
fields.trailText: Tony Blair will today try to kick start a debate on the nature of modern Britishness when he leads off a series of speeches by a group of his cabinet colleagues - Gordon Brown, Jack Straw and David Blunkett.
fields.body:
Tony Blair will today try to kick start a debate on the nature of modern Britishness when he leads off a series of speeches by a group of his cabinet colleagues - Gordon Brown, Jack Straw and David Blunkett.

A Blair aide explains the thinking. "For over a century, the Conservative party has successfully wrapped itself in the flag. By contrast the left has seemed to have had a blind spot about nationalism regarding it as an awkward fault in human psyche.

"But until we are sure we are sure about our own British identity, we cannot resolve our relationship with Europe.

"If we can get this right we can associate Labour with the values and institutions the British people hold most dear and regard as emblematic of Britishness - decency, tolerance, liberty fair play. Even more, we can start to put some pressure on Hague. He will have to decide whether he is going to put himself at the helm of a new English nationalist party, or remain the leader of the Conservative and Unionist party."

Labour, in its various guises, has made many previous efforts to wrest the union flag from the party of Churchill and Thatcher, and conspicuously failed.

The task was made more problematic in the 80s by Labour's commitment to defence cuts and unilateral nuclear disarmament.

Many on the left also felt alienated by the traditional notions of Englishness, unable to come to terms with what they regarded as its blend of imperial nostalgia, conservatism and xenophobia.

Nevertheless, Neil Kinnock repeatedly tried to reclaim the patriotism for the left, placing the union flag on his party platform and most of his manifesto documents.

Before the 1997 election it was largely left to Jack Straw to pursue the English question when he wrote in the New Statesman: "For the left it it is time to end the rightwing ghetto in which public feeling for England has been for too long corralled."

Mr Blair himself strikingly tried to break the Conservative link with the flag in his first speech as party leader in 1995, claiming "Labour is the true patriotic party" and accusing the Tories of waving the union flag at the close of their party conference when they "have spent 16 years tearing apart the fabric of our nation".

In the 1997 election campaign Peter Mandelson paraded a bulldog in an attempt to associate Blairism with the British fighting spirit. But in government the "cool Britannia" theme was aborted, almost as soon as it was launched.

Some currently associated with the present Blair initiative regarded the bulldog and Britannia episodes as crass beyond belief.

At the time of the bulldog episode, a group, largely around Gordon Brown and including his former speech writer and now industry minister Michael Wills, had been thinking about the modern British identity. The challenge of devolution, Europe, globalisation multi-culturalism and the "privatisation" of many British institutions was making British identity ever harder to grasp.

Mr Brown's group had gone so far as to commission qualititive and quantitive polling to find out what values and institutions had come to represent Britishness in the public mind. They discovered the NHS was the single most cherished and unifying institution in Britain and even emblematic of British values.

The group also held seminars with thinkers such as the historian Linda Colley, chosen two months ago to give a mil lennium lecture at Downing Street on Britishness in the 21st century. She called on Labour to "take a healthier, more comprehensive and less apologetic view of our past", adding the British are not a "nice, but an interesting people".

The poll findings suggested the public associate Britishness with decency, outwardness, the work ethic and tolerance. These, the Brownites claim, are the values of the centre-left.

Moreover, the findings showed the British regarded themselves as a pluralist nation, able to accept different identities, including Scottish, Welsh, Irish and English. Devolution and the integrity of the United Kingdom were compatible.

Similarly, the Blairites claim a true reading of British history reveals a nation committed as much to Europe as to a far flung empire.

A government minister explains: "Britain has never been a narrow chauvinst country. From Plantagenets, Tudors Hanoverians, Palmerston to Churchill, we have been committed to Europe. We have to assault this notion that you cannot be pro-British if you are pro-European."

The Blairites also reckon there is a straight political gain since, they believe it places Mr Hague in a quandary.

He has referred in militaristic tones to the drumbeat of English nationalism, and called for English votes for English laws. But there are also powerful Unionist voices inside the Conservative party, not least Lord Cranborne and Michael Ancram, the chairman.

Gordon Brown claims that Mr Hague, by becoming so obsessed by the break up of Britian, has missed the essential British magic. "Perhaps uniquely in the world, Britain is not just a society of many communities, but also a country of nations - with large, contiguous areas of distinct national heritage.

"Instead of a bland Britain, Britain is buzzing with difference; no longer a state in monochrome, but a nation in living colour.".

How Blair has attempted to redefine patriotism

 "The New Britain" was a Labour slogan in the 1960s as the party, led by Harold Wilson, focused on the need for social and economic change. As the economic climate worsened, the catchphrase "I'm Backing Britain" was coined, to encourage shoppers to buy British goods.

1986 Neil Kinnock claimed patriotism as one of Labour's principal values, telling the Scottish Labour conference that his patriotism was the "confident and generous patriotism of freedom and fairness".

 1995 Tony Blair attacked the Tories for waving the union flag at the close of their conference when they "have spent 16 years tearing apart the fabric of our nation". He called on voters to help turn Britain into a nation reborn. "One Britain. That is the patriotism for the future."

 1997 Election campaign mastermind Peter Mandelson introduced the bulldog, in a party political broadcast, as a symbol of New Labour, saying: "Some may be surprised that we use the bulldog. But New Labour is the party of one nation and the bulldog is a way of saying this. It is an animal with a strong sense of history and tradition."

 1997 In his party conference speech later that year Tony Blair used the word "Britain" 53 times, "country" 31 times, and "nation" 19 times.

Sally James

fields.headline: Drugs and the law
fields.trailText:
Why are drugs back in the news again?
An independent report by the Police Foundation has called for a relaxation of the drugs laws to stop ecstasy and cannabis users being given prison sentences.
fields.body:
Why are drugs back in the news again?
An independent report by the Police Foundation has called for a relaxation of the drugs laws to stop ecstasy and cannabis users being given prison sentences.

Drugs and the Law - the result of two years' work by the partly government-funded body - suggests changes should be made to the classification of individual drugs, with ecstasy and LSD being moved from Class A - the category of most harmful drugs - to Class B, the same as amphetamines. Cannabis should be transferred from Class B to Class C.

It also proposes an end to the ban on the therapeutic use of cannabis for specific medical purposes, such as the alleviation of multiple sclerosis, and tougher penalties concerning the confiscation of assets for drug traffickers.

Why has the organisation called for such changes?
According to Lady Ruth Runciman, the former head of the government's drugs advisory council who chaired the report committee, the current categorisation of drugs fails to reflect up-to-date knowledge and applies disproportionate penalties. At present, possessing a class A drug - such as heroin, morphine, cocaine, ecstasy or LSD - can lead to a seven year jail sentence and unlimited fine; possessing a class B one - such as cannabis a five-year one; and possessing a class C drug a two-year sentence.

"Ecstasy is a dangerous drug and we are not saying in any way that it isn't," she insisted today. "What we're concerned to do is to deliver accurate messages about it and to ensure that young people do not devalue the most dangerous drugs - heroin, opiates and cocaine."

What has the response been to all this?
Janet and Paul Betts, whose daughter Leah died after taking an ecstasy tablet on her 18th birthday, have already spoken of their horror at such recommendations. "I hope to God that the government does not implement these recommendations. If they do it will be the last nail in the coffin. We will lose it with the drug dealers and the children. God knows what will happen," Janet Betts said.

And from the government?
The drug tsar Keith Hellawell swiftly ruled out any changes in legislation, insisting: "There will be no change in the categorisation of cannabis and ecstasy. We see no justification for it. It would not improve the situation, it would make it worse."

Political commentators argue it's because Labour won the election on a tough law and order ticket, mollifying traditional Tory voters with their "tough on crime, tough on the causes of crime" stance.

To backtrack now on such an emotive issue could be viewed as a betrayal and lose crucial Middle England support - hence home secretary Jack Straw's robust refusal to countenance it.

There is mild dissent within the cabinet, however, with Mo Mowlam, the cabinet enforcer, recently admitting she inhaled cannabis in the Sixties and suggesting the issue of the drug's decriminalisation be considered. fields.headline: The seduction of Oscar
fields.standfirst: American Beauty is a stylish and intelligent satire, but it was the power of love that won it five major Academy Awards, writes Guardian film critic  Peter Bradshaw
fields.trailText: American Beauty is a stylish and intelligent satire, but it was the power of love that won it five major Academy Awards, writes Guardian film critic Peter Bradshaw
fields.body:
Sam Mendes's American Beauty had a resounding triumph at Sunday night's Academy Awards, winning Oscars for best picture, actor, director, original screenplay and cinematography. The awards demonstrate Hollywood's novel eagerness to be beguiled by a smart, literate script with classy performances from intelligent grown-ups.

The success is encouraging, in that it siphons attention away from sentimental shlockers like The Green Mile, with its questionable take on race, and The Cider House Rules, with its bizarre pseudo-issues. But it is depressing that brilliant nominees vanished utterly from the radar: there was nothing for Michael Mann's stunning The Insider, Spike Jonze's direction of Being John Malkovich or Tom Cruise's acting in Paul Thomas Anderson's Magnolia, movies that are genuinely challenging and experimental in form and tone.

The Oscars showered on Mendes's stylish and exhilarating film are none the less a heartening riposte to dumbing-down and juvenilisation in commercial American cinema. But they also show that in this film Hollywood feels it has an almost perfect combination. There are modish art-house qualities in moderation, a pinch of indie-ness flattering for the Academy's amour propre, and a daring and seductive style that can plausibly showcase both middle-aged sexuality in menopausal revolt and the creamy yearnings of young love. (At some unconscious level, the Academy will have had a shrewd appreciation that candid topless scenes for Thora Birch and Mena Suvari have done box office no harm.)

American Beauty also maintains the astringency of satire. But although its felicitous title is shaded with irony, it conveys an essentially comforting endorsement of the mother country and its warm-hearted family values. American Beauty pulled off the clever trick of soothing and reassuring the Academy's conservative sensibilities - and perhaps members even heard a ghost of Frank Capra's It's a Wonderful Life in Spacey's this-is-where-I-live voiceover.

It is another blow on behalf of elder statesman Steven Spielberg and his DreamWorks SKG behemoth. Who could have guessed we would hear the F-word and the C-word in a DreamWorks picture? His choice of Sam Mendes now looks inspired, and the meeting he engineered between the young British stage director and the veteran American cinematographer Conrad L Hall looks set to pass into Hollywood legend. Mendes's award for direction is the most thoroughly and conspicuously deserved of the list.

Perhaps what put American Beauty ahead of The Insider, The Sixth Sense, The Cider House Rules and The Green Mile is that, for all the dark suburban weirdness, this was the film with the clearest, strongest account of conventional romantic love. This is what appeals most to the Academy's palate and the cinemagoing public: not botched abortions, ghosts, nicotine enhancement, or criminals bursting into flames in the electric chair. The Insider, for example, was notable in that there is no sex interest or sex dilemma of any sort. Al Pacino is a middle-aged guy happily married with grown-up children to an intelligent non-babe his own age, and Russell Crowe plays an intellectual and a scientist whose agonies are not of the heart. Perhaps the Academy just likes that most classical narrative template of all: the story of love.

The male actor winners give pleasingly intelligent turns: nobody deserves promotion to the A-list more than Kevin Spacey, and his delivery of the line in American Beauty about missing the James Bond theme night on TV deserves some sort of award all on its own. (Again, for technical expertise and depth, my vote would go to Russell Crowe, but no one could quarrel with Spacey that much.) But Michael Caine's supporting actor award for The Cider House Rules is a bit baffling. This is an actor with weight and presence, an actor with great technique, often overlooked on account of typecasting. His Dr Larch has twinkling charm, but this is not an outstanding performance from Caine, who was much better in Hannah and Her Sisters and in Educating Rita. Caine's award shows the striking new readiness of the industry and the American public to accept Brits in American roles with American accents, but his accent is outrageously bad, especially considering that Crowe showed how to do a much more convincing one, and transform himself physically into the bargain.

One of the big disappointments of the evening was how lacklustre the female acting awards were. Angelina Jolie is an intelligent performer with sexiness and style, but there is the sinking feeling that she won best supporting actress for Girl, Interrupted because she plays someone in a psychiatric hospital - and playing someone (notionally) mentally ill can often be a free ride to acting plaudits. Jolie was actually better in the more enjoyable, less pretentious Pushing Tin, and she was easily outclassed by Catherine Keener in Being John Malkovich.

And for best actress we got Hilary Swank - someone pretending to be a man. A lanky, short-haired boyish presence, and someone whose repudiation of her female identity leads to disaster. A dull and callow choice, an almost insulting choice, compared with the powerful and vibrant women like Janet McTeer in Tumbleweeds, Julianne Moore in The End of the Affair and Annette Bening in American Beauty. These are real, grown-up women, dramatising strong female roles with passion and intelligence. But the Academy had no appreciation of their power, and went for someone without crow's feet instead. This omission testifies to something immature, obtuse and testosteroney in the Oscar taste.

Once again, Colin Welland's 1981 cry about the British coming sounds faint. Mendes and Caine are associated with two intensely American films, and their awards are light years away from an endorsement for our lottery-funded native industry. Solomon and Gaenor was an honourable runner-up to Almodovar's outstanding All About My Mother in the best foreign film stakes. Topsy-Turvy, Mike Leigh's fine film about the genesis of Gilbert and Sullivan's Mikado, took two well-deserved Oscars for costume and make-up, but these look like the Academy's dutiful, uncomprehending nod to something heritage and picturesque. The fact that Topsy-Turvy had no nominations in the categories of acting, direction or cinematography hints at an Academy prejudice that this is Masterpiece Theater stuff, which but for a technicality would go in the foreign language section.

Ultimately, for all the hype and the over-hype, the most incredible story of Oscar night 2000 is still Sam Mendes, the young director who has leapt to the very top of the movies with his very first jump. In fact, Mendes's training in the distinctively British culture of subsidised theatre - and the awe-inspiringly intelligent way he was able to modify this training for film - are the only things Brit patriots can feel warm about.

fields.headline: Ireland confident plant will close
fields.standfirst: Sellafield crisis - Danish and Irish ministers aim to force shutdown by June but need for safety will keep jobs in Cumbria for generations
fields.trailText: The government could be forced to shut down the Sellafield reprocessing plants by the end of June, it was claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
The government could be forced to shut down the Sellafield reprocessing plants by the end of June, it was claimed yesterday.

The Irish energy minister, Joe Jacob, made the prediction yesterday after he met the Danish environment minister, Svend Auken, to co-ordinate action by the Nordic countries and Ireland in their long campaign to close Sellafield.

Both men are to put proposals before Ospar, the international convention which controls marine pollution in the irish sea, north east Atlantic and North Sea, at the beginning of June. They call for the end of nuclear reprocessing in Europe, which would also include the French plant at Cap de la Hague.

Surprisingly, Mr Auken said he would have the support of the British government in the move. The claim came after the Guardian reported the government was considering closing the reprocessing function at Sellafield.

The government's official spokesman did not deny the closure report yesterday, taking refuge in the comment that it was up to the company to sort out the commercial demands of its customers.

The problem for the government and for British Nuclear Fuels, the state owned company that runs the Sellafield plants, is that most of its customers would be happy to see the end of reprocessing, because storage of spent nuclear fuel is a cheaper option

The problem for everyone is that there are long term contracts for reprocessing 10,000 tonnes of spent fuel, most of which is sitting in storage ponds at Sellafield.

Mr Jacob said after meeting Mr Auken that he believed it was the "beginning of the end" for reprocessing.

"Successive Irish governments have been attempting to close [Sellafield] for a long time, but never with such a background of international opposition to it. With the organised opposition of our colleagues, I think it is going to be very, very difficult to say no to us this time. The Ospar convention is a great opportunity to fulfil our goal."

He said he sympathised with the workers who stood to lose their jobs if the plant was closed. "I very much hope that alternative jobs can be found elsewhere. But we cannot have protection of the environment of the high seas being subordinate to the protection of jobs."

Mr Auken said he was confi dent of support from the UK, although he could not confirm reports that an end to reprocessing was being considered by the government.

"We have noticed that the Labour government has taken a positive interest in finding a resolution to this," he said.

Mr Jacob said he believed the government was "listening" to their complaints. "This is against Sellafield's reprocessing, not against the British government." He hoped closing the reprocessing plant would be the first step towards closing the entire complex.

In a statement BNFL said two-thirds of the 10,000 jobs at Sellafield would be lost if reprocessing ended. It fully supported the government in its obligation to reduce discharges, but only one third came from reprocessing and the rest from clearing up historic wastes.

Sellafield's shop stewards committee last night called for the plant to create a recovery team that could deal with outstanding complaints from customers.

Brian Strutton, national officer of the GMB union, which represents 6,500 Sellafield workers, said: "We must keep things in context. Problems identified in recent weeks must be tackled, but at no time has the overall safety integrity of the plant been compromised."

fields.headline: A new look at learning
fields.standfirst: Demos has come up with radical ideas for reshaping education to take into account the transition to a knowledge-based economy
fields.trailText: Demos has come up with radical ideas for reshaping education to take into account the transition to a knowledge-based economy
fields.body:
Time to fess up. Quadratic equations and coefficients of friction mean nothing to me; structuralism and poststructuralism escape me entirely; I don't know whether Macbeth was written before or after King Lear and the likelihood of my writing an accurate sentence in French is non-existent. In short, I wouldn't stand a cat in hell's chance of passing an A level, let alone a degree course. In truth, I reckon I'd struggle even to pass a GCSE.

My academic amnesia may come as a severe disappointment to the education department, which has spent the last few years trying to nail down the topics and content of the national curriculum in a bid to lift standards and increase the numbers of school leavers with qualifications, but it is hardly uncommon. Almost everyone forgets the huge number of facts they crammed for exams; what they don't necessarily lose - providing they have been taught them - are the conceptual tools for problem-solving and the ability to obtain the relevant information when necessary.

It is against this background, together with the transition to a knowledge-based economy where knowledge is the primary source of economic productivity and the application of learning is as important, if not more so, than the learning itself, that the influential think-tank Demos has come up with radical proposals for the reorganisation of education.

"At present we have a structure where knowledge is transmitted within an institutionalised context," says Tom Bentley, director of Demos. "But our schools are organised in a completely different way to any other institution a person is likely to meet in his or her life. There's widespread recognition that education needs to be seen in a broader sense than the strictly formal to produce a wider set of outcomes for children, such as their ability to become good parents and citizens, but the curriculum has not been adapted to accommodate them."

The Demos buzzword is creativity. Not as an artsy sensibility or technique, but as the application of knowledge and skills in new ways to achieve a desired goal. So within the creative matrix, you find problem-solving, learning from mistakes and the ability to transfer learning across contexts. As an ideal, it's hard to disagree with; any parent or teacher would want their children to leave school with these skills. Where the problems will almost certainly arise are in the practical implementation.

Creativity is not an adjunct to be bolted on to the national curriculum. Demos proposes that half the content be knocked off the national curriculum, that GCSEs and A levels be reshaped to include far more continuous assessment, that pupils take exams when they are able, not at a certain age, and that the whole shape of classroom learning be changed, with far more emphasis on individual and peer assessment.

"I imagine a classroom where pupils would be clustered in groups of five or six working on joint projects," Bentley continues, "where pupils are not segregated by age groups but according to abilities and interests; where the teacher is not necessarily the focal point, as pupils may learn online or from outsiders with specialist knowledge."

Bentley is adamant that the Demos proposals are not a rerun to fluffy educational theory of the 1970s. "I'm not suggesting that formal learning be replaced," he says sharply. "What I do want is to make sure that knowledge is imparted in a practical rather than abstract fashion; not only can it then be applied but people also tend to learn faster that way."

Demos's ideas may receive more of a sympathetic hearing at the education department than you might imagine. Bentley is David Blunkett's former special adviser, and the secretary of state is known to have a more wide-reaching vision for education than government apparatchiks will allow.

But the proposals may get shorter shrift from schools who currently top the league tables and are unwilling to accept any measurement of success other than GCSE passes. Parents, too, may prove resistant. It's one thing to accept an idea in principle, but quite another to allow your children to be human guinea pigs.

Crucially, though, one can't see Demos's ideas getting through government; the added expense of more individualised teaching, together with the radicality of the vision almost guarantees their death. How does Bentley feel about this? "Just because you know the government won't do anything, it doesn't mean you should stop pointing out what's wrong," he says.

fields.trailText: Everything you need to know about the notorious sex manual written by the late Alex Comfort on the net
fields.body:
1. Alex Comfort, author of The Joy of Sex, has died aged 80.

2. The sex manual is what he became famous for, despite his extensive writings on pacifism.

3. Published in 1972, at the tail end of the sexual revolution, it capitalised on the apparent need of many people to hear from an expert that fornication was fun.

4. Comfort wrote the book, which was based on an affair he had with the woman who was to become his second wife, in two weeks. The chapters on starters, main courses and sauces and pickles in the original Cordon Bleu Sex version made it into the final edition: The Joy of Sex: A Gourmet Guide to Lovemaking.

5. Look what it started: "I had many letters from people who had found reading The Joy of Sex a liberating experience," says agony aunt Claire Rayner.

6. Today, sex - joyful or otherwise - is a very popular subject on the net.

7. Not something that Comfort would have appreciated: despite writing several more manuals, he denied being a sexologist, preferring instead to be known for his politics - anarchism - novels and poems.

8. As a physician and scientist, he studied sex, ageing and psychology. He also found time to write popular science and textbooks among his 50 published works.

9. Not bad for a man who had lost four fingers in an accident with a firecracker as a small child. (Maybe the reason why Comfort was something of an evangelist for the powers of the big toe.)

10. Want to know more? Click here and get the book sent straight to your door in a discreet brown package.

webTitle: Shayler gives Gadafy dossier to police

fields.headline: Shayler gives Gadafy dossier to police
fields.trailText: The girlfriend of the former MI5 officer David Shayler yesterday called for special branch to investigate two serving agents for an alleged conspiracy to murder Muammar Gadafy, the Libyan leader.
fields.body:
The girlfriend of the former MI5 officer David Shayler yesterday called for special branch to investigate two serving agents for an alleged conspiracy to murder Muammar Gadafy, the Libyan leader.

Annie Machon, 31, handed in a dossier at Scotland Yard after arriving from Paris where they have lived since he defeated an attempt to extradite him from France to face charges under the Official Secrets Act.

Mr Shayler alleges that MI6 attempted to kill Col Gadafy in 1996 in a plot that led to the deaths of several bystanders. Robin Cook, the foreign secretary, described the allegations as "pure fantasy".

Ms Machon, who was accompanied by Mr Shayler's lawyer John Wadham, who is also director of the civil rights group Liberty, said that special branch had an obligation to investigate the claims.

Mr Shayler's dossier contains evidence he claims incriminates the agents, identified by their codenames PT16 and PT16B. In a covering letter to the head of special branch, Roger Pearce, Mr Shayler reccomended that police interview Mr Cook, Tony Blair, Jack Straw, the Foreign Office minister Peter Hain and the heads of MI5 and MI6.

"Any failure to take this action would indicate the government know I am not lying ... any government interference in the case should be seen as an attempt to pervert the course of justice," Mr Shayler said in a brief statement read by Ms Machon.

Asked why they had sought the help of special branch, she said: "They have had no hesitation in going after us, so we can't see why they would not investigate a conspiracy to murder."

Ms Machon said that Mr Shayler was buoyed by the support he had received in recent months. "His name was very succesfully blackened by private briefings to certain sections of the media, but I think now people realise he is not a traitor but a whistleblower with the best interests of his country at heart," she said.

Mr Shayler's brother, Jeremy, who accompanied Ms Machon and Mr Wadham, said his brother was considering returning to Britain in October following changes to European human rights law.

"He is perfectly willing to give evidence under oath in front of a jury of 12 ordinary people, but he is not willing to spend up to 12 months on remand as a category A prisoner to do so," said Ms Machon.

Last month it emerged the government is to sue Mr Shayler for breaches of confidence and contract, and for infringing crown copyright. The Guardian and Observer are contesting a high court order that they hand over correspondence with him.

Earlier this month Julie Ann-Davies, a student with whom Mr Shayler has been corresponding, was arrested by special branch officers and her computer records were searched.

webTitle: We didn't mislead the British government, BMW boss says

fields.headline: We didn't mislead the British government, BMW boss says
fields.trailText: No one, not even the British government, could have been misled about BMW's intentions for Rover, the German car company's chairman Joachim Milberg told a news conference at his Munich headquarters.
fields.body:
No one, not even the British government, could have been misled about BMW's intentions for Rover, the German car company's chairman Joachim Milberg told a news conference at his Munich headquarters.

"The truth is exactly the opposite," said Prof Milberg. "For years we have taken every opportunity to tell the government that the high value of the pound makes it impossible for companies such as Rover to be viable in the long term."

BMW had drawn the attention of the government to the "serious situation" at Rover on many occasions, and Prof Milberg said that no one could claim to have been misled or not have known about the situation.

Britain's trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers does indeed claim that the German company's decision to pull out of Rover, at the cost of several thousand jobs, came as a bolt from the blue.

BMW would continue to employ several thousand workers in the UK, at the Cowley plant in Oxford and Hamms Hall, Birmingham, the BMW chairman added.

The bitter reality of falling sales and financial losses up by 26% to 2.5bn euro (£1.5bn) for the company as a whole left BMW with no choice, he said.

Prof Milberg said the figures highlighted the "bitter reality" facing the German owners. Sales of Rover cars were down by 7% last year, although BMW's own-brand cars and motor cycles were increasing.

He admitted that BMW had not been able to penetrate the lower mid-range segment of the car market with Rover.

The sale of the Longbridge plant to venture capitalists Alchemy Partners was likely to be completed within the next six to eight weeks, while the sale of Land Rover and its Solihull plant to Ford was likely to go through by the middle of the year, said BMW's chief financial officer, Helmut Panke.

Ford itself has said it expects the deal to be concluded in the third quarter of the year.

There had been no rival offer from General Motors, notwithstanding Ford's Detroit rival saying last week that it would challenge the bid, Prof Milberg said.

But as fast as BMW is offloading one maker of four-wheel drive vehicles, it is considering developing its own rival range. The BMW X5 sports activity vehicle could be used to pioneer a range that could give it a stronger presence in one of the car market's fastest growing sectors.

"The X5 might become the forerunner of an entire model series," said Prof Milberg, without indicating where it would be built.

fields.headline: Mixed reviews for Oscar night
fields.trailText: After lavishing awards on the great and the good of Hollywood, it is now the Oscars' turn to face the critics. As well as reporting on Sunday night's Academy Awards, the American media spent Monday appraising ABC's marathon television broadcast. The general feeling is that it was no prizewinner.
fields.body:
After lavishing awards on the great and the good of Hollywood, it is now the Oscars' turn to face the critics. As well as reporting on Sunday night's Academy Awards, the American media spent Monday appraising ABC's marathon television broadcast. The general feeling is that it was no prizewinner.

One problem was the length. The event's organisers had promised to keep the night moving, yet the four-hour, nine-minute ceremony broke the previous record for longest show (set last year) by some seven minutes. The viewing figures of 79m, meanwhile, showed a slight improvement on 1999, but were still some 20% down on Oscar night 1998 (the year Titanic swept the board).

As for the content, the American media appeared undecided. On the up side, the LA Times felt that ABC's production was "hipper than in years past, sleeker in look and edgier in tone" and paid tribute to wisecracking host Billy Crystal.

But writing in the Washington Post, Tom Shayles took a bleaker view. Despite Crystal's "futile efforts at relief," he wrote, "the Oscar show remains not an entertainment spectacular, but a unique form of national punishment".

Other critics remarked on what they saw as the lack of spontaneity, the tired jokes and the technical glitches (most notably the drowning of singer Isaac Hayes in a cloud of dry ice). The online lifestyle magazine Salon dismissed the whole affair as "painfully boring and bad" and was particularly appalled by Jack Nicholson's rambling presentation of a lifetime achievement award to Warren Beatty. "What's he got, Alzheimer's?" it wondered.

But even the worst casualties of Oscar night (the losing nominees, the panned presenters) got away lightly compared with some others. Two hours into the ceremony, a TV helicopter covering the award crash-landed a short way from the hall. An on-board cameraman broke his leg, and the pilot was critically injured - which puts the whole thing in perspective.

webTitle: The tallest, thinnest tortoise in history

fields.headline: The tallest, thinnest tortoise in history
fields.trailText: Most fast bowlers are sports cars, Ferraris or Aston Martins, exciting but expensive. Courtney Walsh is a Volvo. A number of fast bowlers have been more brilliant, and a few of them are playing today - Donald, Wasim, McGrath, Ambrose. But no fast bowler, past or present, comes close to Walsh for durability.
fields.body:
Most fast bowlers are sports cars, Ferraris or Aston Martins, exciting but expensive. Courtney Walsh is a Volvo. A number of fast bowlers have been more brilliant, and a few of them are playing today - Donald, Wasim, McGrath, Ambrose. But no fast bowler, past or present, comes close to Walsh for durability.

He started slowly, and finished slowly, but he got there in the end, with the help of a man called Olonga. He began, 16 years ago, as the West Indies' uphill, into-the-wind, only-two-slips bowler (somebody had to do it) and was half way through his career before he was even given the new ball. His autobiography, which appeared last year, should have been ghosted by Aesop. Walsh may be the tallest, thinnest tortoise in history.

Only three men have ever reached 400 wickets in Tests. The first, Richard Hadlee of New Zealand, was a great fast-medium bowler and a useful lower-order hitter. The second, Kapil Dev of India, was a great allrounder, and a very good medium-fast bowler. The third, Walsh, is a comically incompetent batsman, as he reminded us yesterday, by lasting three balls when all he had to do was stay in for a few minutes and see his captain to a hundred. How he goes in ahead of Reon King is one of life's mysteries. But great bowlers don't have to be able to bat.

Walsh, unlike Hadlee and Dev, has been classified for nearly all his career as RF: right-arm fast. Just because he bowls within himself five balls an over, doesn't mean he isn't quick. It is fair to assume that no one in history has been so fast for so long. At 37 and a half, on a torpid pitch, he can still make Test batsmen jump. The only Englishman to take even 350 wickets is Ian Botham, with 373. When he reached the age Courtney is now, he was history: a portly shadow of his former self, sending down a few wily slow-medium pacers.

The man with the wide rolling eyes has seen it all. He began in 1983-84, when West Indies still had a decade to go as kings of the world. He played under Clive Lloyd, Viv Richards, Richie Richardson. He succeeded Richardson himself, the first fast bowler ever to captain the West Indies. He lost the captaincy to Brian Lara, but only one of them surrendered any dignity in the process, and it wasn't Walsh.

He is a fast bowler, not a saint. At Sabina Park in 1993-94, he subjected another fast man with a Jamaican heritage, Devon Malcolm, to a vicious barrage. When he did the same to Mike Atherton, that was fair enough, and Atherton relished the duel, whereas Malcolm could hardly see the bowler, let alone the ball. But that was out of character, and one beat-up in 16 years is a pretty good record. As Atherton confirmed in a generous tribute on Sunday, Walsh is as popular with other players as a leading fast bowler can be.

His record is unlikely to stand for long. Shane Warne, seven years his junior, is into the 350s, and Wasim Akram, 33, is on 383. Walsh should become the first man to make it to 450, some time this summer in England, but 500 is surely beyond him. In this series, at last, West Indies have become a team with four fast bowlers again, not two. He will hand over as gracefully as Kapil Dev has, with champagne and good wishes. He has given us many indelible memories and two more came yesterday. One was the sight of Courtney's mum, proudly manning, or womanning, her home-made scoreboard, changing 434 to 435 and No 2 in the world to No 1. The other was Courtney himself, celebrating his first two wickets: the oldest seamer in town, running around in circles, like a small boy being an aeroplane. After 4197 overs, that says a lot.

Tim de Lisle is editor of wisden.com and Wisden Cricket Monthly.

webTitle: Ease up on drug users and hit the dealers, Blair told

fields.headline: Ease up on drug users and hit the dealers, Blair told
fields.trailText: Britain should crack down on organised dealers but ease up on users of "soft" drugs such as cannabis and ecstasy, an independent inquiry recommended today.
fields.body:
Britain should crack down on organised dealers but ease up on users of "soft" drugs such as cannabis and ecstasy, an independent inquiry recommended today.

The inquiry by the Police Foundation - a respected charity partly funded by the government - concluded that current laws have had only limited success in deterring drug abuse and that too much police time is wasted on soft drugs.

But drug tsar Keith Hellawell rejected suggestions that the police should draw a distinction between dealers and users and ruled out any change in the law on ecstasy and cannabis. He told BBC Radio 4's Today programme: "What you get is a lot of street-level dealers with very small amounts. The problem in actually saying 'Well, this is dealing and this is personal possession' is where do you draw the line at what is personal possession."

The government has insisted on a tough line on drugs as part of its strong law-and-order image. Whenever ministers such as Mo Mowlam have mooted the idea of a softer approach, they have been promptly reprimanded. Mr Hellawell's defence of current strategy in the face of recommendations from an impeccable source was in keeping with the government's unyielding approach on drugs.

But Lady Ruth Runciman, who chaired the inquiry, said that the authorities should change the emphasis and concentrate on hard drugs and their traffickers. Drug-treatment facilities receive 13% of the national drugs budget compared with the 62% allocated to law enforcement and the inquiry suggests a substantial shift of resources towards treatment services.

"The most effective tools to deal with use are education and treatment - not criminal sanctions," said Lady Runciman. "There's no evidence that we have been able to find that our extremely severe penalties against the possession of drugs have conferred any advantage on this country." The Police Foundation, which brings together drugs experts, police and legal officials, has researched the issue for two years. While some top police officers advise against any relaxing of the laws, the Foundation calls for an end to prison sentences for users of ecstasy and cannabis. It also advocated making the possession of cannabis a civil offence, and downgrading ecstasy to a Class B drug.

Britain groups narcotics into classes A, B and C, according to their seriousness, and operates a policy on possession that has more to do with local police opinion than national strategy. Lady Runciman said her main focus was to clamp down on serious drugs such as heroin, opiates and cocaine. These drugs have won over a new generation of users, alarming youth workers.

Plummeting prices have increased their popularity along with changing perceptions about the risks involved. "There is some evidence in this country that we need to refocus our attention on the pre-eminent harms," Lady Runciman said.

Although ecstasy remains the drug of choice for many clubbers and cannabis use is now widespread right across society, the government is not expected to soften its stance. It has ruled out easing up on recreational drug use, saying any relaxation in the law would only boost consumption. "The policies we have are realistic," said Mr Hellawell, in defending government strategy. "We have a very sophisticated drugs policy."

The report was welcomed by the national drugs and legal advice charity Release as an enormously significant document. Release director Mike Goodman said: "Since the Dangerous Drugs Act was introduced in 1967, almost 1m people have been prosecuted and punished for cannabis-related offences alone. Most of these have been for possession of small amounts for personal use. The proposal to downgrade possession of cannabis and remove the ludicrous threat of imprisonment for personal use is pragmatic and sensible."

But Janet Betts, whose daughter Leah died in 1995 after taking an ecstasy tablet at her 18th birthday party, said: "My thoughts are that I hope to God that the Government does not implement these recommendations. If they do, it will be the last nail in the coffin."

But Janet Betts, whose daughter Leah died in 1995 after taking an ecstasy tablet at her 18th birthday party, said: "My thoughts are that I hope to God that the Government does not implement these recommendations. If they do, it will be the last nail in the coffin."

fields.headline: EP's Dave Callaghan overwhelms Gauteng
fields.trailText: South Africa
fields.body:
South Africa

An irresistible all-round display from Dave Callaghan propelled Eastern Province into the final of the one-day Standard Bank Cup at the expense of Gauteng. After the first attempt to play the deciding game in the best-of-three semi-finals was ruined by the rain, the teams met again at Johannesburg and it was Callaghan who lit up proceedings. First he made 65 in EP's modest-looking total of 187 for 8. Then he picked up 4-31 as Gauteng were bundled out for 125. Adam Bacher tried to make a game of it with 59, but no-one else passed Zander de Bruyn's 19. EP will meet Boland in the final.

Eastern Province 187 for 8 in 45 overs
Gauteng 125 in 38.2 overs
Eastern Province won by 62 runs

New Zealand

A hat-trick from Tama Canning wrapped up Auckland's heart-stopping eight-run victory over Central Districts in the first-class Shell Trophy at Colin Maiden Park in Auckland - and secured their place in the final. Canning, whose hat-trick was the first by an Auckland player in first-class cricket since 1913, took wickets with the last ball of his penultimate over and the first two of his last as CD collapsed in sight of the victory post. Set 280 to win, they were going along nicely at 246 for 5, but lost their last five for just 25, leaving captain Jacob Oram stranded on 92*. Brooke Walker claimed 5-94. Earlier, Auckland had recovered in their first innings from 139 for 7 to reach 291, thanks to 76* from No.9 Kyle Mills. CD replied with 194 as Andre Adams took 5-63, before Auckland managed just 182 second time round. In the end it proved enough - just.

Auckland 291 (Aaron Barnes 65, Lance Hamilton 4-77) and 182 (Hamilton 4-46)
Central Districts 194 (Oram 54) and 271 (Mark Douglas 56, Canning 3-45)
Auckland won by 8 runs

Northern Districts won the group after coming from behind to beat Canterbury at the Village Green in Christchurch. ND conceded a first-innings lead of 109 after Bruce Martin (5-88) and Chris Harris (28.3-11-39-4) limited them to 191 in reply to Canterbury's 300. But Canterbury then subsided to 139 in their second innings, having at one stage been 77 for 1 (when they led by 186). Martin again did the damage with 6-44 to make it 11-132 in the match. Left needing 249 to win, ND cruised to 251 for 4, with everyone making runs; Neal Parlane top-scored with 61*.

Canterbury 300 (Papps 67, Gary Stead 49) and 139
Northern Districts 191 (Michael Parlane 57) and 251 for 4
Northern Disticts won by 6 wickets

Wellington were too much for Otago at Molyneux Park, Alexandria, and won by nine wickets after enforcing the follow-on. Wellington opened with 307, as recent one-day international recruit Chris Nevin hit 72, and former Test opener Matthew Bell scored 54. Otago stumbled to 144 in reply, 14 short of avoiding the follow-on, before making 208 in their second innings; Chris Gaffaney made 68, Mark Richardson 51, while Mark Gillespie took 5-58. Set 47 to win, Wellington cantered home.

Wellington 307 and 47 for 1
Otago 144 (James Franklin 4-41) and 208
Wellington won by 9 wickets

The final standings: 1 Northern Districts 26pts, 2 Auckland 24, 3 Central Districts 14, 4 Otago 8, 5 Wellington 8, 6 Canterbury 2
Northern Districts and Auckland qualify for the final

Zimbabwe

The highest partnership in Zimbabwean history helped Mashonaland thrash Matabeleland in the first-class Logan Cup at Bulawayo Athletic Club. Dirk Viljoen, with 173*, and Craig Evans, who bludgeoned 153 off just 143 balls with 16 fours and five sixes, added 330 for the fourth wicket as Mashonaland racked up 448 for 4 declared in their second innings. It left Matabeleland a nominal 363 to win. But there was no stopping Evans. He took four wickets for five runs (after beginning with 5-5-0-4) as Matabeleland were humbled for 86, which included slumping from 13 for 0 to 13 for 3, and later from 72 for 4 to 72 for 8. It was all tough luck on Matabeleland's international bowler John Rennie, who had given his side an apparently handy first-innings lead of 86 by taking 5-70 and then hitting 63.

Mashonaland 170 and 448 for 4 decl.
Matabeleland 256 (Mark Vermuelen 87) and 86 (Gus Mackay 4-30)
Mashonaland won by 276 runs

Discarded Test legspinner Paul Strang was in the runs as CFX Academy drew with Manicaland in the other game. Strang made 74* as CFX batted out the match to finish on 250 for 5 after conceding a lead of 97 on first innings. Earlier, CFX collapsed to 191 all out, despite 100* from Greg Lamb; Test offspinner Andy Whittall claimed 5-47 as none of the last six batsmen made more than a single. Neil Ferreira then struck 121 as Manicaland responded with 288; Andy Whittall chipped in with 42.

CFX Academy 191 and 250 for 5
Manicaland 288
Drawn

Lawrence Booth is assistant editor of wisden.com

fields.headline: More than real
fields.trailText: A new perspective on the story of Troy, plus A Voyage of Discovery, Volume 1 and My Brother's Ghost
fields.body:
Troy
Adèle Geras
David Fickling Books, £14.99

Adèle Geras has told one of the founding stories of Western culture, a tale that has been related a thousand times and still comes up fresh. The story of the destruction of Troy at the hands of the Greeks. To her great credit she tells it straight, without the slightest visible straining for effect. Her perspective is interesting, too. This is a Troy seen from below, from the kitchens and the stables and (a wonderful notion) the Blood Room, where the wounded are tended by the young Xanthe.

Geras's other triumph is the way she deals with the gods. They appear suddenly and naturally, to speak or intervene, and then vanish again, leaving us with the sense of a world governed by powers and riddled with jealousies only half understood by the suffering mortals. Every generation needs its version of this great story. This one, powerful, clear, and compassionate, is the best I've read for a long time.

A Voyage of Discovery, Volume 1: From the Land of the Amazons to the Indigo Isles
François Place, translated by Aubrey Lawrence
Pavilion, £12.99

François Place is an extraordinary artist, not quite like anyone else I can think of. A Voyage of Discovery is a series of prodigiously inventive landscapes in words and exquisite pictures. The concept is rather like that of Umberto Eco's Invisible Cities: different places, in this case entire fantastical countries, are described and drawn in as if by curious observers from elsewhere.

The invention is astonishing: in Baïlabaïkal, for example, they build parks among the reed-beds where they rear giant snakes. In spring, the snakes are taken to volcanoes of hot mud, where male midwives help them shed their skins; and the skins are then stretched over a framework of sticks to make canoes. The spirit of the snake lives on in the canoe, helping the boatmen to steer. This little vignette occupies a page, and no less than seven amazingly detailed pictures. In fine pen line and exquisite wash, Place brings both whole panoramas and tiny details to life. And this is only the first of a promised three volumes! It is a triumph of imagination and craftsmanship: one of the most amazing works I've ever seen.

My Brother's Ghost
Allan Ahlberg
Puffin, £7.99

Allan Ahlberg has succeeded in many genres: poetry, picture-book text, short story, he can do them all. My Brother's Ghost is something new. As the title suggests, it's a ghost story: a novella, really, told by the middle-aged Frances, who looks back on the terrible accident that marked her childhood and the life she lives with her guardians, the cold and cruel Auntie Marge and the ineffectual Uncle Stan.

The details are immaculate and affecting: Frances' little brother Harry keeps wetting the bed, enraging Auntie Marge; and it's the ghost of Tom, the brother who died, who gets him up in the night to go to the bathroom. Ahlberg is a genius with details, and the way the story is resolved shows his invention at its best.

fields.headline: Today's other news
fields.trailText: Charlie Sheen is released from probation early, screenwriter Jim Cash dies, Catherine Zeta-Jones is Alfa Romeo's new face, and Sandra Bullock is on the casting couch, planning more comic flicks
fields.body:
 One Hollywood star had good reason to feel cheerful on the morning after the Oscar the night before. Charlie Sheen may not have been up for any awards at Sunday's extravaganza, but discovered on Monday that he has been released 71 days early from his probation. "You have made an enormous turnaround in your life and career," Malibu judge Lawrence Mira informed the 34-year-old actor. "You don't need me any more." Sheen had been placed on two-year probation in 1998 for drug and alcohol abuse and a conviction for battery against an ex-girlfriend, but insiders say the pampered bad boy has since wised up. His career is still stuck in the slow lane, but he can currently be seen in a neat, self-ridiculing cameo in Being John Malkovich and is due to take over from the ailing Michael J Fox in the TV sitcom Spin City. "It's nice to have a second chance," Sheen said.

 Screenwriter Jim Cash has died at the age of 59 following treatment for an undisclosed intestinal ailment. Cash, who died in Michigan at the weekend, worked as a scriptwriter on such 80s Hollywood gems as Top Gun, Legal Eagles, Dick Tracy and The Secret of My Success.

 Catherine Zeta-Jones's star keeps on rising. In the past year, the Welsh-born actress has made her Hollywood breakthrough in The Mask of Zorro and Entrapment, married Michael Douglas, got herself pregnant (though perhaps not in that order) and signed on to star in the controversial new Steven Soderbergh picture. Now, Zeta-Jones has taken on, if not her most demanding role, then certainly one of her most profitable. She will be the new "face" of Alfa Romeo and will promote the car firm's 156 Sportwagon in a TV commercial, which will show her hiking up her dress and climbing head first into the vehicle through the hatchback. Can an Academy Award be following far behind?

Casting couch

 Sandra Bullock is reported to be in talks with Universal to star in Her Leading Man, a tongue-in-cheek romantic comedy. The Speed star has also recently committed to playing an FBI agent who goes undercover at a small-town beauty contest in the comedy thriller Miss Congeniality.

fields.headline: Bass predicts $1bn net bookings
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Bass, the brewer and world's second largest hotel operator, yesterday predicted it would hit its $1bn (£630m) annual target for internet room booking revenues within four years.
fields.body:
Bass, the brewer and world's second largest hotel operator, yesterday predicted it would hit its $1bn (£630m) annual target for internet room booking revenues within four years.

Customers would benefit from cheaper beds as the owner of Holiday Inns, Inter-Continental and Crowne Plaza hotels, passed on some of the financial benefits from web-based booking, it claimed.

Eric Pearson, vice-president for e-commerce at Bass, said the company with 2,800 hotels with 450,000 rooms was already taking $12m a month of hotel bookings over the net. This figure represents nearly 3% of the company's global revenue and it is growing every day.

"We predict that within four to five years we will be doing $1bn of business over the web," said Mr Pearson. This would amount to nearly 12% of revenues.

Web bookings cut out travel agents' commissions and other transaction fees and are said to be able to reduce costs by up to 10%.

Bass sells most of its rooms on the internet via its own websites but also through Lastminute.com, the internet travel agency.

Last December Bass invested an estimated £5m in Lastminute, which has just been floated on the London stock market amid some controversy over its share price gyrations.

Bass has been using Lastminute to market "distressed rooms" at cut-price levels and also market higher ticket packages with hotels linked to other services such as theatre tickets and car rental deals.

Bass started selling via its own website in 1995 and now claims to have the most visited hotel websites in the world.

"We have 11m to 12m page hits a month from 1.9m visits. What we have is high volumes and high usability, " said Mr Pearson.

Meanwhile the battle to takeover Bass's brewing interests is hotting up with diminutive J. Boag & Son in Australia insisting it was in the running to buy the British business.

This year Bass has bought Southern Pacific Hotels and bought up the 90% stake it did not own in Bristol Hotels & Resorts of the US.

But while its hotel interests have grown its commitment to brewing activities has looked increasingly in doubt.

Yesterday a Bass spokesman insisted that no decision had been taken as to whether to keep and develop those interests, which include six British breweries said to be worth up to £2bn.

But Holland's Heineken has made public its interest in buying the Bass brewing empire, while yesterday Boag announced that it had hired Westdeutsche LB as its financial adviser for an offer.

Despite its small size, Boag chairman and chief executive Philip Adkins said its success in the competitive Australian beer market qualified it to compete for Bass.

Bass is nearly 100 times the value of Boag. Its chairman is a former US investment banker who has already tried but failed to buy New Zealand brewer Lion Nathan.

The share price for Bass ended the session up a modest 2p at 750p.

fields.headline: Aria pulita nelle città senz'auto?
fields.standfirst: Could Italians learn to live without their cars? The government is introducing 'Sundays on foot' to find out
fields.trailText: Could Italians learn to live without their cars? The government is introducing 'Sundays on foot' to find out
fields.body:
Le città italiane sono soffocate dal traffico. Le stati- stiche dicono che in Italia circolano 36.827.000 fra autoveicoli e veicoli commerciali: un veicolo ogni 1,6 persone. È il rapporto più alto in Europa. In città si procede a fatica: un'indagine di Legambiente rivela che a Milano, nelle ore di punta, un'auto percorre 9,1 chilometri all'ora e a Napoli addirittura 7,3. Ma nessuno rinuncia alla sua "lumaca".

Negli ultimi mesi i gas nocivi e le famigerate polveri fini Pm10 hanno superato ogni livello di guardia. Ad aggravare la situazione c'è il clima, con alta pressione e assenza di pioggia.

Il Ministero dell'Ambiente ha quindi lanciato le domeniche del pedone, giornate di blocco totale del traffico in città. Si è stabilito che fossero quattro, dal 6 febbraio al 7 maggio, ma parecchie amministrazioni comunali ne hanno aggiunte altre.

Centocinquanta città italiane aderiscono all'iniziativa ed hanno individuato incentivi per incoraggiare i cittadini a lasciare l'auto a casa: noleggio biciclette, prezzi ridotti per servizi pubblici e musei, feste per strada.

Alcune categorie, come commercianti o club calcistici, si sono sentite penalizzate e affermano che i danni patiti sono superiori ai vantaggi per la collettività.

L'ottanta per cento dei cittadini, invece, afferma di gradire il blocco. Sono coloro che si sono impossessati delle strade, lasciate libere dalle auto.

Secondo il Ministro dell'Ambiente "le domeniche senz'auto stanno pian piano entrando nel DNA degli italiani". Ma Grazia Francescato, presidente dei Verdi, puntualizza: "Adesso bisogna pensare all'inquinamento del lunedí, per cui servono al più presto provvedimenti strutturali".

A che cosa attribuisci la responsabilità dell'inquinamento atmosferico nelle città e come proponi di limitarlo?

Mauro Baietto, 17 - La colpa è soprattutto del traffico. Non si è mai incoraggiato un uso razionale delle automobili. Ci sono persone che non escono mai senz'auto. Penso si debbano aumentare le limitazioni del traffico e i blocchi nelle città. E poi bisogna studiare e usare carburanti meno nocivi.

Elena Bollero, 17 - I grandi responsabili sono il traffico, il riscaldamento delle case e l'industria. La responsabilità è di chi amministra ma anche personale. Dovremmo imparare a regolare meglio il riscaldamento, usare una sola macchina in gruppo, fra compagni o colleghi di lavoro, riscoprire il treno, il bus, la bicicletta. Dobbiamo metterci in testa che le piccole iniziative possono fare più dei divieti.

Nicola Ambrosino, 19 - In Italia e a Torino in particolare c'è un uso molto massiccio degli automezzi. L'ho notato viaggiando in Europa. L'automobile è l'oggetto dei desideri di molti italiani. E non si sono sviluppate reti di servizi pubblici efficienti. Torino, ad esempio, avrà una linea della metropolitana solo nel 2005, se tutto andrà bene.

Pietro La Camera, responsabile locale di Legambiente - L'inquinamento atmosferico ha molte concause: il traffico veicolare, gli impianti di riscaldamento, le emissioni delle industrie.

La ricerca di soluzioni è quindi articolata. Per quanto riguarda il traffico, bisogna eliminare quello pesante dalle città e andare ad una legislazione, a livello europeo, che abbassi ulteriormente le emissioni delle auto. È anche essenziale che siano potenziati i mezzi pubblici e si incoraggi un utilizzo diverso dell'automobile.

Come giudichi le domeniche del pedone e che impressione ne hai avuto?

Mauro - È un inizio di soluzione. Significa che finalmente pensiamo al problema. Si risolve poco, comunque, dal punto di vista dell'inquinamento. Un solo blocco al mese non ha senso.

Elena - Ritengo che sia una bella iniziativa culturalmente parlando. Insegna al cittadino a vivere la città in maniera alternativa. Ma penso che per l'ambiente possa fare veramente poco. Anche i dati lo hanno detto: le polveri non sono diminuite. Comunque mi è piaciuto vedere la gente in giro in bici o sui pattini. E poi che silenzio!

Nicola - Una bella iniziativa per promuovere l'abbandono delle auto. Si incentiva la gente a spostarsi in altro modo, con i mezzi pubblici o a piedi. Sono stato in centro a Torino, il 5 marzo. fields.bodyText: Le città italiane sono soffocate dal traffico. Le stati- stiche dicono che in Italia circolano 36.827.000 fra autoveicoli e veicoli commerciali: un veicolo ogni 1,6 persone. È il rapporto più alto in Europa. In città si procede a fatica: un'indagine di Legambiente rivela che a Milano, nelle ore di punta, un'auto percorre 9,1 chilometri all'ora e a Napoli addirittura 7,3. Ma nessuno rinuncia alla sua "lumaca". Negli ultimi mesi i gas nocivi e le famigerate polveri fini Pm10 hanno superato ogni livello di guardia. Ad aggravare la situazione c'è il clima, con alta pressione e assenza di pioggia. Il Ministero dell'Ambiente ha quindi lanciato le domeniche del pedone, giornate di blocco totale del traffico in città. Si è stabilito che fossero quattro, dal 6 febbraio al 7 maggio, ma parecchie amministrazioni comunali ne hanno aggiunte altre. Centocinquanta città italiane aderiscono all'iniziativa ed hanno individuato incentivi per incoraggiare i cittadini a lasciare l'auto a casa: noleggio biciclette, prezzi ridotti per servizi pubblici e musei, feste per strada. Alcune categorie, come commercianti o club calcistici, si sono sentite penalizzate e affermano che i danni patiti sono superiori ai vantaggi per la collettività. L'ottanta per cento dei cittadini, invece, afferma di gradire il blocco. Sono coloro che si sono impossessati delle strade, lasciate libere dalle auto. Secondo il Ministro dell'Ambiente "le domeniche senz'auto stanno pian piano entrando nel DNA degli italiani". Ma Grazia Francescato, presidente dei Verdi, puntualizza: "Adesso bisogna pensare all'inquinamento del lunedí, per cui servono al più presto provvedimenti strutturali". Non si è mai incoraggiato un uso razionale delle automobili. Ci sono persone che non escono mai senz'auto. Penso si debbano aumentare le limitazioni del traffico e i blocchi nelle città. E poi bisogna studiare e usare carburanti meno nocivi. Elena Bollero, 17 - I grandi responsabili sono il traffico, il riscaldamento delle case e l'industria. La responsabilità è di chi amministra ma anche personale. Dovremmo imparare a regolare meglio il riscaldamento, usare una sola macchina in gruppo, fra compagni o colleghi di lavoro, riscoprire il treno, il bus, la bicicletta. Dobbiamo metterci in testa che le piccole iniziative possono fare più dei divieti. Nicola Ambrosino, 19 - In Italia e a Torino in particolare c'è un uso molto massiccio degli automezzi. L'ho notato viaggiando in Europa. L'automobile è l'oggetto dei desideri di molti italiani. E non si sono sviluppate reti di servizi pubblici efficienti. fields.headline: Rumours Unlimited
fields.standfirst: Tomorrow's chip paper today
fields.trailText: The Express Leeds have amassed a huge £30m 'war chest' to spend this summer. Wimbledon's Carl Cort, who is expected to cost £7m, £5m former Everton midfielder Olivier Dacourt, and £2.5m rated Don Hutchinson are David O'Leary's top targets.
fields.body:
The Express Leeds have amassed a huge £30m 'war chest' to spend this summer. Wimbledon's Carl Cort, who is expected to cost £7m, £5m former Everton midfielder Olivier Dacourt, and £2.5m rated Don Hutchinson are David O'Leary's top targets.

Teamtalk Middlesbrough boss Bryan Robson is interested in signing Hertha Berlin's £3m-rated midfielder Sebastian Deisler. With Juninho's future at the Riverside in doubt, Robson considers the 20 year old play-maker as the ideal replacement.

George Graham is another manager ready to spend this summer. He's lining up a £16m double deal to take £10m Chelsea misfit Chris Sutton and Ole Gunnar Solskjaer to White Hart Lane.

Cherno Samba is about to become the most expensive 15 year old in Britain. Liverpool are poised to sign the precocious Millwall U-16 striker in an £1.5m deal.

Planet Football Marc Overmars has reiterated his desire to move to Barcelona. He told the Spanish press: "I dream of the possibility of becoming a league champion in Spain with Barca. But it is delicate. If I say it aloud it immediately becomes news, as has already happened."

The Mirror Aston Villa's Paul Merson has got involved in the debate over Benito Carbone's wage demands. "This club simply cannot afford to be held to ransom," said Merson. "Surely the club won't throw everything out of the window just to please one individual." Carbone's £38,000 a week wage demands, which allegedly include £1,000 towards the rent of a house, have apparently earned him the nickname 'The GLB' (As in Greedy Little B*****d) among the Villa Park hierarchy.

Blackburn have dismissed speculation linking them with a £5m move for Israeli international, Eyal Berkovic. Rovers chief executive John Williams insists that new boss Graeme Souness has made no enquiries for the Celtic star whom he took to Southampton in 1996.

fields.headline: Time travel
fields.standfirst: John Crace finds Beowulf - in the original and Heaney's typed translation - among 1,000 years of literary English manuscripts
fields.trailText: John Crace finds Beowulf - in the original and Heaney's typed translation - among 1,000 years of literary English manuscripts
fields.body:
Generations of English students have only known Shakespeare through the Arden editions and Jane Austen via Penguin Classics. And that's precisely the way it's likely to stay if literary manuscripts continue to migrate eastwards into the archives of US university libraries.

At a recent lecture to the Royal Society of Authors, the poet laureate Andrew Motion called on the chancellor of the exchequer, Gordon Brown, to reverse this trend by creating a tax exemption for manuscripts bought by British institutions. Brown ignored Motion's proposals - so for now English research grants will have to include flights to Texas or wherever.

Motion's appeal is no mere Little England demand to keep Britain for the British. While students and academics can discover the intricacies of a manuscript at second hand, Motion believes you can't beat the original for a direct connection into the heart and mind of an author.

"I can remember seeing a copy of Valerie Eliot's manuscript edition of The Wasteland as a student," he says. "It was a revelation. The poem became much more personal; I got a sense of Eliot writing it on the hoof rather than relating to it solely as a finished, polished work. Writing evolves as much from what goes wrong as from what goes right."

In short, a manuscript can describe a process: it is a pathway into the creative struggle of the writer. This month a new exhibition, Chapter & Verse - 1000 Years of English Literature, opened at the British Library; on display are the original manuscripts of many of the most celebrated pieces of literature, and a pattern that consistently emerges is the gap between the generally received interpretation and perception of the text and the impression the manuscript gives.

Take one of the highlights of the exhibition, the unique 1,000-year-old Anglo-Saxon (Old English) manuscript of Beowulf. "The poem is usually reproduced in three parts," says Professor Kevin Kiernan of the university of Kentucky, one of the world's leading experts on Beowulf and the man behind the new electronic edition. "In fact it's in 42 parts and when you read it section by section it appears far less digressive. The manuscript also reminds you of how much of the original is missing, and how much we have depended on other sources to fill in the gaps.

"There are many indications the poem was not copied exactly, and that the scribes ignored the line rulings to add extra lines per page. Most vellum pages have 20 lines, but some sections are 22 and some 21. The shifts in the format come abruptly: for instance, the heading of chapter 24 has gone missing and on another page of the folio you can see where the original text has been washed down and erased and re-written in a different hand. To make sense of the poem properly, you have to allow for these apparent disorders."

Side by side with the original is Seamus Heaney's prize-winning modern translation, which shows that the word processor has not killed off the literary draft. Heaney began work on his Beowulf in the mid-80s, and one can see that rather than revising the text on screen, he printed out the work in progress and annotated it by hand. It is as if he needed the physical relationship between pen and page to access the emotional connection to the poem.

Andrew Motion does not find this surprising: "I only work on the computer in the later stages of a work, as writing straight on to the screen can give you the impression a piece is finished long before it is."

Heaney's manuscripts provide insights into the battle for precision and economy. Over nearly 15 years he composed seven alternative openings before settling for one. Similarly, in each draft one can see how some words, such as thole (meaning to endure or suffer), pop in and out of the text before Heaney decides it can stay. In the end there is nothing there that shouldn't be.

The idea that the hand of an author is intimately connected to his or her manuscript is not new. The Romantics even took the idea literally: Shelley's ashes were wrapped in one of his manuscripts.

Just how closely a poet should be identified with their work can also be inferred from manuscript. In 1812, Byron "woke one morning" to find himself famous after the publication of the first two cantos of Childe Harold's Pilgrimage. The poem describes the travels of a jaded young man looking for fresh experiences, and commentators have speculated whether Byron and Harold were one and the same. Byron claimed Harold was fictitious, but the proofs from the end of the second canto include Byron's comments on a more egotistical, "affected" alternative for the final two lines, suggesting the poem may be closer to autobiography than the poet was willing to admit.

Elsewhere we find that Austen reworked the last chapters of Persuasion to give Ann Elliot a stronger role in getting Wentworth to declare his love, and that Wordsworth's Daffodils was a more collaborative effort than its mood would suggest; the manuscript was written out by his wife, Mary, who first began the poem: "I wandered like a lonely..."

The 20th century is equally well represented. "From the vigour and toughness of Sylvia Plath's Ariel you would expect to find a frantic and heavily worked manuscript," says Chris Fletcher, curator of manuscripts at the British Library. "In fact, it is naively and girlishly written and is decorated with a small hand-drawn flower at the bottom."

Wilfred Owen's Anthem for Doomed Youth is also revealing. "For one thing, the title was not his," says Fletcher. "His original title was Anthem for Dead Youth, which he changed at Siegfried Sassoon's suggestion. He worked to find the right words. 'Tenderness of mortal minds' is variously 'Tenderness of broken/simple/frail/innocent minds'."

Yet sometimes a manuscript only confuses the issue. The 1816 published version of Coleridge's Kubla Khan conflicts with the poet's note on the manuscript that "this fragment with a good deal more, not recoverable, composed, in a sort of Reverie brought on by two grains of opium, taken to check a dysentry, at a Farm House between Porlock & Linton, a quarter of a mile from Culborne Church, in the fall of the year, 1797". As Fletcher notes, the manuscript does not look opium-induced - it survives as a fair copy with one or two considered annotations.

Manuscripts may offer a window into their author's soul, but sometimes the glass remains opaque.

webTitle: Windies go ballistic as paceman hits critical mass

fields.headline: Windies go ballistic as paceman hits critical mass
fields.trailText: The atmosphere here on the fourth day of West Indies' second Test against Zimbabwe yesterday was not electric, it was nuclear; and the fissionable material was Jamaica's most famous cricket son.
fields.byline: B C Pires  at Sabina Park
fields.body:
The atmosphere here on the fourth day of West Indies' second Test against Zimbabwe yesterday was not electric, it was nuclear; and the fissionable material was Jamaica's most famous cricket son.

When Courtney Walsh took the last available Zimbabwean wicket with the help of his fellow countryman Wavell Hinds to break the record, Jamaicans in the ground danced, cheered, waved "Go Courtney" flags and threw their "Courtney Walsh 435 On Target" baseball caps in the air.

It was almost incidental that Zimbabwe, without the injured Heath Streak, were effectively all out for 102 and that West Indies needed only 72 to win.

Walsh equalled Kapil Dev's record in his third over and passed it with the fifth ball of his 16th. Every one of the 71 times he ran up between his 434th and 435th wicket, the entire ground, and all of the West Indies, braced itself.

"Mentally it's drained me," he said after leading his team-mates off to a standing ovation. "When the wickets started tumbling it got a bit dicey and I wondered would I get it. So when the skipper asked me whether I was ready to bowl I said: 'Great'.

"I was already heading in his direction; I wanted to hint to him that if he needed me to bowl I was ready. In the end I was just happy to get the wicket."

Dev telephoned his congratulations. "Records are there to be broken," he said. "I'm very, very happy to know Courtney has done it because it's not easy to play for as long as he has.

"When you break a record it's a time for celebration and I'm happy Courtney has done it in the country where he grew up."

Every one of the 71 times he ran up between his 434th and 435th wicket, the entire ground, and all of the West Indies, braced itself. "Mentally it's drained me," he said after leading his team-mates off to a standing ovation. "When the wickets started tumbling it got a bit dicey and I wondered would I get it. So when the skipper asked me whether I was ready to bowl I said: 'Great'. "I was already heading in his direction; I wanted to hint to him that if he needed me to bowl I was ready. In the end I was just happy to get the wicket." Dev telephoned his congratulations. "Records are there to be broken," he said. "I'm very, very happy to know Courtney has done it because it's not easy to play for as long as he has. "When you break a record it's a time for celebration and I'm happy Courtney has done it in the country where he grew up."
