webTitle: Walsh bowls to top of the world

fields.headline: Walsh bowls to top of the world
fields.standfirst: The West Indian fast bowler sets new record with his 435th wicket
fields.trailText: Courtney Walsh became the most prolific wicket-taker in Test history yesterday. The 37-year-old West Indian fast bowler had Zimbabwe's Henry Olonga caught at forward short leg by Wavell Hinds to overhaul Kapil Dev's record of 434 wickets.
fields.body:
Courtney Walsh became the most prolific wicket-taker in Test history yesterday. The 37-year-old West Indian fast bowler had Zimbabwe's Henry Olonga caught at forward short leg by Wavell Hinds to overhaul Kapil Dev's record of 434 wickets.

When Walsh had Ian Healy lbw in Port of Spain last year to claim his 400th wicket, it is said he received a fax from Sir Richard Hadlee welcoming him to an exclusive club of three and hoping that he would go on to become its president. Now a year on, and in his home town of Kingston too, he has his 435th wicket.

This has been reward not only for the skill of a great fast bowler but for stamina, longevity, durability, loyalty and honest uncomplaining endeavour.

Now a man whose very existence has been to bowl - and then when he is spent, to go ahead and bowl some more - sits at the very pinnacle of the game. It has taken him the best part of 16 years to get there, and it came from less than auspicious beginnings.

Walsh made his Test debut in November of 1984 against Australia on the turbo pitch at Perth, and in the first innings watched enthralled as Michael Holding, Malcolm Marshall and Joel Garner blew the opposition away for 76. He did not even get a bowl.

In the second innings he took two wickets, the first of them Graeme Wood. It has been a long haul since.

His career has seen the transformation of a workhorse into a thoroughbred, for in its first phase he operated in the shadow of fast-bowling giants such as Holding, Marshall, Garner, Ambrose, Bishop and Patterson. By the time he had chipped away and reached 200 wickets he had scarcely had sight of a new ball, nor bowled an over with the breeze on his back. He did the dirty work, into the wind, old ball, giving the main men their respite (although never the batsman).

In his formative years he used pace and pace alone, urged on by a desire to gain the respect of his peers and as acknowledgement of his heritage; at times he could be devastatingly fast. Later, though, as his head became wiser and support around him less threatening, he began to realise the value of energy-conservation, of the variety that could be brought to his bowling by throttling back, banging up a gear when it was needed, developing an armoury of slower balls and often, as in the memorable Port of Spain Test against Zimbabwe, of simply digging in, giving nothing away and letting the pressure do its work.

He could be chivalrous - he was once awarded a special prize in a World Cup match in Pakistan for not running out a batsman who was backing up too far when the game was on a knife edge - but always retained if not a malicious streak then the hard, uncompromising and occasionally cynical attitude necessary for the fast man to succeed.

Mike Atherton speaks of Walsh's spell in Kingston in 1994 as the most intense he has faced, along with Allan Donald's bowling at Trent Bridge two years ago. The assault on Devon Malcolm, a hapless batsman in anyone's book, in that same match at Sabina Park demonstrated that even the best and most respected can resort to methods beyond the pale.

The record has tantalised Walsh for some years now, but it had become a race against time. How long would the legs or the willpower sustain him?

His devotion to the cause has always been unswerving, even in the dark days when island politics and the overwhelming ambition of Brian Lara saw him jettisoned as captain. Even that appointment, it seemed, had been the equivalent of uphill into the wind.

His response to his disappointment was dignified and conciliatory. Walsh had it within his power to inflame a difficult situation and instead was a calming influence.

He might have retired after that Australian series had he not taken 26 wickets in four matches. It persuaded him to continue, through New Zealand, where in another Caribbean debacle he managed only three wickets in as many Tests, and on into this series.

And now he has achieved his ambition he can rest easy. Someone soon - Shane Warne probably, or his closest rival Wasim Akram - will pass it during the next two years, but that is the nature of records. For now, though, a proud West Indian is top of the tree.

fields.headline: Fanny's novel predicament
fields.standfirst: With its raunchy sex and funky attitude, the new film of Mansfield Park may get good audiences, but it could prove disastrous for Eng Lit students.  John Mullan discusses the dangers of adaptation
fields.trailText: With its raunchy sex and funky attitude, the new film of Mansfield Park may get good audiences, but it could prove disastrous for Eng Lit students. John Mullan discusses the dangers of adaptation
fields.body:
We all recognise the predicament of George (the plump, bespectacled one) in a recent episode of Seinfeld. He joins a book club to meet women, and finds that the work being mulled over is Truman Capote's satirical novella Breakfast at Tiffany's. Disastrously, his contributions to the earnest discussion are based not on the book, which he has not read, but on the bowdlerised Blake Edwards 1961 film version. We watch his literary credentials disappearing as he recalls shots instead of descriptions, and keeps referring to the leading characters as George Peppard and Audrey Hepburn.

He would have been even more at sea with the latest film version of Jane Austen's Mansfield Park. This perennial A-level set book is marketed as "the steamiest Jane Austen adaptation to date". Colin Firth's notorious appearance in clinging wet clothes in the BBC's Pride and Prejudice is modest in comparison. All those students over the years who have fretted at the unalloyed virtue and pained silence of Fanny Price, anti-heroic heroine of Mansfield Park, will have their problems solved. Now she throbs and heaves with the best of them.

As seen by the film's writer and director Patricia Rozema, Fanny Price is no longer the frail girl reduced to a swoon by cutting roses on a warm afternoon, let alone the good Christian reading improving literature in her attic room. "I am a wild beast!" declares this updated Fanny, swishing her riding crop.

She has been given cutting lines from Austen's letters and (dangerously for students) from elsewhere in Austen's fiction. She has, according to her beloved cousin Edmund, a "tongue sharper than a guillotine". "Fanny, you are awful!" he exclaims in amazement at one of her putdowns. Will younger filmgoers recognise the line as more Dick Emery than Jane Austen?

A-level examiners should brace themselves. Perhaps only the worst blunderer will imagine that Austen's Fanny Price did actually find Henry Crawford and Maria Bertram in energetic flagrante in one of the spare rooms. Or that she ever purged her passions by rapturously riding a stallion out into the storm-tossed night. (Characters who go out in the rain in Austen novels usually suffer for it.) Or that she ever enjoyed a giggly kiss with Crawford on the Cobb at Lyme Regis (isn't that in Persuasion?). Yet maybe one should not underestimate the impact that such reinterpretation can have, especially once it is available on video.

Those shapers of the literary canon who decree A-level syllabuses know this well. It is not merely a testimony to his literary skills that Alan Bennett's Talking Heads has been prescribed by every examining board over the last decade. The book and the video are entirely interchangeable, so it is perfect for the less bookish pupil.

In candid moments, English teachers will confess that essays on A Room with a View are often recollections of the Merchant/Ivory 1985 film. A head of English in a large London comprehensive told me that she had hidden the tape of (ex-teacher) Baz Luhrmann's 1996 version of Romeo and Juliet after frequent coursework comments about Shakespeare's depiction of Benvolio, in an Hawaian shirt, trying to stop the gunfight between Romeo and Tybalt, or of the playwright's brilliant idea of showing the lovers' first meeting through a fishtank.

I remember sensing the under swell of adaptation dependence when Samuel Richardson's wonderful but huge novel Clarissa was turned into a television series in 1991. For some years, the tacit contract between students and examiners had been that the few undergraduates sedulous enough to read the book deserved top marks for diligence.

Then suddenly there was a blossoming of exam essays on Clarissa. Perhaps the BBC was succeeding in a Reithian mission to introduce new readers to great literature. Except that the adapters, desperately condensing the novel, changed the identity of the man who kills the libertine villain, Lovelace, in a final duel - and there was a marked tendency for examinees to make exactly the same alteration.

In my class recently, students discussed the importance of reading aloud in Austen's Sense and Sensibility, the novel's Marianne Dashwood being convinced that true sensibility is exhibited in sensitive response to poetry. An undergraduate commented shrewdly on Marianne's tremulous recitation of the Shakespeare sonnet, "Let me not to the marriage of true minds/Admit impediments..." - so appropriate to her tearful predicament on being abandoned by her caddish lover Willoughby. "Love is not love/Which alters when it alteration finds..." Fellow members of the class nodded sagely. Until a small voice enquired, was this version not more Kate Winslet than Jane Austen?

The better the film the longer the distortion lasts. In 1969, Ken Russell transposed Women in Love from the aftermath of the Boer War to the 1920s so that he could flaunt readily available vintage cars and costumes. And there it now stays in the minds of generations of students. One hopes that the grim but lame new opening episode that Alan Bleasdale recently invented for his televised Oliver Twist will not have confused examinees.

So far I have found students of Gulliver's Travels undeceived by the BBC version, at the end of which Ted Danson as Gulliver hugs real-life wife Mary Steenburgen as the camera soars over the white cliffs of Dover. In Swift's book the protagonist actually ends up living in a stable with herbs rammed up his nostrils to keep out the stench of his family. Riskier are more attentive adaptations such as the recent BBC Great Expectations, wooing us at first with its closeness to the novel, yet willing completely to change the novel's ending. How many viewers noticed?

In remaking the classics, film-makers and literary critics are often in cahoots. The film of Mansfield Park is full of references to slavery. Fanny Price even discovers a sketchbook of the horrors perpetrated by Sir Thomas Bertram on the slaves who work his Antiguan plantations. These clearly echo the ways in which the novel has been "reinterpreted" by critical postcolonialist academics such as Edward Said.

And Patricia Rozema has said that her reborn Fanny was influenced by feminist academics writing on Austen. It is a nice irony that academics, ingeniously finding their own political agendas in the novel, have inspired a film that is so different from the book their students are supposed to read.

 John Mullan is a senior lecturer in English at University College London. Mansfield Park is released on Friday.

webTitle: Boy hero takes first step into manhood

fields.headline: Boy hero takes first step into manhood
fields.trailText: Harry Potter will begin to show an interest in the opposite sex in his next book to be published on July 8, his creator revealed yesterday
fields.body:
In real life it was inevitable, but in the magical world of Harry Potter teenage sex had, frankly, no place.

The boy wizard, who has captured the imagination of tens of millions of children and adults worldwide, was far too preoccupied with flying his broomstick, tending his owl, and fighting evil to be bothered by anything as normal as sexual stirrings.

Besides, in JK Rowling's first two books about her eponymous hero he was not even 13. But now the floppy-haired little boy with the round rimmed glasses and exceptional powers has been struck by something as dramatic as the spell which caused the scar on his forehead: puberty.

Harry will begin to show an interest in the opposite sex in his next book to be published on July 8, his creator revealed yesterday.

"Last time you met him he was 13. He's 14 now and he's started to realise girls are quite interesting," divulged Ms Rowling, aged 34, who recently won the Whitbread Children's Book of the Year award for her third Potter story, Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban.

But she denied this would deter readers. "I tend to think that if someone is sufficiently engaged in one of his books, he's not going to be too disappointed if, at some point, his hero holds hands with a little girl."

Along with the delights of stolen kisses, Harry will also have to face a more painful aspect of real life. "I've said all along there will be death. And yes, you see a death in book four," said Ms Rowling.

fields.headline: The reasons why
fields.trailText: Emmanuel Petit may not own football's most famous pony-tail for much longer. Last week, it was announced that women's football is to turn professional. The FA are to set up a women's league of pros, which will be fully functioning within three years, and they will support it with advertising campaigns and TV deals. Broadcasters won't get men's games if they don't take women's ones.
fields.body:
Emmanuel Petit may not own football's most famous pony-tail for much longer. Last week, it was announced that women's football is to turn professional. The FA are to set up a women's league of pros, which will be fully functioning within three years, and they will support it with advertising campaigns and TV deals. Broadcasters won't get men's games if they don't take women's ones.

This is a fantastic breakthrough for a game which, in the past, has been accused of more misogyny than Euripides. The question is: will cricket follow? Recent history would suggest it will. Where football treads today cricket usually scurries along afterwards, late and rather grubby. But at the moment not even the players seem convinced that their future is a paid one - Debbie Hockley and Claire Taylor have both told WCM that they cannot foresee a professional future for the women's game.

The main problem for women's cricket (and to a lesser extent women's football) is that the majority of the population are completely uninterested. Very few people could even be bothered to summon up a yawn. A rough and extremely ready survey of WCM's editorial staff reveals that (shamefully) only two of us have ever been to a women's international match, one might have been but can't remember, and the rest have watched a few overs on telly. Considering our line of work, this isn't the greatest ratio of all time.

So why the reluctance? These were the excuses that came out:

1) "England always lose"
Ah. That old chestnut. Last year's miserable crowds for the New Zealand Test series showed that even the English, yes the Eddie-the-Eagle-loving English, eventually grow sick of defeat. England's women are yet to build up a following to lose, and they're not likely to when they notch up defeat after defeat.

2) "I don't know many of the players"
Recognition will come with success (see above) and a higher media profile. To be fair, England's women don't do badly publicity-wise, at least compared to ten years ago. Some of England's domestic internationals are shown on Sky Sports - but don't get too excited, so is lorry racing. They get coverage in newspapers too - Lucy Pearson had a column in the Independent during England's disastrous antipodean tour. However you get the feeling this is done rather grudgingly - national sports editors (every one of them male) would rather run yet another football - or hairdressing - report.

3) "Slow scoring rates"
Five years ago Mats Wilander said that female tennis players were fat and lazy. Today women's tennis matches men's, set for set, on the exciteometer. Increased speed and fitness (which comes from a more professional set-up and increased funding) will improve the way the women's cricket is played; in Australia it already has.

4) "Dull atmosphere"
If you ain't got no crowd, you don't get no atmosphere. But dull is not the same as different. Different means friendly, cheerful, relaxed and devoid of racist and sexist chants. And a largely female crowd doesn't result in a cucumber sandwich atmosphere. Just ask a player from the 1996 Women's World Cup Final - or a Chippendale.

Women's cricket isn't very cool. Not because female cricketers aren't but because cricket isn't. This can change. At the moment cricket in Australia is sexy; cricket in England, despite the Hollioakemania of 1997, is not. But 15 years ago, this position was reversed, just replace Warne with Botham - sexy buggers both, not because of their blonde manes but because they are electric, colossal, winners.

To draw a crowd and make professional cricket for women anything more than a pipe-dream, England need to win. And they need a hero. Laura Harper, your chance is now.

Tanya Aldred is assistant editor of Wisden Cricket Monthly

fields.headline: Tony Blair's Britain speech
fields.trailText: My argument today is this.
fields.body:
My argument today is this.

 Britain is stronger together, than separated apart.

 True Britishness lies in our values not unchanging institutions.

 The Constitutional changes we have made and a new attitude of engagement with Europe are not a threat to British identity but on the contrary are the means of strengthening it for today's world.

My manifesto for the leadership of the Labour Party in 1994 was called change and national renewal. A lot has changed since then. But those words remain central to my vision of what politics in this country must be about.

We have to recognise the huge changes we are living through and the challenges they present to this country. But also the opportunities for renewal that they offer.

Standing up for our country means standing up for what we believe in. It means standing up for our values and having the strength to realise them in the modern world. It means standing up for the core British values of fair play, creativity, tolerance and an outward-looking approach to the world. It does not mean an unthinking resistance to change. It does not mean railing against the outside world.

Modernisation is the key. It has driven everything this government has done - whether in our constitutional reforms or our reforms of the health service or the education system or the system of criminal justice or our relations with Europe.

To fail to modernise would be fundamentally to fail Britain. But we modernise according to our core values as a country. And we do so on the basis of one key belief. That the United Kingdom is stronger together than apart; all the constituent elements of the Union: its great cities, regions and nations are stronger united than separate, stronger together than the sum of their parts.

Our national identity is not some remote and abstract issue.

National success is not a matter of pushing buttons and pulling levers. Long-term growth and prosperity and stability depend on a clear sense of shared objectives and shared responsibilities.

Our failure in the post-war period to generate a clear sense of national purpose has hindered us.

It left space for a culture to develop in which sectional social and economic interests have fought to secure rights for themselves without a corresponding sense of their obligations to work for the wider public interest as well.

Indeed, I believe that the origins of one of the greatest failings of the economy in the post-war period - short-termism - can be located in our lack of a clear national purpose.

Throughout the post-war period, in the absence of a shared long-term vision of where we were going, successive governments often succumbed to the temptations of boom-and-bust, successive generations of managers often focused on their own pay awards instead of the long-term performance of their companies and successive generations of workers often sought pay increases unjustified by productivity increases.

We are living through a period of unprecedented change. The exponential growth of information and communication technologies is transforming the world's economies and making them increasingly interdependent. The breakup of the postwar international order and globalisation are calling into question systems constructed around the nation state. New ideologies of personal liberation and opportunities for self-fulfillment, made possible by social and economic change, are transforming traditional social structures and turning some inwards to themselves rather than looking outward to the nation and the state.

In this new world, it has become increasingly fashionable to predict the death of the nation-state. A world in which capital crosses national frontiers at the push of a key, where air travel has made the outside world personally familiar to millions, where television has brought it into the homes of millions more, a world where supra-national organisations like the EU and WTO play an increasingly important role is a world where questions are inevitably going to arise about the continuing significance of national identity.

What is the answer to such a challenge? Not to retreat into the past or cling to the status quo, even if it cannot sensibly be justified; but to rediscover from first principles what it is that makes us British and to develop that identity in a way in tune with the modern world.

What makes Britain and Britishness important, valid, as necessary today as ever is a powerful combination of shared values and mutual self-interest. We are stronger together, economically and politically with the nations of the UK able to maximise their collective will and authority. In defence, foreign policy, economic weight, we are better off and stronger together.

But, more important, our identity is not threatened by change. Our identity lies in our shared values not in unchanging institutions.

It is when our values fail to be reflected in the institutions that govern us that Britain and British identity is under threat. When we came to office, the Party of no change - the Conservatives - were left without any seats in Scotland or Wales. Forces for change were left with no alternative but status quo or separatism. Devolution at long last offered a sensible modernisation of the partnership in the UK. Let Scotland and Wales do what they do best locally. Let the UK do what it is right to do together.

The Conservative Party, in the Tory policy document on five guarantees for Britain, proposes "English votes for English laws". While rejecting a proposal to set up a wholly separate English parliament and now today re-affirming that they support devolution, they propose to exclude the Scots, Welsh and Irish from any discussion of laws defined as "English". The rest of Britain's MPs would, in effect, become second class citizens in the UK Parliament - voting on some issues but not on all of them - and the make-up of the executive would have to reflect the possibility of defeat on English issues even if a majority was available for British issues.

But what their proposal reflects is a complete misunderstanding of reality.

The measures needed to protect a minority are not always the same as the measures needed to protect a majority. England can if it chooses outvote Scotland, Ireland and Wales at any point. English MPs are in an overwhelming majority in voting through the money for Wales and Scotland. It is the recognition of this that makes devolution a fairer settlement for the future.

The growing pressure for regional change in England - decentralisation in London, the first steps to better local government in our cities - are a logical consequence of the policy of modernisation.

In Northern Ireland - if, as I do, we value the Union - we had to make progress on fairness and a recognition of nationalist aspirations. What we then are left with is an identity not shaped by institutional rigidity, but by values and common purpose. That purpose is a Britain that is stronger, fairer, modernised to be fit for the new world we live in. That is a constant recurrent theme in all the Government does: modernisation based on values. The NHS is not just a necessary part of a civilised society where need not wealth should determine health care. It is a unifying force. It is a true British service. It represents the best of British values in action. But it has to be updated and reformed to take account of the new opportunities and challenges of today.

On Europe, standing up for Britain does not mean being anti-Europe. It is not pro-British to be anti-Europe. The EU is part of the modern world. Britain is part of the EU. Standing up for Britain means fighting for British values, getting the best for Britain, whether it is economic reform, moving Europe closer to the USA or protecting the British rebate.

Likewise, at a time when individuals have been becoming increasingly empowered in their personal lives and increasingly aspire - and rightly so - to the prerogatives of citizenship, how could a healthy body politic defend the political privileges of hereditary peers and deny the right to freedom of information and to the protection in British courts of the European Convention on Human Rights ?

I believe few would disagree with the qualities that go towards that British identity: qualities of creativity built on tolerance, openness and adaptability, work and self-improvement, strong communities and families and fair play, rights and responsibilities and an outward looking approach to the world that all flow from our unique island geography and history.

If these values are what makes us British, rather than unchanging institutions, the devolution is a necessary part of keeping Britain together; more regional decentralisation in England makes sense, City mayors with real power have their place; hereditary peers in the House of Lords don't; and a constructive engaged attitude to Europe reflects the best of British values of openness and leadership in the world.

Of course, there will always be those who argue the consequences of change will always be worse than the consequences of sustaining the status quo.

But, I think this is as much a cast of mind as a political analysis. And this criticism usually falls into one of two broad categories - both of which play essentially on atavistic fears of the future.

The first category of criticism is a traditional Tory one - based on the claim that the pre-devolution, pre-reformed House of Lords, political institutions have been a uniquely important part of British national identity. Changing them, in this view, destroys something quintessentially 'British'.

Of course they have been historically significant, but they have never been anything more than a reflection of the needs of the British people at any one time. They are not eternal expressions of the British character. To change them does not mean that something quintessentially British has been destroyed, that a part of 'Britain has gone.

On the contrary, it is quintessentially British, it is one of our distinguishing characteristics as a people, that we have always been willing to adapt our institutions to changing circumstances. In the 19th century, in response to tumultuous economic and social change, we reformed the suffrage not once but three times.

This first critique amounts to little more than sentimental nostalgia.

The second critique is more argued: that somehow a process has been unshackled which will not run its course until the Union has disintegrated - that the institutional recognition of complex and enriching plural allegiances will somehow lead - inevitably - to their replacement with simpler and more excluding identities.

And, of course, there are those, like the SNP, who argue that this would be positively desirable and that the Union has had its day and the sooner it is unravelled, the better.

Of course, the great currents in our national life which have produced the climate in which such radical constitutional reform became necessary and was implemented will not suddenly cease. Of course they will continue to flow.

But this does not dictate a retreat from an inclusive British identity to more exclusive identities, rooted in 19th century conceptions of territory and blood? It is actually just not possible to construct any practical and meaningful national identity on such a basis. Why should we want to?

20 per cent of the population of Wales was born in England 7 per cent of the population of Scotland was born in England

745,000 people born in Scotland live in England: equivalent to 15% of the Scottish population.

Why should anyone want to say to all these people that they should suddenly become foreigners in the land they live in ?

This nation has been formed by a particularly rich complex of experiences: successive waves of invasion and immigration and trading partnerships, a potent mix of cultures and traditions which have flowed together to make us what we are today.

Blood alone does not define our national identity. How can we separate out the Celtic, the Roman, the Saxon, the Norman, the Huguenot, the Jewish,- the Asian and the Caribbean and all the other nations that have come and settled here ? Why should we want to ? It is precisely this rich mix that has made all of us what we are today.

Both current critiques of our constitutional reforms, I believe, are rooted in a fundamental misunderstanding of the relationship between a democratic people and the institutions they consent to have rule over them. New institutions do not necessarily create new feelings. They can just give longheld feelings new - and often better - expression.

'This government's progressive programme of constitutional reform is now moving us from a centralised Britain, where power flowed top-down, to a devolved and plural state. A new Britain is emerging with a revitalised conception of citizenship, as the House of Lords finally is reformed to remove the democratic anomaly of the hereditary peers, as the European Convention of Human Rights is incorporated into British law and as we bring in, for the first time, rights to Freedom of Information.

This is a complex journey towards a revived sense of ourselves, applying to modern life historic British values and qualities.

I entered politics to fight for the changes I believe are necessary to modernise this country. I believe in the importance of preserving our British identity and I will fight to strengthen the Union. I will fight against all those who would weaken the Union, whether those forces of conservatism who oppose change on principle or those separatist nationalists who wish to see Britain die.'

Our vision is of a Britain that thrives on optimism, on shaping its own destiny not cowering before the might of the global economy.

For us Britain succeeds when we ally our courage to our imagination. The courage that won wars. The imagination that built the NHS.

Ours is a vision of Britain where pride comes from a strong economy that can compete in the world, and rising living standards that benefits all.

A Britain where pride comes from a modern constitution that strengthens the nations of the United Kingdom.

Where pride comes from strengthening British values - creativity helping us build a knowledge economy, fairness guiding our fight against child poverty, reward for hard work helping us return to full employment, rights matched by responsibilities guiding us in the fight against crime and the reform of welfare.

Ours is an outward looking vision that believes in Britain's place in Europe, but believes Britain will always be much more than that. A "pivotal" nation - a bridge between East and West between the United States and the EU.

In this new world, a new modern patriotism is needed. That is what we offer.

See Britain as it is seen from abroad today. An economy gaining in strength. A society seeking to combine enterprise with investment in public services that bind the nation together. A politics that from relations within the UK, to pursuing peace in Northern Ireland, to engaging with Europe, is prepared to change to overcome the problems of the past and rise to the challenges of a changing world.

We can have confidence in our future. Britain is no longer in decline. We are rediscovering our strength and values. We are uniting those values to a common purpose: modernising the nation for the 21st Century. If we succeed, Britain will be stronger and fairer, on the road to providing opportunity and security for all.

webTitle: 'Renaissance geezer' Ian Dury dies of cancer aged 57

fields.headline: 'Renaissance geezer' Ian Dury dies of cancer aged 57
fields.standfirst: Obituary
fields.trailText: Ian Dury, the artist, musician and "renaissance geezer" who defiantly called himself Britain's most famous "raspberry ripple", has lost his long fight with cancer.
fields.body:
Ian Dury, the artist, musician and "renaissance geezer" who defiantly called himself Britain's most famous "raspberry ripple", has lost his long fight with cancer.

Dury, 57, who played his final sell-out gig at the London Palladium last month attached to a drip, overcame childhood polio to become one of the most charismatic and long-lasting stars of the punk era.

With such cleverly subversive songs as Billericay Dickie and Clever Trevor, which gloried in the rhyming slang of London's East End, he became a kind of cockney Kurt Weill.

Never one to be constrained by others' squeamishness, he wrote Spasticus Autisticus to mark the 1981 year of the disabled. The BBC banned it from the airwaves. Even so, with lines like "I dribble when I nibble" he became a hero to activists rebelling against a society which would have preferred people with disabilities to be meek and grateful.

But his socialism and gravelly music hall banter never sat comfortably with pop stardom. Despite huge hits with Hit Me with Your Rhythm Stick and Sex 'n' Drugs and Rock 'n' Roll with his band the Blockheads, the record deals began to dry up, and he returned to painting; he had once been an art lecturer.

After Roman Polanski cast him in his film Pirates, he turned to acting, also appearing in Peter Greenaway's The Cook, the Thief, His Wife and Her Lover before writing a musical for the Royal Court.

Fittingly for a man who had penned the rueful Reasons to Be Cheerful, Dury viewed his final illness as a chance to get the Blockheads back together.

"I feel very lucky, as if I've had a blessed life," he said last month. "I've had a major crack at it, which is more than most people get."

fields.headline: Want to work in films?
fields.standfirst: Then learn a trade, advises  John Crace
fields.trailText: Then learn a trade, advises John Crace
fields.body:
If the Baftas went missing in a skip then the chances are they would probably stay there. The British film industry is stuffed full of any number of wannabe actors, directors and producers, but can you get anyone to do the hard graft of building the sets? Can you heck. So finding the UK equivalent of Willie Fulgear, the man who last week rescued the Oscars from a Chicago dump, has to be completely out of the question.

The film world, it seems, is firmly divided between the artistic luvvies and their minions. And everyone wants to be a luvvy. "Film and media courses churn out students who are only interested in what they see as the glamorous jobs," says David Bill, who ran part of Shepperton Studios for 18 years, Ealing Studios for two and is now director of the Cheltenham Film Studios. "Most of them go on to get some third-rate job with MTV before becoming disillusioned and starting work for Habitat."

The Cheltenham Film Studios have only been up and running since last summer, but they have rapidly become the studios of first resort for those looking for easy access to locations in Wales and the Cotswolds without venturing too far from the metropolis. Two movies, Cider With Rosie and the Ghost of Greville Lodge, have already been made in Cheltenham, and a third, based on the Guy Fawkes story, is booked in for this summer. Numerous adverts have filled up the dead time between movies and by any measure the enterprise has to be considered a success. But it still can't get the standard of riggers, chippies and plasterers it needs.

"Stage plasterers have to be able to work at about three times the speed of an ordinary plasterer," says Bill. "They also need to be able to do more than merely cover a wall; they have to be able to mould cornices and sculpt busts." fields.headline: Quarrying
fields.trailText: Quarrying
fields.body:
Are you sure this is the right time?... For what?

For thinking about a quarrying career. Why shouldn't it be?

Well, there's this new aggregates tax which Gordon Brown's just brought in. Don't mention that name. Grrr! May he be hurled down the deepest pit and crushed!

Right ho. So what exactement is quarrying? It's extracting materials such as slate, sandstone, limestone, clay, gravel, granite and chalk from the ground. It's also producing materials such as coating stone and ready-mixed concrete needed for road building.

Sounds very messy. Well, possibly, but it doesn't hurt. Everyone - operative, craft, technician - gets a bit grimy. Even managers must get used to dust.

Everyone so to speak gets brown... I told you NOT to mention that word.

Sorry. Tell me about those managers. Apart from the typical managerial stuff - supervising works, planning, finance etc - they ensure that surface minerals are extracted safely and efficiently. Safety's vital. Managers make sure there's proper training for people on machinery. They also get involved in planning applications and liaising with the community over environmental issues.

Quarry management requires what qualities precisement. Managers must be prepared to work in all weathers and some aspects of the job can be physically demanding. Obviously they need a good understanding of legal requirements etc. Diplomacy and good communication and negotiation skills, are a definite advantage, too.

To keep the locals sweet. They can get a bit browned off... I've told you: don't say that word.

Tongue slipped. Sorry. Tell me about the folk at the face. Quarry workers process minerals extracted from open surface excavations and operate the machinery to crush and transport rocks and minerals. Because the materials produced by quarries are overwhelmingly supplied to the building industry, job opportunities may fluctuate in relation to the prosperity of the industry. Quarry workers do simple maintenance duties on machinery. People called shot firers organise blastings and load the necessary explosives, etc.

Wow! What a hoot. How do I grab some of that? Quarry workers must be physically fit. Quarries can be dicey, so common sense and reliability are important. Nearly all of the work is outdoors. It's noisy and dusty.

Entry requirements? Minimum entry age is 18. No formal qualifications are required. Training is mostly on the job, covering safety, plant operation and blasting techniques. The industry has a craft apprenticeship scheme and various NVQs apply, eg engineering maintenance. To move to technician level or above requires formal qualifications and Institute of Quarrying recognition. Some companies have their own progression schemes.

What about managers? You can get in with A levels or equivalents, and follow up with on the job training and study for pertinent further qualifications. Relevant degree courses include BEng (Hons) in Mine and Quarry Engineering and a BEng (Hons) in Quarry and Road Surface Engineering. Once hired, managers can get in-company training towards Membership of the Institute of Quarrying.

What colour's the tie? Brow... AAAaaargh Oh dear. I should have warned you that was a silly place to stand.

 EPIC Ltd(national training organisation for extractive and mineral processing industries) 36-38 London Road, St Albans, Hertfordshire, AL1 1NG Telephone 01727 869008

 Institute of Quarrying, 7 Regent Street, Nottingham NG1 5BY Tel. 0115 9411315

 learndirect (0800 100900) may be able to give further information and advice on courses.

fields.headline: Plumbing the depths
fields.standfirst: Michele Hanson charts one man's fruitless bid for betterment
fields.trailText: Michele Hanson charts one man's fruitless bid for betterment
fields.body:
My friend John has been a plumber for some years. He learned plumbing at a government training centre. But things have changed since then. Now you need a gas safety certificate to be a plumber, so John needed new qualifications.

Up in the north-east, where he lives, he searched for government training centres, hoping to find a refresher course. But the government doesn't have training centres anymore. There had been a management buy-out, plumbing training facilities had been sold off to a large building firm keen to get in on government training, which had then found it a bit of a burden, sold the whole lot and the training facilities were no more.

Of course John could have gone on an expensive Corgi training course, but Corgi keep changing their requirements and providing new courses, which he'd have to keep paying for if he wanted to hang on to his certificate, so, being 50 and still out of a job, he gave up on plumbing and decided to try teaching.

But 50 is apparently too old for teacher training, so he decided to take an NVQ course in management to enable him to teach adults. At least this course did exist and he had already done some of the relevant studying. Years ago he had taken the City and Guilds course in training adults, the predecessor of the course for which he was now applying.

And he had already been awarded an NVQ Level 4 in management so he knew all about taking NVQs, what the procedure was, how to compile a portfolio. John applied confidently for the new NVQ course. It was even at the same college at which he'd taken his first C&G and NVQ.

He had pleasant memories of his old C&G and NVQ courses. They seemed to make sense. They had a curriculum: how to produce teaching aids, theory of teaching, sociology. They had placements and projects.

But, again, things had changed. There were tons more pupils on the course and far fewer teachers. Tutorials and personal tutors no longer existed. John couldn't recognise the structure of the new NVQ and was baffled by the new language. Try as he might, he couldn't spot an overall strategy. There were simulations instead of proper placements, modules, outcomes and all the other new style vagaries that rather tend to increase the drop-out rate.

Originally there were three tutors on this course, but soon it was down to one, John asked the one harassed lady left what all the jargon meant, but for the life of her she couldn't explain it.

John is not a pillock. He has a degree in History and Philosophy, but he could hardly understand a word of the new NVQ speak. So in the end he gave it up as a bad job. He now cannot learn to be a proper plumber or a trainer. He remains disillusioned. The philosophy helps a little.

fields.headline: 'Real' employers
fields.standfirst: Gary Williams  says don't bother trying to get employers involved in post-16 education
fields.trailText: Gary Williams says don't bother trying to get employers involved in post-16 education
fields.body:
Once again I find myself wondering why so many people put so much effort and energy into insoluble problems.

The problem this time is that old chestnut about getting more employers involved in shaping the post-16 education system.

For me this is one that can't be solved so let's accept it and move on. I'm also minded to believe it probably isn't a problem either.

The event that triggered it was a DfEE roadshow in Bristol, reported in Guardian Further, which was designed to recruit employers to the local Learning & Skills Councils.

The first activity by principals at these events is to spot the REAL employer. There were 92 delegates on the list, but how many REAL employers? A definition might help.

First, rule out all public sector empoyers, and those who need to keep in with the public sector because the bulk of their business is in contracting with the public sector to deliver public services (eg TECs, Private training providers), and those who work for representative employer bodies (Chambers of Commerce etc), and those involved in delivering the event (eg Coca Cola).

So how many real employers were there? Did I hear you say none?! You've obviously been a principal too long and become a cynic!

And who said twenty? I hadn't realised we had such a novice on the patch still gullible enough to believe such unrealistic data! You deserve £500,000 from the Standards Fund to get your forecasting right!

The answer of course is 8, assuming they all turned up.

But why don't employers turn up to these events, and get involved? Well, a multiplicity of reasons. At least one delegate, like the majority of us not a REAL employer, felt that one of the barriers for very small employers - ie with one or just a few employees - wishing to get involved in their local Learning and Skills Council was lack of payment. More than 90% of employers in the Cornwall area fall in this category.

How, the panel from the DfEE was asked, will this majority of employers be engaged, and has paying them been considered. The answer was stunning: paying local Learning and Skills Council members had been rejected by a working group of employers - the so-called "Business Champions" group established to advise David Blunkett. Its leader, appointed by the secretary of state, is Nick Reilly, chairman and managing director of Vauxhall Motors Ltd and it includes top people from Coca Cola, the Post Office, Jaguar Cars and Unipart amongst others.

I rest my case! Where was the micro-employer's perspective in that decision? Their needs and issues are significantly different from large employers', as is their ability to commit resources.

Surely this is building discrimination against the micro-employer into the emerging structures which should be engaging them. Worse - these big businesses are not typical of the bulk of employers in most local Learning and Skills Councils areas.

Micro-employers will be major recipients of the post-16 system and all that it is directed, or required, or encouraged to produce.

It will be the local college principal and the local chief executive of the private training provider who will have to cope with the complaints from these employers that the national and local post-16 system isn't delivering the goods. We'll probably get blamed too!!

This is despite the fact that we only deliver the qualifications. The exam boards, advised by the employers, dictate what should be taught.

So it looks like nothing will change. The "problem" will still exist. We won't have solved it, but at least we'll be able to take comfort in the fact that we can carry on pouring scarce resources into trying to solve it! While the big employers make the problem worse.

 Gary Williams is principal of Weston College, Weston-super-Mare.

fields.headline: It's the teaching, stupid
fields.standfirst: Peter Kingston reveals what the new inspections will hold
fields.trailText: Peter Kingston reveals what the new inspections will hold
fields.body:
The new Ofsted-led regime of inspecting post-16 education will put a much greater stress on the quality of teaching and learning than at present, college principals have been warned.

More inspector hours will be focused on classroom activity than under the present system, which gives equal time to administration issues.

It also looks clear that the last batch of 25 colleges scheduled to be inspected under the existing Further Education Funding Council regime will now in fact be scrutinised under the new orders, which come into force in April 2001.

And it looks unlikely that colleges awarded "accredited" status by the funding council inspectorate will continue with their privileges of "lighter touch" inspections and greater independence from official scrutiny.

No final decision has been taken on whether accredited status will be recognised under the new Common Inspection Framework, currently being thrashed out by Ofsted, the funding council and the Training and Skills Council. But the view that it is fairer to scrap it totally rather than let only some institutions keep it seems to have wide currency.

Key details are still being worked out, Stephen Grix, newly appointed head of Ofsted's post-compulsory education division, stressed to a conference of college principals and senior managers.

The proposed inspection framework is due to be published "before Easter", together with a consultation document, he told the Association of College Management annual conference in Cardiff.

Some principals were clearly frustrated that it is still not fixed whether the new regime will carry out full inspections on first visits. Under the existing system only part of an institution's provision was scrutinised during the first four-year cycle of inspections, from 1993 to 1997.

"In the new model you're going to see much more about teaching and learning and about what is being called the effectiveness of teaching and management," said Grix, currently principal of Sir George Monoux sixth-form college, Walthamstow, who doesn't start his new job until May 2.

The five separate strands of administration known as "cross-college provision" - support for students, general resources, quality assurance, governance, and management - will be boiled down to one: organisational effectiveness and efficiency.

This is expected to free up many more inspector-hours for sitting in on lectures. Current inspections typically look at just four curriculum areas. That number could double.

Self-assessment by institutions of their provision, a central plank of the present inspection regime, looks likely to survive. And colleges are likely to be able to continue to nominate a member of staff to join the inspection team. But as Ofsted head Chris Woodhead has already said, the nominee may not in future be admitted to all meetings of the inspectors as "this might inhibit free and frank discussion".

Schools inspection teams do not include a staff nominee.

"We are trying to have a model to make it easier to compare between school sixth forms and post-16 providers," said Grix.

Woodhead has also revealed that teachers will be told the grades inspectors award them.

Principals from the 25 colleges which now look certain to have their second-cycle inspections carried out under the new regime were anxious to know whether they would remain eligible for cash under the Standards Fund. Under the funding council inspections colleges which excelled or scored low four and five grades in curriculum areas received extra money from the fund. This also has not been decided yet.

fields.headline: Engine trouble
fields.standfirst: As BMW dumps Rover, is an outstanding training scheme also to be ditched?
fields.trailText: As BMW dumps Rover, is an outstanding training scheme also to be ditched?
fields.body:
BMW's decision to offload Rover has chucked a huge spanner into the works for one of Europe's most advanced and imaginative engineering training schemes.

Among the 20,000 anxious people linked to the seemingly doomed Rover plant at Longbridge, West Midlands, now awaiting news of their fate, are a group of "super" apprentices on the German parent company's extremely progressive European Engineering Development Scheme.

This gleaming, top-of-the-range training effort dazzled lifelong learning minister Malcolm Wicks when he visited BMW's Munich headquarters just a few months ago.

The scheme represents a significant change from any previous or existing engineering training in this country. A new generation of young people in both the UK and Germany is being taught to be at home working either abroad or over here.

In this country the apprentices divide their training between attending classes at Sutton Coldfield College, Birmingham, and working on BMW's production lines in either Germany or Austria.

Gaining enduring language and cultural skills - rather than merely learning the nuts and bolts of how to build secure cars - are the most important tools of the trade these trailblazing trainees get on the five-year course that starts before they leave school at age 16. The aim is for them to acquire a degree-level qualification or one even higher.

In a recent report, the Further Education Funding Council found that over 7% of all further education students are budding engineers attending courses put on by 365 of England's 423 colleges. Despite massive closures over the past 20 years, the engineering industry still employs some 1.7 million people. Engineering exports are presently worth a staggering £72 billion a year - precisely one third of the UK's annual total exports.

The European Engineering Development Scheme is a tiny component in this mighty engine of the economy. But it is a critically important one. Just 20 trainees are on it - half from the 1998 first year's intake and the rest from last year. But already these trailblazing engineers have demonstrated enough skill to be the envy of production line colleagues - and of bosses worried about their jobs.

John Berkeley is a Warwick University senior fellow, funded by Rover. He has been one of the instrumental figures behind this important gear change. Normally outspoken, he's now discreet as the uncertainty and false dawns pile up.

Yet he's able to refer to a recent survey of employers involved in modern apprenticeships. This discovered that over two-thirds thought all youngsters doing vocational education and training required a European dimension to their studies.

"If young people from the UK are to be ready to undertake an extended period of work overseas on anything like equal terms with their German or Austrian counterparts," he said, "they will not only need language instruction from the start of their training, but their learning must impact upon their engineering skills as well as their social and personal skills."

Berkeley points out the scheme is the result of eight years of Rover thinking on how to create a new approach to engineering education and training. "Dissatisfied with the practical competence of engineering graduates and convinced that 16-year-old school leavers were capable of achieving much more than they, or their schools, believed possible, the company set out to develop a seamless, post-14 process for young people to progress through apprenticeships to degree level and beyond."

But a disturbingly dark cloud now hovers over these intentions and best-laid plans.

Graham Jones, Sutton Coldfield College principal, says his and other colleges are used to coping with the fall-out of large redundancies flowing from sudden dips in the fortunes of the UK car manufacturing trade. With neighbouring colleges, he reckoned that he was once again, through nimble foresight and course planning, well positioned to help jobless workers get dirt back under their fingernails.

But elation is a staunch bedfellow of pessimism. "I don't want to look at the present situation regarding the future of the European training scheme as a terrible tragedy," he says.

"BMW's new £6 billion plant, down the road, at Hams Hall is offering major new employment and our role, as a local further education college, will be to help people who are leaving Longbridge and getting employment there. So it's not all gloom and doom."

Less than an hour later, Jones rings back. His mood has shifted. The first-year trainees have just been told their trip to Germany has been postponed. There was no sign of when, or if, it might be rescheduled. "Some of the early optimism seems to have evaporated," he laments. "There's now a fair amount of concern."

Besieged BMW spokesman in Munich, the aptly named Axel Obermuller, denied the European training initiative - widely acknowledged as centre-stage of car engineering training - would be put in reverse. His equally bullish BMW colleague, Christine Krepolv, claimed it would continue in training's outside lane. "Yes, Rover's sale will mean some casualties," she said. "But we're doing our best to ensure our new contract partners keep this outstandingly inventive scheme running."

Viewed from the hard shoulder, it remains to be seen whether BMW's expensive damage limitation exercise, in the shape of verbal and financial assurances - alongside the pledge by trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers, last week to inject £129m of government funding to pay towards the reskilling of Rover's workers - will be enough to keep the European car engineering training scheme on the road.

fields.headline: Dyslexia drive
fields.standfirst: Simon Midgley on a typing course taking the prison population by storm
fields.trailText: Simon Midgley on a typing course taking the prison population by storm
fields.body:
A pioneering literacy scheme for dyslexic prisoners is so successful that it is rapidly being taken up by British jails.

The Pentonville Prison Dyslexia Project, launched in September 1998, gives inmates a chance to take part in an innovative computer course specially designed to promote literacy. Touch-type Read and Spell is a highly structured course that incrementally reinforces reading, spelling and writing skills.

Studies suggest that almost a third of the prison population could be dyslexic. The HMP Pentonville project, managed by Amersham and Wycombe College, has been so successful that the prison's education manager, Jane Broadfoot, has won a national award from the Butler Trust, a charity that recognises excellence in the prison service, for her part in setting up the scheme. Similar pro jects are now in 10 other prisons

Initially there were fears that prisoners - often educational drop-outs with poor self-esteem - might not be willing to participate in the course. However early recruits were very enthusiastic and word of mouth commendation soon led to a waiting list.

A small storeroom at the prison has been renovated and painted bright yellow to create an airy classroom with British Dyslexia Association posters of famous dyslexic people - Einstein (no less), Eddie Izzard and Richard Rogers - on the walls.

Before being accepted, participants are screened for dyslexia. While the course is in progress tutors report a "buzz of engagement and energy" and having to "tear the men off the machines at the end of their sessions".

Prisoners spend three hours a week on the HMP Pentonville, British Dyslexia Association and National Year of Reading grant-funded modular course, which enables them to work at their own pace, repeating material as often as necessary.

And they can review their progress easily as they go along. One of the comments inmates make most often is that for the first time in their lives they feel in control of their own learning.

Of the 82 prisoners who enrolled on the scheme, two dropped out, 80 steadily improved and at least 15 made "phenomenal" progress. Twelve men have not yet completed the course, 20 men have used it as a springboard to full-time education in the prison and a further 15 have gone on to part-time education.

The prison's education staff, including Krysia Martin, dyslexia expert, and Jane Amphlett, the course facilitator, believe such progression would not have been possible without the self-esteem and literacy skills the programme has engendered.

"It's been so successful. The spotlight is on us," Jane Broadfoot said. "Voluntary organisations, drugs projects, other prisons, agencies for the homeless, you name it, have come from all over the country to see what we are doing."

For one inmate, Louis, an early drop-out from school, outstanding success on the scheme helped him to an early prison release. Another prisoner, Paul E, aged 25, who has spent eight months a year in institutions since he was 17 years old, said his most vivid memories of school were of his teacher screaming at him.

"I was only seven. Stuff was always wiped off the board before I'd had a chance to copy half of it down. Art was the only exam I passed, and I got kicked out of most lessons. By the end, drugs were just a way out."

Now Paul E says the course has helped him to understand how to spell and to write with confidence. "I'm sick of being inside, of not having a life. I want a new start, and think it is within my grasp now. I'm sure that if they'd known at school about my dyslexia, I wouldn't be in prison today."

 The British Dyslexia Association's helpline phone number is 0118-966 8271.

fields.headline: A flock of good ideas
fields.standfirst: When children bunked off school to help on their farms, Ysgol y Berwyn knew it was onto something
fields.trailText: When children bunked off school to help on their farms, Ysgol y Berwyn knew it was onto something
fields.body:
Perhaps if their children had had the good fortune to attend Ysgol y Berwyn School, the troubled Grundys of Radio 4's The Archers fame would not find themselves bankrupt and facing almost certain eviction from their farm.

Just like their farming counterparts in the radio programme, pupils studying for their NVQ in Agricultural Studies at this predominantly Welsh-speaking secondary school on the shoreline of Lake Bala will be busy in the weeks ahead with the task of caring for the lambs produced by the school's herd.

The busy Easter lambing period is just one in the calendar of events for aspiring farmers in years 10 and 11: sheep are reared and prepared for auction at local markets throughout the year; sheep are shorn, both mechanically and by hand, at a nearby farm involved in the course; and in the summer, the herd of black sheep are groomed ready for the country shows.

The majority of pupils at Ysgol y Berwyn come from a background steeped in agriculture. When the school realised that pupils were missing school due to commitments on their own farms, it sparked off the idea of harnessing the natural inclination of these youngsters to be involved in the rural employment of their community. And so, six years ago, the school introduced the NVQ in Agricultural Studies.

Whilst these courses are primarily aimed at those individuals who do not aspire to lofty academic achievement, there has been a positive effect on pupil motivation and interest in the more traditional curriculum, according to the headteacher, Geraint Owain. "The programme has improved the motivation, attendance and behaviour in general of many of the pupils at the school. The chance of doing the programme can act as a carrot for good work and attendance from pupils in year 9 who wish to opt for the NVQ. Numbers are limited. We even have pupils who say that they wanted to come to Berwyn simply because they want to do Agricultural Studies," Owain reports.

But it is not only the younger generation which is benefiting: the community at large, and parents in particular are also involved. The school became aware that poor administrative skills were resulting in local farmers not getting the grants they were entitled to. So a basic ICT evening adult education course is offered to the farming community in the area, and parents and pupils are also encouraged to attend a Welsh ICT course in farm administration. In addition, the school's agricultural department has been running a Sunday morning sheepdog-handling course for pupils and parents, with the latter acting as both learners and helpers.

This last strand of the programme culminated in the school planning and staging its own sheepdog trials, which last year attracted an entry of almost 70 handlers and dogs from across North Wales. Perhaps this success should come as no surprise, however, since Marialyn McNaught, one of the teachers involved in the Agricultural Studies course, has been a member of the Welsh team in the annual International Sheepdog Trials for the last two years.

fields.headline: Trouble at the top
fields.trailText: The chairman of the governors was extremely rude to parents. He shows no sign of stepping down. How can we get rid of him?
fields.body:
I recently attended my first parent/governor meeting. Quite frankly, the attitude of the chairman towards parents shocked me. He was extremely rude and made derogatory comments about parents who hadn't come. He shows no sign of stepping down. How can we get rid of him?

Christine Gale is chair of the National Governors' Council.

It is always very sad to hear of relations between parents and governors being less than happy.

The rationale behind the annual parents meeting is that this is the only mechanism for ensuring that the governing body, headteacher and local education authority are held directly to account by parents and governors. Some people would like to see this type of meeting abolished, partly because of its traditionally poor attendance. But I feel strongly that it is important for parent/ guardians and governors alike.

At its best, the annual parents meeting is an excellent way for parents and guardians to become more involved in their child's school and education. It is used to agree the annual report that governors are responsible for producing. This is essentially a plan for raising standards, improving behaviour and meeting the wider needs of pupils.

It allows parents and guardians to make their views known about these plans - to have a say about the targets set by the governor.

The main purpose of a school's governing body is to help raise the standards of achievement of pupils in the school. It could be that your chair is actually very good at and committed to this. Remember, all governors are volunteers and give up a considerable amount of time for that. Preparing the annual report and getting ready for the annual meeting is hard work, although in most cases few parents and guardians turn up. Perhaps the chair is just letting off steam about it.

Despite this, parents and guardians should have access to governing bodies, and expect their part to be taken seriously. If you feel the chair is failing here, you can take various steps.

It is good practice for every school and governing body to have a complaints procedure. Generally, the person to whom complaints should be made, in writing, is the clerk to the governors, who manages the business of the governing body, including all correspondence. He or she will then pass the matter to the appropriate committee.

Only the governing body itself can remove the chair, except in extenuating circumstances, when the Secretary of State may be asked to step in. Again, this procedure is clearly laid down. Some governing bodies elect the chair for a set period. But it is becoming increasingly difficult to find individuals prepared to take on this sometimes arduous role, so that many chairs are serving for longer than they - or others - might wish. Another way of directly removing the chair could be to discuss the issues with the school's parent governors.

Being a governor can be very rewarding. The role is often compared to that of a non-executive on a board: governors have plenty of influence over and responsibility for making important and wide-reaching decisions on how a school can provide the best possible education for its pupils.

If you feel your governors are failing here, why not stand for election as a parent-governor yourself! Governing bodies need - and welcome - people who contribute constructively. If you have attended the annual meeting and feel strongly enough about the chair's behaviour to have written in to this column, you would be an excellent candidate.

Christine Gale's tips: Continue to actively support the governing body and the school by going to events such as the annual meeting. Consider whether your concerns truly merit removing the chair or if there is an alternative. But if your mind is set, find out the procedure and address your complaint in writing to the clerk to the governors. And think about standing as a parent governor yourself.

Next week's query: I have just found out that our son has failed to get into the secondary school of our choice. Instead, he has been given a place at the local "sink" school. I am very angry about this, and would like to know what I can do about it.

fields.headline: Augenzeuge
fields.standfirst: Alexandra Meißner gives a teacher's view of a fly-on-the-wall series about ordinary people
fields.trailText: Alexandra Meißner gives a teacher's view of a fly-on-the-wall series about ordinary people
fields.body:
Am Tag nachdem die erste Sendung über den Bildschirm geflimmert war, war Big Brother dann das einzige Thema in meiner Klasse. Die meisten fanden es, glaube ich, ziemlich cool, daß ganz normale Menschen jetzt die Hauptdarsteller einer Fernseh-Sendung sind. Einige meiner Schüler haben sich auch Gedanken gemacht, ob sie selbst 100 Tage lang auf engstem Raum leben könnten.

Ich finde das ganze Trara ziemlich übertrieben. Der Produzent will ja beweisen, daß das Leben von Otto Normalverbraucher viel spannender ist, als das von Hauptdarstellern einer Fernseh-Serie oder eines Spielfilmes. Meiner Meinung nach ist ihm das nicht gelungen. Die Übertragungen aus dem Big-Brother-Haus sind stinklangweilig. Unterhaltungswert haben sie für mich nur, weil einige der Bewohner sich so blöd benehmen, daß ich mich jedesmal krank lachen könnte. Auch bei den Jugendlichen in meiner Klasse hat die Euphorie ziemlich schnell nachgelassen.

Die zehn Bewohner des Hauses nehmen es in Kauf, in jeder Situation von Kameras beobachtet zu werden. Sie alle sind Selbstdarsteller und ich glaube auch, daß viele Dialoge nur so geführt werden, weil sie von Kameras und Mikrofonen belauscht werden.

Big Brother verleitet Jugendliche außerdem dazu, ihrer voyeuristischen Ader völlig freien Lauf zu lassen. Ich für meinen Teil halte es aber für äußerst wichtig, daß es im Leben eines Menschen Privatsphäre gibt, die von den anderen akzeptiert wird. Und das sollten wir schon in jungen Jahren lernen.

fields.headline: Beating the bully
fields.standfirst: It causes misery, it wrecks lives, it can even lead to suicide.  Jerome Monahan  on the horror of bullying
fields.trailText: It causes misery, it wrecks lives, it can even lead to suicide. Jerome Monahan on the horror of bullying
fields.body:
Thousands of children in Britain are suffering the misery of being bullied. Between 1998 and 1999 the national charity Childline received 22,332 calls from children who were being picked on. Many put up with the torture, but some find it too awful to bear. Between 10 and 14 cases of childhood suicide occur every year as a direct result of bullying.

What is bullying?

Most bullying means repeated acts of intimidation. It is deliberately carried out. It happens when a person or a group tries to dominate others who they consider weaker. It always causes the victims pain. The charity Kidscape says bullying can be physical, verbal, emotional, racist or sexual.

Does it always include violence?

No. A recent survey of 2,300 six- to nine-year-olds found the most common bullying was name-calling.

Who are the bullies?

Bullies are usually people with problems themselves. They may feel inadequate or scared and use bullying as a cover. The consequences for bullies who receive no help can be serious. According to research conducted by Professor Dan Olweus, children who bully are four times as likely to become young offenders with criminal records when they leave school. Over the past 15 years bullying by girls has increased. Many reasons for this have been suggested, including even the way some styles of behaviour are promoted by pop groups.

Who are the bullied?

Bullies are quick to spot characteristics that might mark someone as being different from the crowd. How the victim behaves is crucial. If the bully gets away with the first act, he or she is likely to continue.

Is being violent back the answer?

There is no guarantee that meeting violence with violence will solve anything. It may result in the victim being excluded from school or even seriously injured.

What are the first things that someone being bullied should do?

Tell an adult. No one deserves to be bullied and speaking about it should not make the situation worse. In a recent survey, seven out of eight victims of bullying felt that speaking out made things better.

What protection do pupils have a right to expect while at school?

Schools have a "duty of care" for pupils. This means they must do all they can to protect students from harm. Since September 1999, the law requires schools to draw up an anti-bullying policy.

What should schools do to solve the problem of bullying?

The best thing is to stop bullying before it starts. Pupils need to discuss the subject and know how to seek help. Young people need to be taught how to solve conflicts without being aggressive. In some schools students are trained to be "peer mediators" - stepping in to support fellow pupils in difficulties.

Is bullying against the law?

If a bully hurts someone physically, they are guilty of assault. The age at which a person in England is considered to be capable of responsibility for a criminal act has recently been reduced to 10. In Scotland, it is eight. There are also laws that protect people from harassment.

What are the most common false ideas about bullying?

"I was bullied at school and it didn't do me any harm." "You need to learn how to stand up for yourself." "Sticks and stones may break your bones but names can never hurt you."

Myths like these are unhelpful because they give some adults an excuse not to take the matter seriously and make victims feel that they should put up with bullying.

Why is bullying such a serious matter?

Anything that can cause young people to kill themselves must be taken seriously. For those who suffer in silence, the effects of bullying can affect the rest of their lives.

A survey by Kidscape in 1998 among 1,000 adults showed that many felt their school days had been stolen from them by bullies and that they had been haunted by feelings of anxiety and bitterness ever since. One 34-year-old woman told the researchers: "If I had enjoyed school I might have bloomed into a more confident person. It makes me feel I have wasted my life being too careful and nervous to succeed."

 Kidscape 0207 730 3300
 Childline 0800 1111
 Childline Scotland has a dedicated bullying line 0800 441111
 Anti-Bullying Campaign 0207 378 1446

 First Edition is a current affairs series for schools on C4 presented this week by Jon Snow and produced in association with Guardian Education. It is transmitted every Tuesday morning at 11am and repeated on Wednesday at 11am.
