fields.headline: Friend or foe
fields.standfirst: Girls' friendships can be fraught and fickle affairs.  Hilly Janes asks what parents and schools can do to help children forge healthy relationships
fields.trailText: Girls' friendships can be fraught and fickle affairs. Hilly Janes asks what parents and schools can do to help children forge healthy relationships
fields.body:
You got the IQ of a digeridoo

You look insane like you got no brain

You got a big fat belly like a bowl full of jelly

Your fat mum Milly looks like Free Willy

Ooh stick you

Your Mama too

And your Daddy

These lyrics are not the dernier cri in gangsta rap, but from the current chart hit, "Ooh stick you" by two 16-year-old girls from New Jersey, Daphne and Celeste, who take it in turns to chant insults at each other. If you find them worryingly "in your face", perhaps you should put it down to a sense of humour failure. But as every woman knows, female friendships are often no laughing matter.

Lily Fraser was in year 1 at her mixed north London primary school when she started coming home in a bad mood, saying she had had a horrible time. There would often be tears at bedtime. Lily had been in what her mother, Liz, thought was the enviable position of having three best friends. However, they made new best friends. Lily was bereft.

"By year 2 things got really difficult," Liz explains. "The pattern of one-to-one friendships Lily understood expanded to playing complicated role-play games. Lily would complain about the others not wanting to play her versions, and it was only after prompting that I realised how convoluted the protocol was," Liz says. "Someone would have ownership of the game and decide who was going to be what. To be elected as the big brother or the mother was grossly insulting. If Lily couldn't be what she wanted she'd get upset, but that got her nowhere. "

Liz realises with hindsight that the unhappy times in the playground may have lasted only a few minutes, but that they were what Lily remembered. Now she and her classmates are reaching the grand old age of seven, they are more relaxed and compromise more, although she can still come home upset.

"I think she has a really good network of friends, but she doesn't always see it like that. If she has a big falling out with one of them occasionally, she'll still say 'nobody at school likes me' or 'I've been left out'. You have to have quite roundabout conversations to find out that this means they are not playing the game the way she wants to. She is the oldest of two, and a lot of it is about accepting that things can't always go her way."

If the pressure of playground life in a mixed school seems intense, what happens when there are no boys to leaven the mix? Jenny Walwyn has three daughters, all at private, single-sex schools in London. Dora, her youngest, is in a class of only 18 girls who will stay together for seven years.

"Most of them seem to divide up into pairs, but during her first years there Dora didn't have a special friend and felt there was something wrong with her," Jenny recalls. "It's taken years but I've tried to persuade her that it is not necessary to have just one best friend. If there is a particular focus on one child and things get stormy, it affects everything else."

Jenny noticed that at her oldest girl's secondary school, staff went out of their way to encourage different groupings and avoid focusing on one friendship. "That made me feel confident to use this strategy with Dora," says Jenny. "She still forms close attachments and there are ups and downs, but the fact that she's able to focus on lots of different people has helped." Jenny also tries to ease the pressure by encouraging Dora to see different friends at weekends, particularly boys.

Child's play? Not at all, says Dr David Campbell, consultant clinical psychologist in the child and family department of the Tavistock Clinic in north London, who explains that children as young as seven are busy establishing their identity outside the family. "They are developing relationships that give them feedback about what kind of person they are - pretty, sporty, aggressive etc. It's a very important time from a psychological point of view. These experiences are so new to them that they need to establish patterns - what would it be like if I played dolls with this girl, or football with the other. As they get older, relationships become more routine and predictable.

"Psychological theories indicate that women are more likely to find their identity through relationships than boys, who define themselves more through activities," he adds. "At first, rejections are extremely painful for girls, so they can seem much more important than they really are." He points out that the oldest child may feel more threatened by relationships that go wrong. "If they lose a girlfriend at school, it reverberates with all their past experiences of losing out to siblings."

Dr Campbell suggests that parents try to promote the understanding that there are good times and bad times in the best of relationships, and that the downs are not always permanent. "So much of it has to do with family values," he says.

At West Kidlington Primary School in Oxfordshire, the mantra is "to find a friend you have to be one", and when the headteacher, Linda Rafferty, arrived in January she immediately felt the strength and quality of friendships right across the school. There is no differentiation made between genders, but as well as a school council, buddy system and Circle Time, there is a strong emphasis on the promotion of values.

Here Rafferty is carrying on the pioneering work of the former head, Neil Hawkes, now a special adviser for the county. "Over a two-year cycle we concentrate on 22 values, one for each month excluding August. In January and February it was respect and love, this month it's courage. They are talked about in assembly and during class reflection time and discussions as well as in written work. It all makes children more aware of how their own actions affect others, and helps to raise self-esteem," Rafferty explains.

Staff at the 470-pupil school, which is in a mixed catchment area, are carefully selected for their ability to work in a team with respect and humour, as a model for pupils. Dinner-hall and playground supervisors are included. This is, after all, where learning to be friends mainly goes on. "Inconsistency there means you could lose the whole thing completely," Rafferty admits. Parents are kept informed through newsletters informing them of the value of the month and so on, in the hope that they will support the ethos at home.

By year 6, girls will probably have settled into more consistent relationships, but the move to secondary school and increasing sexual awareness can change all that. Wendy Granditer, agony aunt for teenage magazine Sugar, gets hundreds of letters on the subject.

"Girls can be desperate to be in with the in-crowd," she says. "They'll ditch an old primary school mate for friends who they think will serve their image better. If one friend gets a nice boyfriend, the other can feel very lonely and excluded, and it can turn into a spiteful battle."

Granditer advises trying to get things in perspective. "t may just be a flash in the pan - you are enemies now but you'll be best friends again next week. It's about learning that good friends really appreciate each other, and how to patch things up. This is an important skill because it's about learning to negotiate and function in a relationship.

"Mothers should try to boost confidence," Granditer says. "Tell your daughter she's great, she's special, the girl she's fallen out with will probably feel sorry and it will all blow over the next day. Bitchy comments can't do you any real harm. It's about the other person, not yourself."

But supportive mother-teenage daughter relationships can be easier in theory than in practice. "Teenage girls are much more likely to speak to their friends than speak to you," says Isobel Bletcher, head of the behaviour support centre at Madras College, a 1,800-pupil mixed comprehensive in Fyfe.

Her view is based on extensive research, and her practice includes a peer counselling system. Older pupils volunteer to help younger ones with relationships with teachers and schoolmates, as well as with academic work. She currently has 121 sixth-year students on her scheme, as well as students from St Andrew's University. The scheme was inspired by the work of Andrew Bell, who founded the school in 1833, and his peer system of education in which older pupils taught younger ones.

"School is the only time in your life when you will find yourself in a room with 30 other people and be expected to get on with them just because they are the same age as you," Bletcher says. "Support from people of different ages can really help." Friendship skills groups are available to those with serious problems, based on the views of students. Older ones might also be encouraged to offer low-key support to a girl who has had a bust-up with her best friend, for example.

Bletcher believes that parents have had an enormous influence on the way their children interact with friends by adolescence. Her advice is: "Offer help and wait for the reaction. You can break down the door and say, tell me what's wrong, but that doesn't mean they are going to speak to you. Listen to what they are saying and not what you think they are saying because you think you know them so well. The chances are that by the time they are adolescent you don't know them as well as you thought you did."

Melanie and Paula, two 17-year-olds who are counsellors at Madras, agree that it is easier to talk to other girls. Melanie feels that encouraging them to form bigger groups of friends is important because it helps if you fall out with one of them. Paula points out that boys are more likely to make friends through sport. "Very intellectual girls often feel left out, too, because although they are more mature academically, their social skills haven't caught up," she says.

At the all-girls grammar school that Isobel Williams, 16, attends in the north-west of England, there is no special help beyond the usual personal and social development lessons. She agrees that being able to talk to someone nearer your own age is much easier. "You have to have a lot of confidence to talk to an adult you don't really know," she says.

Isobel is part of a group of about five close friends. "I never really fall out with any of them," she says. "Sometimes there's a bit of tension over pathetic things but it all blows over. It does get more complicated when boys come on the scene, but you work out who you can talk to about them and who you can't." Isobel rates respect and trust as essential qualities in a good friend and puts loudmouths at the top of her list of people to avoid.

Ooh stick you, Daphne and Celeste.

Cope with your mates

Sometimes your friend might seem to be ignoring you or have turned on you for no obvious reason. Feeling left out is horrible. What can you do in that situation?

 Don't keep it to yourself - tell your mum or another friend.

 If one particular person in the group is being unpleasant, why not talk to someone else in the group at another time, to try to find out what's going on?

 Try joking and staying (on the surface at least) cool about nasty remarks.

 Never put all your eggs in one basket. Make sure that you have other friends apart from that group. If they are acting like that, maybe they are not worth bothering with at the moment.

 Concentrate on filling your time with things you like to do.

 Suppose that it is someone else in your group getting the cold shoulder - what would you do to be a good friend to them?

fields.headline: Art and artists
fields.trailText: Art and artists
fields.body:
Gateway to Art History

****

Aimed at: everyone

An online encyclopaedia of art history, Gateway is rather like a discriminating Yahoo! directory. Choose a historical period or artistic movement and follow the links to online exhibitions elsewhere on the web. The site is maintained by a US art history professor and therefore links to journals and high-level resources too.

Art Studio Chalkboard
***

Aimed at: teachers

GCSE and A-level teachers should find the Chalkboard - which concentrates on technical skills and life drawing - a good resource to recommend to their students.

A Lifetime of Colour
***
Aimed at: everyone

Ignore the irritating presence of a fluorescent reptile named Carmine and use this site as a source of teaching ideas and, for parents, art games. Although it's tied to the US National Visual Arts Standards, it is useful for teaching practical techniques.

Art Subject Hub

*

Aimed at: teachers

The department of education is going to have to try much harder than this if they want to create a real hub for art teachers online. Two brave souls have left messages on the discussion boards, a single outside link is provided, and you can find the national curriculum requirements for art. A wasted opportunity.

Computer Art Museum
***
Aimed at: everyone

You probably won't have heard of Lichty, Mickelsen or Vysniauskas, but they may prove an unintimidating introduction to art for KS3 children who are indifferent to the established canon. Some of these pictures, all of which were created with the help of a computer, are reminiscent of Play Station landscapes or Cubist paintings; others develop patterns that have a mathematical element.

Great Buildings
***
Aimed at: everyone

Architecture is, of course, not a hands-on subject and it's frequently ignored in schools for that reason. But Great Buildings still deserves a mention, because it catalogues buildings from all over the world systematically, cross-referencing and sometimes providing digital 3D models. You can search by architect, place and the building's name, although the site is also fun to browse.

Crayola
****
Aimed at: everyone

Whatever your child has been doing with crayons - scribbling, eating them, or scrawling on the wall - he or she can't have tried all the activities here. While there are plenty of pictures to colour in and decorate, the card creator and learning activities are just as useful for KS1 teachers. Whines of "I don't know what to do..." can probably be silenced by the Inspring Ideas section.

The National Gallery
**
Aimed at: everyone

Not all the gallery's paintings are online, but those that are do have accompanying notes - something many galleries don't think necessary. Click on the images to enlarge them. Two possibilities spring to mind: you could use the site to prepare for a visit or choose a picture each week as a warm-up or filler activity in a lesson. The games section has an amusing activity in which you can mix and match the top and bottom halves of portraits.

Art Studio Chalkboard *** Aimed at: teachers GCSE and A-level teachers should find the Chalkboard - which concentrates on technical skills and life drawing - a good resource to recommend to their students. A Lifetime of Colour *** Aimed at: everyone Ignore the irritating presence of a fluorescent reptile named Carmine and use this site as a source of teaching ideas and, for parents, art games. Although it's tied to the US National Visual Arts Standards, it is useful for teaching practical techniques. Art Subject Hub * Aimed at: teachers The department of education is going to have to try much harder than this if they want to create a real hub for art teachers online. Two brave souls have left messages on the discussion boards, a single outside link is provided, and you can find the national curriculum requirements for art. A wasted opportunity. Computer Art Museum *** Aimed at: everyone You probably won't have heard of Lichty, Mickelsen or Vysniauskas, but they may prove an unintimidating introduction to art for KS3 children who are indifferent to the established canon. Some of these pictures, all of which were created with the help of a computer, are reminiscent of Play Station landscapes or Cubist paintings; others develop patterns that have a mathematical element. Great Buildings *** Aimed at: everyone Architecture is, of course, not a hands-on subject and it's frequently ignored in schools for that reason. But Great Buildings still deserves a mention, because it catalogues buildings from all over the world systematically, cross-referencing and sometimes providing digital 3D models. You can search by architect, place and the building's name, although the site is also fun to browse. Crayola **** Aimed at: everyone Whatever your child has been doing with crayons - scribbling, eating them, or scrawling on the wall - he or she can't have tried all the activities here. While there are plenty of pictures to colour in and decorate, the card creator and learning activities are just as useful for KS1 teachers. Whines of "I don't know what to do..." can probably be silenced by the Inspring Ideas section. The National Gallery ** Aimed at: everyone Not all the gallery's paintings are online, but those that are do have accompanying notes - something many galleries don't think necessary. Click on the images to enlarge them. Two possibilities spring to mind: you could use the site to prepare for a visit or choose a picture each week as a warm-up or filler activity in a lesson. fields.headline: Spend on a budget
fields.standfirst: How will schools use their windfall from the chancellor?
fields.trailText: How will schools use their windfall from the chancellor?
fields.body:
Last week's budget announcement of £1bn for education included the welcome news of cash that will bypass local education authorities and head straight for schools' bank accounts in the forthcoming financial year.

The total pot amounts to £300m and the final amount of cash for each school will be determined by the number of pupils - typically between £3,000 and £9,000 for primary schools and between £30,000 and £50,000 for secondary schools. For hard-pressed schools now finalising their budgets and spending plans for the next financial year, that means being able to pluck some extra items from their wish lists. But as our straw-poll of headteachers shows, their "must-haves" include much more than the inevitable books and computers.

Elaine Kay, head of Gillas Lane primary school in Tyne and Wear, said she hoped to restore some of her budget for special educational needs teaching, which she had been forced to cut by at least 20%. "We have had some very lean times recently, and it has been regrettable that we have lost our targeted support for special needs". Her school is a small, one-form entry primary school with a nursery class, which currently has 208 pupils on the roll.

"There are lots of things we would like to do, including extending our resource base - and particularly investing in new computers - and improving the school buildings," she said. "But our main priority will be to get more part-time teaching help to benefit the 20% of our pupils who need targeted support and extra help with basic skills such as numeracy and literacy."

Susan Springford, head of Parsloes primary school in Dagenham, Essex, explained her imaginative plans to make more constructive use of the lunchtime break, training the school's so-called dinner ladies to do more than simply supervise the younger children's eating. "It's like a concrete jungle here," she said of the school, which has 438 pupils. "The kids have very little to do at lunchtime, apart from play football and use skipping ropes. I would like our dinner ladies to have a broader educational role and become more involved in the school, helping the younger children with games and reading."

Paul Barraclough, head of Glebelands primary school in Chatteris, Cambridgeshire, said he expected to receive around £9,000 for his 280-pupil school. "Our immediate priorities will be to buy books and equipment, because like many schools we are increasingly reliant on our parent-teacher association to help us out with these things through fund-raising events. In particular, we need books to support literacy, numeracy and ICT teaching. More computer equipment would also be useful, as we have only one computer per classroom at the moment."

City technology colleges and specialist schools may not be perceived as cash-strapped compared with many other state comprehensives. At the top-performing Thomas Telford school in Shropshire, headteacher Kevin Satchwell said he would like to use the money to expand its partnership projects with the local community. At the top of the list is a pioneering mathematics project run in conjunction with three local feeder primary schools, which send some of their year 6 pupils to the comprehensive for "master classes" in maths.

All three schools use white-board technology, which taps into Thomas Telford's teaching resources, and their own maths teachers receive extra training from those at Thomas Telford. "We would very much like to add another school or two to this programme," a school spokeswoman said. "A recent Ofsted inspection found that the additional emphasis on maths prepared children very effectively for their transition to secondary school."

David James, head of Uplands Community College in Wadhurst, on the Sussex and Kent borders, has 1,000 pupils at his mixed comprehensive, which would make him eligible for £40,000. He has imaginative plans to use the money to free his "middle management" teachers for at least an hour a week in order to concentrate on the new system of performance management used to assess staff for performance-related pay. "An extra hour a week is the equivalent of £1,400 for every member of staff," James said. "All these changes in education are putting a great deal of pressure on middle management in particular".

New language laboratory facilities are also on his wish list. The school was the beneficiary last year of a £20,000 cash prize in the first round of the Teaching Awards, after its maths teacher, Romilda Scannelli, was named Secondary Teacher of the Year. As well as establishing an annual school prize, the money is also being used to improve student facilities.

George Wiskin, head of Westwood School, Leek in Staffordshire, a mixed 13-plus comprehensive with 850 pupils (including a 280-strong sixth form) said he also expected to receive around £40,000. "This is a very welcome addition to our budget," he commented.

"We expect to spend it on extra books and other resource material for our pupils, as well as offsetting the rising costs of exam fees. We have already pencilled in £75,000 for books and £50,000 for exam fees for this year, and things are pretty tight. Set textbooks are always needed. And the school has around 40 students studying for A-level history, for which good-quality books between £10 and £25 are also essential. The money for books will be allocated to individual departments, at £200 to £500 each. If the extra cash allows it, I will also try and buy an extra computer for our art department."

In inner-city Greenwich in south-east London, Rosemary Leeke, deputy headteacher of Thomas Tallis secondary school (which has 1,250 pupils and 80 teaching staff) said: "Most initiatives come with strings attached, so it will be nice to be able to spend the money as we wish. For years, our building was our biggest headache but we have now reached an agreement with the local authority to sort that out. I think teachers do suffer from initiative overload, so we would like to use the money to free up teachers' time."

fields.headline: The young ones
fields.trailText: The young ones
fields.body:
"There are times, I fear, when libertarian politics have to be overruled by parental duty," James Dallingpole wrote in the Telegraph a few weeks ago. He was writing, of course, about the internet and the Pandora's box it holds for children. Whether his youngsters would really have been able to make a bomb using the online recipe he discovered is questionable; but Dallingpole was right about the need to supervise children.

Holding your child's hand while they're online can be surprisingly good fun however and although the number of sites suitable for pre-school and Key Stage 1 is small, it will grow. At the moment the BBC leads the field with plenty of Teletubbies-related material at a site called Tots' Time and the delightful Little Animals Activity Centre.

What all these sites have in common is a parents' section that helps you make the most of the activities. They aren't confined to the computer screen; your child can, for example, search for an outdoor game involving Po the Teletubby. Used judiciously, www.lego.com is also fun. There is lots of inspiration for Lego games and in the process children can navigate a virtual Lego town and a medieval landscape.

All these sites make extensive use of sound, and all use Shockwave Flash. You won't need Flash, however, to read the Early Learning Goals and KS1 requirements online.

Schoolchildren can ask very simple questions at Ask Jeeves for Kids. A growing number of schools have placed pupils' work online, even at the earliest levels. Gareth Pitchford, a teacher at Edleston primary school, explained how the Year 2 animated story Ryan in Trouble was adapted for the web. Together with older members of the school's internet club, he transformed the book into an online story using Flash.

Perhaps surprisingly, most of the club members are girls, says Pitchford. "We tend to use the net to get boys to write a story." At the justly celebrated Ambleside primary school website everyone, regardless of age or gender, is involved. Parents will find dozens of activities and games; teachers will find a plethora of tips and advice for ICT.

fields.headline: Performing arts
fields.trailText: What should governors be doing to prepare for performance management?
fields.body:
A lot of governors are getting concerned about what they could and should be doing to prepare for their role in the new arrangements for performance management. This can be summed up in one word: nothing. At least, not yet.

What's it all about? You will no doubt be fully aware of the answer to this question if you have read the interim guidance contained in "Reviewing Performance and Pay of Heads and Deputy Heads", issued by the education department, but I dare say it could do with being recapped here.

The roles proposed for governing bodies in the Green Paper are as follows. First, governors will play a strategic role in agreeing a performance management policy, which incorporates annual appraisal and links it to pay in line with the changes in the Green Paper. In other words, governors will not be assessing teachers' performance themselves, but will be expected to ensure that there is a good performance management policy in place for it.

Second, governors will take responsibility for the annual appraisal of heads, making appraisal and the performance review part of the same process.

So far I may not have done much to allay your anxieties, but I can assure you help will be at hand. The education department is busy preparing all kinds of goodies to ensure that the new arrangements are smoothly introduced in September 2000.

Every governor will receive a guidance booklet. Other training materials will go to local authorities and other training providers for use in governor training. Schools will also be encouraged to invite governors along to the training they receive, and a trained external adviser will support governing bodies in their role of performance management.

A national training programme is scheduled to take place in July, September and October. I understand that the first module of this will cover policy matters, and the other three will give you the skills and information necessary to deal confidently in appraising and working with the new external advisers.

So, to reiterate, you will need to ensure that as a governing body you have a policy in place with regard to how teaching staff will be measured, but when it comes to doing the actual assessing, your role is confined simply to the appraisal of the headteacher.

Of course, when I say "simply", this presupposes that the relationship between head and governing body is one of openness, trust and mutual understanding. If, however, the relationship is difficult, performance management may well require both sides to go back to basics and re-examine exactly how they as governors work with the head, which may not be a bad thing.

For the time being, remember the words of The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy: Don't panic.

 Fred Browning is senior governor development officer for Essex local education authority.

fields.headline: Surfing, surfing USA
fields.standfirst: Technology is the key to reform in a huge state school system in the US
fields.trailText: Technology is the key to reform in a huge state school system in the US
fields.body:
It's a hot March morning in Charlotte, North Carolina, but Ann Clark is keeping her cool despite the worry of an earlier highway pile-up involving two of her pupils.

Even by US standards of sprawling state schools (known as "public" schools in the US), Clark's job is a daunting one. She is in overall charge of four newly built schools on a single campus, with more than 6,500 children aged five to 18 in her care. And as well as being principal of one of them - Vance High School - she also helped to set them up just four years ago. The "governors' village" schools - named after former North Carolina state governors - are also pioneering an innovative programme of local educational reform where technology plays a key role.

The schools consist of Vance High along with a middle school and two elementary schools. Together they offer the so-called K-12 educational programme, which covers the entire school age range from those at kindergarten, aged five, through to 12th graders aged 17 and 18. The schools attract a broad ethnic and social mix, drawing their intake from poor local housing estates as well as more prosperous suburbs.

Visitors from all over the world have come to find out what they can learn from this unique educational test-bed. Even before they were opened, the schools were the first in the world to receive funding from the technology giant IBM, under a new education programme. IBM, a big local employer, awarded the school a $2m (£1.3m) grant in the first round of its "reinventing education" scheme to help put its classrooms at the cutting edge of new technology.

Now, although the funding is almost spent, the partnership will continue in the form of ongoing support. Since the award to Charlotte in 1994, IBM has subsequently awarded grants of this kind to 21 other US states. Global investment has followed, with schemes in Dublin, Brazil, Italy and Vietnam; more will soon be announced in Singapore and Australia.

Next month it will introduce the programme, which incorporates revolutionary new software called Wired for Learning, to Britain. IBM is putting $1m - to be matched by an equivalent sum from the education department - into 50 beacon schools, which are designed to spread good practice and innovation. In the first step, the heads of beacon schools attended a workshop yesterday.

Free internet access in the US has put the web at the heart of the classroom, and at the governors' schools children are taught how to surf the net while still at elementary school. Now, Britain is hoping to learn from the experience of the Charlotte schools, and to benefit from reduced internet charges, which have previously restricted its use in the classroom.

Clark says that although it is still too early to claim that Wired for Learning has helped to raise student achievement, it has undoubtedly improved teachers' approaches by helping with lesson planning and communication. And, crucially, it has fostered better communication between parents, teachers, pupils and members of the community.

Wired for Learning was developed as a result of close collaboration between IBM and the Charlotte teachers, and tailor-made for the schools' own use. It combines the power of the internet with the security of Lotus Notes to allow the delivery of information through the web for teaching purposes, while also allowing confidential communication via email.

Using the technology to get busy, working parents more involved in their children's schooling has been a priority. Parents are encouraged to communicate with the school via email, and to look at the teachers' websites where details of lesson plans and homework assignments are posted.

For Clark, there are downsides. On a typical day, she will receive a staggering 300 email messages, around half of them from parents. She will try to answer all of them.

Teachers are also able to develop lesson plans, tapping into a database to ensure that they meet performance standards, and subsequently mapping and monitoring pupil progress throughout their school careers.

Pupils can use the programme to work on their school assignments both in and outside the classroom.

The regular use of the internet for schoolwork means that parents must sign a consent form for their child to surf "acceptable" sites. Vance High's technology director, Jim Storch, says that a minority of parents decline to do so, mainly on religious grounds. The schools have on average one computer for every four pupils, as well as extensive facilities in their libraries.

Raising standards is undoubtedly key to the longer-term agenda. North Carolina has a poor academic record, languishing in the bottom 10 of all American states in terms of school performance. Education chiefs accepted the need for innovative changes to raise standards, which coincided with the need to open more schools to cope with the fast-growing local population.

Clark, who in 1994 was awarded the prestigious national accolade of principal of the year in her previous job, was hired to oversee the setting-up of the new schools. IBM's new technology has been key to achieving what she describes as a "seamless, multi-disciplinary, instructional process". In a nutshell, this has meant abandoning traditional age-grade schooling, instead allowing pupils to move in and out of groups as they master skills, concepts and knowledge.

Over at the Nathaniel Alexander elementary school, principal Nancy Hicks explains how modern teaching must recognise the need for new skills such as sifting and evaluating information on the internet. Pupils are often computer-literate when they arrive at her school, where there are 1,100 youngsters. "We have five-year-olds starting here who are used to using email," she explains.

One of the school's biggest hurdles when opening from scratch, she claimed, was that parents anticipated the kind of more traditional schooling they had enjoyed. "We had to re-educate the parents before we could start educating their children," she says. "It was a matter of completely re-examining outdated and impractical practices within education, and replacing them with teaching that is more appropriate to today's knowledge economy."

fields.headline: A Faustian pact
fields.standfirst: Geoffrey Alderman blames vice-chancellors for the increase in academic bureaucracy
fields.trailText: Geoffrey Alderman blames vice-chancellors for the increase in academic bureaucracy
fields.body:
Last December a shabby deal was done between the Committee of Vice-Chancellors and Principals (CVCP) and the Quality Assurance Agency (QAA). In unveiling its plans for new quality assurance arrangements for the UK's higher education institutions, the QAA had dutifully danced to the tune of its ultimate paymaster - the government - and had proposed the retention of a particular system of grading for the university departments it inspected.

Although literal descriptions were to be used, they were ones which could easily be converted into numbers, and thus could be used by newspapers to compile league tables, which the Treasury believes is the only way to promote efficiency in the public sector. At first the CVCP condemned the proposal. But in an abrupt about-face, its leadership accepted it, even though more than four-fifths of its members had indicated their opposition to what had been offered.

The significance of this capitulation can hardly be exaggerated. In principle, the QAA has always distanced itself from the league-table industry. But in practice its proposed new methodology, like its present one, aids and abets the compilers of league tables, as is intended.

Whitehall believes that universities, like factories, can be made more efficient only through competition, and that universities must therefore be made to compete against one another whether they like it or not. Civil servants hold to this view, even though evidence has emerged that the league-table culture fostered by the QAA's current methodology is actually leading to a dumbing down of academic standards, notably in "old" universities, which perceive themselves as having more to lose if their "scores" are low.

So in accepting the QAA's new proposals, the CVCP has accepted also the view that the quality of a university education can be enhanced through competition - a doctrine for which there is absolutely no empirical basis.

But the significance of what has happened goes much deeper than this. Dissatisfaction within the HE sector with the activities of the QAA focused eventually on its grading proposals, but in fact covered a much wider range of issues. Not the least of these was, and is, the growing drain on scarce resources represented by the QAA's convoluted plans for inspection cycles involving an army of "academic reviewers" (ie inspectors), programme-specification templates, subject benchmarks, codes of practice and so on.

In seeking to excuse the CVCP's capitulation, its spokespersons intimated that had they not capitulated: the government had indicated that it would bring into play reserve powers it had given itself in the 1992 Further & Higher Education Act, and impose an Ofsted-type regime on the entire sector.

If made, this threat was almost certainly a bluff, which a strong and confident CVCP leadership should have called at once. But suppose the government had not been bluffing? It would have taken a massive diversion of government resources to put the threat into operation; meanwhile the QAA's timetable would have been heavily disrupted.

It was also said that the government might have imposed sanctions against the sector, by withholding funding from any HE institution not accepting the QAA's proposals and collaborating in their implementation. The truth is that although taxpayer-funded HE institutions must provide the government's funding councils with such information as they may reasonably require, this obligation almost certainly does not extend to cooperating with the QAA in its inspectorial activities.

Indeed, a number of universities (Oxford, Cambridge, Glasgow, Edinburgh and Middlesex) are reported to have politely declined to cooperate in a second round of academic audits, arguing that they could not justify the diversion of yet more resources in the face of the demands of teaching quality inspections, none of which has resulted in anything other than very satisfactory gradings.

And suppose a spiteful government does indeed threaten to withhold funds? Universities which it targets would have to shut down, throwing thousands of staff and students (almost all of whom are voters, by the way) onto the dole queues. Is this a realistic scenario?

Last December the CVCP had the government against the ropes. Not for the first time, it failed to press home its advantage. The true significance of what has happened is that the CVCP has surrendered much of the remaining vestige of that academic autonomy which was once the backbone of our university system. The rest of the world is laughing at us.

 Geoffrey Alderman is visiting professor at Middlesex University.

fields.headline: Administrators steal a march
fields.trailText: While debate about the Institute of Learning and Teaching for lecturers rumbles on, university administrators have stolen a march on their academic colleagues with today's launch of the Association of University Administrators' continuous professional development scheme.
fields.body:
While debate about the Institute of Learning and Teaching for lecturers rumbles on, university administrators have stolen a march on their academic colleagues with today's launch of the Association of University Administrators' continuous professional development scheme.

The challenge has been to produce a scheme that is rigorous enough to be credible, but at the same time is flexible enough to meet the needs of a wide range of staff, both in terms of professional background and in seniority. From the year-long debate on the development of the scheme has emerged a professional code of standards for university administrators.

"No one is in any doubt that universities and colleges are complex institutions to manage," said Lord Nolan, introducing the association's new code. "University administrators must strike a balance between the needs of a number of stakeholders. They are responsible in many ways for the welfare of our institutions, for the interests of staff and students, for dealing with suppliers of goods and services, as well as having a regard to the broader public interest and the proper use of funds.

"A set of professional standards which an individual can turn to when there appears to be a tension between corporate and individual professional values is essential," Lord Nolan continued.

"I welcome the Code of Professional Standards, which provides the framework of core values and principles to underpin the pro fession of university administration."

The association has always positioned itself as an open and accessible body for all those with administrative and managerial responsibilities in higher education. It has committed itself to raising the profile of the profession and to developing best practice and the highest standards of professionalism in higher education management and administration.

"The work of the Nolan Committee on Standards in Public Life emphasised the need for all those working in higher education to observe the highest standards of professionalism," commented the association's chairman, David Allen. "Our members have a wide range of professional interests, expertise and experience. Administrators and managers are key members of the teams responsible for delivering high-quality research, learning, teaching and knowledge transfer.

"The Code of Professional Standards is a welcome development in achieving and sustaining this goal," Allen concluded.

Sir Ron Dearing has also added his support to the continuous professional development scheme and the code of professional standards. "It is a truism, but no less important for that, to say that our staff are our greatest asset. We must nurture and develop them so that they can achieve the maximum possible, both for themselves and for their institutions," Sir Ron added.

The new code sets out a number of expectations of university administrators. They are expected to:

 provide high-quality professional services

 develop an appreciation of the academic culture, of the traditions and values of the organisations and institutions through which it is sustained, and of the roles of colleagues at all levels and in all branches

 be sensitive to the multiplicity of clients served by the higher education administrator and to the need to balance conflicting demands

 act with integrity, honesty, fairness, professional impartiality and diligence and without discrimination

 observe due care, objectivity and respect for confidentiality

 be explicit and straightforward in their dealings with colleagues and clients

 ensure that personal interest does not override the needs of clients

 accept responsibility for their actions

 challenge existing practices and ideas when necessary

 be committed to their own personal and professional development by seeking new knowledge and skills to enhance professional performance

 foster the development of others by sharing expertise and good practice and by encouraging employers to support professional development.

Peter Reader is the director of external relations at Southampton University.

fields.headline: Poverty rules, ok?
fields.standfirst: Cambridge scheme for poor students scuppered by red tape
fields.trailText: Cambridge scheme for poor students scuppered by red tape
fields.body:
Cambridge University's efforts to provide more grants for hard-up students are being thwarted by government regulations designed to claw back money from poor students on bursaries.

The university is stepping up its campaign to generate bursary funds from endowments, alumni contributions, charities and companies, amid growing fears that the spectre of rising debts is deterring poor students from applying to university. However, rules forcing students to start paying tuition fees when they receive over £1,800 in bursaries and grants are proving a major obstacle.

This week, the Cambridge colleges are unveiling a comprehensive support scheme for needy students, with up to £900 awarded to every Cambridge student fully or partly exempt from government tuition fees. In the current academic year, the university will channel £1m into access bursaries for over 1,200 students.

The aim is to double the number of students getting support over the next three years, and increase the value of the awards. About a fifth of Cambridge freshers come from low-income backgrounds, according to the official admissions figures. The drive is part of a push to widen access and attract talented students, irrespective of background.

But many dons believe the task is being made difficult by the government's decision to scrap maintenance grants and charge tuition fees, which they feel is alienating some students from university. Two weeks ago we revealed complaints from leading academics that the rules fly in the face of efforts to widen access to universities, and will create a new poverty trap for cash-strapped students. Department for Education officials have now said the regulations are under review but will not be changed until the 2001-02 academic year.

Capping of bursaries is seen as a large hindrance to the access drive. The government's student support regulations state students can receive £820 of income of any description, and £1,000 of any bursary, before they must start paying fees.

"If bursary income is to be capped at such a low level, it is a major disincentive to raising the necessary funds to help the people who really need help the most," said Dr Gordon Johnson, chair of the Cambridge colleges. He said there were many cases where the university would want to offer financial support above £1,800 to help students through university.

Baroness O'Neill, president of Cambridge's Newnham College, fears the regulations will deter companies from offering industrial sponsorships, particularly for students on engineering and science courses.

Last week officials at the DfEE stressed that they had not intended bursaries to be used for tuition fees, and the regulations were under review. "We know some colleges want to offer higher bursaries to disadvantaged students. The best way for institutions to contribute to the government's agenda to widen participation would be to offer bursaries at the existing level to as many students as possible," said one official.

"It is not our intention that any student from a low-income family be asked to use their bursary to contribute to tuition fees. For this reason we are reviewing the way bursaries affect the individual and family income assessment in preparation for the new regulations for 2001-02."

The government is also monitoring students' financial situation through two major surveys - the student income and expenditure review, and the review of access funds and hardship loans in universities.

 Dr Lee Elliot Major is deputy editor of Research Fortnight.

fields.headline: Back from a war
fields.standfirst: After ten years of exile, death and despair, Albanian Kosovans are reclaiming their university.  Paul Bennett  on a painful start
fields.trailText: After ten years of exile, death and despair, Albanian Kosovans are reclaiming their university. Paul Bennett on a painful start
fields.body:
A year has passed since Nato began its bombing campaign in Serbia. Set against the media's harrowing images of displaced Kosovars and defiant youth on the streets of Belgrade, it's not surprising that few in Britain spared a thought for their universities.

But now academics on both sides are trying to re-establish some normality and stability in a region where the political sands keep shifting. University teachers in Serbia, feeling the isolation of 10 years of war and sanctions, convinced the trades union-based organisation, Education International, to investigate threats to academic freedom from the Milosovic regime.

Belgrade University, like almost everything else in the city, is under tight control. Since the Universities Law was passed in 1998, deans of faculties are no longer elected by peers but directly appointed by the regime. Political opponents have been dismissed and sometimes replaced by political activists from the governing coalition parties. The demand that academics sign a loyalty oath to the state has been met with reactions ranging from weary acquiescence to angry resistance.

Serbian academics are suffering - primarily because of the economic hardship borne of prolonged social and economic isolation from the west. Teachers at Belgrade University are paid about £100 a month - one tenth of the level a decade ago. There is a chronic shortage of money for salaries, buildings and equipment.

Serbians are still bitter about the Nato bombing and continuing isolation. Although we saw no evidence of damage to university buildings, the psychological damage of sanctions - which has cut off normal academic discourse with international colleagues - runs deeply through the academic community. Yet few Serb teachers wanted to admit Serbia might be the author, even in part, of its own misfortunes.

But the scale of deprivation pales beside the scale of the deaths, displacement and physical damage inflicted on Kosovo. Seven thousand people, including several university staff, are still missing - at best, they will be in Serbian prisons.

When we met the principal of the metallurgy faculty in Pristina University in Mitrovica, he was sitting by the gas fire in his otherwise unheated office, overlooking the river - the front line between the Albanian and Serb communities. For 10 years he had struggled to maintain the work of the faculty in private houses and small firms, always facing the threat of police, military or unofficial harassment and violence.

Kosovar Albanians have returned to Pristina University after years of working clandestinely. University staff, who had been dismissed by the Milosovic regime because they were Albanian, kept classes going across a range of subjects and specialisms that had been available prior to their expulsion from campus in 1991.

The work was funded by voluntary "taxes" paid by the Kosovar Albanians themselves, including those abroad. Now the metallurgy faculty was "squatting" in rooms given them by a run-down high school.

The agricultural faculty, on the outskirts of town, is housed in a group of run-down buildings with only the most basic equipment. The only modern building, a biological analysis wing, had been trashed by the Serbs. Libraries and Albanian language archives were also destroyed.

And the violence continues. In February, 15 staff members had been ousted from their homes by Serb neighbours, with only the possessions they could carry - in the struggle, one of their wives had been killed. Upstairs, students in their late teens and twenties were having an exam, crammed into desks for school pupils, wearing their overcoats against the cold in a bare room.

Meanwhile, many official and unofficial agencies are working with the Kosovans to rebuild civil society in a land where the infrastructure has been shattered to a degree the western press reports scarcely prepared one for. Buildings that the Serbs occupied and neglected for 10 years had been comprehensively vandalised as they left. At least the university buildings are still standing: in the countryside, the havoc wrought on the schools reflected an extraordinary degree of hatred - mirrored by the killings last year of 400 teachers in the Kosovar Albanian teachers' union, SBASHK.

Focusing on the restoration of the material conditions for education, the Kosovar Albanians know the price they have paid in pain and trauma - but counting the psychological cost will take longer. Hopefully, the Milosevic regime in Belgrade will not unleash further destabilising violence on their own people and their neighbours, giving them time to work, however painfully, towards a normalised society, in which education has a key part to play.

 Paul Bennett is a Natfhe national official; he visited Kosovo as chair of Education International Europe's higher education committee at the invitation of education unions in Serbia and Kosovo. The university in Kosovo, in particular, needs books, equipment and IT support. Education International will be coordinating these efforts. For details contact Paul by email.

fields.headline: So what do you want?
fields.standfirst: Retiring NUS president  Andrew Pakes calls on students to climb out of the rut of factionalism
fields.trailText: Retiring NUS president Andrew Pakes calls on students to climb out of the rut of factionalism
fields.body:
There is a crisis of identity in the student movement. Next week student activists will gather in Blackpool to choose a new leader and shape NUS at the start of a new century. If you read the popular press on a regular basis then you could be mistaken for believing we are on the verge of a mass uprising by students with more occupations and greater protests. On the other hand, student activists have been inspired by the much quieter revolution heralded by the Cubie report into fees and grants for Scottish students.

So what are delegates to NUS annual conference to make of all this confusion? And what are the alternative visions on offer from the candidates in the race to become president?

This is the least ideological election for many years. All the candidates are opposed to tuition fees, argue for the return of some sort of grant and are against top-up fees. Similarly, all three presidential hopefuls believe that direct action is a key ingredient in a good campaign. The real question is where the candidates disagree.

There are three issues at stake in the election. The big disagreement is still about the grant, but now it is about universal grants against the new, targeted approach. The hard left slate, led by Alison Angus, believes that all four million students in further and higher education need a living grant entirely funded by the state. The other main candidate, an independent named Owain James, is campaigning for Cubie to be extended to England and Wales. However, there is also a healthy debate about democracy in the national union and the political nature of slates and coalitions standing for election.

NUS has faced a greater number of difficult disaffiliation votes this year. While NUS successfully won in Southampton on a Yes vote of 72%, and Birmingham with 63%, where more than 2,000 students voted, the trend of referendums looks likely to continue.

Even though many small colleges are joining the national movement, the NUS is in danger of getting stuck in a rut.

Students aren't frustrated by the lack of radicalism, by the leadership or by the failure to agitate for a campus uprising, but rather by the cumbersome bureaucratic machinery and domination of top positions by political factions.

Even though Labour Students have stood aside, this year the battle for president is as much about whether someone standing on a political slate should be elected or whether it is time to get an independent in place.

Do students want a leadership from the traditional political groups or is it time for something different? After 18 years, Labour Students have opted not to fight the election; in the current mid-term climate of government, we would have found it increasingly hard to triumph at the polls. This year NUS has a chance to make a new start. My greatest fear is that the student movement will opt for more of the same. It is a comforting option to vote for the well-worn factional slogans and slick campaigns.

NUS needs to accept that its funding campaign failed. In the past it was trapped in a tortuous and false debate between "grants for all" or "let them have loans". This year NUS has started to get it right again, arguing for a mixed system of student financial support.

Election campaigns, however, rarely touch the big issues in a logical manner. For instance when the hard-left slate is fighting for an end to business involvement in education, where does that leave the hundreds and thousands of students on vocational courses or taking part in placements? The shifting identity of students and the growth in new learning styles deserves serious consideration.

On the other hand, student activists have been inspired by the much quieter revolution heralded by the Cubie report into fees and grants for Scottish students. So what are delegates to NUS annual conference to make of all this confusion? And what are the alternative visions on offer from the candidates in the race to become president? This is the least ideological election for many years. All the candidates are opposed to tuition fees, argue for the return of some sort of grant and are against top-up fees. Similarly, all three presidential hopefuls believe that direct action is a key ingredient in a good campaign. The real question is where the candidates disagree. There are three issues at stake in the election. The big disagreement is still about the grant, but now it is about universal grants against the new, targeted approach. The hard left slate, led by Alison Angus, believes that all four million students in further and higher education need a living grant entirely funded by the state. The other main candidate, an independent named Owain James, is campaigning for Cubie to be extended to England and Wales. fields.headline: Regional Diamond
fields.standfirst: The government comes under scrutiny over its allocation of research funds
fields.trailText: The government comes under scrutiny over its allocation of research funds
fields.body:
Research has got regional - and personal - it seems. The long-term outcome of the government's decision to locate the £500m X-ray synchrotron machine, Diamond, at the Rutherford Appleton Laboratory near Oxford instead of the Daresbury Laboratory in Cheshire promises to be a new regional battleground over the allocation of research funds.

Many have chastised the government for concentrating even more research resources in the south-east, following the long-delayed decision. But, while it may be seen as little more than a sop in the circumstances, it is the north-west that sets new ground as the first region to receive ring-fenced money (up to £50m) from the annual science budget.

Meanwhile, the government's first major statement on science and innovation policy in seven years is to be delayed until the summer. Yet one of its main proposals - a regional innovation fund, aimed at forging links between science groups and businesses at the local level - is to be unveiled ahead of schedule this month by the trade and industry secretary, Stephen Byers. This follows the confirmation of a new regional venture capital fund to kick-start new high-tech businesses in last week's budget statement by the chancellor.

The moves represent a radical change in policy for the government's annual £1.5bn science budget. Research council chiefs have always stressed that research grants should be allocated according to the scientific quality of proposals. Debate has raged over how national priorities may also inform funding decisions, but never, under any conditions, has it been suggested that they be influenced by geographical location.

As part of the compensation package for the north-west, a review team headed by the chairman of the Economic and Social Research Council, Bruce Smith, will advise the science minister, David Sainsbury, on how to allocate a minimum of £25m from the science budget to the region. The government will also fund a new £25m biotechnology facility.

Yet many MPs have accused the government of being bullied by the project's other funding partners - the Wellcome Trust and the French government - to wrongly choose the south-east for the Diamond facility. "This doesn't seem to fit in with the fine words on regional development and the agencies established to ensure the economic regeneration of the regions," said Ian Gibson, MP for Norwich North. The House of Commons science and technology committee has asked the government to explain its decision.

In developing a new science and innovation policy, the government has heard many good arguments for creating a regional strategy. The government's contention that research will underpin the knowledge-based companies of the future, coupled with its vows to promote economic rejuvenation in the regions, points to a more equitable distribution of research funds. And devolution for Scotland and Wales has highlighted further the needs of the English regions.

There are some difficult issues to reconcile. Each regional economic plan contained the same priorities - exploitation of research, university-business links, high-tech business clusters. Can all the regions do all these things? University researchers in the south-east attract more research funds, and are more highly rated than their academic colleagues in the midlands and the north, according to figures recently compiled by the Higher Education Funding Council for England. Should there be a redistribution of resources?

Some hints of the government's regional policy may emerge when Byers unveils the details of the regional innovation fund. More substantial proposals are expected in the summer, when the government publishes its new science strategy. But most believe that the funding package for the north-west announced this month has been waved through without considering these wider issues. Political expediency won the day.

fields.headline: University challenge
fields.standfirst: Peter Reader looks at the hurdles facing administrators at the launch of a new scheme
fields.trailText: Peter Reader looks at the hurdles facing administrators at the launch of a new scheme
fields.body:
Globalisation will be as big a challenge for managers and administrators as for other university staff, Howard Newby, president of the College of Vice-Chancellors and Principals, is to tell university administrators at their annual onference in Nottingham later today.

"Globalisation is a familiar feature of research programmes, but encouraged by governments and forces of competition, it is acquiring new significance for all aspects of higher education," Newby said. "It has led to the forging of cross-continental partnerships and global alliances, and more are to be expected.

"Development of international courseware and brands, UK universities marketing worldwide and inter-continental research collaboration all have major implications for administrators.

"Many staff will have to acquire new skills. Not only will they need to be even more technologically and linguistically literate, but also many will have to gain a better understanding of different patterns of national education provision and of cultural differences towards education and the ability to negotiate across these boundaries. Finance staff will have to raise funds on the private market, corporate planners will need to understand differing national expectations of higher education and registry staff will have to grapple with different assessment and examination regimes.

"Above all, new technologies will have to be understood and exploited." Welcoming the continuing professional development programme of the Association of University Administrators, which is also being launched today, Prof Newby added that all staff will be expected to have a lifelong commitment to professional training and development.

Staff would have to travel. But while Prof Newby conceded that higher education "tourism" could be gruelling, there were cultural benefits for staff from visiting other universities and seeing how they operate.

There may be some casualties in working practices - collegiality, particularly between colleagues in different institutions, will suffer as more staff are working in competitive positions.

Prof Newby stresses that just as research and teaching staff are expected to be at the leading edge of their professions, world-class higher education is going to depend on world-class administration. But he adds a note of caution. UK universities that turn their backs on their own communities do so at their peril, he says. He recalls that in the 70s and 80s, many UK universities seemed to take pleasure from distancing themselves from their towns and cities. "It is not antithetical for world-class research to be based in the institution's local communities," he said.

webTitle: Dead and buried Lynch film given new lease of life

fields.headline: Dead and buried Lynch film given new lease of life
fields.trailText: Mulholland Drive, a TV pilot written and directed by David Lynch for the ABC network, may now be released as a feature film.
fields.body:
Mulholland Drive, a TV pilot written and directed by David Lynch for the ABC network, may now be released as a feature film.

Lynch shot the $7m, two-hour drama last year, but ABC executives disliked it so much they refused to screen it. Now the French conglomerate Canal Plus have expressed an interest in acquiring the picture.

"We're getting close to a deal where Canal Plus would pay ABC $7m for the rights and will put another couple of millions in for David to give it a new ending," executive producer Tony Krantz explained to TV Guide.

Mulholland Drive was conceived as a dark-edged Los Angeles soap opera in a similar style to Lynch's classic early 90s whodunnit Twin Peaks. Throughout his career, Lynch has been fascinated with the way television drama has allowed him to fashion an ongoing story, one that he can develop and progress over time.

After clashing with ABC, however, he has vowed never to work in TV again: "Basically they hated it," he said. "They hated the story, the acting. They thought it was too slow, that's for sure. Basically they hated everything about it."

Since abandoning Mulholland Drive, Lynch has won plaudits for his quirky, Oscar-nominated road-movie The Straight Story. Last week, he announced plans to develop a series of animated shorts on the US website Shockwave.

The web, it seems, now gives Lynch the opportunity to create the ongoing narratives which he once looked to TV to provide. Meanwhile, if the Canal Plus deal goes through, the feature-length Mulholland Drive could be in cinemas as soon as this autumn.

webTitle: BMW revives plan to invest in Hungary

fields.headline: BMW revives plan to invest in Hungary
fields.standfirst: Rover in crisis: special report
fields.trailText: German car maker BMW has reopened talks about investing in Hungary - days after announcing it was ditching its planned £1.7bn investment in Rover's Longbridge plant in Birmingham.
fields.body:
German car maker BMW has reopened talks about investing in Hungary - days after announcing it was ditching its planned £1.7bn investment in Rover's Longbridge plant in Birmingham.

Gyorgy Matolcsy, Hungary's economic minister, yesterday confirmed the approach and said he and the Hungarian prime minister, Viktor Orban, would visit BMW in April.

Local reports said BMW was considering making small and medium-size cars in Hungary.

That would rub salt into the wounds of Rover workers who stand to lose their jobs as a result of BMW's plans to carve up the British car maker and sell Longbridge to London venture capitalist Alchemy Partners.

BMW planned to invest heavily to develop and build a replacement for the Rover 25 and 45 at Longbridge with the help of £152m of government aid.

But the European Commission ordered an in-depth investigation into the proposed aid package, expressing doubts about BMW's claim that it had seriously considered building the new car in Hungary.

BMW cited the delay in getting the aid approved when it first hinted it was about to give up its attempt to turn Rover around. But in the end the reason for BMW's decision to break up Rover turned out to be the strength of the pound which left the German company with losses of £2m a day at its British subsidiary.

Senior Rover shop stewards meet in Coventry yesterday to discuss the likelihood of other bids for Rover and to plan a mass march in Birmingham on April 1.

The unions' national officers are due to return to Munich for further talks with BMW officials on Thursday. They want a solution which avoids the job losses envisaged by Alchemy.

webTitle: Bloody Sunday inquiry: army's secret plan

fields.headline: Bloody Sunday inquiry: army's secret plan
fields.standfirst: The Bloody Sunday inquiry: special report
fields.trailText: Twenty eight years on, the families of 14 unarmed catholics shot dead by the army in Derry in one of Northern Ireland's darkest days gathered for the start proper of what will prove to be the biggest judicial inquiry in United Kingdom history: Lord Saville of Newdigate's fresh probe into the tragic events of Bloody Sunday.
fields.body:
Twenty eight years on, the families of 14 unarmed catholics shot dead by the army in Derry in one of Northern Ireland's darkest days gathered for the start proper of what will prove to be the biggest judicial inquiry in United Kingdom history: Lord Saville of Newdigate's fresh probe into the tragic events of Bloody Sunday.

It was an important leap in their long struggle to overcome security force claims that several of those killed on the anti-internment march in January 1972 were tainted: either IRA gunmen or nail-bombers. They have fought ever since Lord Widgery, the lord chief justice, exonerated the army within three months, ruling that paratroopers only started shooting after coming under fire.

They listened as Christopher Clarke QC, counsel to the inquiry, began his mammoth four-week opening statement at the Guildhall, in Londonderry, saying he was determined to find the truth. He went on to relate a secret plan for the army to resume command of no go areas in Derry. The hardline proposals were forwarded three months before members of the first battalion of the Parachute Regiment shot dead the demonstrators.

Lieutenant General Michael Carver, chief of defence staff, wrote to the prime minister, Edward Heath, warning there would be casualties if the government opted for the choice he recommended, to storm the Creggan and the Bogside to "root out the terrorists and the hooligans". He was seeking Mr Heath's recommendations.

Bloody Sunday led to the restoration of direct rule from Westminster two months later, and it was to pour petrol on the flames of the troubles, acting as an immense force for IRA recruitment.

Lord Widgery exacerbated the hurt in his speedy 36-page report exonerating the army. The bereaved and the survivors never accepted the findings, and eventually forced Tony Blair to announce the new inquiry two years ago. It is proving to be the biggest judicial investigation in UK legal history, with more than 100,000 pages of evidence amassed so far.

Opening, Mr Clarke said: "The tribunal's task is to try to discover so far as humanly possible in the circumstances and with the means now available, the truth.

"Not the truth as people see it. Not the truth as people would like it to be, but the truth pure and simple, however complex, painful or unacceptable to whomsoever that truth may be."

On a glorious day in Derry, Linda Roddy held breakfast prayers with her family, hoping at last the clouds of 28 years were going to lift. The new inquiry marks the opening of hearts, she whispered, as she arrived at the Guildhall.

Her brother, William Nash, 19, was on his way there in January 1972 when the anti-internment parade was halted 400 yards from its destination. The army opened fire, and he was one of 14 unarmed Catholics killed.

The army claimed Nash was an IRA gunman. It was a disgusting lie, said his sister. All she wanted from Lord Saville's inquiry was for the security forces to admit it. She wanted no blame, no prosecutions.

She took her place in the public gallery alongside Michael Bradley, 50, one of 14 wounded. He was due to start work at a painters the next day when he was shot in both arms and the chest. He has never had a job since.

Mr Bradley said: "I thought they were firing plastic bullets. We all ran, and then a woman told me a boy had been shot. I couldn't believe it. I still can't believe it."

fields.headline: Bloody Sunday inquiry seeks 'simple truth'
fields.standfirst:
After 28 years, QC's pledge begins hearings into 14 deaths

The Bloody Sunday inquiry: special report
fields.trailText: Counsel to the Bloody Sunday inquiry yesterday started with what is expected to prove the longest opening address in United Kingdom legal history, vowing to uncover the truth "pure and simple" about one of the most notorious episodes of the troubles.
fields.body:
Counsel to the Bloody Sunday inquiry yesterday started with what is expected to prove the longest opening address in United Kingdom legal history, vowing to uncover the truth "pure and simple" about one of the most notorious episodes of the troubles.

Christopher Clarke QC, beginning the oral hearings, promised his team was committed to finding out what led the army to open fire on an anti-internment march in Londonderry 28 years ago. His determination was absolute, he said, and witnesses would be tackled without fear or favour.

Members of the First Battalion of the Parachute Regiment shot dead 13 unarmed Catholics on the illegal parade. One of the 14 people wounded died five months later.

Mr Clarke, at the Guildhall in Londonderry, said: "What happened on January 30 1972 was, whatever the truth of the matter, a tragedy, the pain of which has endured despite the passage of years. It was and it remains of serious concern."

Mr Clarke admitted there had been problems in gathering evidence. The inquiry has been amassing documents for two years, and is expected to go on for at least two more years, making it the longest such tribunal ever.

Mr Clarke said: "There are those who have chosen to regard the task of the inquiry as impossible. It is not so.

"But what is true is the ability of the inquiry to get to the truth is dependent on two things: first, the extent and quality of the evidence available to it and secondly, the assistance that is provided to it. There are those who see through the distorted prism of guilt or anger, prejudice or predisposition."

He said the understandable urgency in the aftermath of Bloody Sunday led to the failure of the lord chief justice, Lord Widgery, to find out what had happened. His report, accepted by Edward Heath's government as vindication of the army, had engendered resentment which had lasted until now, and not just among the families of those who died.

Lord Widgery held hearings over 21 days. He delivered his 36-page report within three months, declaring the army had started shooting only after coming under gunfire, a finding furiously disputed by the bereaved and survivors.

Mr Clarke said in contrast 1,400 witnesses had so far been interviewed for Lord Saville's inquiry. The search for evidence had taken the inquiry team from Nevada in the United States to Hong Kong and had included every continent except Antarctica.

Although he recognised witnesses' memories may be failing, he hoped the passage of time would encourage frankness. He believed it would allow some now to face up to unpalatable truths.

Mr Clarke said: "Truth has a life of its own. Although the first casualty of hostilities, it has formidable powers of recovery, even after such a long interval."

Several figures, including Sinn Fein's Martin McGuinness, who then led the IRA in Londonderry, have yet to provide statements. He said as he arrived at the Guildhall yesterday he would do so if he became convinced Lord Saville's inquiry was open and impartial.

Mr Clarke warned he would use the powers of subpoena if witnesses refused to give evidence. All would be treated equally no matter what their power or influence.

He pointed out witnesses had immunity from prosecution. None could face criminal action as a result of appearing before Lord Saville, except for committing perjury.

Mr Clarke described the discrimination faced by Catholics in Londonderry in the run-up to Bloody Sunday, daily battles between security forces and local youths, and secret army documents highlighting military fears they were losing control in Londonderry.

The inquiry continues today.

Who, what, where - and how much?

The judges
The inquiry in the city's Guildhall is chaired by Lord Saville of Newdigate, an English law lord who usually sits in the court of appeal. Married with two sons, Lord Saville previously chaired a Department of Trade and Industry committee into arbitration, the findings of which were encompassed into the 1996 Arbitration Act.

He is joined by the former New Zealand judge Sir Edward Somers, a judge in New Zealand's court of appeal from 1981 until 1990, and Canadian William Hoyt, who for 14 years was a court of appeal judge in New Brunswick.

The court
Technology is being used as never before. Each member of the Saville panel and every lawyer and official has a computer screen in front of him to study the thousands of documents which will be presented to the inquiry. Proceedings will be published on the internet daily.
