webTitle: The TV cameras have gone but Mozambique's misery goes on

fields.headline: The TV cameras have gone but Mozambique's misery goes on
fields.standfirst:
After the floods the world faces its biggest test of commitment to the ongoing tragedy in Africa

Mozambique floods: special report
fields.trailText: The lakes of floodwater that consumed whole towns are trickling back into Mozambique's rivers, but the TV cameras have gone, and with them the international attention that set off the scramble to rescue a drowning people.
fields.byline: Chris McGreal in Ilha Josina Machel
fields.body:
The lakes of floodwater that consumed whole towns are trickling back into Mozambique's rivers, but the TV cameras have gone, and with them the international attention that set off the scramble to rescue a drowning people.

In the next few weeks Mozambicans will have good reason to wish that the cameras were back.

It is now, at just the moment when the world's focus has moved on, that foreign governments must decide how far their commitment goes. Do they walk away, having completed the job of saving lives? Or do they stop and face a far larger task - to help Mozambique rebuild and save its once-shining economy?

Here in Ilha Josina Machel, a town still marooned in a sea of water, people are surviving at the end of a clattering lifeline of British, American and South African helicopters delivering food. But once the water drains away, the future of this community will be determined by how quickly the roads that have paved the way to prosperity are rebuilt.

Today, the government in Maputo will publish an assessment of the havoc wreaked by more than two months of flooding. It will form the basis for an appeal next month for the huge sums of money it will cost to rebuild the shattered infrastructure. But without the drama of the rescue pictures, Mozambique is far from certain of success.

The water wrecked or damaged the homes of about 250,000 people. Their livestock drowned, their crops rotted and their tools washed away. It will take years for many to recover.

But the destruction is not, at the moment at least, a catastrophe for Mozambique's much vaunted economic revival, fuelled by generous dollops of aid, rising foreign investment and a government surrender of financial control to the World Bank and International Monetary Fund.

Most factories and other export earners were largely untouched by the floods. But there was considerable damage to the roads and railways that underpinned the boom.

The government provision ally estimates that it will need another $280m (£175m) to rebuild more than 620 miles of roads that were completely swept away, and long stretches of railway track. Then there are the electricity and telephone lines, and more than 600 schools in need of repair.

The appeal for money to reconstruct the shattered infrastructure will be made at an international donors' conference in Rome in four weeks' time. Mozambique's foreign minister, Leonardo Simao, is betting on his country's status as a favourite son of western governments and global financial institutions.

He says the country is held up as too much of a success story to be allowed to fail. "Our success was a source of inspiration for many countries in Africa. If this example is left to die, we are killing their hope. This economic growth is a major condition for peace and stability in the region."

But Mozambique has failed to persuade foreign creditors to write off its debt, although a number of governments have unilaterally scrapped outstanding bilateral loans. And there are real concerns that donors will use money earmarked for development aid in the country to pay for reconstruction, at the expense of other projects.

"What we require is additional aid, not at the expense of development money," Mr Simao stressed.

The outcome of the meeting will be decisive for towns such as Ilha Josina Machel. Two months ago torrential rains flooded the Incomati river and laid waste to part of the southern end of the town. A month later a surge of water swept down the Limpopo river to the north, wrecked hundreds more homes and cut the town from the rest of Mozambique.

It is now an island, accessible only by helicopter or boat and wholly reliant on the out side world to feed itself. Even when the waters recede, the town will count on aid from the World Food Programme for at least three months. But its mayor, Samo Timoteo Samo, is stoic.

"More than 1,000 homes were destroyed in the town and surrounding villages. For those people this is a disaster. For the rest of us it is merely difficult," he said.

But difficulty could turn to disaster for the whole region. In recent years, the town prospered, selling sugar cane to a factory a few miles away. Now the crop is almost completely destroyed.

The factory is helping with an advance on future sales, so people can buy tools to replant. But the roads were ripped up by the floods. Without new ones the town can only get its crop to the factory with great difficulty, and the factory will find it virtually impossible to ship the sugar out.

Although many Mozambicans dislike the comparison, Mr Simao argues that the floods caused more devastation than the 16 years of civil war between 1978 and 94.

"It's much worse than the war if you look at the losses in terms of human beings in a short space of time, the losses of houses, schools, telecommunications systems, power lines. If you look at the losses of cows - more than 1m dead. We never had 650,000 people dependent on food aid in such a short time," he said.

"There's also the psychological impact, because those who suffered are the survivors of war. They had seven years of hope and now they are back to square one. It is very easy to get discouraged."

webTitle: Haider's crocodile snaps at Austrian art world

fields.headline: Haider's crocodile snaps at Austrian art world
fields.standfirst:
Threat to cut state arts funding to opponents of rightwing agenda

The Austrian far right in power: special report
fields.trailText: Jörg Haider's retreat to Carinthia after his resignation as national leader of the far-right Freedom party may have pleased most Austrians but it it is worrying artists, musicians and writers in the region.
fields.body:
Jörg Haider's retreat to Carinthia after his resignation as national leader of the far-right Freedom party may have pleased most Austrians but it it is worrying artists, musicians and writers in the region.

Mr Haider, who remains governor of Carinthia, has appointed himself the province's cultural supremo. Artists fear that emboldened rightwingers will repress experimental art by withdrawing state funding for artists who criticise them.

Mr Haider's plan, which he has said he wants to expand nationwide, involves a radical shift from state support for the arts to private sponsorship, which has little precedent in Austria. Art critics fear this would mean that critical voices were silenced.

"Community brass bands and art celebrating beauty and harmony, the land and the people, blood and soil will have the upper hand over fringe theatre groups whose critical art alienates the man on the street," one said.

The Freedom party, whose inclusion in the coalition government has earned Austria its current status as international pariah, has already been accused of targeting the cultural avant garde and "degenerate" art for cuts in an attempt to silence some of its most powerful critics.

"Artists don't know where they stand," Uschi Loigge, the cultural editor of the Carinthian daily Kleine Zeitung, says. "Haider has only ever criticised them for being spongers and lazy leftwing intellectuals. He uses every public appearance to promote traditional culture like yodelling and to denounce the modern. And he's sure of getting applause every time."

But the real focus of the artists' wrath is Andreas Mölzer, Haider's cultural adviser, an extreme rightwinger who outlined his ideals in tracts published 20 years ago.

In an interview with the Guardian he has admitted he will make a lot of unpopular decisions as cultural adviser with the aims of "curbing pluralism" and "bringing Carinthians back to their roots".

"I don't have political responsibility and that's the beauty of it," he says. "Someone has to play the crocodile and for that I'm paid a princely sum."

Mr Mölzer, 54, is editor-in-chief of Zur Zeit, a national weekly which he founded and which even he admits gives space to "the loony right". He is currently facing charges of "attempting to resurrect the Third Reich" - a criminal offence in Austria - for an anti-semitic article he printed.

Mr Mölzer, whose allegiance to the far right is symbolised by a schmiss - a fencing scar running from jaw to nose which is recognised as a "badge of manhood" among male student fraternities - wrote a book about the students' wing of the Waffen SS in which he said: "The first aim of our fight should be the reawakening of a strong German cultural and spiritual consciousness."

Twenty years on, Mr Mölzer stands by all he wrote although he says it was written "when the political correctness mechanism wasn't in place". He believes that for years "left- wing intellectuals have been helping themselves to the spoils and that won't happen any more".

Under a pseudonym, he writes a weekly column in Austria's most popular tabloid which he uses to outline his plans to "repatriate Carinthia through art and culture" and to denounce outspoken artists.

One of the leftwingers he likes to target is Bella Ban, who owns Cafe OM in Pernhart Strasse in Klagenfurt, close to the Hotel Sandwirt, from where in 1938 Hitler addressed an adoring crowd.

In the past 10 days she has been forced to make two changes to the way she runs her business: she vets each customer before unlocking her door and she's stopped cleaning the huge front window.

The reason is a large transparent screen print stretching the full height of the glass, depicting the cabinet members of Austria's government distorted with Hitler haircuts and moustaches. Mr Haider's face is covered in swastikas.

The window artwork by Carinthias's most famous dadaist, Viktor Rogy, has transformed Ms Ban's cafe into a focal point for supporters and opponents of Mr Haider.

"Old people rap on the window with their walking sticks and lots of others have spat in protest," says Ms Ban.

Mr Rogy, 75, who sports a thin Hitler moustache with irreverent irony, has ordered her not to wash the saliva off. "They've turned my art into a spitting altar, and they're adding more value to it because they're spitting on their own government," he says.

So far the police have called twice and the city authorities have even threatened to close the cafe down and take the couple to court for attempting to resurrect the Third Reich.

"This attempt from certain quarters to show our country in such a morbid light must be stopped as fast as possible," a spokeman for the Freedom party said. "Art has its limits."

Another target is Cornelius Kolig, a Carinthian artist who was commissioned to add frescos to a room in the state parliament building 18 months ago. Mr Kolig's grandfather had painted frescos in the building but they were condemned as degenerate by the Nazis and destroyed.

Mr Mölzer says commissioning Mr Kolig was a "bad decision" and derided his work as "faecal".

The Freedom party also criticises Klagenfurt's civic theatre which they complain is disrepectful towards the German language by bringing in international artists and staging bilingual productions.

The theatre's artistic director, Dietmar Pflegerl, recently won a long battle with Mr Mölzer, who was threatening to slash his budget until Mr Haider intervened at the last minute. Mr Pflegerl is convinced the two are "playing a game, to see how far they can go".

Mr Mölzer's ire was roused last year by a play by one of the Freedom party's staunchest enemies, Elfriede Jelinek, about the attempts to isolate non-German speakers in Austria.

Mr Pfegerl expects this year's programme, which includes two plays by Carinthian authors that deal candidly with Austria's recent history, will cause even more anger.

"This is a time when Austria has to deal with its ghosts like at no other time before," he says. "But Mölzer's pushing for artists to plug the image of our cosy homeland and wants to ban anything foreign or critical."

The theatre's press spokesman, Stefan Zoltan, is even wary when using his mobile telephone these days. "The atmosphere has changed. You have the feeling that you are being watched all the time.

"I hear things I've said to people in private being repeated, even in Mölzer's newspaper columns. I'm sure there are many informers out there who report back to the chief what's going on."

fields.headline: Africa's angry old man
fields.standfirst:
Mugabe's machinations hurt Zimbabwe

Zimbabwe: special report
fields.trailText: Robert Mugabe's postponement of Zimbabwe's general election until some time in May - the president was rather vague about dates - raises a question about whether the poll will take place at all. The house of assembly, dominated by Mr Mugabe's Zanu-PF, was elected on April 8-9, 1995, for a five-year term.
fields.body:
Robert Mugabe's postponement of Zimbabwe's general election until some time in May - the president was rather vague about dates - raises a question about whether the poll will take place at all. The house of assembly, dominated by Mr Mugabe's Zanu-PF, was elected on April 8-9, 1995, for a five-year term. Thus, constitutionally speaking, it will soon lose its legislative mandate. But this rule-bending should come as no surprise. Mr Mugabe demonstrated his contempt for constitutional limits last week by ordering police to ignore a Harare high court ruling ending the government-organised, illegal occupation of 700 white-owned farms. He also broke international treaties by personally instructing officials to open a British diplomatic bag. Such dictatorial behaviour strengthens suspicions that if Mr Mugabe believes he will lose the election, as he lost last month's referendum, the farms crisis will be used to justify imposing an emergency and suspending the democratic process.

Even if the election does eventually go ahead, there are well-founded concerns that it will be neither free nor fair. The opposition Movement for Democratic Change led by Morgan Tsvangirai faces the prospect of concerted intimidation, vote-buying, and ballot-rigging. But it has commendably rejected Mr Mugabe's cynical attempts to exploit land and race issues, warning instead that in a country so reliant on agriculture, the president's machinations may prove disastrous. Mr Mugabe, unheeding, presses on with a vote-catching law allowing farm seizures without compensation, even though in the past such land has often been "redistributed" to his cronies and left literally to go to seed. "Lawlessness and anarchy are being promoted by the highest authority in the land," Mr Tsvangirai says. Sadly, this is not campaign hyperbole.

Mr Mugabe, aged 76, once a man of considerable stature, shrivels daily before our eyes. Zimbabwe certainly needs land reform, as part of a broader economic regeneration. Its friends, in particular Britain and South Africa, stand ready to help with cash. The US, the IMF and World Bank would all back a rational recovery programme. And they have all told him so. But like a latterday Lear, Africa's angry old man plunges blindly on, deaf to all advice, the victim of imagined conspiracies and betrayals, still fighting the colonial battles of his youth. The problem is how to stop his unredeemed tragedy becoming Zimbabwe's.

Mr Mugabe, unheeding, presses on with a vote-catching law allowing farm seizures without compensation, even though in the past such land has often been "redistributed" to his cronies and left literally to go to seed. "Lawlessness and anarchy are being promoted by the highest authority in the land," Mr Tsvangirai says. Sadly, this is not campaign hyperbole. Mr Mugabe, aged 76, once a man of considerable stature, shrivels daily before our eyes. Zimbabwe certainly needs land reform, as part of a broader economic regeneration. Its friends, in particular Britain and South Africa, stand ready to help with cash. The US, the IMF and World Bank would all back a rational recovery programme. And they have all told him so. But like a latterday Lear, Africa's angry old man plunges blindly on, deaf to all advice, the victim of imagined conspiracies and betrayals, still fighting the colonial battles of his youth. The problem is how to stop his unredeemed tragedy becoming Zimbabwe's.

webTitle: Cook's guide puts torturers on trial

fields.headline: Cook's guide puts torturers on trial
fields.standfirst: Ethical foreign policy: special report
fields.trailText: The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, will tomorrow take the unprecedented step of publishing a torture handbook aimed at bringing international justice to bear on regimes which abuse human rights.
fields.body:
The foreign secretary, Robin Cook, will tomorrow take the unprecedented step of publishing a torture handbook aimed at bringing international justice to bear on regimes which abuse human rights.

An unusual initiative for a government, it will revive Mr Cook's flagging '"ethical dimension" in foreign policy as well as raise the profile of abuses and their remedies in hotspots like Bosnia and Kosovo.

The 160-page Torture Reporting Handbook, to be launched in the ornate Locarno room at the Foreign Office, gives advice to activists and organisations working in human rights on how to gather evidence that would stand up in court. It says: "Each piece of reliable information meticulously collected is a weapon in that struggle [to eradicate torture], and every door thrown open is one less door for the torturers to hide behind."

There is concern worldwide that individuals and governments escape justice because of inadequate gathering of evidence. The book is part of a momentum towards creation of an international criminal court, and to the increasing recognition that human rights abuses have no borders, and oppressive leaders no certain refuge.

Its existence would probably not have made much difference to Augusto Pinochet's Chile, as abuses then were well documented, but it could help bring to court abuses elsewhere in Latin America, as well as cases in Central America, Africa and Asia that have been less well documented.

Work on the book has been carried out by the University of Essex on behalf of the Foreign Office's human rights section.

Amnesty welcomed the book, as did the Medical Foundation for the Care of Victims of Torture. Sherman Carroll, spokesman for the foundation, said it gave activists on the ground a practical guide: "It will make its mark on years to come with the creation of the international criminal court when torturers will be brought to trial."

The book says: "In torture allegations, it is unfortunately the case that a significant portion of the information received from NGOs [non governmental organisations, such as charities] is wasted, not because the allegations are unfounded, but simply because important facts are omitted, because the allegation is worded in excessively political language, or because it is submitted in a language which the person receiving the allegation does not understand or does not possess the resources to have translated." It sets out how to document allegations, how to protect persons giving evidence, and where to send the evidence. It also deals with consent of victims in giving evidence, and their support and rehabilitation.

Results cannot be guaranteed, it says, and often it will seem "as if little has been achieved... eradication of torture is a long, slow process, and should not be measured in terms of individual results only".

fields.headline: Diary
fields.standfirst: Matthew Norman
fields.trailText: Matthew Norman
fields.body:
 Sad to report, the relentless rise of Peter Hain is under threat. Until recently, the foreign office minister was lined up to replace Clare "Bomber" Short (poor Bomber's sell-by date is close) both as Mr Tony's preferred tame leftie and as minister for international development. But then Peter mixed it up with that Glaswegian street fighter George Galloway, by frustrating George's plans to take a plane-load of supplies to Iraq. The two exchanged irritable letters in the Guardian before Peter made his big mistake: he wrote to Glasgow's Herald accusing George of telling fibs. Interfering in another MP's home patch is poor form, and George swiftly launched a counter-strike, first undermining the Neath MP's left-wing credentials at home with letters attacking his role over sanctions in all main Welsh papers; and then booking Neath town hall for a public debate on May 8. When Peter said he'd be in Angola, George offered any other date he was free. A hounded-looking Peter now wanders around the Commons complaining. Now Peter, no one likes a whinger, any more than they like a chicken. Do stop clucking, man, and debate the issue.

 It's great to see Frank Dobson among today's Guardian comment writers, but this is only one of his countless media engagements. On Friday Dobbo granted an interview to a woman from the Asian channel Zee TV. Everything went fine, until just after ending the interview, the reporter seemed to remember something. Oh, she said, before we go would you mind looking into the camera and saying "Oooh, you amaze me!" Dobbo affected bafflement at this. You know, said the reporter, your catchphrase. Still feigning confusion, Dobbo nonetheless pointed his beard at the camera and delivered it with gusto, just as Bruce Forsyth would have done in the same boat. What a pro he is.

 The minute we receive a tape of the incident, several Oooh You Amaze Me! T-shirts will be on their way to Zee TV. Yes, the garments have arrived, and most tasteful they are too, as you will see in the newspaper when a picture appears in Wednesday's diary. To remind you, they come in two sizes (Ken, which equates to medium, and for the fuller figured person, the Frank), and are available via the Diary at a reasonable £7.50. We hope to persuade celebrity readers to model for us (volunteers are most welcome), but so far a call to Melanie Coupland, Graham Norton's agent, provides little hope. Still, it's early days.

 Tomorrow sees the return of Frank's Chuckle, as the patriotic mayoral candidate pulls our chuckle muscle with a gag at the expense of those Rover-destroying Germans.

 After several appearances across the media, my friend Jonathan Aitken's godly veneer becomes so tarnished that, if you didn't know better, you might guess he's the same amoral shyster as ever. Yesterday, for example, Jonathan went on Start the Week and treated Paxo to the old one that the Guardian withdrew the allegations of his pimping. In fact, as Jonathan and regular readers must know, four witnesses to this were waiting outside the court to testify when his case collapsed. How delightful it would be if, with Jesus's help, Jonathan could wean himself off this whopper before the witnesses are tempted to dredge up the whole sordid business again.

 Hats off to my colleague Polly Toynbee, who has achieved ultimate fame by becoming a question on Who Wants To Be A Millionaire? On Sunday Tina Nicol had £8,000 when Chris Tarrant asked her what Polly is well known for. Stumped, Tina opted for the 50-50, but although she suspected journalist over actress, she wouldn't risk it. A shame for Tina, but a singular honour for Polly. The best this column has ever managed was when my former colleague Simon Bowers was a question on Fifteen To One.

webTitle: £20m Barclays link gives vital boost to Freeserve

fields.headline: £20m Barclays link gives vital boost to Freeserve
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Shares in Freeserve, Britain's leading internet service provider, received a much needed fillip yesterday after the company announced a joint venture with Barclays Bank to set up a portal for small businesses.
fields.body:
Shares in Freeserve, Britain's leading internet service provider, received a much needed fillip yesterday after the company announced a joint venture with Barclays Bank to set up a portal for small businesses.

The venture will be 60% owned by Freeserve and 40% by Barclays. It aims to provide online advice on everything from net name registration to employment issues. If successful, the portal may be floated separately.

Freeserve shares have taken a bruising since rivals such as AltaVista and NTL sought to increase market share by launching unmetered internet access.

Faced with the loss of telephone call revenues from matching such offers, Freeserve is under increasing pressure to provide more revenue-earning content. The deal with Barclays improved the Freeserve share price by 22.5p to 538.5p, still well below the 920p achieved at the beginning of the month. Barclays shares rose 17p to £16.65.

Freeserve and Barclays will each plough £10m into the small business portal in the first year. Barclays claims to be Britain's largest internet bank with 100,000 of its 450,000 small business customers on line. Freeserve estimates it has 300,000 small business users.

John Pluthero, chief executive of Freeserve, said: "Freeserve has a good reach among small businesses and with the Barclays brand we have a powerful combination."

The joint venture will launch in May and will offer advertising and e-commerce. Other services will include advice on accounting, sales and marketing, payroll control, law and online access to account information for Barclays customers.

 Britain's biggest building society, Nationwide, will put 250 terminals in branches so that customers can try internet banking free of charge. They will allow customers to register, carry out transactions or just see a demonstration.

Nationwide's online service, set up in 1997, offers mortgages, loans and credit cards. Customers can manage accounts, pay bills and set up standing orders.

webTitle: Putin keeps west in dark on foreign policy

fields.headline: Putin keeps west in dark on foreign policy
fields.standfirst:
Air of uncertainty as world leaders queue up to make friends with the new president-elect of Russia

Russia: special report
fields.trailText: President-elect Vladimir Putin signalled a shift in Russian foreign policy yesterday as world leaders rushed to court him in the hope that his election victory would usher in a more stable era in east-west relations.
fields.byline: Ian Traynor in Moscow and Julian Borger  in Washington
fields.body:
President-elect Vladimir Putin signalled a shift in Russian foreign policy yesterday as world leaders rushed to court him in the hope that his election victory would usher in a more stable era in east-west relations.

But US officials and analysts said they remain unsure what the new leader, a former KGB agent, stands for in the fields of economic reform, disarmament, and relations with Nato.

Igor Ivanov, the Russian foreign minister whose job in the new administration is not necessarily secure, added to the air of uncertainty. He said Russian foreign policy would undergo changes, but declined to give specific examples.

Tony Blair, the only western head of government to meet Mr Putin during his tenure as acting president, continued his courting in a 15-minute phone call. He was pipped by China's president, Jiang Zemin, the first foreign leader to talk to Mr Putin yesterday.

The calls reflect the president-elect's record of working on a surer footing for Sino-Russian relations while promoting firmer ties with the west - he displayed a moderate and pragmatic approach towards western interests in meetings with Mr Blair and the US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright.

Keith Bush, the director of Russian and Eurasian affairs at Washington's Centre for Strategic and International Studies, said: "When it comes to reform, nobody knows what he's going to do. We'll have to wait until the swearing-in."

But Mr Bush said that, despite the lack of details, Washington welcomed a more reliable interlocutor than the frequently ill Boris Yeltsin.

The US state department believes that Mr Putin may be readier than his predecessor to negotiate with the US over the 1972 anti-ballistic missile (ABM) treaty. Washington wants to modify the treaty to allow US forces to develop an anti-missile programme, to act as a shield against ballistic weapons fired by rogue states.

Mr Yeltsin was fiercely opposed to the suggestion, but Mr Putin appears to have signalled that he might be open to bargaining.

"He does look like a person with which the west can do business," said Graham Allison, an arms control expert at Harvard University. "I can imagine some do-able deals. There's an opening and an opportunity."

Mr Allison said there was a potential deal by which Moscow allowed modification of the ABM treaty in return for some technology transfer, and a framework for Start III (a nuclear arms limitation treaty) which reduces the number of nuclear warheads on each side of the former iron curtain.

Mr Putin is also expected to promote the much-delayed ratification of the Start II treaty, which also cuts nuclear warhead arsenals, in the Russian Duma, as an overture of goodwill towards the west.

But Mr Allison said Mr Putin's policy on the safeguarding of nuclear material in Russia's hands had far more substantial relevance to western security.

"The prospect of Russian nuclear weapons being stolen, or sold to Iran, Iraq, Hamas or whoever is much more important. On that latter issue, there should be a very great opportunity now, because a Russian president who thinks he's been fighting a war on terrorism has more interest in stopping weapons being stolen than we do."

No new government team is expected in Moscow until after Mr Putin's inauguration in early May, when he should also make a major policy speech to the parliament.

All western leaders who have visited Moscow in the past two months have described Mr Putin as an internationalist and westerniser who wants to strengthen ties with the west after a year of estrangement caused by the Kosovo crisis, Nato expansion into eastern Europe, and Mr Putin's campaign in Chechnya.

He is keen to make Russia a more attractive place for western investment. But following years of Russian decline, Mr Putin is also resolved to project power and will also at tempt to be a robust defender of what he determines to be the national interest.

The US president, Bill Clinton, is expected to have a summit with Mr Putin before leaving the White House next January. And now that the Russian election is over, foreign countries are queueing up to host a visit by Russia's new leader

China and Japan said yesterday they hoped for visits, while Britain also hopes to host Mr Putin following Mr Blair's night at the opera with Mr Putin in St Petersburg earlier this month.

Mr Putin is also expected to visit Germany, where he once worked as a spy. Chancellor Gerhard Schröder told Mr Putin that Germany had "great expectations of a strong, democratic, peaceful, and prosperous Russia that is aware of its international responsibility and fully shares in European processes".

The European Union's foreign and security policy chief, Javier Solana, is expected in Moscow next week to meet Mr Putin.

webTitle: Yes TV seals video deal for BBC shows series

fields.headline: Yes TV seals video deal for BBC shows series
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: BBC Worldwide, the commercial arm of the broadcaster, yesterday announced a deal with Yes Television to provide up to 600 hours of programming for its nascent video-on-demand service.
fields.body:
BBC Worldwide, the commercial arm of the broadcaster, yesterday announced a deal with Yes Television to provide up to 600 hours of programming for its nascent video-on-demand service.

The two-year agreement worth "seven figures" to the BBC will allow subscribers to download series including Pride & Prejudice , Airport and Nazis - A Warning from History on to their TVs via a phone line or cable. The so called video-on-demand will enable viewers to watch the shows when they want during a 24-hour rental period as well as being able to pause, fast forward and rewind.

Yes TV is running commercial trials of its service in London in a joint venture with British Telecom as well as an offer in Hull with Kingston Communications. Both use a technology called digital subscriber lines which upgrade ordinary copper telephone wires for "broadband" applications such as broadcasting and high speed internet access. BT will begin marketing its service to 6m homes initially in the early summer with the video-on-demand element coming fully on stream later in the year.

Steve Garvey, Yes TV's head of marketing said: "The BBC not only adds authority but some great programming." Yes TV is planning a £600m flotation on the stock market.

 BBC Online
 Yestv.co.uk

fields.headline: Mobile bidders bust £5bn barrier
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Bids for the government's auction of third-generation mobile phone licences burst through the £5bn mark yesterday, as competition intensified among the 13 contenders.
fields.body:
Bids for the government's auction of third-generation mobile phone licences burst through the £5bn mark yesterday, as competition intensified among the 13 contenders.

The sale of the five licences could reach as much as £10bn, as the four existing operators continue their aggressive bidding.

One.Tel, backed by News Corp, offered £1.3bn for Licence A and Vodafone a similar sum for licence B. WorldCom bid £964m for C, while 3GUK, an Eircom subsidiary, offered £965m for D and Orange bid £1bn for E. The total cash offered now exceeds £5.56bn.

In Cannes yesterday, Michael Fallen, chief financial officer at Eircom, would not comment on the price the group was prepared to pay, saying only: "We have bid aggressively so far and we will bid sensibly on price."

The bid fitted with the group's ambitions to expand in the UK and Ireland. He cited Eircom's combination of local market knowledge and international experience in mobile operations.

Virgin, which brought together the SpectrumCo consortium, denied it had sold its 1% stake in the group. Virgin confirmed it has the option of going to 5% if it wins a licence. Other big shareholders include Tesco and Marconi.

 www.spectrumauctions.gov.uk For up to the minute information

webTitle: NHS to lose spending powers in Labour shake-up

fields.headline: NHS to lose spending powers in Labour shake-up
fields.trailText: The government is to introduce a merit system under which hospitals will directly receive millions of pounds in extra funding, in radical measures that will bypass the spending decisions usually made by senior healthcare managers.
fields.body:
The government is to introduce a merit system under which hospitals will directly receive millions of pounds in extra funding, in radical measures that will bypass the spending decisions usually made by senior healthcare managers.

The health secretary, Alan Milburn, will today set the pace for the prime minister's NHS shake-up when he announces a £60m performance bonus for hospitals and GPs that cuts out local health authorities when allocating funds.

And Mr Milburn is also planning a warning system to supplement the new funding arrangements where hospital and doctor performance will be monitored to encourage them to meet agreed targets.

It means that taxpayer- financed health care will move down the road taken by Labour over education, whereby Whitehall will not hesitate to send in "recovery teams" to take over failing hospitals or GP teams in primary care.

A week after the chancellor's Budget confirmed a four-year boost for the NHS - worth 6.1% extra each year - Mr Milburn will start to spell out how senior ministers expect health teams to deliver the quality of performance demanded by the extra funds. The health secretary will announce how the first £600m of extra funds - part of the £2bn injection set out by Gordon Brown - will be spent.

Some £200m will be used to pay off debt, some of the rest will be used to improve winter services and to meet the inpatient and outpatient waiting lists that Labour is finding hard to cut. The new primary care groups (PCGs) will also get money for new services.

The money will be formally sent via health authorities but with strict instructions about it being given to the health "providers", the hospital trusts and PCGs. In addition there will be a £60m performance bonus scheme to encourage best practice in key disciplines, intermediary care and winter problems. Performance will be judged against priorities set by regional NHS officials.

Likely priority targets would be waiting times for hospital inpatient and outpatient appointments and measures to head off a repeat of the politically damaging winter crisis.

Ministers are keen to stress that high-performing NHS hospital trusts and and PCGs - due to start at GP level next week - will get more freedom to manoeuvre. Tony Blair has been persuaded that tackling the variations in performance of hospitals is crucial to restoring public confidence. He wants the bulk of hospitals to catch up with the best.

Poor performers can expect direct intervention after a series of warnings - two yellow cards and one red card on the way to the imposition of a recovery team led by the local NHS regional director. Those establishments getting a yellow card will lose their quarterly performance bonus and be told to produce an action plan. A second warning will require them to deliver. After that, a "hit squad" will be sent in.

In reality, ministers will use carrots more readily than sticks, although a hotel star system to mark hospitals' customer-friendliness is also on the cards as part of the new regulatory regime.

fields.headline: Scoot.com pins all on relaunch
fields.standfirst:
Conference call - Bonnier predicts dramatic revenue rise

E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Scoot.com, the online publishing and information group, aims to increase revenue from £16m to £1bn within five years - if its relaunch next month is successful.
fields.body:
Scoot.com, the online publishing and information group, aims to increase revenue from £16m to £1bn within five years - if its relaunch next month is successful.

Robert Bonnier, chief executive, said yesterday the launch of Scoot.com2 on April 28 would deliver a platform that was more user friendly to consumers and businesses users.

Scoot.com clients will be able to find a product or service using a an improved search system on its directory, ask for a quote for a service and make online reservations.

"We are very confident that within five years we will have 2m transactions a day across Europe and that we can make £1.50 per transaction," Mr Bonnier said at the SG Cowen Global Technology Conference. "It looks very ambitious from where the company stands today."

In 1999 the company lost £20.6m. To meet Mr Bonnier's target sales need to grow by 129% annually for five years.

Scoot.com has 350,000 users, mainly small to medium size businesses, in the UK, Netherlands and Belgium. Of these only 7,000 are paying clients, with an average transaction generating £1 in revenue.

Scoot.com's estimates of client numbers have been questioned. Mr Bonnier said: "We never get complaints from our investors or analysts. We've previously explained that it was just somebody bad-mouthing the company. This is a very evolving business and we try to reflect the underlying business numbers as accurately as possible."

Scoot.com has also had problems attracting advertisers to its directory service. The annual fee of £700 was considered too high by some and that charge has been cut to £200 a year plus a per-transaction levy.

Mr Bonnier said the relaunch would attract more advertisers and he predicted the number of companies listing with Scoot.com in Britain would grow from 20,000 to 200,000 in the next three years.

Scoot.com expects 80% of its revenues to come from requests for household, gardening and office services. Those areas currently account for 55% of sales.

Mr Bonnier is also counting on the group's joint venture with Vivendi, announced earlier this year, to drive subscriber numbers. Vivendi owns 65% of the venture and will invest to help expand Scoot.com across Europe. It has an 11% stake in Scoot.com.

"We want to build a pan-European service within the next five years but it is a very rapidly changing landscape and it won't give us five years," Mr Bonnier said.

Scoot.com is launching in France in September and has brought forward its launch in Germany and Italy to December.

fields.headline: Former minister attacks 'colonial' Budget
fields.standfirst: Budget 2000: special report
fields.trailText: Gordon Brown's Budget strategy came under fire last night for upholding the "colonial raj" mentality of Whitehall in the way the civil service governs the English regions and deprives them of funds.
fields.body:
Gordon Brown's Budget strategy came under fire last night for upholding the "colonial raj" mentality of Whitehall in the way the civil service governs the English regions and deprives them of funds.

In his hard-hitting resignation speech, delayed two months after splitting from the government over its "heartland" failures, Peter Kilfoyle, the former defence minister, complained that the chancellor's Calvinistic instincts had made some of his jobless Liverpool constituents feel "they are being chastised for being unemployed".

It would minimise the sense of injustice among those in fear of the latest crackdown on benefit fraud if fraudsters "at the other end of the social scale" - people with lawyers and accountants - were the target of some deterrent sentences, he said.

While praising Mr Brown as "monarch of all he surveys", Mr Kilfoyle commented that that political glory was transient. He singled out for attack the lack of Treasury matching funds to co-finance EU-backed projects in the three poorest English regions, and the government's refusal to locate the £500m hi-tech Synchrotron science project in the north-west. "Failure [on regional policy] cannot be contemplated," Mr Kilfoyle said.

The MP for Liverpool Walton acknowledged Mr Brown's achievements. "I know the government has done many good things for which it seems to get little credit," he said. But he added a sting to the tail. "However, I do not recall the Good Samaritan extending his hand to the man fallen among thieves and then remonstrating with him that he was the author of his own demise."

He added: "We wonder when we will be afforded the flexibility that a degree of regional autonomy would bring. That would require a change in the colonial raj epitomised by the government offices which implement decisions within the regions themselves."

webTitle: Dying ex-smoker wins £12m from tobacco firms

fields.headline: Dying ex-smoker wins £12m from tobacco firms
fields.standfirst: Smoking: special report
fields.trailText: A dying ex-smoker who sued America's two largest tobacco companies was yesterday awarded $20m (£12.6m) in punitive damages.
fields.body:
A dying ex-smoker who sued America's two largest tobacco companies was yesterday awarded $20m (£12.6m) in punitive damages.

The superior court jury ordered Philip Morris and RJ Reynolds to each pay $10m to Leslie Whiteley and her husband. The same jury awarded the couple $1.7m in compensation last week after finding that the companies deceived the public about the dangers of smoking.

Last week's verdict was the first in favour of a smoker who took up the habit after warnings from the US surgeon general first appeared on cigarette packets in the 1960s.

The Whiteleys had asked the jury for $115m in punitive damages, which they said would represent 1% of the companies' combined net worth. Their lawyer said cigarette makers remain unrepentant for the harm they cause.

Lawyers for Philip Morris and RJ Reynolds suggested punitive damages of $3.4m to $5.1m. They argued that the companies had got the message from similar lawsuits, and had demonstrated goodwill on the issue through the $206bn settlement reached in 1998 by cigarette makers and 46 states suing over health costs.

Philip Morris will appeal if the trial judge upholds the verdict, said a company lawyer, William Ohlemeyer.

"Mrs Whiteley never smoked a pack of cigarettes that didn't have a health warning on it that was written by the surgeon general," Mr Ohlemeyer said. He said punitive damages were improper because "the companies have made profound changes in the way they do business".

The jury voted 9-3, the margin needed for a verdict.

Of the nation's five other jury verdicts in favour of individual smokers, two in Florida and one in New Jersey were overturned on appeal; an $80m verdict in Portland, Oregon, was reduced to $31m by the trial judge; and a $51m verdict against Philip Morris in San Francisco a year ago was cut in half by superior court judge John Munter, who is also presiding over Ms Whiteley's case.

Ms Whiteley, 40, of Ojai in southern California, said she started smoking in 1972, when she was 13. She smoked Philip Morris' Marlboros and Reynolds' Camels until 1998, when she gave up shortly before doctors diagnosed small-cell lung cancer. Doctors say she is likely to die this year.

The tobacco firms said Ms Whiteley harmed herself by her admitted use of marijuana, by smoking during pregnancy and by disregarding warnings on cigarette packages.

But after reviewing internal industry documents, jurors found that the companies designed cigarettes negligently, then made false or misleading statements to the public and concealed information about the dangers of smoking.
AP

webTitle: Dover, no port in a storm for refugees

fields.headline: Dover, no port in a storm for refugees
fields.standfirst:
In a special series Guardian reporters look at the experience of asylum seekers in Britain and the bitter politics that lie behind a question that stirs the deepest of emotions. Today: the arrival Impact on the south coast has led to claims of lives of luxury

Refugees in Britain: special report
fields.trailText: In the garden of England, a hatred is kindling. Dover is being torn apart by the presence of 700 asylum seekers and 1,400 of the port's 30,000 residents have signed a petition protesting at Kent country council's decision to add £3 to the council tax to pay for the upkeep of the refugees.
fields.body:
In the garden of England, a hatred is kindling. Dover is being torn apart by the presence of 700 asylum seekers and 1,400 of the port's 30,000 residents have signed a petition protesting at Kent country council's decision to add £3 to the council tax to pay for the upkeep of the refugees.

Sitting in her garden, petition organiser Sheila Farrell rails against the asylum seekers. She is joined by Chris Ryan, a former fisherman, who is appalled by the impact of the newcomers on Dover. "We're trying to do something for the residents and we get called racist," says Mrs Farrell.

It is not hard to see why. Mrs Farrell, together with a teacher, was behind a leaflet called Dover the Land of Plenty and subtitled "refugees, 33 reasons why we should send them back and close the door".

Reason number nine claims that the local hospital has advised that should anyone have "any blood contact with these people, then medical help is of the utmost importance". Reason number 13 reads: "Pregnant refugee mothers only want brand new equipment for their new offspring. Are these infants now entitled to hold a British passport to success now that they have been born in our local hospitals?"

Reason number 21 reads: "No medical checks on refugees, with the knowledge of their promiscuity and selling sex for money, who is to answer for the epidemic of venereal disease that will undoubtedly become rife."

It would be wrong to dismiss Mrs Farrell as heartless. In that contradiction of Englishness, Mrs Farrell is kind to animals, and keeps a bird pool in her neat garden while disliking some human beings.

Chris Ryan claims that only one in 10 of asylum seekers has a case. "At the start about 90% were genuine and 10% bogus, it's the other way round now. "People are resisting because of what they've got. They're on benefits, they're walking around with mobile phones, the latest clothes and cars. They're having the life of luxury on it. Some are sending back £500 in cash a week to Romania." Mrs Farrell joins in: "They're going into travel agents and booking flights for their families. In the post office there was uproar as one man was getting £700 in cash."

Requests for names and proof are unheeded.

Last summer the tension led to clashes between gangs of local youths and asylum seekers at a funfair. Local councils managed to get a dispersal system enacted and have halved the numbers of refugees in the Dover area. While the government's strategy struggles to get off the ground, Kent's reduction in refugee numbers is credited with taking some of the heat out of the situation locally.

New asylum seekers are still arriving. One is Pavel, 32, a Roma from the Czech Republic. He came to Britain in January with his wife, Natasha, 31, and four children. He says that twice in his homeland a skinhead gang broke into his flat and the first time, using baseball bats, chains and sticks, attacked him, his wife and their children.

After the first attack he was in hospital for three weeks. His children were so traumatised that they required psychiatric counselling. "They were scared of loud shouting and had nightmares," says Pavel.

Reprisal fear

He and his wife were attacked and humiliated in the street by skinheads, in a town he does not want to name for fear of reprisals if he is sent back. "The main feeling we experienced was a lack of basic dignity," says Natasha.

Pavel's family of six are now living in one room of a house on £188.09 a week. They flew to Britain separately and applied for asylum at Heathrow, but came to Dover where there were already family members.

The furore over asylum seekers in sections of the press, mirroring the mood among some in Dover, has produced more than just anti-refugee rhetoric.

Some like Farid Kohistani, 26, from Afghanistan, have been physically attacked and he says that every day he is verbally abused. "The white tribes don't like us, we don't like them. Especially the Dover people." Now when he is sworn at, he swears back.

The spikiness of this young man melts away when Farid talks about why he fled Afghanistan. He and his family were opposed to the Taliban regime. Farid himself fought against them. Within three months of the Taliban taking control of Kabul, Farid's father was murdered. His brother was killed in front of his mother and then she herself was killed. He does not know how they were killed, and he never even got to bury them.

Farid arrived in Dover in July 1999. An uncle paid $9,000 (£5,600) to an agent who got him a false Pakistani passport. From Afghanistan he flew to Moscow, from where he came to Britain in the back of a lorry. The overland journey took 33 days.

"I never knew what country we were in. There were 12 people in the truck. You could never feel good, you're frightened of being caught."

Farid, who fears being murdered if returned to Afghanistan, was caught at Dover docks after police checked the truck. Within weeks of arriving he was attacked. Farid said: "I was on the Folkestone road. There were three of us, and four of them. They used bad language, at this time I didn't know what they said. They attacked us. They punched me in my body. It lasted three to four minutes. Nobody helped us."

Now Farid makes sure that he goes out with four or five other people at night to minimise the chances of being attacked, or losing the fight.

Voucher humiliation

He has £37 worth of vouchers a week to live on and £10 cash. "When I use the vouchers in shops, it is horrible, horrible. The other shoppers stare, they look very bad. I feel humiliated. When you go to the shopping centre you are made to feel you're an animal, you're a dog."

If the voucher system and the media attacks were designed to put pressure on asylum seekers to leave, then they are working. Farid said: "When the war in Afghanistan finishes, I go back the first day. Before I was very relaxed. Now if the English use bad language, I'm ready to fight back. All asylum seekers are."

Farid stays in a hostel, owned by a woman who does not want to be named. Her windows have been broken, and she was assaulted after trying to help a refugee who was being attacked.

The hostel she runs tries to provide a family atmosphere for the mainly young asylum seekers it houses. At dinner the victims of failed geo-politics - Afghans, Iraqis and Kosovans - gather in the dining room for a vegetable curry and rice. Afghani music is playing in the background, the different nationalities take it in turns to listen to their different sounds.

Rahim, not his real name, is one of 800 unaccompanied minors in Kent. Aged 15, he came to Britain from north Afghanistan in June last year. He soon regrets telling his story, and as we leave he follows, pleading that his real name is not used. He fears that his classmates will turn hostile if they realise he is an asylum seeker. "I'm at college, no one knows I'm a refugee there. If my name is in your paper, I can't go to college. It's hard, someone will swear."

Rahim has a one year visa to stay. "I've seen hundreds of killings. My house was near a mosque where they were killing people. They washed the blood off afterwards." He last saw his parents a year ago and does not know if they are alive or dead. He arrived in the back of a lorry, and does not realise that he arrived in Dover from France.

There is little infrastructure in place to help the refugees. Every Wednesday in a drafty hall belonging to the United Reform Church asylum seekers gather for a drop in session.

Teenagers play table tennis and pool, children paint, adults sit and chat while volunteers help others to fill out forms for benefits.

On Tuesdays the church hall is used for English classes, run by the Reverend Norman Setchell. "I don't want to look back in five years time and hang our heads in shame because we haven't done enough," he says. "After two-and-a-half years this is still the only daytime place asylum seekers can come to in Dover.

"There seems to be a feeling that the vast majority, if not all, are here on an economic bandwagon. It doesn't seem to matter that you can show statistics about 50m nomads and refugees in the world.

"What bothers me is the fundamental lack of compassion coupled with the lack of knowledge and awareness of where these people come from."

In the church hall is community officer PC Norman Liggins. "Everytime the press attacks asylum seekers, it doesn't help the situation on the ground. As soon as it appears in the press, feelings begin to rise, you can sense it."

PC Liggins says much of the violence asylum seekers face is not reported.

A dossier prepared by Dover against racism lists over 20 attacks in the past year. Some victims are too scared to speak even with anonymity, while others, under the dispersal system, have left the area.

Despite the reduction in the numbers of asylum seekers, the attacks go on. Marcel Malik, 25, a Czech Roma who fled after repeated attacks by skinhead gangs, has been assaulted twice.

"This situation is much better than the Czech Republic, but I'm not safe here. We can go out, but we are scared."

His girlfriend's mother, a Roma, was also attacked in another incident where she was kicked by a male neighbour while on the ground.

Other incidents have seen refugees driven out of their homes and reports of numerous attacks on refugee children in the school system.

It is a sign of the strength of feeling the issue arouses in the town. Paul Watkins, leader of the Tory group on the Labour controlled Dover district council, says that tension is still "simmering under the surface".

He blames the government for not meeting the full cost leaving the council with a £400,000 shortfall.

Election issue

Conservative canvass returns for a council byelection in Castle ward show immigration as the first or second most important issue. At the next general election Mr Watkins will be the Tory candidate for the Dover and Deal constituency, which Labour's Gwyn Prosser holds with an 11,739 majority.

Mr Watkins says: "This will be the main local issue in parts of the constituency. It shouldn't be down to local people to fund a national problem, that in itself is one of the reasons for local tension and the government has caused that tension by not meeting the cost."

Back in Mrs Farrell's garden Chris Ryan predicts that the asylum seeker issue will cost Labour the seat. He voted for them in 1997: "I can see them losing the election on this. Mr Prosser hasn't come out and made a statement about what they are going to do. He talked about dispersal, but it's not happening."

On the Folkestone road, a white resident who did not want to be named, cannot believe the hatred the asylum seekers encounter. "The problems are overblown. A lot of those creating trouble are like sheep and listen to people who have nothing to say.

"People will tell you the refugees are all thieves, it's unbelievable what you hear. It makes me ashamed to be British. I think Dover has something to be ashamed of. I don't know what kind of noose we're making for ourselves."

Asylum: the figures

 Since 1997 the average wait to get a decision on an asylum application has dropped from two years to 13 months

 In 1998 two-thirds of applicants were between 21 and 34, with less than 5% aged 50 or over; the average age was 26

 In 1998, a total of 2,833 unaccompanied children aged 17 or under applied for asylum

 In the 11 years from 1988 to 1998 37,700 people were given leave to remain in the UK as refugees; refusals for the same period totalled 213,100

 Between December 1999 and February 2000, an average 825 applications a month were received from Serbia, Montenegro and Kosovo (the Federal Republic of Yugoslavia), and 575 applications a month from Sri Lanka
fields.bodyText: In the garden of England, a hatred is kindling. Dover is being torn apart by the presence of 700 asylum seekers and 1,400 of the port's 30,000 residents have signed a petition protesting at Kent country council's decision to add £3 to the council tax to pay for the upkeep of the refugees. Sitting in her garden, petition organiser Sheila Farrell rails against the asylum seekers. She is joined by Chris Ryan, a former fisherman, who is appalled by the impact of the newcomers on Dover. "We're trying to do something for the residents and we get called racist," says Mrs Farrell. It is not hard to see why. Mrs Farrell, together with a teacher, was behind a leaflet called Dover the Land of Plenty and subtitled "refugees, 33 reasons why we should send them back and close the door". Reason number nine claims that the local hospital has advised that should anyone have "any blood contact with these people, then medical help is of the utmost importance". Reason number 13 reads: "Pregnant refugee mothers only want brand new equipment for their new offspring. Are these infants now entitled to hold a British passport to success now that they have been born in our local hospitals?" Reason number 21 reads: "No medical checks on refugees, with the knowledge of their promiscuity and selling sex for money, who is to answer for the epidemic of venereal disease that will undoubtedly become rife." It would be wrong to dismiss Mrs Farrell as heartless. In that contradiction of Englishness, Mrs Farrell is kind to animals, and keeps a bird pool in her neat garden while disliking some human beings. Chris Ryan claims that only one in 10 of asylum seekers has a case. "At the start about 90% were genuine and 10% bogus, it's the other way round now. "People are resisting because of what they've got. They're on benefits, they're walking around with mobile phones, the latest clothes and cars. They're having the life of luxury on it. Some are sending back £500 in cash a week to Romania." Mrs Farrell joins in: "They're going into travel agents and booking flights for their families. In the post office there was uproar as one man was getting £700 in cash." Requests for names and proof are unheeded. Last summer the tension led to clashes between gangs of local youths and asylum seekers at a funfair. Local councils managed to get a dispersal system enacted and have halved the numbers of refugees in the Dover area. While the government's strategy struggles to get off the ground, Kent's reduction in refugee numbers is credited with taking some of the heat out of the situation locally. New asylum seekers are still arriving. One is Pavel, 32, a Roma from the Czech Republic. He came to Britain in January with his wife, Natasha, 31, and four children. He says that twice in his homeland a skinhead gang broke into his flat and the first time, using baseball bats, chains and sticks, attacked him, his wife and their children. After the first attack he was in hospital for three weeks. His children were so traumatised that they required psychiatric counselling. "They were scared of loud shouting and had nightmares," says Pavel. Reprisal fear He and his wife were attacked and humiliated in the street by skinheads, in a town he does not want to name for fear of reprisals if he is sent back. "The main feeling we experienced was a lack of basic dignity," says Natasha. Pavel's family of six are now living in one room of a house on £188.09 a week. They flew to Britain separately and applied for asylum at Heathrow, but came to Dover where there were already family members. The furore over asylum seekers in sections of the press, mirroring the mood among some in Dover, has produced more than just anti-refugee rhetoric. Some like Farid Kohistani, 26, from Afghanistan, have been physically attacked and he says that every day he is verbally abused. "The white tribes don't like us, we don't like them. Especially the Dover people." Now when he is sworn at, he swears back. The spikiness of this young man melts away when Farid talks about why he fled Afghanistan. He and his family were opposed to the Taliban regime. Farid himself fought against them. Within three months of the Taliban taking control of Kabul, Farid's father was murdered. His brother was killed in front of his mother and then she herself was killed. He does not know how they were killed, and he never even got to bury them. Farid arrived in Dover in July 1999. An uncle paid $9,000 (£5,600) to an agent who got him a false Pakistani passport. From Afghanistan he flew to Moscow, from where he came to Britain in the back of a lorry. The overland journey took 33 days. "I never knew what country we were in. There were 12 people in the truck. You could never feel good, you're frightened of being caught." Farid, who fears being murdered if returned to Afghanistan, was caught at Dover docks after police checked the truck. Within weeks of arriving he was attacked. Farid said: "I was on the Folkestone road. There were three of us, and four of them. They used bad language, at this time I didn't know what they said. They attacked us. They punched me in my body. It lasted three to four minutes. Nobody helped us." Now Farid makes sure that he goes out with four or five other people at night to minimise the chances of being attacked, or losing the fight. Voucher humiliation He has £37 worth of vouchers a week to live on and £10 cash. "When I use the vouchers in shops, it is horrible, horrible. The other shoppers stare, they look very bad. I feel humiliated. When you go to the shopping centre you are made to feel you're an animal, you're a dog." If the voucher system and the media attacks were designed to put pressure on asylum seekers to leave, then they are working. Farid said: "When the war in Afghanistan finishes, I go back the first day. Before I was very relaxed. Now if the English use bad language, I'm ready to fight back. All asylum seekers are." Farid stays in a hostel, owned by a woman who does not want to be named. Her windows have been broken, and she was assaulted after trying to help a refugee who was being attacked. The hostel she runs tries to provide a family atmosphere for the mainly young asylum seekers it houses. At dinner the victims of failed geo-politics - Afghans, Iraqis and Kosovans - gather in the dining room for a vegetable curry and rice. Afghani music is playing in the background, the different nationalities take it in turns to listen to their different sounds. Rahim, not his real name, is one of 800 unaccompanied minors in Kent. Aged 15, he came to Britain from north Afghanistan in June last year. He soon regrets telling his story, and as we leave he follows, pleading that his real name is not used. He fears that his classmates will turn hostile if they realise he is an asylum seeker. "I'm at college, no one knows I'm a refugee there. If my name is in your paper, I can't go to college. It's hard, someone will swear." Rahim has a one year visa to stay. "I've seen hundreds of killings. My house was near a mosque where they were killing people. They washed the blood off afterwards." He last saw his parents a year ago and does not know if they are alive or dead. He arrived in the back of a lorry, and does not realise that he arrived in Dover from France. There is little infrastructure in place to help the refugees. Every Wednesday in a drafty hall belonging to the United Reform Church asylum seekers gather for a drop in session. Teenagers play table tennis and pool, children paint, adults sit and chat while volunteers help others to fill out forms for benefits. On Tuesdays the church hall is used for English classes, run by the Reverend Norman Setchell. "I don't want to look back in five years time and hang our heads in shame because we haven't done enough," he says. "After two-and-a-half years this is still the only daytime place asylum seekers can come to in Dover. "There seems to be a feeling that the vast majority, if not all, are here on an economic bandwagon. It doesn't seem to matter that you can show statistics about 50m nomads and refugees in the world. "What bothers me is the fundamental lack of compassion coupled with the lack of knowledge and awareness of where these people come from." In the church hall is community officer PC Norman Liggins. "Everytime the press attacks asylum seekers, it doesn't help the situation on the ground. As soon as it appears in the press, feelings begin to rise, you can sense it." PC Liggins says much of the violence asylum seekers face is not reported. A dossier prepared by Dover against racism lists over 20 attacks in the past year. Some victims are too scared to speak even with anonymity, while others, under the dispersal system, have left the area. Despite the reduction in the numbers of asylum seekers, the attacks go on. Marcel Malik, 25, a Czech Roma who fled after repeated attacks by skinhead gangs, has been assaulted twice. "This situation is much better than the Czech Republic, but I'm not safe here. We can go out, but we are scared." His girlfriend's mother, a Roma, was also attacked in another incident where she was kicked by a male neighbour while on the ground. Other incidents have seen refugees driven out of their homes and reports of numerous attacks on refugee children in the school system. It is a sign of the strength of feeling the issue arouses in the town. It makes me ashamed to be British. I think Dover has something to be ashamed of. I don't know what kind of noose we're making for ourselves." webTitle: Tories blow raspberries at starry-eyed Labour claims gold.

fields.headline: Tories blow raspberries at starry-eyed Labour claims gold.
fields.trailText: The morning after Oscar night, and the air was, as usual, filled with the sound of politicians trying to scramble on to the podium and grab some of the glory.
fields.body:
The morning after Oscar night, and the air was, as usual, filled with the sound of politicians trying to scramble on to the podium and grab some of the glory.

"I'd like to thank all my team at the Department of Culture, Media and Sport," Chris Smith would say, "because this really has been a team effort. And I'd like to thank my permanent secretary, my driver, those wonderful canteen ladies, and of course Alastair Campbell for writing such a marvellous script and making sure I stuck to it!

"But most of all I want to thank you, my fellow MPs, without whom none of this could have happened. You love me, you really love me!"

Of course he couldn't say any such thing. But Janet Anderson, who appears to be in charge of helping the British film industry, such as it is, wanted to claim credit for the two Oscars won by Mike Leigh's film Topsy-Turvy. "The British have arrived!" she said, as does everyone in years when we get more than one Oscar, even if it is for best technical effects in an animated short, so pathetically grateful are we to be noticed by that big powerful nation across the Atlantic.

Peter Ainsworth, the least known member of the Tory front bench (there is only a tiny barrage of flashbulbs when he emerges from his limo at the members' entrance, and his meals out are rarely troubled by the paparazzi) felt that Phil Collins had been left out, and praised him for his Oscar.

Mr Ainsworth is a very Phil Collins sort of person. I see him in a Mondeo heading round the M25 listening to Genesis tapes while shouting into his mobile and looking for a Harvester restaurant.

As for the government, though, he thought they should be nominated for the Golden Raspberry awards, a real event that precedes the Oscars. "As the Golden Raspberry citation reads, you spend too much, you entertain no one, and you fall flat on your face," he said.

Ms Anderson remarked that his attempts at humour were "more pathetic every time". It crackled from opening sequence to closing credits. Clearly they are both aiming for best original screenplay next year.

Later Peter Kilfoyle, the minister who resigned a few months ago because he felt the government had lost touch with the heartland - meaning "poor people" - rose to speak on the Budget. Mr Kilfoyle has a soft Merseyside accent and with 10 minutes raced through his speech so that the words sounded rather less devastating than they might have. But the words on the page were powerful, even furious.

The state had failed to keep its part of the bargain with pensioners, who had paid taxes all their lives and were now being held in poverty, placated only by the "diversions" of fuel allowances and free television licences.

Ministers were too eager to blame the poor for their predicament, he said. "I don't recall the Good Samaritan telling the thieves' victim that he was the author of his own misfortunes."

He went on. The government had failed to mind the gap between reality and wishful thinking. And as for the war on benefit fraud, that was all right, but why not a war on "the people at the other end of the scale who also steal from their country".

Mr Kilfoyle's speech was fine. I saw lots of members nodding, and he was praised warmly by the next speaker, Sir Peter Tapsell, who is so grand he probably thinks a scouser is something the maid uses to clean dirty pots.

But I'm the worst person to review it. I regret to say that we Mancunians mentally switch off when we hear the authentic voice of a Liverpudlian blaming someone else for everything.

fields.headline: Some dotty, some not
fields.trailText: Council tax (Authority figures, March 27) is indeed a steeply regressive tax. But the idea that making it progressive would "penalise those famous little old ladies living on reduced incomes in big houses" is nonsense.
fields.body:
Council tax (Authority figures, March 27) is indeed a steeply regressive tax. But the idea that making it progressive would "penalise those famous little old ladies living on reduced incomes in big houses" is nonsense. Already in place are a 25% single-occupier rebate (regardless of income) and council tax benefit. Discouraging mobility through increased stamp duty is not the way to attack it: progressively slanted property tax is.
Ian Leslie
Ludlow, Salop

 In his admirable account of Elian Gonzalez's predicament (Review, March 25), Gabriel Garcia Marquez writes: "An infallible way to be well-received in the US as an immigrant is to be shipwrecked in US territorial waters." The sentence should have been amended to: "an immigrant from Cuba, although not from Haiti, Honduras, Guatemala or El Salvador." I suspect Senor Marquez knew that and did not bother to state the obvious.
Charles Glass
London
charlesg@vossnet.co.uk

 The first example of a silent full stop (Letters, March 27)? Your correspondent must still be communicating by telegram. Actually though, stop-dot-stop-com sounds more attractive.
Jonathan Ratty
Kingston, Surrey

 Some of us are in serious danger of going com.dotty.
Frank Mockler
Preston, Lancs
taaffe1@aol.com

 I am sick of dots.
Elizabeth Fiddick
Dersingham, Norfolk

 Shame on you for publishing Dr Heath's letter (March 25) responding to Polly Toynbee's article on the NHS. His letter made no attempt to answer her charges, but was merely impolite and abusive.
Russell Sweeney
Leeds

fields.headline: Refugees we like
fields.trailText: Peter Hain is reported as being ready to offer refuge to 20,000 white farmers from Zimbabwe, disturbed by the loss of what they regard as their land (Foreign Office plans Zimbabwe evacuation, March 27). Yet Britain is busy sending back genuine asylum seekers, most of whom happen to be black.
fields.body:
Peter Hain is reported as being ready to offer refuge to 20,000 white farmers from Zimbabwe, disturbed by the loss of what they regard as their land (Foreign Office plans Zimbabwe evacuation, March 27). Yet Britain is busy sending back genuine asylum seekers, most of whom happen to be black.

One case in point. One evening last week a black Zimbabwean detained for months in Campsfield House, a known member of the opposition, in great fear of imprisonment or worse at the hands of Mugabe's "security" forces, received notice from immigration of the refusal of his appeal. The next morning he was taken away at dawn to be deported, with no chance of contacting his lawyer, who was ready to launch an appeal against deportation, nor of saying goodbye to his friends. He has promised to write, but not I fear with good news.

Similar cases are happening all the time. Things will get much worse for those few able to reach this country when the new Immigration and Asylum Act comes into force next week.
Helen Kimble
Oxford
hkimble@eggconnect.net

 So the UK faces the possible influx of 20,000 white Zimbabweans. Will the tabloid newpapers and those vocal racists create a furore and claim that these "spongers" will abuse our welfare provisions and beg on the streets?
AJ Blackmore
London

fields.headline: More nuclear fall-out
fields.trailText: The scapegoating of Sellafield workers provides a classic example of collective self-denial by the nuclear industry establishment. Although the falsification of fuel data scandal may have been the catalyst for the current crisis in nuclear power, the roots of the problem lie much deeper (Fresh blow to nuclear power plant, March 27).
fields.body:
The scapegoating of Sellafield workers provides a classic example of collective self-denial by the nuclear industry establishment. Although the falsification of fuel data scandal may have been the catalyst for the current crisis in nuclear power, the roots of the problem lie much deeper (Fresh blow to nuclear power plant, March 27). The construction of Thorp, and the reprocessing of spent fuel long after its original rationale had become obsolete, can now be seen as one of the biggest and most expensive mistakes in British public policy since the war.

The only way out of this mess is for BNFL to finally accept that there is no future in reprocessing or the manufacture of MOX fuel; and that it should concentrate on the rapidly expanding business of nuclear clean-up, decommissioning and waste management. Allowing the privatisation process to flush out the unsustainable economics of reprocessing and MOX is not now an immediate option. Consequently, a clear lead from the Government on the future direction of BNFL would be extremely useful.

There is one thing we can be grateful for, however. Given the 60 tonnes of plutonium currently stored at Sellafield, it does at least look as if nuclear reprocessing is coming to an end with a whimper and not with a bang.
David Chaytor MP
chaytor@ilovebury.co.uk

 An historic opportunity is beginning to emerge for the government from the ruins of BNFL. Abandoning plutonium separation at Sellafield not only opens the way for a safer, less polluting policy of used nuclear fuel storage in the UK (including storage of foreign used fuel until supplier countries construct their own facilities) but also creates an opportunity for this country to take the lead on a comprehensive fissile materials cut-off treaty.

Instead of going into next month's review of the nuclear non-proliferation treaty embarrassingly empty handed, as noted by Menzies Campbell (Petrified by our nuclear arsenal, March 24), the government has an opportunity to go to the review ready to canvass support for a truly ethical foreign policy - a global ban on the separation of plutonium for any purpose - military or civil.

Such a move would focus international attention where it is now urgently needed - on France and its huge plutonium plant at the tip of the Normandy peninsula. It is as vital to stop the French plutonium trade as it is the British. Government action on this may ruffle feathers in Paris, but it would remove the charge of inertia on its election manifesto pledge to work for a nuclear weapon free world - an end as much in France's interests as our own.
Cllr Ken Wyatt
Chair, UK Nuclear Free Local Authorities
nfznsc@gn.apc.org

 It's enlightening that the most effective way of closing a nuclear installation is economic rather than popular protest.
Chris Jeffries
Cheadle Hulme, Cheshire
ChrisJeffries1@compuserve.com

fields.headline: Showdown
fields.trailText: It is a pity that John Willis, in his blanket condemnation of arts programmes on British television (Arts: going down the tube? Media Guardian, March 27) failed to mention the South Bank Show. Perhaps it would contradict his gloomy thesis?
fields.body:
It is a pity that John Willis, in his blanket condemnation of arts programmes on British television (Arts: going down the tube? Media Guardian, March 27) failed to mention the South Bank Show. Perhaps it would contradict his gloomy thesis?

Since January the South Bank Show has produced programmes on Shakespeare, Sam Mendes, Michael Douglas, Chuck Close and Emir Kusturica. Our next three programmes will be on Martin Amis - his relationship with Kingsley - and two programmes with Simon Rattle exploring his work on two new compositions by British composers. In my view these programmes are made to an extremely high standard, as awards here and abroad confirm. They gain audiences averaging over 1.5m late on a Sunday evening.
