fields.headline: Pope Pius XII was (wasn't) anti-semitic
fields.trailText: During his visit to Yad Vashem (Tears at memorial, March 24), the Pope assured the Jewish people that "the Catholic Church ... is deeply saddened by the hatred, acts of persecution and displays of anti-semitism directed against the Jews by Christians".
fields.body:
During his visit to Yad Vashem (Tears at memorial, March 24), the Pope assured the Jewish people that "the Catholic Church ... is deeply saddened by the hatred, acts of persecution and displays of anti-semitism directed against the Jews by Christians".

Is he apologising for the Vatican's response to the Vichy government's anti-semitic law passed on June 2, 1941 that, "In principle, there is nothing in these measures which the holy see would ... criticise?"

Is he apologising for Pope Pius XII's reported reply to Dr Eduardo Senatro, the Berlin correspondent of L'Osservatore Romano, who asked whether the Pope would protest against the extermination of the Jews: "Dear Friend, do not forget that millions of Catholics serve in the German armies. Shall I bring them into conflicts of conscience?"

If the Pope is "deeply saddened" by these utterances, why is he beatifying Pope Pius XII, the man responsible for such anti-semitic statements?
Fred Lowe
Dublin

 Your photo (The Vatican's silent concord, March 24) is misleading. It actually shows the then Archbishop Pacelli in Berlin, some 10 years before he became pope. He left Berlin in 1929 - four years before Hitler came to power - and never returned.

At no time did Pius XII "welcome" the Nazis. It is on record that he considered a Nazi victory in Europe would be a disaster for Christianity.

In February 1944, Maurice L Perlzweig of the World Jewish Congress, wrote that: "The repeated interventions of the Holy Father on behalf of Jewish communities in Europe has evoked the profoundest sentiments of appreciation and gratitude from Jews throughout the world."
Felicity O'Brien
Petts Wood, Kent
fobrien@rcsouthwark.co.uk

 Over the past week at least five articles have stated as a fact that Pope Pius XII did nothing to help the Jews during the Nazi persecution. In fact, the Jewish historian Pinchas Lapide estimated that the Pope was instrumental in saving 860,000 Jewish people. Indeed, Emilio Zolli, the chief rabbi of Rome during the war, was so impressed with the efforts of the Pope on behalf of the Jews that he later became a Catholic.
David Paton
Nottingham

fields.headline: What is Britain for?
fields.standfirst: Blair is right to raise the question
fields.trailText: One of the most frequently heard criticisms of today's politicians is that they too rarely rise above the day-to-day to address the big picture. In what is casually referred to as this post-ideological age, our representatives fight shy of the grand, sweeping vision. They prefer to stick to this tax scheme, that guideline rather than the loftier terrain of national destiny.
fields.body:
One of the most frequently heard criticisms of today's politicians is that they too rarely rise above the day-to-day to address the big picture. In what is casually referred to as this post-ideological age, our representatives fight shy of the grand, sweeping vision. They prefer to stick to this tax scheme, that guideline rather than the loftier terrain of national destiny. So when they dare talk big, we ought to applaud them, if only for trying. That is why we welcome the speech on Britishness and national identity that will be delivered today by the prime minister. We do not yet know every word he will say, but we are glad he is doing it. Leaders need to have a view of the country they lead. It is murky, vague stuff, but essential. We are glad, too, that his speech is not to be a token, one-off event. Instead it will be followed by variations on the same theme from Gordon Brown, Jack Straw and several others. Perhaps politicians in other countries would find such a collective round of head-scratching puzzling.

But in Britain, at least since the war, there has been uncertainty about Britain's place in the world, even about its fundamental purpose. As Dean Acheson remarked so pithily, Britain lost an empire and had to find a role. Mr Blair's predecessors have all sought to come up with an answer. Britain would be Greece to America's Rome, offered Harold Macmillan. We would be the home of white-hot technology, suggested Harold Wilson. We would be a proud, capitalistic, semi-imperial nation once more, dreamed a flag-waving and hopelessly England-centric Margaret Thatcher. But none of those answers ever quite filled the gap.

Now the hole where our idea of Britain should be is becoming more troubling. There are pressures from all sides. Nationalists in Scotland and Wales are de manding the break-up of Britain: what case can the union make in its own defence? Others imagine a federal Europe in which England or Scotland or Wales might have its own place, but with little need for the four-nation unit of the United Kingdom. Globalisation is playing a part, too: why do we need a structure like Britain, when we can be part of something so much larger - the world? Fuelling these questions have been historians like Linda Colley and Norman Davies, who have argued that Britain was only ever an artificial construct, stitched together for the purposes of empire. Now that the sun has set on that empire, the need for the union has gone.

Not so, says Labour which, in an unexpected twist, finds itself cast as the unionist party of Great Britain. It argues that even if the union was a mere political project once, it is now a cultural fact with over 300 years to put down real roots. Britishness has become part of us, which cannot easily be discarded. Moreover, the government reckons Britain has far from outlived its usefulness. For it provides an umbrella which, by its nature, covers the full range of people living on these islands. Invented as a cobble-together of distinct nations, Britishness contains the very idea of difference within it. So, just as you can be Scottish and British or Welsh and British, you can now be Pakistani and British or Jewish and British without any contradiction. Britishness may well be the first nationality in the world which is inherently comfortable with dual or even multiple identity. As Britain becomes a more multicultural country, this facet of Britishness becomes an invaluable asset. Mr Blair is right to celebrate that today, and to launch a debate on what else this Britain of ours actually means - and what it might be for.

fields.headline: Education: local or central control?
fields.trailText: Neither I nor the LGA have any problems with the extra money for schools going to them directly (Blunkett doubles budget for school repairs, March 24). Our concern is that the government may change the entire system for funding education along similar lines.
fields.body:
Neither I nor the LGA have any problems with the extra money for schools going to them directly (Blunkett doubles budget for school repairs, March 24). Our concern is that the government may change the entire system for funding education along similar lines. That would involve an unacceptable and impractical extension of central control over the service that needs to be planned and administered locally in an accountable manner. The LGA is open to new ideas. For example, the government could assume responsibility for funding teachers' pay to an agreed national pupil/teacher ratio, leaving authorities free to augment teacher numbers if they and the schools wish to do so.
Sir Jeremy Beecham
Local Government Association

 Now there is local management of schools the work of running them is done by heads and governors, which raises the question of why local education authorities still exist? It is far more efficient and democratic for governors representing parents, teachers and the local community to run the school with direct funding from the DfEE. This way the money is used to raise standards by spending it on teachers and equipment instead of more bureaucrats. With the new executive boards in local government, parents will have even less chance of finding out what is happening to their school.
Dr JR Langan
Leeds

fields.headline: Crushing hatreds
fields.standfirst:
As the first anniversary highlighted Nato's failures, it became fashionable to despair about Kosovo

Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: As the first anniversary highlighted Nato's failures, it became fashionable to despair about Kosovo.
fields.body:
A year after the start of Nato's air strikes against Yugoslavia it is becoming fashionable to question whether Nato was right to intervene in Kosovo. Opponents of the war have seized on continuing tensions in the province to argue that nothing was achieved by Nato's action. Yet to imagine that there was any cost-free alternative to military action a year ago is to enter the realm of make-believe. The result of Nato doing nothing would have been a newly divided Europe, with much of the Balkans consigned forever to an outer darkness in which human rights count for nothing. No one who understood that danger a year ago has any reason to alter their view today.

The present risk does not come from any doubt about the rightness of Nato intervention. It comes from the failure so far of the allies to follow through with the civilian and military resources that are needed to make it work. By the end of the war most of the infrastructure needed for any kind of civilised life had ceased to exist in Kosovo. The devastation was not only physical. Most of the institutional infrastructure had broken down as well. Police and law courts, education and health care had all been massively disrupted. The task faced by the allies when Nato ended its air campaign was not just peace-keeping. It was building the institutions of a modern civil society and state.

Both the magnitude and the difficulties of this task have been underestimated. A massive programme of civilian aid will be required to get the province back on its feet. Yet it remains an open question whether the resources will be forthcoming on the scale that is required. The countries that managed to screw up the resolution needed to take military action - despite their genuine and in some contexts continuing differences of outlook and purpose - are finding that shouldering its consequences imposes unexpectedly heavy burdens. It is finally beginning to sink in that the allies' commitment to Kosovo cannot be a matter of months or years. On any realistic scenario it must be counted in decades.

In the aftermath of the war, Kosovo was in a condition of anarchy. Worse, the stage was set for another round of ethnic conflict. Serbs who feared revenge attacks from Kosovo's returning Albanians have fled in large numbers. Those who remain live in an atmosphere of dread and insecurity. It is wishful thinking to expect this situation to improve greatly over the next few years. Despite the achievements of international agencies over the past nine months, Kosovo's recent history has left a climate of vendetta and mutual hatred that could last for generations.

In these circumstances, the international community's determination that it will not abandon the goal of multi-ethnic democracy in the province may prove to be misplaced. Democratic institutions are not workable when society is divided into ethnic groups that hate and mistrust one another with the intensity of feeling that exists in Kosovo. It is not inconceivable that the price of democracy in the province will turn out to be further population transfers.

Yet even partition - admitted or de facto - is not a risk-free solution. Any shift in policy on the part of the international community that appears to put the present, horribly fragile status quo in Kosovo into question will have knock-on effects throughout the region. The break-up of what is left of Yugoslavia would leave it desperately unstable. There is no magic wand which the international community can wave that will make the region's problems suddenly tractable.

It is at this point that we reach the heart of the difficulty. On any short- or medium-term time-scale the problems of the region are not fully soluble. They arise from the political vacuum created by the fragmentation of the multinational Yugoslav state and the anarchy that has followed the collapse of communism in Albania. In a more extended historical perspective, they are the long-delayed aftershock of the break-up of the Habsburg and Ottoman empires in the aftermath of the first world war.

Ultimately, the problems faced in Kosovo today come from the fact that in the Balkans the principle of national self-determination is a recipe for unending conflict. The shifting, post-imperial mosaic of peoples in the region cannot be organised in nation-states without horrendous suffering. Peace and the infrastructure of civilised life cannot be achieved in Kosovo unless the province is placed under long-term international trusteeship. Without fully realising it, the international community committed itself to some such outcome when it sanctioned Nato intervention. Whether we like it or not we are in for a very long haul.

Building consensus on a long-term presence in Kosovo will be far from easy. Nato's member-states are all of them in some degree post-military societies. Their citizens view costly military commitments of indeterminate duration with deep suspicion. As was shown by the reaction to Mr Blair's resolute stance throughout the Kosovo war, the public can be unstinting in its support for decisive action in support of human rights. But it is notably less enthusiastic when it comes to footing the bill. Using soldiers to protect human rights in far-away countries costs money. It pre-empts resources that could be used for schools and hospitals. The reaction to the dislocated casualties of such conflicts when they turn up on London's streets suggests that public altruism is severely limited.

Public opinion has not yet understood that protecting human rights across all of Europe will use up much of the peace dividend that came with the end of the cold war. Understandably, politicians are reluctant to press the point. There are not many votes in dwelling on the cost of coping with intractable problems. Yet if voters are not educated in the cost of peace in Europe it will not be secure. The risk is that, as public support ebbs away, the international agencies in Kosovo will be starved of the resources they need. At worst, the whole international presence could be cut back, with the Balkans drifting slowly into an unmanageable chaos.

Nato's action was a response to the danger of a redivided Europe. If it had not intervened, Europe's Orthodox and Muslim regions would have ended up beyond the pale of civilised life, prey to ruthless tyranny and subject to gross abuses of human rights. That prospect has been averted. But it has not been removed. If the international community fails to deliver on the commitment it has made, the aftermath of the war in Kosovo may come to be remembered as the time when the redivision of Europe began.

 John Gray is professor of European thought at the London School of Economics.

webTitle: French colonel held over leaked Kosovo papers

fields.headline: French colonel held over leaked Kosovo papers
fields.standfirst: Kosovo: special report
fields.trailText: A French gendarmerie colonel is being held in custody for revealing details of the army's allegedly pro-Serb policy in Kosovo, raising more doubts about the strength of France's military commitment to the west's stance in the province.
fields.body:
A French gendarmerie colonel is being held in custody for revealing details of the army's allegedly pro-Serb policy in Kosovo, raising more doubts about the strength of France's military commitment to the west's stance in the province.

Jean-Michel Méchain, a gendarmerie lawyer, was questioned by an examining magistrate, Jean-Louis Bruguière, yesterday, after the leaking of army documents criticising the UN administrator for Kosovo, Frenchman Bernard Kouchner, for being anti-Serb.

Six weeks ago Col Méchain, who supports Dr Kouchner, was recalled from Kosovo where he was the legal adviser to the commander of the French K-For contingent, General Louis Le Mière.

In a classified report to the defence ministry and senior officers, published by French newspapers, the general said that French soldiers were fed up with what they saw as Dr Kouchner's partiality towards ethnic Albanians.

The former humanitarian affairs minister was implicitly blamed for the tension in the divided Kosovan town of Mitrovice, where ethic Albanians and Serbs have frequently clashed.

The area is controlled by French troops but after questions about the French army's neutrality, other K-For troops were brought in to help.

The colonel was sent back to France from Pristina on February 14 and has since been pursued by the DST, the country's counter-intelligence service.

A week ago, he was involved in an incident in a Paris street while being followed by eight secret servicemen. Police had to be called after an exchange of insults and blows. Col Méchain made an official complaint against DST harassment shortly before he was arrested.

The French defence minister, Alain Richard, has refused to explain why the colonel, who was awaiting promotion to general, has been arrested. But he said that Gen Le Mière had sent the officer home because he was a "bit exalted".

Since the beginning of the Balkans crisis, the French army has frequently been accused of pro-Serb bias. In Nato investigations into leaks of sensitive information to Belgrade, France has always emerged as the principal suspect.

France has also been criticised by the United States for its reluctance to join Nato's bombing campaign last year.

webTitle: Police warn doctor over trip to Iraq

fields.headline: Police warn doctor over trip to Iraq
fields.trailText: The government was yesterday accused of trying to intimidate opponents of its policy on Iraq after it emerged that an Iraqi-born British doctor has been visited by a special branch officer in an effort to dissuade him from attending an expatriates' conference in Baghdad.
fields.body:
The government was yesterday accused of trying to intimidate opponents of its policy on Iraq after it emerged that an Iraqi-born British doctor has been visited by a special branch officer in an effort to dissuade him from attending an expatriates' conference in Baghdad.

A Thames Valley police spokesman confirmed yesterday that a detective constable had gone unexpectedly last Wednesday to the Oxfordshire home of Jerrard Misconi, 66, a retired orthopaedic surgeon, on behalf of the government.

"We did go and see him last week to pass on a message from the Foreign Office advising him against travelling back to Iraq," the spokesman said.

Mr Misconi, a British citizen who has been living in Britain since 1964, had been planning to accompany his wife on the humanitarian trip to Baghdad planned earlier this month by a Labour MP, George Galloway. The flight was cancelled after delays and restrictions demanded by British and American officials.

The conference Mr Misconi planned to attend discusses issues such as dual citizenship problems. "The plainclothes policeman who came to my house told me 'we have reservations about this conference'. He claimed it would give Saddam Hussein money, technology and a propaganda platform, and allow him to recruit agents from those attending," said Mr Misconi.

Last night Mr Galloway said he would protest to the home secretary about the "disturbing use of the police for a political purpose".

The Home Office said that the police had visited "some Iraqis" who had been invited to the conference organised by the Iraqi government.

fields.headline: Sidelines
fields.trailText: Instant karma? | VPL-and-be-damned
fields.body:
It's not as though one leaps upon any excuse for instant gratification in this cruel and fickle world, but Sidelines would like to lodge a formal complaint about the latest development in cheer-your-life paraphernalia: karma beads. Spurred into purchasing one of the dainty wee bangles through a sorry desperation to fit in, Sidelines has since noticed something peculiar. The charming lady bead-seller may have insisted the jolly orange colour means "blessing" but as far as I can discern from subsequent wear, it instead signifies "illness", "distress" and "wide-ranging disaster", culminating in a near fatal tea spilling last week, which occurred in suspiciously close proximity to said life-enhancing bangle. Am I wearing it upside down? Does it speak to a deeper feng shui issue? Perhaps the rubbish bin's in my fulfilment corner.

 Where will it all end? Tesco is pioneering the latest in internet shopping: click and sniff. Online purchasers will be able to select smells from a palette of chemicals plugged into their computer, thus an order for a pound of Danish will be accompanied by the scent of fried bacon. But what of the piquant whiff of strong bleach, the waft of raw prawns? The stench of trolley rage, the niff of screaming toddlers? Presumably those will be left to our imagination.

 Not content with making the worst pantyliner ads on the planet, Bodyform's latest padding innovation leaves us a mite queasy. Sidelines has always stood firmly in the VPL-and-be-damned camp as far as the Great Thong Debate is concerned. The introduction of pantyliners for said thongs - tiny wee slivers that look like they could no sooner absorb than swim the Channel - confirms the rectitude of our stance. At least you know where you are with a knicker line.

 So Johnny Depp is to play Robert Burns in a new film about the life of Scotland's national poet. Jolly good. As a Scot, I can confirm that there are no actors whatsoever from north of the border (all right, one or two, but they're only good at playing loonies) as we are a retiring nation, much preferring to watch movies about us filmed in other places, acted by other people.

webTitle: To have and to hold hands

fields.headline: To have and to hold hands
fields.standfirst: Jenny Madden  considers Posh and Becks' public displays of affection
fields.trailText: Jenny Madden  considers Posh and Becks' public displays of affection
fields.body:
They're at it again. As Victoria and David Beckham emerged from Browns' nightclub in London's Covent Garden at the weekend, sporting new hair and new-made-to-look-fashionably-old outfits, the only thing continuous about these sartorial chameleons was the body language. As ever, their hands were sweetly entwined, Posh very much in the lead as she strode forward, lips pursed shut, leading a lagging Beckham behind her.

Not that there's anything unusual about newlyweds holding hands. And in the case of the Beckhams, constantly in the media glare, who can blame them for wanting, literally, to stick together? Posh's Spice colleague Baby has been known to wax lyrical about the fact that, even when the pair are holding separate conversations at parties, they continue to hold hands, inseparable in body and spirit, one presumes. How sweet. How symbolic. How trying.

Do you remember the first time you held hands with a boy in public? Did it seem wildly grown-up and sophisticated, a rite of passage from girlhood to womanhood, an intimate early expression of undying devotion for all to see? Or was the experience marred by his sweaty palms and ragged fingernails? Was it just plain embarrassing?

Bombarded as we are with folk doing the nasty right, left and centre - on screen, in advertising and, if the conversation's really bad, in the pub - holding hands in public seems fairly innocuous. But when you're 13 years old and up till then have held hands only for practical reasons like crossing a busy road, it can seem thoroughly scandalous.

But then again, does the fear of showing mutual affection in public ever really disappear? A quick poll suggests not. Siobhan Lewis, a 29-year-old PR exec, is a pragmatic paw-handler. "I'd never do it on a busy street," she says. "Doing that whole 'Look at us, we're so in love and no one can tear us apart' thing just becomes an affectation when it gets in the way of people trying to walk along the road."

Sarah McIntosh, a 24-year-old administrator, is firmly against the whole enterprise. "I hate holding hands with my boyfriend in public. I was single for years before I met him and whenever I saw couples holding hands, it looked really naff and sappy, especially when it was done by the kind of couples who dress identically. I'd be such a hypocrite if I started doing it now."

Simon Coles, a 25-year-old researcher, says he thinks it's "quite sweet" to hold hands with his girlfriend, with one condition: that he doesn't get dragged along like a sulky child. "I went out shopping with one girlfriend and I was getting bored after a few hours and dragging my heels a bit. Suddenly she grabbed my hand and, with this kind of joke mumsy voice, said: 'Come along now, Simon' and started literally dragging me along the road. That really annoyed me."

And so we see that, as with all expressions of affection, hand-holding can be open to subtle abuses, easily imbued with the underlying power dynamics of the relationship. Who'd have thought such a simple, romantic guesture could be so richly deconstructed? Still, these are lean times and we'll analyse anything if the price is right.

Meanwhile, let's be thankful that hand-holding in public retains at least a modicum of innocence. There are, after all, far more embarrassing ways of asserting the power play of your relationship and far more nausea-inducing parts of the anatomy to grasp. Clamping a possessive hand over your partner's arse is surely the nadir of public body contact. Perhaps I am disproportionately repelled by this practice, having had the misfortune to grow up near a biker couple who, permanently dressed in matching leather jackets bearing the legends Mr Animal and Mrs Animal, frequently sauntered down my street with Mr clutching Mrs' rear end. The fact that this impaired her ability to walk straight appeared not to trouble her husband.

But perhaps I should be grateful that, at such a young age, I was instilled with an acute sense of public affection consciousness. I doubt I'm the only one who finds this kind of thing repulsive. We've all seen pictures of Hugh Grant, photographed far more than is seemly with one grubby mitt clamped to his long-suffering girlfriend's posterior, in a gesture that allows only one reading: she is mine. At least with the Beckhams there is room for multiple interpretations.

webTitle: Gore to clean up campaign finance

fields.headline: Gore to clean up campaign finance
fields.standfirst: The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Al Gore yesterday unveiled a plan for campaign finance reform, promising to limit the role of big money in US politics by banning unregulated "soft" political financing and to create a $7bn publicly-run endowment to pay for general election campaigns.
fields.body:
Al Gore yesterday unveiled a plan for campaign finance reform, promising to limit the role of big money in US politics by banning unregulated "soft" political financing and to create a $7bn publicly-run endowment to pay for general election campaigns.

The vice-president's initiative is evidence that this year's campaign by John McCain against the influence of well-funded special interests has had a lasting impact on US politics. Despite Senator McCain's defeat in the Republican party primaries this month, the vigour of his campaign demonstrated widespread support for political reform.

Mr Gore's proposals reflect a concerted strategy to win over Mr McCain's supporters among independents and moderate Republicans in his electoral duel with George W Bush, the Texas governor who opposes radical campaign finance reform.

Mr Bush denounced his presidential rival's initiative as unnecessary state interference in political campaigning, and reminded Mr Gore of his role in past Democratic fundraising scandals. Mr Gore repeated his admission of past mistakes yesterday, describing himself as an "imperfect messenger" for reform.

Tens of millions of dollars are siphoned into party campaigns through a loophole in finance law which allows businesses, unions and other organisations to fund political and issue-oriented advertising, provided that advertising does not explicitly advocate voting for a particular candidate. This "soft" financing is not subject to federal limits.

Mr Gore said yesterday that his first priority as president would be to push for the passage of legislation to ban all soft financing, tabled last year by Mr McCain and a Democratic senator, Russ Feingold.

"If you elect me as president," Mr Gore said, "the McCain-Feingold bill will be the first domestic legislation I send to the congress on my first day in office."

Under the plan, the opaque role of soft campaign financing would be largely replaced by a transparent and publicly managed "democracy endowment", a $7.1bn (£4.3bn) fund amassed from public and private tax-deductible contributions to be supervised by a board of trustees confirmed by the senate. From its interest earnings, the endowment would pay for congressional and presidential campaigns on condition that recipient candidates did not accept money from other sources.

Mr Bush said the scheme represented "a government takeover that replaces individual spending decisions with decisions by an unelected government committee".

He made a clear reference to Mr Gore's misconduct in the 1996 election, when the vice-president broke federal rules by fundraising from White House telephones and seeking financial contributions at a religious institution, a Buddhist temple - actions which earned him rebuke from congressional investigators.

"Any promise to reform our campaign finance system will ring hollow unless it is grounded in credibility, credibility based on consistency, integrity and disclosure," Mr Bush said.

fields.headline: Dial M for murder
fields.standfirst: A Bristol man made 4,000 nuisance calls to women, before he strangled one.  Raekha Prasad asks whether his conviction last week will change the way we handle telephone harassment
fields.trailText: A Bristol man made 4,000 nuisance calls to women, before he strangled one.  Raekha Prasad asks whether his conviction last week will change the way we handle telephone harassment
fields.body:
The first call got me out of bed. It was midnight, I was reading and my female housemate was out. There was silence at the other end and I hung up. The phone rang again, and again. Until, by the tenth call, I no longer said hello but just lifted the receiver and listened to the silence.

I dialled 1471 and was told the caller had withheld their number. I phoned BT. They told me it was probably a fax left on redial and to turn off the ringer.

The next night it started again but this time I waited on the line. Hanging up meant they had won. After a couple of minutes, a man's voice whispered: "I've got your number." I phoned BT again and was told there was nothing they could do until the morning. And until then? The male operator asked if "females" lived in the house, then suggested we get a man to leave a message on our answering machine. Next morning, I rang BT again, had a trace put on the line and installed on our machine the standard BT answering message.

More than 97,000 requests were made for traces last year. Since 1992, when BT set up its Nuisance Calls Bureau, half of all calls reported have been silent, 15% are obscene and sexual, and most are made to women. Research shows two-thirds of nuisance calls are aimed at us.

The image of the lonely wanker heavy-breathing down the line took a more serious turn last week when a Bristol man was convicted of sexually assaulting and murdering a woman on the same day that he made threatening calls to 80 other women. In the six months preceding Jenny King's murder, Paul Hunt made 4,000 calls to women, but local police say these came to light only after he was arrested and his phone bills examined. He was a random caller: each time he dialled, he altered the last digit. If a man answered, he hung up. The police say that, to their knowledge, none of the women reported the calls.

Why? Was it that they weren't frightened by the threats? That they thought nothing could be done? Or, worse, that the threat didn't feel out of the ordinary? It is significant that only when Hunt was convicted was his prolific phoning revealed. Until then, the calls barely featured in the hierarchy of harassment. Sexual harassment by telephone is in fact so ordinary that, according to Home Office research, one in 10 women receives obscene calls every year. Single, separated and divorced young women are the most likely targets and four out of five calls come at home, usually in the afternoon or evening.

Equally, there is little obviously out of the ordinary about the callers. Research by sex offences consultant Ray Wyre found that, in a sample of offenders, 40% were aged 26-30 and 41% single. Of the 43% who made random calls, many got numbers from local classified and dating ads. The majority of calls, however, are made to women known to the caller. And the telephone may be the first step in an escalation of stalking.

Claire Finch's first few encounters with a man who stalked her for four months began on the phone. The man was from the same town and got her number from the phone book. Though she reported his calls to the police and was able to get the numbers of the phone boxes from which he called, BT did not change her number immediately and after yet another midnight call, she began to panic.

"Was he close to home? In my area? Known to me? His silence became violence," says Finch, 29. "I was shaking then and convinced the person at the end knew I was on my own."

When her number was changed, the harassment intensified. The police have now arrested the man but Finch says she refuses to give her number to anyone she doesn't know well and is ex-directory. "In the wrong hands," she says, "the phone is a weapon."

BT advises not to enter into conversation with a caller. Put the receiver down for 10 minutes, then replace it. Don't leave your name or number on the answering machine. Under the Telecommunications Act 1984, a malicious caller may be fined up to £5,000 and/or face a maximum of six months in prison. The fact that obscene calls receive low rating as a serious form of harassment is perhaps due to the fact that the violence is psychological rather than physical. Wyre cites research that shows women who have experienced phone harassment judge the effect on them as worse than women who have not experienced it. Significantly, in all other forms of harassment, the opposite is the case, suggesting women underestimate the effect of psychological harassment - until it happens to them.

"Most people have no idea how phone calls can create a feeling of threat," Wyre says. He believes advising women to change their number is unhelpful: "Most men who sexually harass are into the thrill of the chase and will want to find out the new number." Instead, Wyre says BT "should give women the choice of putting another line in free of charge" thus wrong-footing the harasser.

Betsy Stanco, professor of criminology at Royal Holloway, University of London, says obsence calls are part of the continuum of sexual harassment. "Making some forms more relevant than others creates a hierarchy of what is considered dangerous," she says. "What is important is the way the phone fits into a wider web of sexual intimidation. The receiver understands that call within a wider experience of harassment: that any woman on the end of a phone is accessible, available. She understands that, at random or in particular, a man can target a woman because he wants to and that it would work. The calls tap into social relations between men and women that have used power."

In the case of my caller, I didn't want a male voice on my answering machine, or to wonder if it was him every time I picked up my phone, or to waste precious time alone wondering if I were being watched, or have to record every silent call on a time sheet. After a few weeks, BT told us that 80% of the calls we had recorded came from the same number. At the same time, the calls became less frequent and then stopped. Our house had a new resident who appeared to have put our caller off: a man.

webTitle: Dentists told not to pull wisdoms

fields.headline: Dentists told not to pull wisdoms
fields.trailText: Dentists were advised yesterday that healthy wisdom teeth should no longer be removed on the NHS, even if patients ask, thus saving the service £5m a year.
fields.body:
Dentists were advised yesterday that healthy wisdom teeth should no longer be removed on the NHS, even if patients ask, thus saving the service £5m a year.

The advice from the National Institute for Clinical Excellence, which will be commented on later by the Department of Health, is among a range of measures designed to end the prescription of certain drugs and treatments on the NHS.

It covers only impacted teeth, those wisdom teeth that do not come through normally, and does not apply if the wisdom teeth are diseased or the patient has other oral conditions.

The institute said there were two reasons for its recommendation: first, there was no reliable research to suggest that the removal of disease-free wisdom teeth benefited patients; second, patients who did have otherwise healthy wisdom teeth removed were being needlessly exposed to the risks of surgery, including nerve damage, damage to other teeth, infection, bleeding and, in extreme cases, death.

Impacted wisdoms occur when the other teeth grow to the extent there is a shortage of room in the jaw when the wisdoms come through. But, said the institute, in many cases the problem righted itself.

The advice was posted to dentists in England to arrive yesterday, and NHS trusts are being told to review their waiting lists for dentists and surgeons, to review cases, bringing in patients if advisable, and to see if they can cancel such operations. The advice was welcomed by the Royal College of Surgeons of England, as broadly following its recommendations of 1997.

Up to 40% of wisdom teeth operations are done only as a precaution, said Andrew Dillon, the institute's chief executive. If dentists and surgeons followed the insititute's advice, it would almost halve the 50,000 carried out every year in England, and the 3,000 in Wales. Mr Dillon said: "Until it is clearly a problem, there is no reason to do the surgery.

"Sometimes the teeth can right themselves and sometimes, even though they impact, they somehow sort themselves out and there is still no problem. It's the idea that we do the surgery on the off-chance that we are addressing." Not only would waiting lists be shortened and surgeons freed for other work, £5m could be saved on the NHS budget.

The advice is the first in a stream of guidance from the institute, which was set up to evaluate medicines, equipment and procedures for the NHS. It expects to issue guidance on a range of medical issues every week or two.

webTitle: Moors try to revive charabanc tourism

fields.headline: Moors try to revive charabanc tourism
fields.trailText: The heyday of the charabanc trip and works outing is to be revived by one of Britain's wildest national parks, after surveys which suggest that visitors are overwhelmingly from the wealthier end of society.
fields.body:
The heyday of the charabanc trip and works outing is to be revived by one of Britain's wildest national parks, after surveys which suggest that visitors are overwhelmingly from the wealthier end of society.

Leaflets and slideshows will be taken to inner city areas of the north by staff from the North York Moors park, to try to revive the original concept of "people's parks" which drove the national park movement under Clement Attlee's post-war Labour government.

Pubs and chip shops in deprived areas of Middlesbrough, Hull and other centres will be used as bases under the scheme, which follows research at park visitor centres and on the free Moorsbus services which cross the huge tracts of heather inland from Whitby and Scarborough.

"Taking one bit of data on newspaper readership alone," said Mike Pratt of the national park headquarters in Helmsley, North Yorkshire, "we had no end of Guardian readers on the Moorsbus last summer, but no one who took the Sun or Mirror.

"The authority is worried that the moors may be building up a bit of an exclusive image, contrary to the whole idea of green lungs for people living in urban areas - assets which were meant to be enjoyed by everybody."

The initiative will start with a programme of "more equitable" information-spreading, highlighting bus services in supermarkets on Teesside to emphasise that a car is not necessary to enjoy the moors.

Employers are also likely to be targeted, to encourage a return to the charabancs which left factories in Stockton and Hartlepool for the moors and coast almost every summer weekend in the 1920s.

Attempts will also be made to reach particular communities, notably Asian and Afro-Caribbean families, which have been relatively slow to try out the charms of the long-distance Lyke Wake Walk and the ghostly industrial archaeology of the old ironstone industry in Rosedale. Targeted infor mation in West Yorkshire has been modestly successful in increasing black and ethnic visitors to the Yorkshire Dales national park.

The initiative will finally try to tempt visitors away from a relatively small number of honeypots such as Goathland, which doubles as Aidensfield in the TV series Heartbeat and attracts readers of all known national newspapers to a village street made up of cafes and souvenir shops.

One of the distinctions of the 1920s charabancs was their intrepid willingness to toil up one in three slopes such as Rosedale Bank and take picnickers to within easy walking distance of remote standing stones like Fat Betty and Blue Man-i-th-Moss.

webTitle: Voice of the excluded debunks US politics

fields.headline: Voice of the excluded debunks US politics
fields.standfirst:
Clinton's favourite author rails against the whites-only American presidential race

The US elections: special report
fields.trailText: Bill Clinton's favourite author has entered the political arena with a call to "break the chains" of the electoral system and a scathing attack on both Democrats and Republicans.
fields.body:
Bill Clinton's favourite author has entered the political arena with a call to "break the chains" of the electoral system and a scathing attack on both Democrats and Republicans.

Walter Mosley, the author of the critically acclaimed Easy Rawlins mysteries, has delivered a savage polemic in book form in which he outlines his imaginary candidacy and platform and claims Americans have been "drugged and chained and made into property".

The author claims that the current presidential race is merely a chance to vote for "one white man in a suit over another white man in a suit".

Mosley, whom President Clinton has cited as his favourite writer, places the failure of most Americans to understand African-American history at the heart of what he sees as a catastrophic political crisis.

In his manifesto, Workin' on the Chain Gang, he outlines a radical platform which he hopes will steer political debate away from the sniping between the two main presidential candidates.

Mosley, 48, is the son of an African-American father and Jewish mother. He grew up in Los Angeles and lives in New York.

"Everywhere I look I see chains, from the planned obsolescence that binds us to an endless line of ever more useless machines to captivating television shows about nothing to the value of dollar bills nestled at the bottom of my pocket," writes Mosley, whose books include Devil in a Blue Dress, which was turned into a film starring Denzel Washington.

"My candidacy is based on my desire to break the chains of yesterday's politics," Mosley adds.

The book is receiving prominence partly because of the absence of a black voice in the presidential race and partly because of the lack of discussion of race in the campaign.

"What do we vote for?" he asks. "Is that vote enough to make us free? Voting for one white man in a suit over another white man in a suit? There are no Jews or Hispanics, American Indians or Vietnamese up there in the presidential arena. No black people either. No women either. If there's a homosexual up there, he'd better keep it hidden.

"Black people are feared, hated and blamed for all kinds of social maladies. And, having been culturally isolated for so long, we have also become celebrated curiosities who have maintained certain artistic traits that most of the white population can only mimic.

"Blues, jazz, rap, tap, slang, style and that impenetrable visage put on to protect what little freedom of personality we have managed to maintain - those attributes represent a mountain of gold that others have mined and stolen."

Among the "chains" that Mosley feels enslave the American people are "spectacle and illusion".

He writes: "The best way to keep a worker working is to bedazzle her or him. Sublimation is the best remedy for rebellion. Give them something inconsequential to think about or a dream that leads nowhere." He cites television and sports as the ideal way to keep people from complaining.

But he says that most of the population would not be able to exist without illusion. "To give up the lies of the nightly news magazines, the fantasies of professional sports and the melodrama of the soaps would be harder than training for a marathon. To face one's own life with all of its inadequacies, for 12 weeks - a great many Americans just could not do it."

Mosley makes it clear he does not believe there is a sim ple ideological solution to the crisis. "I am not looking to the socialist or communist experiments of the 20th century to answer our economic or social problems. Instead I want to look directly into the voracious maw of capitalism to see if there is a way to survive the onslaught."

He adds: "Our systems are nearly perfect but our minds are no more advanced than a dog's nose."

As part of his platform, Mosley calls for the decriminalisation of drugs.

During the last week, Americans were dramatically reminded of an important part of African-American history.

Jamil Abdullah Al-Amin, who, as H Rap Brown, was a leading member of the Black Panthers in the 60s, was arrested and charged with killing a sheriff's deputy in Atlanta, Georgia. As he was taken out of the courthouse he told reporters: "It's a government conspiracy, man."

The day after his arrest, another former Black Panther leader, Bobby Rush, won the Democratic nomination for the post of mayor of Chicago.

fields.headline: Britons steal the Oscars show
fields.standfirst: Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: They have won more Oscars before, but the Brits stole the show at the Academy Awards, with Sam Mendes's debut film American Beauty sweeping the board and Michael Caine delivering the wittiest speech of of an excruciatingly long night. "I do not feel like a winner," quipped Caine as he paid tribute to fellow Londoner Jude Law who he beat to best supporting actor. "I'm basically up here as a survivor."
fields.body:
They have won more Oscars before, but the Brits stole the show at the Academy Awards, with Sam Mendes's debut film American Beauty sweeping the board and Michael Caine delivering the wittiest speech of of an excruciatingly long night. "I do not feel like a winner," quipped Caine as he paid tribute to fellow Londoner Jude Law who he beat to best supporting actor. "I'm basically up here as a survivor."

Mendes too was modest in victory as American Beauty won best picture, best director, best actor, best screenplay and best cinematography awards, thanking "his boss" Steven Spielberg for trusting a "bloke from the English theatre".

A thief had made off with the Oscars the previous week, and 4,000 ballots also went missing, but on the night there was barely a suggestion that any rightful winner had been robbed. Everything went pretty much as predicted in the previous day's Wall Street Journal, which had polled members of the academy on their votes.

While actresses Janet McTeer and Samantha Morton had always been outside bets, Mike Leigh's first foray into costume drama, Topsy-Turvy, overturned the form book to win two Oscars for best make-up and best costumes. There was also a rare British victory in the documentary category for Kevin MacDonald, the grandson of legendary screenwriter Emeric Pressburger, whose One Day In September, about the massacre of Israeli athletes at the 1972 Olympic Games in Munich, pipped the highly-fancied Buena Vista Social Club. Phil Collins won best song with You'll be in My Heart from Tarzan. "This is hell," he joked.

Kevin Spacey was equally tongue-in-cheek when he accepted the best actor award for his role in American Beauty. "This is the highlight of my day," he drawled. "I hope it doesn't go downhill from here."

Hilary Swank struck a more serious note when she won best actress award for her part in the small-budget film Boys Don't Cry, based on the true story of a woman who passed as a man and was murdered for it. She used her speech to call on people to "celebrate our diversity". Angelina Jolie, daughter of the actor Jon Voight, wasted few words as she won supporting actress award for Girl, Interrupted.

The same could not be said for the Spanish director Pedro Almodovar who won two prizes, the official Oscar for best foreign language film for All About My Mother and the unofficial one for the longest acceptance speech in which he explained how his siblings had lit candles for a wide variety of saints to ensure he carried off the prize. He was finally dragged off stage by Antonio Banderas as the orchestra tried to drown him out. "We live in a different culture," he said, explaining that in Spain it was already "six years in the morning".

The ceremony lasted marginally less time than previous years despite efforts by the organisers to speed it up. Two of the most concise acceptance speeches came from members of the Topsy-Turvy crew. Lindy Hemming had designed the spectacular outfits for Mike Leigh's "little film" about Gilbert and Sullivan and Christine Blundell and Trevor Proud took the make-up Oscar. "Mike Leigh, top guy," said Ms Blundell.

Warren Beatty won the Irving Thalberg award and said that he regarded it as a greater prize than the White House in which direction it had seemed last year that he might be heading. There was also an honorary Oscar for Polish director Andrzej Wadja.

Politics made a brief appearance. The compere Billy Crystal referred to the Robin Williams film about a robot who wants to become a human being. "It's called the Al Gore story," he said.

John Irving also received cheers when he paid tribute to the National Abortion Rights League in his acceptance of Oscar for the adapted screenplay of the Cider House Rules, in which Michael Caine had played an abortionist.

The man who had already picked up more Oscars than anyone on stage was there as guest of honour: Willie Fulgear, the 61-year-old freelance salvage worker who found 52 of the 55 stolen Oscars in a skip last week.

A-list: The Oscar winners

 Best Picture American Beauty
 Best Director Sam Mendes, American Beauty
 Best Actor in a leading role Kevin Spacey, American Beauty
 Best Actress in a leading role Hilary Swank, Boys Don't Cry
 Best Actor in a supporting role Michael Caine, Cider House Rules
 Best Actress in a supporting role Angelina Jolie, Girl, Interrupted
 Best original screenplay Alan Ball, American Beauty
 Screenplay Adaptation John Irving, The Cider House Rules
 Cinematography Conrad Hal,l American Beauty
 Original score John Corigliano, The Red Violin
 Foreign language film All About My Mother, Spain
 Visual effects John Gaeta, Janek Sirrs, Steve Courtly and John Thum, The Matrix
 Documentary feature Arthur Cohn, Kevin Macdonald, One Day in September
 Original song Phil Collins, You'll Be in My Heart from Tarzan
 Makeup Christine Blundell and Trevor Proud, Topsy-Turvy
 Costume design Lindy Hemming, Topsy-Turvy
 Irving Thalberg memorial award Warren Beatty

webTitle: End News at Ten row, says McDonald

fields.headline: End News at Ten row, says McDonald
fields.trailText: The broadcaster Sir Trevor McDonald has called for an end to the debate over the demise of News at Ten.
fields.body:
The broadcaster Sir Trevor McDonald has called for an end to the debate over the demise of News at Ten.

The ITN newsreader gave his strongest hint yet that he had opposed the decision last year to axe the programme, the flagship in the ITV schedules for 30 years, but he urged critics and supporters to let the matter rest.

Speaking after a London Institute lecture at the Cochrane Theatre, Sir Trevor said: "We all loved the News at Ten but it's time to move on. We cannot keep looking over our shoulders at how things used to be."

He added: "News at Ten had been going for a long time and at ITN we are just relieved this thing has finally come to some sort of conclusion and we are able to get on with our lives."

News at Ten was axed by ITV last March and replaced by bulletins at 6.30pm and 11pm. The decision led to criticism that ITV had "dumbed down" in an attempt to gain viewers.

The Commons culture select committee recently recommended that News at Ten be brought back. The Independent Television Commission is also considering the evidence on whether to instruct ITV to reinstate the programme.

webTitle: QC says ousted lawyers' leader was victimised

fields.headline: QC says ousted lawyers' leader was victimised
fields.trailText: The row between the Law Society and Kamlesh Bahl, its former vice-president, escalated yesterday when she released a legal opinion from Cherie Booth QC accusing the society of breaching Ms Bahl's right to a fair hearing and victimising her in handling complaints of bullying made against her.
fields.body:
The row between the Law Society and Kamlesh Bahl, its former vice-president, escalated yesterday when she released a legal opinion from Cherie Booth QC accusing the society of breaching Ms Bahl's right to a fair hearing and victimising her in handling complaints of bullying made against her.

The saga has taken a new and embarrassing turn for the society, forcing it to exhume a scandal thought to have died five years ago, that of a previous vice-president, John Young, who resigned as a presidential hopeful when unmasked as a serial groper.

Ms Booth, in a joint opinion with junior barrister Margaret McCabe, contrasts the society's treatment of Mr Young, whose colleagues simply took him aside and advised him not to do it again, with the moves against Ms Bahl.

She resigned last week after the society's council voted overwhelmingly to suspend her following a report by an independent inquiry headed by a retired law lord, Lord Griffiths, which found five complaints of bullying proved.

She has launched sex and race discrimination claims against the society and its president Robert Sayer and secretary general Jane Betts. In the written opinion the barristers advise Ms Bahl's solicitor, Jill Andrew, to serve a questionnaire on the society demanding details of any complaints against Mr Young and how they were dealt with.

Such questionnaires provide ammunition in race and sex claims for arguing that the complainant was treated less favourably than a man or a white person would have been. The barristers say "a well-organised and orchestrated anti-Kamlesh campaign" was put into effect after the first complaint that included threats and attempts by Mr Sayer, which he denies, to have Ms Bahl removed from the society's central London headquarters.

The opinion states that Ms Bahl may have a claim against the society for breach of contract as well as sex and race discrimination. The society breached its dignity at work policy and the rules of natural justice in not handling the complaints informally and confidentially, the opinion holds. It was "a very serious breach of duty" not to have raised the complaints earlier with Ms Bahl and not to have them investigated as they arose.

webTitle: Ball game Auction of soccer memorabilia

fields.headline: Ball game Auction of soccer memorabilia
fields.standfirst: David Beckham's football boots and a good luck message to the Welsh international goalkeeper Jack Kelsey from Pele should have the crowds cheering at Christie's in London on Thursday,  writes Pippa Crerar.
fields.trailText: The Manchester United star's size 8 boots have "Beck's" stitched on the tongue and are expected to fetch £700 to £1,000. Pele's message to Kelsey in a book followed their meeting at the 1958 World Cup finals.
fields.body:
The Manchester United star's size 8 boots have "Beck's" stitched on the tongue and are expected to fetch £700 to £1,000. Pele's message to Kelsey in a book followed their meeting at the 1958 World Cup finals.

The items are part of two football memorabilia sales. Other items include signed footballs, and an FA Cup winners medal won by Alf Griffin of Wolverhampton Wanderers in 1893, the first time the team won the cup.

The second sale on the same day is devoted to Manchester United and has around 200 lots. Fans can pick up Peter Schmeichel's autographed gloves and shirts worn by players including Roy Keane, Ryan Giggs and Eric Cantona.

The highlight of that sale is the shirt worn by Bobby Charlton in England's 1966 World Cup semi-final against Portugal. The shirt is expected to fetch up to £15,000.

fields.headline: Galleries share £2m windfall
fields.trailText: Thirty-four galleries will share in £2m of funding announced by the Arts Council of England yesterday.
fields.body:
Thirty-four galleries will share in £2m of funding announced by the Arts Council of England yesterday.

Through the regional arts boards, the 34 will receive cash injections of between £15,000 and £200,000, in a "substantial shift in funding" to invest in visual arts and crafts, including photography and new media, artists' film and video, live art and architecture.

The Arnolfini in Bristol will receive £200,000 to further its architecture centre, one of a small network of units in the country.

The Photographers' Gallery is one of three galleries in the capital to get £150,000. Camden Arts Centre gets a grant to develop as an international centre for the visual arts. The third, the Serpentine, has a dedicated education studio and 360,000 visitors a year.

Whitechapel Gallery gets £100,000, as an international venue for modern and contemporary visual arts.

In Manchester, the Cornerhouse will get £100,000. It has three cinemas, three galleries, two book shops, cafes and a bar.

FACT, the new media arts organisation in Liverpool which has an international profile, also gets £100,000.

In Southampton, the John Hansard Gallery will get £100,000 to further experimental contemporary art, and to help its move to a city centre arts space.

The Museum of Modern Art in Oxford, the largest independent visual arts venue outside London, is to receive £150,000. Housed in a converted 19th century brewery in the city centre, it plans an entrance though the shopping centre.

Yorkshire Sculpture Park, in West Yorkshire, will get £100,000 to develop as a national centre for modern and contemporary sculpture.

fields.headline: Vitamins help fight dementia
fields.trailText: Vitamin C and E supplements may increase mental ability in the elderly, prevent some forms of dementia and limit brain damage from strokes, according to the journal of the American Academy of Neurology.
fields.body:
Vitamin C and E supplements may increase mental ability in the elderly, prevent some forms of dementia and limit brain damage from strokes, according to the journal of the American Academy of Neurology.

Kamal Masaki of the University of Hawaii in Honolulu reported on a study of more than 3,000 Japanese-American men over 30 years.

In 1991, when aged 71-93, they were assessed for dementia and tested on their mental ability; those taking weekly vitamin C and E supplements since 1988 were 88% less likely to have vascular dementia - caused by brain damage suffered after strokes.

Victims suffer paralysis, mental impairment and speech, language and sight problems. In the UK, 120,000 people a year suffer a first stroke and it is the third biggest killer after cancer and heart disease.

Men taking vitamin C and E were also 69% less likely to have certain other forms of dementia - but the vitamins did not reduce the risk of Alzheimer's. Vitamins also helped where there was no dementia: those taking supplements since 1988 had a 20% greater chance of better mental ability, and, from 1982, a 75% greater chance.

Dr Masaki wrote: "Antioxidants like E and C may protect against vascular dementia by limiting brain damage after a stroke. The supplements may also protect against brain injury involved in many ageing -related diseases."

fields.headline: Egg man's stamp ruled unlawful
fields.trailText: A poultry farmer yesterday lost a battle against Brussels bureaucracy when the high court outlawed his practice of labelling his eggs with a "laid between" date.
fields.body:
A poultry farmer yesterday lost a battle against Brussels bureaucracy when the high court outlawed his practice of labelling his eggs with a "laid between" date.

Martin Pitt, 66, a producer of free range eggs now retired, persuaded magistrates nearly two years ago that he should use carton stickers showing a three day "laying" timespan, guaranteeing egg freshness. The scheme was a huge success with customers.

Lord Justice Schiemann, sitting with Mr Justice Astill, ruled that the labels did not comply with EU legislation, since the law appeared to envisage only a single date being stamped on each egg pack, and because whatever was stamped on the pack had to be also stamped on the eggs.

Mr Pitt started with 70 chickens in 1959, and by the time he sold up in February last year had 50,000. The Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food prosecuted him for being in breach of EU law and the 1995 eggs marketing standards. Maff said that if Mr Pitt used his own system he would have to stamp each egg with the same message.

Mr Pitt, whose eggs came from Levetts Farm, Marlborough, Wiltshire, and who had top London hotels as customers, argued that people would not want eggs stamped with indelible red ink.

The judge ruled that Mr Pitt would not be convicted.

webTitle: Ostrich farmer found guilty of theft

fields.headline: Ostrich farmer found guilty of theft
fields.trailText: A 36-year-old woman was yesterday found guilty of stealing hundreds of thousands of pounds from investors who poured money into her ostrich farm.
fields.body:
A 36-year-old woman was yesterday found guilty of stealing hundreds of thousands of pounds from investors who poured money into her ostrich farm.

Esther Evans was also convicted of fraudulently trading after setting up the farm with her husband Martin, 38, in Dunvant, near Swansea, in 1995.

Investors poured nearly £1m into the ostrich breeding farm thinking they would make large profits through the sale of the meat.

Evans, of Uplands, Swansea, was found guilty of four charges of theft totalling around £275,000 and one count of fraudulent trading, at Swansea crown court. Last Friday, Evans was cleared of three further charges of stealing a total of around £55,000 from investors.

During the two-week trial the court heard how the couple set up the ostrich breeding farm in November 1995.

Investors believed their money would be used to buy and look after ostriches which would be bred to produce others. The second generation would then be sold off for meat.

The court heard that 115 people invested a total of about £875,000 in the farm before the business was declared insolvent in July 1996.

Much of the money paid into the company by investors had been taken out and transferred to other bank accounts, including one in the Bahamas.

Sentence was adjourned for reports to be prepared. Evans was given conditional bail.

fields.headline: £3m award for car crash child
fields.trailText: Toni Wilson, 14, was yesterday awarded £3m in compensation for being left severely disabled in a car crash caused by a Dutch motorist driving on the wrong side of the road.
fields.body:
Toni Wilson, 14, was yesterday awarded £3m in compensation for being left severely disabled in a car crash caused by a Dutch motorist driving on the wrong side of the road.

She was four-and-a-half-months old and a back seat passenger in her aunt's car when it and a Mercedes driven by Marcus Visschers collided in 1986.

She received severe brain injuries, and needs 24-hour care from two carers and her grandmother, Myra Cook.

At the high court sitting in Birmingham, Brian Leveson QC, sitting as a deputy high court judge, said he "entirely and totally" endorsed the agreed settlement.

He also paid tribute to Mrs Cook for the "selfless devotion" she had paid to her granddaughter.

Philip Mott QC, for the claimant, told the court that Mr Visschers and his insurance company had accepted total liability for the accident in 1988. "She was left in very poor state with limited mobility, unable to feed herself, has poor eyesight and is in need of constant care," he said.

"The progress she has made since the accident is in no small measure due to the devoted and high quality of care given by her grandmother," he said.

After the hearing, Mrs Cook, 55, who lives with her granddaughter in Bishopthorpe, North Yorkshire, 100 yards from the scene of the accident, said: "I'm relieved it is all over after 14 years. This will make life a bit easier for Toni. We'll never live a normal life but as near to a normal life as possible. She's a happy child but doesn't know any different."

fields.headline: Mandelson urges Good Friday accord
fields.standfirst: Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Peter Mandelson issued a stark warning yesterday on Northern Ireland saying it would become a "byword for political failure" unless unionists and republicans worked together to revive the Good Friday agreement.
fields.body:
Peter Mandelson issued a stark warning yesterday on Northern Ireland saying it would become a "byword for political failure" unless unionists and republicans worked together to revive the Good Friday agreement.

Amid growing fears that the peace process had been severely undermined by the divisions in the Ulster Unionist party, the Northern Ireland secretary insisted that the vast majority of people wanted the agreement to work.

Describing the 1998 agreement as the best deal on offer, Mr Mandelson said: "We are faced with a choice. We either implement [it] broadly as it is, or we just face many years of continued stalemate, of impasse. If people are not going to be prepared to accommodate, to see other people's point of view, Northern Ireland is simply going to be a byword for political failure. The ordinary people in the street are fed up to the back teeth with political failure."

His remarks came after the peace process was dealt a hard blow over the weekend when David Trimble retained the leadership of the UUP by only a narrow margin in the face of a challenge from Martin Smyth, the party's chief whip at Westminster. Mr Trimble's authority was undermined further when the Ulster Unionist Council voted to link Sinn Fein's return to government to keeping the RUC's name.

Mr Mandelson said he was standing by his decision to implement the Patten report which advised on the constabulary's name change. He said it was "inappropriate" to link reforms to the RUC with efforts to revive Northern Ireland's power-sharing executive.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Backpackers held in Perth
fields.body:
Backpackers held in Perth

Two backpackers were yesterday remanded in custody in Perth, Western Australia, accused of slashing an Aborigine in the head, throat and stomach. Alan McPherson, 33, from Cumbernauld near Glasgow, and David Howells, 34, from Chester, were charged with grievous bodily harm.

Babies to fly in style on BA

British Airways has ordered nearly 1,000 cots to enable infants up to six months old to fly lying down in specially designed units attached to bulkheads in its aircraft.

No 10's nanny row is settled

Cherie Blair has settled her legal action against the Mail on Sunday over an account of life in No 10 by the family's former nanny.

A statement by the prime minister's wife said she and Associated Newspapers had agreed to resolve "amicably" her claim; the group has given permanent undertakings not to publish or disclose any information obtained from Ros Mark.

Joy of Sex author dies

Alex Comfort, who wrote The Joy of Sex, has died aged 80 in hospital after a series of strokes. Dr Comfort's "gourmet guide to lovemaking", published in 1972, sold 12m copies worldwide.

fields.headline: Body found in Kashmir 'not Briton'
fields.trailText: Metropolitan police forensic scientists yesterday contradicted a claim by Indian police that a body dug up in Kashmir two years ago was that of the missing British hostage Paul Wells.
fields.body:
Metropolitan police forensic scientists yesterday contradicted a claim by Indian police that a body dug up in Kashmir two years ago was that of the missing British hostage Paul Wells.

The Foreign Office said that fresh DNA tests revealed that the remains were not those of Mr Wells, a photography student from Blackburn, Lancashire, who vanished in July 1995 during a holiday in the Indian Himalayas. He was abducted with three other tourists by a Kashmiri separatist group.

The conclusion from the Metropolitan police team is at odds with Indian police in the state of Jammu and Kashmir, who announced in January that the body belonged to the missing student.

The Foreign Office yesterday said that the remains did not match any of the other abducted hostages, Briton Keith Mangan, German Dirk Hasert and American Donald Hutchings.

The body was discovered in 1997 in a shallow grave in a south Kashmir village, following a tip-off. Indian scientists initially concluded it was not that of Mr Wells, but later changed their minds after obtaining blood samples from Mr Wells' parents.

Two months ago Kashmir's police chief Gurbuchan Jagat declared that the "exhumed body" was that of the missing Briton.

webTitle: Kick start for old industry into new era

fields.headline: Kick start for old industry into new era
fields.trailText: The "closure" of the two Sellafield reprocessing works in Cumbria would not mean the biggest nuclear plant in the country would disappear. It would kick start a new industry out of the old, and safe storage of nuclear fuel and waste would keep thousands of people in work for centuries.
fields.body:
The "closure" of the two Sellafield reprocessing works in Cumbria would not mean the biggest nuclear plant in the country would disappear. It would kick start a new industry out of the old, and safe storage of nuclear fuel and waste would keep thousands of people in work for centuries.

The nuclear fuel awaiting treatment at Sellafield would have to be stored. Although reprocessing jobs would disappear, in the short term the move would create an employment boom, building stores to contain the hot fuel rods.

Reprocessing has produced its own legacy over nearly 50 years. Producing plutonium from dissolving spent nuclear fuel in nitric acid creates large quantities of dangerous nuclear waste.

The workforce at Sellafield is now around 10,000 - 6,000 staff and 4,000 contractors. The largest single number, around 3,000, work at the older Magnox reprocessing works which takes fuel from the original stable of nuclear reactors.

The current plan is to close each of the remaining six Magnox stations round the country over the next 12 years and close the reprocessing works in 2015. The larger and newer Thorp reprocessing works opened in 1994 is only through 2,750 tonnes of its first 10-year target of 7,000 tonnes of spent fuel.

If Thorp were closed around 1,200 jobs would go, and around 3,000 would be lost at Magnox over a longer period.

webTitle: The widow, the legacy and a Porsche

fields.headline: The widow, the legacy and a Porsche
fields.standfirst: Great Ormond Street hospital fights for bequest as court hears how woman's fortune was passed to her cleaner
fields.trailText: Near the end of a lifetime devoted to the care of others, Lily Morris looked back over her career and decided to make a final gesture of the generosity that characterised her life. But pledging a share of her substantial legacy to Great Ormond Street children's hospital, where she had worked as a nurse, has led to a high court battle as extraordinary as the circumstances surrounding her last years.
fields.body:
Near the end of a lifetime devoted to the care of others, Lily Morris looked back over her career and decided to make a final gesture of the generosity that characterised her life. But pledging a share of her substantial legacy to Great Ormond Street children's hospital, where she had worked as a nurse, has led to a high court battle as extraordinary as the circumstances surrounding her last years.

For instead of an estate worth at least £300,000, Mrs Morris's assets upon her death were substantially less. As the high court in London has heard, she had transferred the ownership of her beautiful Derbyshire country home to her cleaner and companion 14 months earlier.

Farmhouse

Pauline Rushin, who lives more modestly in the same area, is fighting with her daughter to keep the stone farmhouse along with a Porsche and a BMW bought with cash drawn from a joint account set up in the name of Mrs Rushin and the former nurse. "We were friends for years," Mrs Rushin said before the case began.

Great Ormond Street, however, wants to know how the agreement transferring the home out of Mrs Morris's control came to be drawn up with the help of a struck-off solicitor, Stephen Bowman, who was later jailed for unrelated offences. While the arguments fly amid the spartan decor of court 53 at the royal courts of justice in London, Home Farm House at Idridgehay in the Peak District lies silent, unoccupied since Mrs Morris's death three years ago.

It wants Mr Justice Rimer to rule on whether Mrs Morris's agreement to hand over control of her home over to Mrs Rushin was valid. It also wants the judge to decide whether Mrs Rushin and her family have any right to use a Porsche, BMW and Peugeot cars bought with money from joint accounts held with Mrs Morris. In addition, the hospital wants an inquiry into the name and the value of the accounts.

The court heard yesterday from Mrs Rushin's son, Austin Billinge, who described how he occasionally helped out at Mrs Morris's home, and said that she had once offered to buy him a car but he refused. He later changed his mind and asked Mrs Morris for a loan, which he used to pay for a Porsche.

He said the loan had been for £5,000, and he was aware that it had come from an account in the name of Mrs Morris and Mrs Rushin. The car had cost £3,995, and he had bought a private number plate worth £800. He had made one repayment of £200 to Mrs Morris. They made no formal agreement on the terms of the loan. "I always said to the police that I would pay Mrs Morris's estate off," he said.

Gordon Nurse, counsel for the hospital, said: "She flicked through it."

Mr Billinge replied: "I don't know how much of it she took in."

Mr Billinge told the court that he had first met Mrs Morris in 1991 or 1992. "I found her to be an intelligent and articulate lady," he said.

Concerns

The court later heard from Maureen Walters, a solicitor for the Manchester lawyers Michael Levy and Co, the firm that came to deal with Mrs Morris's affairs at the time of her death. She conceded that some concerns had been raised about Mrs Morris's mental capacity at the time the house transfer deal was being drawn up. But she accepted that the pair had worked together on Mrs Morris's legal affairs: "I collaborated to a certain extent with Mr Bowman."

Mrs Rushin, in a 1998 interview, insisted that Mrs Morris was of sound mind when she signed the agreement handing over the house. She said that her relatives were always welcome: "No one stopped them coming over." Mrs Rushin said the police "haven't been able to prove anything after eight months of questioning".

Some of Mrs Morris's relatives are supporting the Great Ormond Street court action. Bernard Codling, her nephew, who is not a beneficiary of her will, said they were not motivated by financial gain. "We are not bothered about money. Most of it has gone now anyway."

Mr Justice Rimer will hear the barristers' closing speeches today, and is expected to reserve his judgment.
