fields.headline: British Oscar beauty
fields.standfirst:
British Oscar beauty

Film Unlimited
fields.trailText: Hours after picking up the last of five Oscars for his first film, American Beauty - and being declared a "bright shining star" by none other than Steven Spielberg - Sam Mendes was keeping his legendary cool.
fields.body:
Hours after picking up the last of five Oscars for his first film, American Beauty - and being declared a "bright shining star" by none other than Steven Spielberg - Sam Mendes was keeping his legendary cool.

Even as Hollywood's most powerful players queued to schmooze him at the post-Oscar parties, Mendes' mind was turning to the play he will direct at his relatively tiny 250-seat Donmar Warehouse in London in September.

"I don't think they quite know what to make of me," the 34-year-old wunderkind said yesterday. "Hollywood wants all of you. They find it hard to grasp that I'm going back to the theatre before I think about anything else. I am really attracted by it but I can't wait to get home.

"On the other hand, I'm hoping that makes me even more interesting and mysterious."

Mendes, who described himself as "just a bloke from English theatre" as he got his Oscar for best director, admitted he was terrified of falling at the final hurdle after his film had won just about every other big award.

"When you are favourite, you feel the pressure. About a week ago the tension was quite bad, with everyone questioning me about how I felt and asking for bizarre personal details, childhood experiences and what collar size I was. I had to get away and clear my head. It's been fine since."

His preparation for the ceremony itself was so laid back it was almost horizontal. "I had a few friends round and I didn't actually get out of my dressing gown till three. Then I put on my lucky Prada suit I wore to the Golden Globes. I didn't exactly lock myself away in the bathroom but I stopped myself looking at newspapers or the television."

Even so the ceremony, which dragged on for more than four hours, was an ordeal: "It felt like a week."

Only when Kevin Spacey won best actor did Mendes start to relax. "This was an actors' film. They drove it. I wanted so much for Kevin and Annette [Bening] to win."

When his name was finally read out as best director, his mother, Valerie, who was sitting next to him, jumped for joy. "She nearly exploded. If I'd lit a match I think she'd have combusted with pride."

Back in London, the entire Donmar Warehouse staff and the cast of its current production, Helpless, who had been partying all night at the One Aldywch hotel, "went berserk". From the stage in Los Angeles, Mendes thanked them and toasted the rest of his friends who had gathered in his flat in Primrose Hill, north London, to watch the show on TV.

"Its just a great relief," he said. "Being a director is like being an alcoholic: no one understands what it's like until you've been one. That's why it meant so much to meet people like Spike Jonze [director of Being John Malkovich] and Kimberly Peirce [Boys Don't Cry]. Being at the Oscars is like having your own personal AA meeting.

"I still can't believe that a film which features masturbation, an older man and a younger woman, repressed sexuality in the suburbs and a plastic bag has won so many Oscars. But I'm not complaining."

Spielberg, who asked Mendes to direct American Beauty for his DreamWorks studio after seeing his stage versions of Oliver! and Cabaret, said: "I am so proud of Sam and it was great to be able to present him with the Oscar. When I saw his work in the theatre I knew we had to have him. He has a great eye for telling a story visually, something you often don't expect from theatre directors."

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Radio
fields.body:
In an age when only one country in the kingdom has missed the devolutionary boat, Jonathan Freedland recalls the ardent nationalist who demanded parliamentary rule for the English. It was unfortunate, as The Long View (9.0am, Radio 4) is obliged to point out, that Simon de Montfort was really a Gallic chancer, but no one's perfect. His capture of Henry III didn't help the English much, bringing destruction to large tracts of the country. He was, sadly, Not A Good Thing.

Nor, if it comes to that, was the political record of Richard Strauss exactly wonderful. As Peter Ainsworth observes in Discord: Music And Dissent (1.30pm, Radio 4), it is never easy being a creative artist in a totalitarian madhouse. But Strauss had no need to head the Third Reich Chamber of Music nor to join the Nazi boycott of Jewish music. His lame explanation for not, like other musicians, choosing exile was that "It would have reduced my income."

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Cable, satellite and digital
fields.body:
Half-Baked (Tamra Davis, 1998) 10pm, Sky MovieMax
It starts out with so much promise. Three stoner pals decide that they have to raise bail for their hapless friend, who has been sent to jail after feeding a munchies-run bag of goodies to a diabetic police horse, thereby killing it. So they become dope dealers after one of their members discovers a huge supply of extremely potent chronic, thereby falling foul of local crimelord. Unfortunately, the gags revolve around getting stoned, of the variety that are only very funny at three in the morning. (WH)

The Discreet Charm Of The Bourgeoisie (Luis Buñuel, 1972) 10pm, FilmFour
Brilliant Oscar winning comedy from the Spanish master that follows the efforts of Fernando Rey's ambassador of Miranda to take his friends to dinner. Seems normal enough, but bizarre events intervene: a corpse is discovered; the police, and the army arrive; the hosts dive off into the garden to make love. Utterly charming middle-classes mickey (Miguel?)-taking; and as a bonus it even contains Buñuel's unbeatable recipe for the perfect dry martini too.

Love And Death On Long Island (Richard Kwietniowski, 1996) 10pm, Sky Premier
The story of widowed author Giles De'Ath, who, wandering into the wrong screening at the cinema, conceives a sudden infatuation with its star, Ronnie Bostock (Jason Priestley). Soon he's on a flight from London to New York and Long Island. It's quiet, very funny, and delicately nuanced, with a wonderful performance from John Hurt as De'Ath.

Dolores Claiborne (Taylor Hackford, 1995) 12.20am, FilmFour
A Stephen King homage to Hollywood's deranged-woman melodramas: Mildred Pierce meets Misery. Kathy Bates (pictured), star of the latter, plays a woman once suspected of husband murder, and 15 years later accused of killing her boss (Judy Parfitt). Her daughter (Jennifer Jason Leigh) returns to confront past and present deeds: it's Three Go Bonkers On Remote Island (PH)

fields.headline: Warts and all
fields.standfirst: Documentary king Paul Watson isn't angry. Oh, no. He's not bitter about falling out with the BBC, he's not annoyed that TV is run by 'monsters'. And he doesn't even mind being accused of inventing the docusoap, as he insists on telling  Jacques Peretti
fields.trailText: Paul Watson is annoyed with The Guardian. "You keep calling me Paul Wilson, or Phil Watson." The rest of the press don't like him much either. "The Times said I was bitter about being sacked from the BBC. Bitter!? Bitter!!!?" Watson isn't bitter. He tells you he isn't bitter for roughly 45 minutes. And why should he be?
fields.body:
Paul Watson is annoyed with The Guardian. "You keep calling me Paul Wilson, or Phil Watson." The rest of the press don't like him much either. "The Times said I was bitter about being sacked from the BBC. Bitter!? Bitter!!!?" Watson isn't bitter. He tells you he isn't bitter for roughly 45 minutes. And why should he be?

This is Paul Wilson (sorry, Watson) for god's sake! The man who directed The Family in 1974, inventing docu-soap ("I didn't"); ran the ground-breaking 40 Minutes strand; made the Thatcher-skewering Fishing Party in the mid-80s; and then The Dinner Party, a portrait of Tories turning heliotropically towards Blair in the mid-90s. There was Sylvania Waters some time in between, which got him sacked from the BBC, but not really.

In short, he's made a lot of very good and memorable films ("over 300 of them, and all my own ideas"), but now Watson is reduced to peddling ideas like everyone else. It's an outrage! And it is an outrage.

"I was told by the BBC suits that I'm not 'a team player'. Then I was told by a bunch of middle management thuggoes that I don't make 'balanced films'. Then I was told I couldn't make this or that film because 'we did poverty last year'. Well, fuck off. It wasn't done by me."

Watson relishes telling all these BBC anecdotes now. It helps to bolster his self-image as maverick film-maker. The natural-born outsider too good and too big to be told what to do. Watson now makes TV for people half his age with a tenth of his experience. Is he bitter? Wouldn't you be?

Watson has just made a film for C4, A Wedding In The Family, which is a technically perfect, almost self-parodic film. Ostensibly about a wedding in middle England, Watson's real quarry is the central matriarch, an evil stepmother called Sue.

"I told Sue that, at the start of the film, you'll be 100 metres behind the starting line in terms of the audience's goodwill, but that that will change."

Maybe. In fact, it's yet another case of reassuring the subjects before shafting them on the final cut. But Watson has been used to such criticisms for 30 years.

"It's called editing. But if you really want to know," he says wearily, "they trust me, and therefore trust in the film because they know the context will be okay. The couple (getting married) knew they were just a vehicle to get to Sue."

Have you had feedback from C4? Any word on the film from Michael Jackson? "No", he says, and laughs.

The only documentary film-maker in Britain as well known as Watson is Molly Dineen. Dineen, like Watson, now attacks docu-soaps (having created them). So what does Watson feel about Dineen's Faustian pact with puff promo-mentaries à la Geri Halliwell?

"Molly made one of the best films of the 20th century with The Zoo. But with success comes a temptation to think you're showbiz yourself." Ouch. At a talk by Dineen, I once heard a male film-maker ask her if she thought the reason people talked to her so openly was not because she was a skilled film-maker, but because they secretly fancy her.

Dineen's films, like Watson's, are classic 70s really (a style parodied recently by comedian Peter Kaye, complete with patronising voice- over from Andrew Sachs). But Watson is a product of the gritty macho docu-making tradition that essentially amounted to "my film's harder than yours". A garlicky male environment in which women didn't make films, but paid loyal service to their auteur bosses.

Don't you think there's a superior, dated, classist tone to your films, I ask Watson. A cold detachment to the subjects, which belies your claim to be making films with any empathy?

"If you think that, I'm sorry. I'll re-voice the whole film, or have no commentary at all - I don't want anything, anything at all, to get in the way. My films need to work, they've got to leave a scratch, make a difference."

Watson is sincere in this. His favourite phrases are 1) "I'm a painter" and 2) "I'm an individualist, not an anarchist". In TV, there's a sliding scale of self-perception from Picasso to Animal Hospital and Watson believes his films are most definitely not at the Rolf Harris end of the market.

In a way, Watson is disingenuous, paying lip-service to old-school hardcore doc-making, while actually making films that are so über-docu-soap, they're trailed by Channel 4 as if they were Ibiza Uncovered.

As for making "a difference", Watson is more sanguine in these days of TV exec "monsters" and programmes "made by robots". "If I'm about to make love to my wife, and suddenly we stop and have an argument about my film, then I've caused a stir. I've promoted greater understanding, however small."

Watson knows the reality. No one cares that you've worked on 40 Minutes any more because that's not what TV's about now. Today, it's shifting units, not winning Greerson Awards that gets your calls returned. Say Watson didn't make docs at all, but sold 40 billion gallons of Sunny Delight via some convergent TV gimmick, he'd be well and truly back in the loop.

In TV, there's a sliding scale of self-perception from Picasso to Animal Hospital and Watson believes his films are most definitely not at the Rolf Harris end of the market. In a way, Watson is disingenuous, paying lip-service to old-school hardcore doc-making, while actually making films that are so über-docu-soap, they're trailed by Channel 4 as if they were Ibiza Uncovered. As for making "a difference", Watson is more sanguine in these days of TV exec "monsters" and programmes "made by robots". "If I'm about to make love to my wife, and suddenly we stop and have an argument about my film, then I've caused a stir. I've promoted greater understanding, however small." Watson knows the reality. No one cares that you've worked on 40 Minutes any more because that's not what TV's about now. Today, it's shifting units, not winning Greerson Awards that gets your calls returned. Say Watson didn't make docs at all, but sold 40 billion gallons of Sunny Delight via some convergent TV gimmick, he'd be well and truly back in the loop.

fields.headline: Thaw, the god of ham
fields.trailText: Monsignor Renard | Omnibus: Anthony Gormley | True Bible Stories | Journey To The Bottom Of The Sea
fields.body:
Is that John Thaw as a Frenchman? My god, yes it is. Wheeling his bicyclette over the brow of the hill, Monsignor Renard (ITV) is coming to ville to save the buxom peasant girls from the Nazis. A cross between The Seventh Samurai and Rene from 'Allo 'Allo.

You'd have thought he'd learned his lesson with A Year In Provence, but no. He's back for more punishment at the hands of a Berlitz Travel Guide: "You sink a day doesn't go by when I don't sink of little Phillipe?" he said, feeling the pain for all of us.

You could tell it was an ITV war by the devastation: a single shoe in the road; a few smoke-bombs and a deserted farmhouse last used in Sharpe. Occasionally, a Messerschmitt dived and attempted to murder Thaw for ham acting.

Like he cares. The man is ITV drama department's answer to Des Lynam. All he needs to do is turn up and throw on a wig, a red jag or, in this case, a sexy cassock, and the entire nation comes to a standstill.

In Monsignor Renard ("Dr Fox"), ITV were so mindful of their star, they built the whole thing round Thaw's inability to speak any language other than Morse. Consequently, the French spoke in a broad Lancastrian accent (a couple were cockneys). The Germans, strangely, spoke German in a German accent.

It was another Arvo Part attack on Omnibus: Anthony Gormley (BBC1) those interminable bells wheeled out whenever moodiness and intellectual depth are urgently required. In this case, plastering 56 views of the Angel Of The North.

Having curbed their ratings-desperate urge to profile such artistic giants as Jen nifer Saunders, Omnibus has now lurched from enjoyably bad to high dull.

It didn't help that Gormley was a singularly charmless man, exuding unpleasantness from every pore. Sole friend, the fantastically pompous and equally bogus Anish Kapoor talked a lot of made-up-on-the-spot rubbish about what a great artist Gormley is.

The sole dissenting voice (apart from a couple of patronising vox pops with "real people") was Jake Chapman, who observed that Gormley's works have grown bigger with his ego.

Compare Gormley, film and man, to Equinox: Simply Complex (C4) about the physicist Murray Gell-Man. Here was a science documentary about a true artist, a bird-watching freak with triple-thick specs who "set on a programme to define mathematically what complexity is." Simple as that.

Watching Gell-Man and his septuagenarian colleagues doing kooky scientist things, it occurred to me that Einstein and his tongue gag had a lot to answer for. It's now obligatory for any Nobel Prize Winner to act out the crazy old bird routine to look the part and thus be taken seriously as a genius.

What did Gell-Man recall about his youth (apart from winning the Nobel Peace Prize)? "I once went to a beach in Indiana and a girl called Rosa smeared me with sunscreen." What did he learn about complexity? That complexity is a complex thing.

True Bible Stories (C4) and Journey To The Bottom Of The Sea (BBC2) furthered the most unfathomable TV phenomenon for decades: the underwater documentary.

For some truly X-Files reason, Monday night has been decreed the evening for sub-aquatic investigation, and True Bible Stories was a classic of the genre.

In some ways, it was a first. The first-ever film in which one could truly say that NOTHING, ABSOLUTELY NOTHING (not even a spoon) was found. And, consequently, that there was NO, ABSOLUTELY NO reason for watching it.

Lots of men who looked like Kris Kristoffersen congregated on the deck of a ship (don't they always?). Location: The Dead Sea. Mission: To discover Sodom and Gomorrah.

After days of discussion, they dive to the sea floor where they observe NOTHING. "It's like someone took a giant salt cellar and covered everything in salt", Kris 1 observes of the featureless landscape. They resurface.

Two days later, they dive again. "We appear to have come across some fairly large mounds, covered in salt", Kris 1 says excitedly. Kris 2: "Do you think they might be man-made or unnatural? Kris 1: "I dunno."

In desperation, they started prodding the salt with a stick, hoping to unearth the twin cities of sin. If only they'd had Professor Gell-Man there to tell them it was just... salt.

fields.headline: Today's TV
fields.trailText: Terrestrial
fields.body:
Cutting Edge 9pm, C4
To invite pioneering documentary film-maker Paul Watson to your wedding may not be the wisest move, as guests at a certain dinner party will remember. But while some of Watson's subjects have been ghastly people showing themselves at their worst (think Sylvania Waters), the Hutton and Vaughan-Smith clans have little to fear. As Stuart Hutton and Anna Vaughan-Smith prepare to marry, their views and those of their families are gently coaxed out of them by Watson, making for honest and thought-provoking viewing. While Stuart's parents have been together for 37 years and represent the ideal, Anna's family is full of painful splits and battle-scarred people. But with Watson as auteur rather than voyeur, the result is absorbing without being embarrassing.

Affairs Of The Heart 10.30pm, C4
In a pat bit of scheduling, clinical psychologist Oliver James follows Watson with his own exploration of marriage. Engaged himself, he's well aware that he has a 50% chance of divorce, and he wonders if lifelong vows to fidelity are still relevant today. He certainly gets a negative answer from Peter Stringfellow. It takes Jonathan Ross to provide a surprisingly serious and more balanced view. But, as James says, maybe he should stop being neurotic and just get on with it.

The Mission: Viva Las Venice! 11pm, BBC1
Sheldon Adelson is one of those American millionaires whose vulgarity sends a delicious shiver down the spine. He bought the Sands hotel in Las Vegas, tore it down and wants to replicate Venice in its place. But of course. Vegas has the Pyramids already; why not bring the Grand Canal and the Doges Palace along for the ride? We know Adelson has more money than taste, but it's pure fun watching him take pains to make every replica as authentic as possible. Although it's missing one important element: as the Grand Canal sweeps through the vast shopping mall, it's all so hideously clean.

fields.headline: Livingstone in new 'cover-up' row
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Ken Livingstone last night faced the prospect of a fresh inquiry into his financial affairs after an angry Labour colleague accused him of cynically covering up a further £15,000 in after-dinner speaking fees.
fields.body:
Ken Livingstone last night faced the prospect of a fresh inquiry into his financial affairs after an angry Labour colleague accused him of cynically covering up a further £15,000 in after-dinner speaking fees.

So angry are some of the critics of the Brent East MP for his having avoided serious political damage over his under-declared income of £200,000-plus since mid-1999, they want him - and other errant MPs - to be fined the total amount of earnings that have not been declared in public.

The latest attempt to underline Mr Livingstone's frontrunner status in the race for election as London mayor has coincided with a fresh attack from his main rival, the former Labour health secretary, Frank Dobson.

Mr Dobson has accused Mr Livingstone of being "an oddball" whose description at the weekend of the IRA being "freedom fighters" shows he is still "soft on terrorism". Mr Livingstone also stands accused of being indifferent to crime problems in the capital. Whether or not these comments will damage his apparently Teflon candidacy remains to be seen in the next five weeks of the campaign.

Last night he replied: "Far from being soft on terrorism my commitment to encourage a negotiated settlement in Ireland has been shown, by events, to have been right."

As a further indication of Mr Livingstone's talent for winning unlikely support it emerged last night that the Shirayama Shokusan corporation - which, in controversial circumstances in 1993, bought County Hall, the one-time headquarters of the greater London council - had offered him the use of his former south bank office as a campaign base, free of charge. Most of County Hall is now a hotel and leisure complex.

"We are very impressed with your energy in seeking to become mayor," said the Japanese company's chairman, Mac Okamoto.

Mr Livingstone's excuse for not reporting the £15,000 of speaking fees to the register of members' interests at Westminster - along with the £158,000 he did declare - was that the additional fees unearthed by the Daily Mirror were all paid late.

But Brian Sedgemore, one of his most most vociferous critics on the Labour benches at Westminster, last night called this comment a "daft" excuse and demanded a further investigation by the parliamentary commissioner for standards, Elizabeth Filkin.

Mr Livingstone was forced to make what Mr Sedgemore, MP for Hackney South, called "a synthetic, cursory, insincere and hypocritical" apology to the Commons after Mrs Filkin found against him.

But the fact that the standards commissioner had been tipped off in an underhand fashion, by a supporter of Mr Dobson's candidacy, turned the controversy into a dirty tricks row - with every sign that the former GLC leader, now independent candidate for mayor, was suffering little political damage.

In a letter sent to Mrs Filkin, Mr Sedgemore last night complained that the revelation of the undeclared £15,000 suggested that the MP's earlier declaration - made after the close of Labour's London ballot, narrowly won by Mr Dobson - might be inaccurate. He has demanded a re-check of possibly misleading accounts, but has also asked Mrs Filkin to examine Mr -Livingstone's contradictory statements on radio and TV. In future MPs' "personal statements" of apology to the Commons should also be vetted and given more advance publicity, he said.

Mr Livingstone yesterday won the backing of the London region of the Fire Brigades Union (FBU), although the move was repudiated by their general secretary, the veteran leftwinger, Ken Cameron. Individuals could back him, he said, but not the union, which had decided at national level not to support him "financially or in any other way". The FBU is affiliated to the Labour party and cannot remain so if it backs another candidate.

fields.headline: Good day, bad day
fields.trailText:
Good day (1)
Defence minister John Spellar, who became one of the first people to possess a ministry of defence charge card which can be used to buy supplies. He said: "People will no longer have to fill in hundreds of purchase forms, sign things in triplicate and wait weeks for their order to turn up."

Good day (2)
Peers. House of Lords officials installed two portable defibrillators for peers who suffer heart attacks. It follows the death in November of Lord Montague of Oxford who collapsed in the chamber. The average age of peers is 68.

Bad day
Frank S Dobson. The man who threw the London mayoral race into confusion when he announced he was standing, withdrew his candidature. The 65-year-old retired publisher from New Malden, Surrey, blamed cost and administrative obstacles.

Farewell of day
Barely a day goes by without a figure in the last Tory administration announcing they are standing down at the next election. Yesterday it was the turn of former attorney general, Sir Nicholas Lyell.

Today
Commons: Criminal justice and court services bill, second reading. Lords: Census bill, third reading. Care standards bill, report.

webTitle: Making pushers pay drug cash helps fund school sports drive

fields.headline: Making pushers pay drug cash helps fund school sports drive
fields.trailText: The England football coach, Kevin Keegan, yesterday appealed for soccer stars to take part in a £1m scheme to boost sport in schools - paid for largely from drug dealers' confiscated wealth.
fields.body:
The England football coach, Kevin Keegan, yesterday appealed for soccer stars to take part in a £1m scheme to boost sport in schools - paid for largely from drug dealers' confiscated wealth.

Keegan, appearing with the Cabinet Office ministger, Mo Lowlam, at the launch of 24 projects in four cities, said he was keen for more clubs to join the scheme to help steer vulnerable young people away from crime.

The former England and West Ham football star, Trevor Brooking, was also at the launch at Geoffrey Chaucer school in south-east London.

Ms Mowlam said: "You cannot legislate for confidence and self-respect but a scheme like this can help people." The scheme will be run by Sport England and the Youth Justice Board, and will start with projects in London, Manchester, Southampton and Oxford.

Of the £1m allocated to the initiative, £500,000 will come from assets confiscated from drug dealers and traffickers.

The school chosen yesterday for the launch is to benefit from the cash with a scheme administered by the youth project Kickstart.

webTitle: Green belt limit lifted to boost Silicon Fen

fields.headline: Green belt limit lifted to boost Silicon Fen
fields.trailText: Ministers last night braved the wrath of the countryside lobby by signalling they are prepared to lift restrictions on building in green belts in the south and east of England.
fields.body:
Ministers last night braved the wrath of the countryside lobby by signalling they are prepared to lift restrictions on building in green belts in the south and east of England.

Studies to pave the way for thousands of new houses on protected land surrounding Cambridge, now the country's fastest growing area, are to begin immediately, the Department of the Environment announced. A new town, on the north western outskirts, is also a possibility.

The housing and planning minister, Nick Raynsford, told the Guardian that limited building in other green belts was also possible as the government tried to curb piecemeal developments further afield in the countryside.

The shadow environment secretary, Archie Norman, claimed that the government was reversing policy. "No green belt is now safe," he said.

The government broadly followed the recommendations of local councils by agreeing that at least 4,000 houses a year should be built in Cambridgeshire.

More controversially, it has also accepted the need to "review" the green belt around the city - on the grounds that curbing growth in so-called Silicon Fen would damage the national economy. This provides about 30,000 jobs in 700 companies.

Defending the approach, which critics will claim further widens the north-south divide, Mr Raynsford said: "Cambridge is the leading edge of the new economy, with a synergy between the university and industry. We don't want to switch that off because it would be damaging not only to Cambridge but to the country."

The minister said the city's green belt was so tightly drawn villages and small towns further afield were being developed. "It is far better to concentrate development around the edge of the city."

Tony Burton, assistant director of the Council for the Protection of Rural England, accused the government of abandoning regional policy by concentrating more growth in the overheating south.

"There is a strong case for dispersing industry to bring economic and social benefits to other regions and big cities,"he said.

Ruth Bagnall, Labour leader of Cambridge city council said: "It makes sense to have a thorough look to see if the green belt is in the right place. It needs redefining otherwise the risk is that all the development will take place futher afield."

John Reynolds, planning spokesman for Conservative-controlled Cambridgeshire county council, warned that the housing plans would place enormous pressure on transport and the environment.

The government also produced county-by-county figures for the south-east yesterday. The region will have to plan for 43,000 houses annually, 10,000 more than a recommendation from local councils. Kent, for instance, has been set a target of 6,440 annually, almost 1,500 more than the county council wants.

fields.headline: Alex Comfort
fields.standfirst: Dazzling intellectual whose prolific output of novels, poetry and philosophy remains overshadowed by a sex manual
fields.trailText: Alex Comfort, who has died aged 80, was a physician, poet, novelist, anarchist and pacifist. He was never known for the length of his temper, and would have been extremely annoyed today to be reminded that, for many people, his name means only sex.
fields.body:
Alex Comfort, who has died aged 80, was a physician, poet, novelist, anarchist and pacifist. He was never known for the length of his temper, and would have been extremely annoyed today to be reminded that, for many people, his name means only sex. Never mind his poetry, his novels, his gerontology, his startling politics or the breathtaking width of his mind and the power of his grasp; it was his production of a couple of books about sex as a leisure activity, like snooker or tennis, or cooking and eating, that made him a household name.

It was back in the early 1970s that James Mitchell, of publishers Mitchell Beasley, suggested to his friend, Comfort, that he might write a sex manual. Mitchell had previously published an anthology, The Complete Lover, a rather soggy collection of poems, stories and mildly erotic romance for which Comfort had written a chapter on real sex; this had been withdrawn from The Complete Lover because the American publishers, McGraw Hill, would have been too shocked by it - but the idea remained with Mitchell.

Thus was The Joy Of Sex: A Gourmet Guide To Lovemaking, born to be published in 1972. It was an easy birth, incidentally. Comfort wrote the book in two weeks, drawing largely , it was said by insiders, on his affair with the woman who was to become his second wife . Its original title was Cordon Bleu Sex (hence the chapters headed Starters, Main Courses, Sauces and Pickles) but the owners of the Cordon Bleu name objected, so the title was changed.

His fictional debut came in 1941 with No Such Liberty, written while he was at Cambridge. The Power House, a long and acclaimed third novel, appeared in 1944. On This Side Nothing, probably Comfort's best novel, followed in 1949. There were also several books of verse. Art And Social Responsibility (1946), was his first collection of articles.

His lifelong pacifism dated from his schooldays; during the second world war, he was, he said, "an aggressive anti-militarist". It came to a head in the campaign against the indiscriminate bombing of Germany. The 1950s saw his main effort concentrated on the biology of ageing. After the volume of poetry, And All But He Departed (1951), there was nothing until Haste To The Wedding (1962). After A Giant's Strength (1952) no novel appeared until Come Out to Play (1961). A second collection of articles, Darwin And The Naked Lady, was not published till 1962.

There followed a transitional decade for Comfort. Barbarism And Sexual Freedom (1948) had been the starting point for Sexual Behaviour In Society (1950), which was revised as Sex In Society (1963). Then, in 1962, came a formative experience, when he visited India. A translation from the Sanskrit of the erotological mediaeval classic, The Koka Shastra, resulted in 1964. In the 1970s, came Comfort's own manuals on sex.

In 1973, he moved to the Center For The Study of Democratic Institutions at Santa Barbara, California. The center soon folded, but he remained on the west coast, in a series of medical and academic posts. In 1985, he retired to England.

Comfort had written several works of scientific popularisation in the 1960s, but later books, such as I And That: Notes On The Biology of Religion (1979) and Reality And Empathy: Physics, Mind, And Science In The 21st Century (1984), were a good deal more abstruse. After the 1960s, he published another three novels, but only two collections of poetry. He was now a household name, but as something he always denied being: a sexologist.

David Hall writes: Towards the end of the 1950s, gerontology could hardly be called a well-defined or highly- respected discipline. The Club For Ageing, founded in 1947, had split into two, and it was to be nearly 30 years before clinicians and biologists found it possible to collaborate convincingly again. There was, however, a small group farsighted enough to realise that this dichotomy could only detract from the development of age research. One of this group was Comfort.

His early medical career enabled him to bring a clinician's point of view to his research, acknowledging that the ultimate aim of age research must be the interpretation of the ageing process to the human subject. On the other hand, he had an insatiable curiosity, which, on his arrival in the physiology department at the London Hospital Medical School, and later in the zoology department of University College, encouraged him to study age phenomena from whatever source appropriate data could be obtained.

This led him to examine ageing processes in both wild and captive populations of fish and other animals. He also realised that other people's studies could often be employed to good effect. For instance, he found it possible to use information from horse breeders' stud books to explain genetic factors associated with ageing. This biological research led to the publication of The Biology Of Senescence (1961), to be followed by Ageing: The Biology Of Senescence (1964). And one of the milestones of popular gerontology in the 1960s was a television interview featuring Comfort and the "red" dean of Canterbury, Hewlett Johnson.

I began to appreciate the way Alex could explain the growing points of age research when, in the late 1960s, we were both officers of the British Society for Research on Ageing, in which he played an important role. It was about this time that he became a popular presenter at international meetings. These lectures were characterised by such a degree of optimism about the future development of gerontology - and the possible enhancement of lifespan - as to make some of his more conservative colleagues cringe. Thus, in Washington, in 1969, he suggested that, within 20 years, human life span might extend to 120 years.

Throughout Comfort's career, it was his ability to be deeply and simultaneously engaged in a variety of fields which characterised his activities. Such activities were not always scientific or liter ary. I attended a scientific meeting with him in Czechoslovakia, during the 1968 Prague spring, where he surprised his hosts at a social evening by singing a socialist ditty extolling the work ethic. He informed us he had attempted to teach it to Bertrand Russell when they were both on remand following a CND protest.

That Alex packed such a variety of activities into one life is truly remarkable. Whatever the assessment of the value of his research, and of his non-scientific studies, from the standpoint of the 21st century, he will be remembered as someone who left an indelible mark on the one that preceded it.

fields.headline: Ian Dury
fields.standfirst: Charismatic singer, songwriter and actor who straddled the worlds of punk and rock
fields.trailText: Ian Dury, who has died of cancer aged 57, was one of the few originals of the English music scene, the only man to successfully combine the energy and excitement of rock 'n' roll and funk with the bawdy humour, wit and homespun philosophy of music hall and of his native Essex.
fields.body:
Ian Dury, who has died of cancer aged 57, was one of the few originals of the English music scene, the only man to successfully combine the energy and excitement of rock 'n' roll and funk with the bawdy humour, wit and homespun philosophy of music hall and of his native Essex. The fact that he had been crippled since childhood, and was severely ill during his final years as a performer, merely added to his stature. He was truly brave - both physically, and in the way that he approached his music.

That bravery was evident at his first major London concert, at the Hammersmith Odeon in May 1978, at the height of the punk era. The audience were told to prepare for "one of the jewels in England's crown", and on came not Dury but his hero, the veteran music-hall star Max Wall, who was barracked by the crowd until Dury stormed on to quieten them down. When he reappeared with his band, he hobbled across the stage, supported by a stick, looking like some spivvy update of a Dickensian villain. The punks were suitably impressed.

Here was a man already in his mid-30s, who looked crippled but dangerous, and had an armoury of quite extraordinary songs, ranging from the realistically romantic to the outrageous. He could belt out a thoughtful rock song like Sweet Gene Vincent, and then introduce a distinctive Essex spin. Even hardcore punks were taken aback by the stories of Plaistow Patricia or Billericay Dickie, dealing with the life and loves of losers, chancers and wide-boys from the east end and beyond. No one could match lyrics like "a love affair with Nina in the back of my Cortina, a seasoned- up hyena couldn't have been more obscener".

The man responsible was born in Harrow , west London. His father was a bus driver and later a chauffeur, who split up with his university-educated mother soon after the war. The young Ian went to live in Upminster, Essex, with his mum, but contracted polio at the age of seven. He spent several years in hospital, and at a disabled school in Sussex, then moved to the Royal Grammar School, High Wycombe. He left, with three O-levels, for Walthamstow Art School.

Then came the Royal College of Art, a stint teaching art in Canterbury, and, in 1970, the formation of his first band, Kilburn and the High Roads. They developed a minor following on the emerging London pub-rock scene, and their first album, Handsome, in 1974. It included some distinctive Dury lyrics, but was not successful.

The transformation came after Dury started writing with pianist Chas Jankel and signed to the independent Stiff label, co-founded by David Robinson, "one of the great showmen and the godfather of British funk." Dury toured with his fellow Stiff artists, including Elvis Costello, and, in October 1977, released his classic New Boots And Panties!! The album, which sold more than 1m copies, included the erotic Wake Up And Make Love With Me. In April 1978, Dury notched up his first top-ten single, What A Waste, followed later the same year by the number-one hit, Hit Me With Your Rhythm Stick, and, a year later, Reasons To Be Cheerful (Part 3). In 1980, the compilation album Juke Box Dury packaged these singles along with Dury's best-known stage anthem, Sex & Drugs & Rock 'n' Roll.

At the time, Dury insisted to me that, as an unlikely pop star, he was merely continuing his career as an artist: "I was a painter for seven years, a successful illustrator for two years, and now I'm a rock 'n' roll singer. I still feel I'm doing the same thing, but I'm not painting with paints." As for his physical disability, he had confidently used it as a part of his stage act. "I'm charismatic, and I'm not ashamed about my physical appearance," he said. "Even good-looking people have got a weakness. My weakness is so obvious that there's no point in worrying about it. Luckily, I'm quite interesting to look at. I know 'cos I painted myself as an art student about 500 times."

He succeeded partly because of the care and attention he put into his work, explaining: "I ain't a poet, I'm a lyricist," and spending weeks carefully perfecting his songs. He described his influences as "the Stax and Motown labels and Max Miller, with a lot of television thrown in."

During the 1980s, with the waning of punk and the rise of the new romantics, Dury fell out of fashion, despite some glorious tours with his band, the Blockheads. But he continued his policy of musical bravery, collaborating with trumpeter Don Cherry on the 1980 set Laughter, and travelling to Nassau the following year to record with the reggae rhythm section, Sly and Robbie, for Lord Upminster.

This was the Year Of The Disabled, and Dury contributed the thoughtfully realistic Spasticus Autisticus. The song, which contained lines like "I dribble when I nibble", was considered to be in such bad taste that, despite Dury's own disability, it was banned from radio play.

The departure of Chaz Jankel from the Blockheads proved a more serious blow and, in 1984, after the release of the unsuccessful album 4000 Weeks Holiday, Dury took a rest from live performance, and concentrated on acting. He appeared in a series of unremarkable films, including Polanski's Pirates (1986) and Hearts Of Fire, a vehicle for Bob Dylan. He had more success on stage the following year, in the Royal Court production of Jim Carter's Road. Two years later, he was back at the Court with a musical, Apples, which he had co-written with former Blockhead Mickey Gallagher. It was not a success, but Dury had continued with his policy of doing exactly what he wanted.

Never too concerned about personal wealth, he had turned down an offer from Andrew Lloyd Webber to provide the lyrics for Cats (a commission that reportedly earned millions for Richard Stilgoe). Dury had a simple explanation for rejecting Lloyd Webber: "I can't stand his music."

In 1990, the Blockheads came together again, initially to play a benefit for their former drummer Charlie Charles, who was suffering from cancer. The reunion was so successful that further shows followed over the next two years, and several members of the band collaborated on Dury's 1993 album, The Bus Driver's Prayer And Other Stories. Then, just as his career was heading for another upswing, Dury himself was diagnosed as suffering from cancer. In 1996, a tumour was removed from his colon, but two years later, further tumours were detected on his liver.

He reacted, in typical fashion, by plunging himself back into work, and 1998 will be remembered as his finest period since the glory days of the late 1970s. Once again reunited with Chaz Jankel and the Blockheads, he embarked on a series of concerts that showed he had lost none of his old verve, wit or musical skill. Their songs ranged from the funk and black humour of Mash It Up Harry and Jack Shit Georgie (an attack on the education system), through to a love song, You're My Baby.

Their new album, Mr Love Pants, was rightly hailed as the best Dury in two decades, and its success led to a series of triumphant shows that continued this year. Only last month he gave an ebullient show at the London Palladium, and also made a guest appearance on a new Madness single, Drip Fed Fred. His plans had included an appearance at the Poetry Oympics, alongside Joe Strummer, next month.

Ian Dury married twice. His first wife, Betty, was a fellow art student, and they had a son and daughter by the time they were divorced in 1985. After Betty later died of cancer, Dury married Sophie Tilson, a sculptress daughter of artist Joe Tilson, and 23 years his junior. Talking about his cancer in 1998, he said that he wouldn't be worried by the prospect of dying if it weren't for his two young sons, Bill and Albert.

webTitle: Tories accused of trying to bog down right to roam

fields.headline: Tories accused of trying to bog down right to roam
fields.trailText: Conservative MPs were yesterday accused of trying to wreck the government's right to roam legislation by tabling 138 amendments to ban access to the countryside at night, greatly restrict where walkers can enter private estates, and make criminals of those convicted of breaking new rules on ramblers' behaviour.
fields.body:
Conservative MPs were yesterday accused of trying to wreck the government's right to roam legislation by tabling 138 amendments to ban access to the countryside at night, greatly restrict where walkers can enter private estates, and make criminals of those convicted of breaking new rules on ramblers' behaviour.

Countryside campaigners claimed that many of the proposed changes would render "almost meaningless" the new freedoms promised by ministers. But opposition MPs insisted that they were trying to make the access laws workable, safer and less tempting to thieves.

Damian Green, Tory MP for Ashford, said that allowing access at night "seems a potential recipe for accidents and unnecessarily encouraging to those who might want to 'case the joint' for remote farmhouses. Most people who want access will want it during the day. If people want to see the sun set and then walk off, fine, but we don't want people wandering round all the rest of the night." He said that there were similar night-time bans in Denmark.

"We also think there should be designated access points so local authorities can say 'this is the place, you can park your car here and walk from here', rather than having people wander all over the place. It would be safer for everyone."

The changes outlined by Mr Green and fellow Tory James Paice, MP for south-east Cambridgeshire, would not entitle anyone to walk on private land unless signs, gates and paths were provided and there was "an adequate system of wardens" to police their behaviour.

Other amendments could also mean huge cuts in the up to 4m acres in England and Wales intended to be open to ramblers. Mr Green denied that the amendments were an attempt to wreck the countryside and rights of way bill, which begins its committee stage today.

"We want to make the bill practicable. We accept that the government will get the bill through. We want to get rid of the worst wrinkles," he said.

Kate Ashbrook, chairwoman of the access committee of the 128,000-member Ramblers Association, said: "It is clear they want to put a spanner in the works. If the committee debated all the amendments, they would be there to Christmas. Many of the proposals are laughable and clearly against the interests of the general public. If they get their way the freedom to roam will have so many restrictions it will be less than meaningless.

"Thousands of ramblers like walking by moonlight, looking at the stars, for badgers, or things like that. People getting lost would become criminals simply because they did not get off the fells fast enough."

Making criminals of people who swam in mountain tarns, camped or played organised games, was "over the top", Ms Ashbrook said. "They want minimum access, and people afraid to use even that."

Gordon Prentice, Labour MP for Pendle, has also tabled an amendment to the bill, which the association regards as helpful. This will seek to make clear that grazing land and moorland which is planted with heather should not be regarded as "cultivated" property which will remain closed to walkers under the proposed legislation.

webTitle: MPs investigate benefit funds that 'trap disabled'

fields.headline: MPs investigate benefit funds that 'trap disabled'
fields.trailText: MPs are to investigate the government's Independent Living Funds after accusations that they trap severely disabled people on low incomes.
fields.body:
MPs are to investigate the government's Independent Living Funds after accusations that they trap severely disabled people on low incomes.

The Commons social security committee is to hold an inquiry into the £127m ILF system after growing concern that means-testing and costly penalties are dissuading many handicapped people from taking jobs.

MPs agreed to review the system after the Guardian disclosed how Colin Hughes, 34, a BBC producer with muscular dystrophy, faced the loss of most of his grant. From this month, Mr Hughes, who uses a wheelchair, will have to contribute £234 a week - about half his take-home pay - to paying a full-time carer after he was reassessed.

ILF grants are intended to help disabled people live independent lives yet only 80 of the 15,000 people receiving grants are in employment. MPs and campaigners believe tough clawback rules are deterring people from finding jobs.

ILF recipients earning more than £30 a week lose 55% of grant up to an earnings level of £200, then pound for pound for all pay above that.

webTitle: Gates set for deal on Windows

fields.headline: Gates set for deal on Windows
fields.standfirst: Microsoft on trial: special report
fields.trailText: Microsoft, the world's largest software company, is understood to have offered a significant concession in its landmark legal battle with the US government by opening up its Windows computer code.
fields.body:
Microsoft, the world's largest software company, is understood to have offered a significant concession in its landmark legal battle with the US government by opening up its Windows computer code.

The move would allow rivals to develop products that can be used with Microsoft Windows, the software used on more than 90% of the world's personal computers, and managers hope it would be enough to head off legal attempts to break the company apart.

The Seattle-based company would also "unbundle" its internet browser from Windows. This concession goes to the heart of the government's case, as it was Microsoft's insistence that its browser be sold together with Windows that provoked the authorities into launching the anti-monopoly action more than three years ago.

Despite the moves, there were signs yesterday that an agreement between the two sides could be some way off. Sources close to the talks believe several of the 19 American states that brought the case alongside the US justice department remain to be convinced of an agreement that falls short of a break-up. Their unease about Microsoft's offer stems from the fact that a behavioural remedy - one forcing Microsoft to open up Windows, for example - is difficult to police.

There is also little trust between the two sides, largely because of the failure of a previous agreement designed to stop allegedly anti-competitive behaviour in the mid-1990s. Professor Bill Kovacic of George Washington University law school said that leaks to US papers about Microsoft's position underlined the difficult relationship. "To be successful, negotiations of this type must be secret," he said. "The fact that there has been so much disclosure by insiders of what's going on is a bad sign."

The company founded by Bill Gates has jealously guarded its source code in the past, maintaining that its frequent updates are good for the consumer and not an abuse of a monopoly position. Significantly, Microsoft's position paper, faxed to the government on Friday night, agreed that a settlement should apply to all current and future versions of Windows, according to a report in the Wall Street Journal.

This would limit the company's ability to insist on bundling any new products with Windows and would therefore remove a key part of the government's argument. The company is also expected to agree to stop using its Windows licences as a way of punishing or rewarding computer manufacturers as part of any agreement. Legal experts believe Microsoft would have to agree to some kind of third-party audit of its behaviour as well as a set of penalties if it transgresses the settlement.

Mr Gates, who gave up the day-to-day running of Microsoft earlier this year, has opposed opening up the company's source code in the past.

webTitle: Rival club owner held over Durban deaths

fields.headline: Rival club owner held over Durban deaths
fields.trailText: The owner of a rival nightclub was charged yesterday with the murder of the 13 children who died in a stampede at the Throb club in Durban last Friday.
fields.body:
The owner of a rival nightclub was charged yesterday with the murder of the 13 children who died in a stampede at the Throb club in Durban last Friday.

Swanhthan Chetty, who owns the Silver Slipper club, and two others appeared before Durban magistrates to face 13 charges of murder and more than 600 charges of assault. They were ordered to be held without bail pending another appearance on Friday.

Around 600 children were celebrating the end of term in the Throb club in Chatsworth, on the outskirts of Durban, when someone set off a teargas canister, triggering the stampede, which killed 11 children, some as young as 11. Two more died later and another 150 children were injured.

The three accused men are believed to have turned themselves in after being identified by a fourth man, understood to be a policeman, who allegedly supplied them with the teargas and who is giving evidence for the state in return for indemnity against prosecution. He is believed to be a member of the public order policing unit, or riot squad.

Witnesses say a man detonated the teargas canister and then tried to stop children fleeing. Forensic investigations are believed to have confirmed that the teargas used in the attack was police issue.

Chatsworth police officers are under investigation for alleged involvement in criminal activities. Internal police investigators working at the station complain they are overloaded with complaints.

Earlier this month four policemen from the station were charged with beating to death a deaf and speech-impaired man who had sheltered from the rain at the police station.

webTitle: De Beers: Diamonds no longer a guerrilla's best friend

fields.headline: De Beers: Diamonds no longer a guerrilla's best friend
fields.trailText: The company which has dominated the world diamond trade for nearly three-quarters of a century yesterday guaranteed for the first time that the stones it sells do not originate from rebel-held areas in Africa.
fields.byline: David Pallister and  Chris McGreal  in Johannesburg
fields.body:
The company which has dominated the world diamond trade for nearly three-quarters of a century yesterday guaranteed for the first time that the stones it sells do not originate from rebel-held areas in Africa.

At a London sale for its registered buyers De Beers, which markets around 65% of all diamond production, promised that the diamonds had not fuelled the conflicts in Angola and Congo.

The move follows intense international criticism of the company's practices in the 1990s when it bought billions of dollars worth of diamonds from war-torn areas in west and central Africa, allowing rebel groups to buy arms and supplies on the black market.

A spokesman said it would also continue its ban on stones from Sierra Leone, where diamonds fuelled a horrific conflict marked by the rebels systematic hacking off civilians' hands, arms and legs from civilians, even those of tiny children.

While human rights groups welcomed the initiative, diamond experts expressed scepticism that De Beers would be able to control the complex smuggling routes associated with the trade.

A spokesman for London-based group Global Witness, which spearheaded a campaign for more accountability, said the decision could only be regarded as genuine if De Beers promised never to buy "conflict diamonds" again.

For decades the rationale of De Beers - effectively a cartel - has been to buy as much of the world's diamond production as possible and to stockpile to maintain the price. Until 1998, De Beers's annual reports boasted of the company's ability to absorb Angolan production.

Its sales, which are held 10 times a year, are attended by about 125 "sight holders" - cutters, polishers and dealers - from Antwerp, Tel Aviv, Bombay and New York.

Yesterday's guarantee was the company's response to a June 1998 United Nations resolution which prohibited the import of Angolan diamonds without a certificate of origin from the Angolan government.

The frailty of that embargo was demonstrated last October when De Beers announced that it was suspending all imports of Angolan diamonds because of evidence of fraudulent certificates.

The UN report on sanctions-busting, published last month, detailed how diamonds from the Unita-held areas of Angola were smuggled on to the world market through Rwanda, the Ivory Coast, Namibia, South Africa and Zambia and through the unregulated parts of the diamond market in Antwerp.

Belgium accounts for nearly 80% of the rough diamond trade. Robert Fowler, the Canadian author of the UN report, accused Belgian authorities of failing to establish an effective import identification system.

"Nor has any effort been made to monitor the activities of suspect brokers, dealers and traders - virtually all of whom appear to travel freely and operate without hindrance. Once diamonds are brought to Antwerp they are almost impossible to trace," he said.

De Beers, which itself mines about 40% of diamonds produced each year, insisted yesterday that its controls would include instructing its buying offices in Antwerp as well as Tel Aviv not to buy any diamonds imported from Africa.

The company would also stop buying from the informal sector of the economy. It has closed its offices in the Congo and Guinea - two centres traditionally used for smuggling stones from Unita territory and areas held by the rebel Revolutionary United Front in Sierra Leone.

The question of whether the origin of stones can be easily determined is much disputed. De Beers said yesterday that "run of mine" diamonds - those coming from a particular area - can be sourced, reversing its longstanding insistence that Angolan diamonds could not be identified.

"Our experts can be 90% certain," the spokesman said. But the director general of the Antwerp Diamond Council, Peter Meeus, said: "It will be unworkable in practice. Batches of diamonds are handled in a mix. That makes a search for origin an impossible task."

Speaking on Radio France Internationale yesterday, a spokesman for the Belgian for eign ministry said: "It is very difficult to identify a diamond's origin. You can't find adequate systems in Africa for origin certificates."

Earlier this month, two South African diamond dealers, who were named in the Fowler report as breaking diamond sanctions against Unita, said they had sold gems purchased from the rebels to De Beers.

Brothers Joe and Ronnie de Decker were said to have supplied light weapons to Unita in exchange for the diamonds.

Ronnie de Decker denied shipping arms to the rebels but admitted that between 1993 and 1997 he bought diamond parcels worth up to $5m (£3m) from Unita, and says he sold them to De Beers or one of its associated companies. Mr De Decker claims De Beers was not in any doubt about the source of the diamonds.

A De Beers spokesman in Johannesburg said it was "very likely" that the company had bought diamonds from Mr De Decker, but that it was impossible to establish where diamonds came from once they had been polished.

Another dealer named in the report, David Zollman, said he stopped buying diamonds from conflict areas in 1997.

webTitle: Schröder joins attack on British press

fields.headline: Schröder joins attack on British press
fields.trailText: The German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, has joined Britain's ambassador in Berlin in deploring British press coverage of his country.
fields.body:
The German chancellor, Gerhard Schröder, has joined Britain's ambassador in Berlin in deploring British press coverage of his country.

"Sometimes, I see in the reports on Germany in the British press a kind of time lag," Mr Schröder was yesterday quoted as saying. "I would like more reports on the Germany of today and not on the Germany that was."

His remarks will reignite an already heated dispute which followed BMW's controversial decision to pull out of Rover.

The owner of the Telegraph group, Conrad Black, announced last week that he was suing the ambassador to Germany, Sir Paul Lever, over views he expressed in a German press interview.

Sir Paul had told the daily Die Welt that certain newspapers were not interested in "objective truth and enlightenment", but were bent on purveying a particular political line. "That's partly because these newspapers are foreign-owned by Mr [Rupert] Murdoch and Mr Black, and their underlying political philosophy is anti-European ...", the ambassador added.

While not mentioning individuals, Mr Schröder made it clear at the weekend that he too would like to see a change in the British press's outlook. Addressing the annual Königs winter conference, which aims to improve Anglo-German relations, Mr Schröder accused British journalists of being "more concerned with themselves or with far-flung parts of the world".

He said one example was the British media's perception that German society is resistant to change, arguing: "Germany is becoming more flexible."

Doubts were expressed about Germany's commitment to globalisation and rationalisation after Mr Schröder criticised the hostile bid for the German firm Mannesmann by Britain's Vodaphone Airtouch.

The Social Democratic chancellor was echoing widespread exasperation over the wartime overtones of much of the British media's coverage of Germany. Die Welt published his comments alongside a cartoon from the Sun showing Rover as a ruined building over the word "Blitzkrieg".

Mr Schröder has repeatedly signalled that he believes the rest of the world should give Germany credit for having left behind its Nazi past.

But a leading German daily newspaper, Frankfurter Allgemeine Zeitung, yesterday called his appeal for a change in British media perceptions as "worthy as it is forlorn".

The reaction to Sir Paul Lever's remarks showed that, in Britain, the battle against European integration was still being pursued by all available means, the paper said.

webTitle: Black Sea benefits as economies slip into the red

fields.headline: Black Sea benefits as economies slip into the red
fields.trailText: The Black Sea, polluted for decades by fertilisers and pesticides, is beginning to stage a limited ecological recovery, surprising scientists by its resilience.
fields.body:
The Black Sea, polluted for decades by fertilisers and pesticides, is beginning to stage a limited ecological recovery, surprising scientists by its resilience.

The improvements - solely due to the widespread economic depression in former communist states bordering the sea and along the Danube river - could, however, be rapidly reversed, an environmental conference in Istanbul heard yesterday.

Unless industrial and farming methods were transformed in the next five years, Professor Laurence Mee of Plymouth University warned the Black Sea Borders conference that an upturn in business would again trigger gigantic phytoplankton blooms which deprive plants of light and asphyxiate fish.

"There's a window of opportunity. The pressure is off for a while," said Professor Mee, a marine biologist who spent six years studying the sea's peculiar ecosystem.

"Fish stocks are increasing in some areas as the level of pollution declines in places. But there's a lack of sewage treatment and the evidence is that as economies recover they tend to go back to the same methods as before," he said.

Certain species, such as the monk seal, which was once common in the Black Sea, are said to have entirely disappeared from its waters.

The population of sturgeon, prized for its caviar, has declined dramatically - bottom-dwelling animals on which the fish graze were victims of the plankton blooms which cut out light to the sea floor.

Bottlenosed dolphins, once thought to number a million, have been reduced to no more than 300,000.

The Black Sea, landlocked apart from the narrow Bosphorus straits connecting it to the Mediterranean, has a unique ecology. Water below 150m contains vast quantities of dissolved hydrogen sulphide, the accumulation of thousands of years of decaying plants, and is devoid of marine life.

Only the top layers are fertile, particularly in the north-west, off the coast of Ukraine and Romania, where the sea is shallow.

It was the draining of marshes at the mouth of the Danube and intensive pig farming, introduced by President Nicolae Ceausescu in Romania, which resulted in thousands of tonnes of nitrogen and phosphorous fertilisers draining directly into the Black Sea from the 1960s onwards.

Those nutrients fed the phytoplankton blooms.

"Surprisingly the sea is getting better," Radu Minhea of the Black Sea environmental programme told the conference, convened in Istanbul by the British Council to bring together environmental activists from across the region.

"Economic decline has meant there's less industrial waste getting into the sea. People said it was dead, but the response has been quick."

Overfishing has also depleted the sea's stocks. Only anchovies have staged a significant recovery.

Pesticides - which can upset hormone balances, preventing breeding - may still be slowly poisoning larger mammals such as dolphins, warned Chloe Webster of the World Wide Fund for Nature.

The former Conservative environment minister, John Gummer, told the conference: "The pollution of the Black Sea is an international fact and affects us all.

"The Black Sea is part of the world's heritage."
fields.bodyText: The Black Sea, polluted for decades by fertilisers and pesticides, is beginning to stage a limited ecological recovery, surprising scientists by its resilience. The improvements - solely due to the widespread economic depression in former communist states bordering the sea and along the Danube river - could, however, be rapidly reversed, an environmental conference in Istanbul heard yesterday. Unless industrial and farming methods were transformed in the next five years, Professor Laurence Mee of Plymouth University warned the Black Sea Borders conference that an upturn in business would again trigger gigantic phytoplankton blooms which deprive plants of light and asphyxiate fish. "There's a window of opportunity. The pressure is off for a while," said Professor Mee, a marine biologist who spent six years studying the sea's peculiar ecosystem. "Fish stocks are increasing in some areas as the level of pollution declines in places. But there's a lack of sewage treatment and the evidence is that as economies recover they tend to go back to the same methods as before," he said. Certain species, such as the monk seal, which was once common in the Black Sea, are said to have entirely disappeared from its waters. The population of sturgeon, prized for its caviar, has declined dramatically - bottom-dwelling animals on which the fish graze were victims of the plankton blooms which cut out light to the sea floor. Bottlenosed dolphins, once thought to number a million, have been reduced to no more than 300,000. The Black Sea, landlocked apart from the narrow Bosphorus straits connecting it to the Mediterranean, has a unique ecology. Water below 150m contains vast quantities of dissolved hydrogen sulphide, the accumulation of thousands of years of decaying plants, and is devoid of marine life. Only the top layers are fertile, particularly in the north-west, off the coast of Ukraine and Romania, where the sea is shallow. It was the draining of marshes at the mouth of the Danube and intensive pig farming, introduced by President Nicolae Ceausescu in Romania, which resulted in thousands of tonnes of nitrogen and phosphorous fertilisers draining directly into the Black Sea from the 1960s onwards. Those nutrients fed the phytoplankton blooms. "Surprisingly the sea is getting better," Radu Minhea of the Black Sea environmental programme told the conference, convened in Istanbul by the British Council to bring together environmental activists from across the region. "Economic decline has meant there's less industrial waste getting into the sea. People said it was dead, but the response has been quick." Overfishing has also depleted the sea's stocks. Only anchovies have staged a significant recovery. Pesticides - which can upset hormone balances, preventing breeding - may still be slowly poisoning larger mammals such as dolphins, warned Chloe Webster of the World Wide Fund for Nature. The former Conservative environment minister, John Gummer, told the conference: "The pollution of the Black Sea is an international fact and affects us all. "The Black Sea is part of the world's heritage."

webTitle: Jospin calls on old guard to revive his government

fields.headline: Jospin calls on old guard to revive his government
fields.trailText: Lionel Jospin yesterday turned the clock back 15 years in a radical cabinet reshuffle that returned two political heavyweights from the Mitterrand era into leading posts and underscored the prime minister's determination to create an election-winning team.
fields.body:
Lionel Jospin yesterday turned the clock back 15 years in a radical cabinet reshuffle that returned two political heavyweights from the Mitterrand era into leading posts and underscored the prime minister's determination to create an election-winning team.

Mr Jospin, whose plans to modernise the tax, school and pension systems have run into tough union opposition, appointed Laurent Fabius, a former prime minister, and Jack Lang, the flamboyant former culture minister, to the posts of finance and education.

Mr Fabius, who was prime minister under the late president François Mitterrand from 1984 to 1986 and has been parliamentary speaker since 1997, replaces Christian Sautter, an uninspiring technocrat who last week was forced to cave in to striking civil servants over his bid to streamline the inefficient tax service.

Mr Lang, a media-friendly populist, will take over from the education minister, Claude Allègre, whose programme of school reforms has brought tens of thousands of teachers onto the streets in protest.

An opinion poll published yesterday showed a majority of voters still supported Mr Jospin's stalled attempts to drag the bloated state bureaucracies into the 21st century, with 60% saying he was capable of reforming the sprawling civil service of 5m employees.

But the prime minister had to take drastic action nearly three years after his surprise general election victory of 1997 to regain the upper hand and keep alive his expected challenge to the president, Jacques Chirac, in the presidential election due in 2002.

"Everything was starting to go wrong," said one political analyst, Catherine Nay. "Jospin no longer appeared invulnerable. He had become an ordinary politician, with his qualities and his shortcomings, his failures."

Four full ministers were replaced in the reshuffle, with four new lower level posts being created by dividing up portfolios to form an enlarged leftwing cabinet of Socialists, Communists and Greens that Mr Jospin said would prove to be "even stronger in the pursuit of [our] reform policies".

A former communications minister, Catherine Tasca, took over the culture portfolio from Catherine Trautmann, who was seen as having bungled her planned reform of television advertising, while a former finance minister, Michel Sapin, replaced the luckless minister in charge of civil service reforms, Emile Zuccarelli.

Mr Sautter, who said last week he was "mortified" by the failure of the tax collection reforms, resigned before the reshuffle was confirmed.

With local elections due next year and national and presidential polls scheduled for 2002, analysts said the arrival of Mr Fabius and Mr Lang was a clear signal of Mr Jospin's desire to consolidate the party.

Conservative MPs said the reshuffle marked a step back to a bygone era of socialism. Mr Chirac's Gaullist RPR party described the changes as "rather sad" and "a return to the Mitterrand system", while another centrist opposition group, Démocracie Libérale, said the comeback of "the old guard" was clearly a pre-election gambit.

Profile: Laurent Fabius

Laurent Fabius, 53, named finance minister, is a onetime Wunderkind who for the past two years has occupied the largely ceremonial post of speaker of the national assembly. A Mitterrand protege - the late president made him his economic adviser in 1975 - Mr Fabius became the country's youngest prime minister in 1984 at the age of 37.

Strongly critical of government economic policy over the past two years, he has called for the government to be more ambitious in cutting taxes, and to speed up privatisation.

Quite how Mr Fabius will reconcile Mr Jospin's somewhat traditional view of Socialism with his own more liberal outlook remains to be seen - some observers say the finance portfolio may well prove a poisoned chalice for Mr Jospin's greatest political rival.

But Mr Fabius, a graduate of the elite École Nationale d'Administration, is no stranger to fighting his corner. His appointment as finance minister comes after his acquittal last year on manslaughter charges, after he was accused with two of his ministers of knowingly al lowing Aids-contaminated blood to be used by the national transfusion service. France's biggest post-war public health scandal led to more than 1,000 deaths.

Profile: Jack Lang

Jack Lang, 60, is a familiar Socialist figure to French voters. Surprisingly, he appears to have given up hopes of becoming mayor of Paris to take over at the education ministry, a portfolio he held in 1992-93.

The sharp-suited, politically correct mayor of Blois, Mr Lang was twice culture minister during Mitterrand's 14-year rule and is closely associated with the late president's more grandiose cultural projects, such as the new national library.

He more than doubled the French culture budget, funded dozens of new museums, theatres, opera houses and libraries and launched an annual national music festival that draws hundreds of thousands of music-lovers into the streets every June.

In the past two years, Mr Lang has chaired the national assembly's foreign affairs committee, and until yesterday was considered a walkover for the high-profile job of Paris mayor, for which over 60% of Parisians thought he was eminently suitable.

But Mr Jospin may well have thought that the mayor's job was just a touch too plum, and rather than welcoming visiting dignitaries at Paris's ornate town hall, Mr Lang will now have to try to appease France's deeply unhappy teachers.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Elian gives first TV interview
fields.body:
Elian gives first TV interview

Elian Gonzalez, the six-year-old Cuban boy at the centre of an international custody war, drew a picture of the shipwreck in which his mother drowned during his first television interview yesterday.

The boy, interviewed on ABC's Good Morning America programme, said he believed his mother was alive but had lost her memory. The interview coincided with a US justice department deadline for Elian's Miami relatives to agree to file appeals documents by April 3 or allow the boy to return to his father in Cuba.
Reuters, Miami

New mass grave found in Uganda

Prisoners under armed guard yesterday uncovered 74 bodies from a grave in Rugazi, in south-west Uganda, which authorities suspect may be those of members of The Church for the Restoration of the Ten Commandments of God.

They appeared to have been dead about a month. Last week, 153 bodies were found in the nearby village of Buhunga and more than 400 are thought to have died when the sect's main church burned down on March 17.
AP, Rugazi

228 stranded by pilot's arrest

New York police arrested a Swissair pilot while he was jogging in Central Park and held him for 18 hours, leaving 228 passengers stranded overnight, the airline said yesterday.

The pilot, who maintains he did nothing wrong, ran into a police check while jogging in the park on Thursday. Swissair is considering whether to take legal action.
Reuters, Geneva

Serbs release 15 Kosovans

Fifteen Kosovo Albanians have been released from Serbian prisons over the last two days, the International Red Cross office in Pristina has announced, leaving approximately 1,500 ethnic Albanians in Serbian prisons.

A Serbian court also sentenced 16 Albanians who attacked Serb police during the Kosovo conflict to three years in jail.
AP, Belgrade

Voting begins in Iraqi election

Iraqis began voting yesterday in their second parliamentary election since the 1991 Gulf war.

About 8.5m Iraqis were eligible to choose 220 members of parliament from 522 candidates in the one-party state. Candidates include President Saddam Hussein's eldest son Uday.
Reuters, Baghdad

Shutdown at Chernobyl

The only working nuclear reactor at Ukraine's troubled Chernobyl power station cut its capacity by 50% yesterday after safety systems shut down a turbo-generator, an official said.

A spokeswoman for the state nuclear power company Energoatom said that no increase in radiation levels was recorded and repairs would be completed by March 30.
Reuters, Kiev

Nazi victims call for swift payout

A group representing Ukrainian victims of Nazi slave labour policies have called on Germany to speed up distribution of a compensation package, saying many survivors will die before seeing the money.

Germany's parliament, the Bundestag, must still approve the DM10m (£3.1bn) package. Negotiators reached agreement last week on how to divide the funds.
AP Kiev
