fields.headline: Storm warning
fields.standfirst: In the second world war, it defended Britain from enemy bombers. In the 60s, it was declared an independent principality, an unknown major its leader. Now the former RAF platform has become unwittingly involved in an international smuggling ring.  Will Woodward  on the strange past, fraught present and uncertain future of Sealand
fields.trailText: In the second world war, it defended Britain from enemy bombers. In the 60s, it was declared an independent principality, an unknown major its leader. Now the former RAF platform has become unwittingly involved in an international smuggling ring.  Will Woodward  on the strange past, fraught present and uncertain future of Sealand
fields.body:
For almost 33 years the principality of Sealand has appeared to be an eccentric English joke. In 1966 businessman and former army major Roy Bates took a fancy to a disused gun tower seven miles off the Suffolk coast. It measured 140m by 40m and had seen little action since enemy planes flew over on their way to bombing the capital. This, he thought, was just the place to establish his kingdom - or, to be more precise, his principality. He annexed the metal structure, originally known as Roughs Tower, and immediately installed himself as Prince Roy and his wife, a former beauty queen, as Princess Joan.

Then they set about enjoying themselves. They furnished the tower, issued their own stamps and coins (bearing the head of Princess Joan), and passports. They live there part of the time - the rest of the year they live down the coast in Westcliff-on-Sea - but some of their friends live on the tower permanently to guard it. It hasn't exactly been a quiet life - there was a failed attempt to set up a pirate radio station, the acquisition of the nation's largest inshore fishing fleet, an attempted invasion by navy helicopters, an attempt by German and Dutch armed raiders to kidnap their son and a strange link to the murder of Gianni Versace. But now they are falling victim to a multimillion-pound fraud that police believe is being carried out over the internet.

Somewhat ironically, the prince and princess are on holiday in Spain, travelling incognito as Mr and Mrs Bates, while the Spanish civil guard is investigating a gang that is involved in arms trafficking, drug smuggling and money laundering - all of which, it seems, is being conducted with fake passports supposedly issued by the Principality of Sealand.

Members of the family are not the subject of this investigation and, says Michael Bates, Prince Roy's son, are completely innocent. His father had a visit from a detective from the serious fraud squad, acting for Interpol, last year, but that was very polite and amicable.

"There is nobody more anti-drugs than my old man," says Bates, "and we have never done any money laundering. I am not saying we couldn't be used as a tax haven but we have never done anything like that."

Tap "Principality of Sealand" into your internet keyboard and chances are two sites will appear prominently. One, at www.fruitsofthesea.demon.co.uk/sealand, is a site created by Michael Bates. Official. It tells you how the family's "rights and claims of sovereignty over the island and its territorial waters have been ratified time after time over the intervening years by national courts and leading international jurists".

But there is a second website: the "official website of the Principality of Sealand", at www.principality-sealand.net. This site has a plausible explanation of the taking over of the island, features pictures of Prince Roy and his family, and is full of convincing officialese.

"The existence of the Principality of Sealand as a state and the 'de facto' recognition of it as a state was not only confirmed by expert opinions of renowned experts... but also by numerous legal acts undertaken by other states."

True enough, as far as the family is concerned. But, says the family, the site is a fake. When you run a state that officially doesn't exist, it is hard to argue that someone is pretending to be you - but this is what the Spanish police are investigating.

Princess Joan, 70, and Prince Roy, 78, are mystified by the latest investigation. But they are having a fine old time in a nice hotel on the Costa del Sol, where the former Miss Joan Collins from Essex does still think of herself as royalty. "Would you ask the same question of Princess Grace of Monaco?" she scolds.

"We declared an independent state and I thought if I had to have a title I couldn't think of a nicer one."

They have spent millions on the island, she says, since the idea first came up during a spot of pub talk with her daring husband. People have suggested various schemes involving off-shore business schemes, but nothing came of them. "Unless there was something that comes to the aid of England, we wouldn't do it. There is no way we would ever do anything anti-British. My family fought for generations. I am always English, no matter what. But I have dual nationality."

The prince calls his wife "the boss", and they say they are as blissfully happy as when they got married, 51 years ago, within three months of meeting each other at a dance. And he loves his principality: "Listen old boy, I like a bit of adventure. It's the old British tradition. Maybe Britain's changed, but there's a lot of us still about. We're very vulnerable - we are the smallest state in the world. We are wide open for criticism, but we are very careful; we don't want to do anything wrong."

He reckons someone got hold of one of his passports and copied it to make huge numbers of forgeries. "We have issued passports - several hundred. We have given them to people who work for us or people who need them. But we have never given passports [for] illegal entry. "

By contrast, the "fake" website under investigation says "the Principality of Sealand has approximately 160,000 citizens". In parts of the Spanish version, it reads, "160,000 inhabitants ", quite difficult on an island 932 yards square.

"The population of the Principality of Sealand is primarily made up of businessmen. They live in the countries they originate from," the unofficial site says. "From a political point of view, a micro-state like the Princi pality of Sealand is not very influential," it concedes. "This is why the government of the Principality of Sealand founded the Sealand International Business Foundation (SIBF) as an instrument to efficiently safeguard the economic interests of the citizens organised in its network.

"Irrespective of his/her origin, race and his/her religion, anyone can become a citizen of the Principality if he is prepared to make use of his/her talents to establish and boost the acceptance of an emerging state."

In the Spanish-language version of the site, respondents are asked to say what they are interested in: citizenship, ID cards, passports or driving licences. According to investigators from the civil guard, Spain's paramilitary police force, yesterday, those privileges are on offer to anyone willing to pay between £5,500 and £35,000 for a range of documents that includes titles, academic degrees and full Principality of Sealand diplomatic passports.

They allege that a Spaniard from the southern province of Almeria, Francisco Trujillo Ruiz, is presenting himself as the "Prince Regent of Sealand". He drives around Madrid with diplomatic number plates and refers to his office, in a luxury building on Calle Serrano, one of the smartest streets in Madrid, as Sealand's embassy.

The Spanish foreign ministry, like the British government, takes quite a different view. It does not recognise passports issued by the Principality of Sealand and says they do not comply with criteria laid down by the Schengen Treaty for international documents. But according to the investigation, several countries have been taken in by "ambassadors" who claim to represent Sealand and use their prestige in business deals.

The embassies of Gabon, Paraguay, Nepal, Syria, Haiti, Liberia, Honduras, Jamaica, Pakistan, Cyprus, Ethiopia, Jordan and Turkey all responded to requests for information from Sealand representatives who claim to be preparing lucrative investments in those countries.

Access to other Sealand privileges does not come cheap. There is a basic "goodwill" charge of £300 for the first contact. Membership of "Mare Libertas", described as Sealand's exclusive international business foundation, costs £25,000. Its main project was described as the construction of a micro-city in Sealand, with ports, sports com plexes, a medical centre, a cathedral, heliports and universities.

Trujillo Ruiz's team all hold "official" titles. His legal adviser is described as the "secretary general of the state", and there is a "foreign affairs minister" and a "chief political adviser". The civil guard is investigating the group, which appears to be "an organised crime ring" concentrating its activities on falsification and swindling. Documents supposedly issued by Sealand have been passed to investigating magistrates, who will decide whether to order arrests.

This is not the first time that passports from Sealand have found their way into the news. One was found on the killer of Gianni Versace, Andrew Cunanan, and he was said to have a car with Sealand diplomatic plates. In 1997 forged Sealand passports were used to launder drug money in Slovenia, and there were reports that 4,000 forged passports were sold at £1,000 a head before China's takeover of Hong Kong. People involved in an illegal pyramid-selling scheme in eastern Europe had Sealand papers; one had border stamps from Libya, Iraq and Iran.

This hardly seems to be Prince Roy's fault, but it is easy to see how it happens. Official-looking, plausible papers from the Principality of Sealand may raise eyebrows in Britain but, reckon the authorities, it might not attract so much suspicion in new or faraway countries that, while aware that there are tax havens off the British coast, don't necessarily know the details.

Michael Bates says he wrote to the Spanish website, asking them to leave his father's principality alone. Someone replied, citing connections with the good name of King Juan Carlos and paying tribute to the Sealanders. "He said he'd written a book on Sealand," says Bates, which may explain the pictures on the site, "but I'm thinking, what the hell is this all about. If you want, I'll go to Spain to confront them. I'd be only too happy to. They are doing us a dreadful disservice."

Meanwhile, back on Sealand, people are doing very nicely, thank you. It has electricity, television, double-glazing in the 75ft towers.

"It's not a palace, but it's not too bad," says Michael Bates. There are ongoing talks about annexing more land, maybe within the next couple of years, and even setting up a casino.

Though Sealand is not recognised by the British government, the authorities don't make life too difficult, he says. Ashore, he runs a shellfish business in Leigh-on-Sea, and says he has one of only 14 licences in the Thames estuary to farm cockles. He plans to keep Sealand going, even when his parents die. The principality has seen its way through other crises and it will see its way through this one.

There have been worse moments. In 1967, when the Ministry of Defence tried to evict them, sending out navy helicopters and the Royal Maritime auxiliary vessel Golden Eye for what Prince Roy liked to call the Battle of Roughs Tower, gunshots and molotov cocktails were fired back - as a "warning". Prince Roy was hauled to court, but a judge ruled that the platform was outside the three-mile limit of territorial waters, making the prince immune from his order.

In 1978, German and Dutch raiders - businessmen - took over the tower in a KLM helicopter in a wrangle with Prince Roy involving several million deutschmarks. They kidnapped Michael and took him to the Netherlands.

But within days Prince Roy had recaptured the island, sliding down 100ft ropes from a helicopter, fighting the invaders and capturing one of the raiders in turn. Gernot Putz, a 34-year-old German lawyer who had been a Sealand passport holder, was charged with treason and held for seven weeks. He received a "pardon".

But Michael Bates and his family are sanguine about such things. The trouble with independent states, he says, is that they are always at risk from a coup d'état. "If you are your own defence, you have got nobody to bleat to."

 Additional reporting by Adela Gooch

When you run a state that officially doesn't exist, it is hard to argue that someone is pretending to be you - but this is what the Spanish police are investigating. Princess Joan, 70, and Prince Roy, 78, are mystified by the latest investigation. But they are having a fine old time in a nice hotel on the Costa del Sol, where the former Miss Joan Collins from Essex does still think of herself as royalty. "Would you ask the same question of Princess Grace of Monaco?" she scolds. "We declared an independent state and I thought if I had to have a title I couldn't think of a nicer one." They have spent millions on the island, she says, since the idea first came up during a spot of pub talk with her daring husband. People have suggested various schemes involving off-shore business schemes, but nothing came of them. "Unless there was something that comes to the aid of England, we wouldn't do it. There is no way we would ever do anything anti-British. My family fought for generations. I am always English, no matter what. But I have dual nationality." The prince calls his wife "the boss", and they say they are as blissfully happy as when they got married, 51 years ago, within three months of meeting each other at a dance. And he loves his principality: "Listen old boy, I like a bit of adventure. It's the old British tradition. Maybe Britain's changed, but there's a lot of us still about. We're very vulnerable - we are the smallest state in the world. We are wide open for criticism, but we are very careful; we don't want to do anything wrong." He reckons someone got hold of one of his passports and copied it to make huge numbers of forgeries. "We have issued passports - several hundred. We have given them to people who work for us or people who need them. But we have never given passports [for] illegal entry. " By contrast, the "fake" website under investigation says "the Principality of Sealand has approximately 160,000 citizens". In parts of the Spanish version, it reads, "160,000 inhabitants ", quite difficult on an island 932 yards square. "The population of the Principality of Sealand is primarily made up of businessmen. They live in the countries they originate from," the unofficial site says. "From a political point of view, a micro-state like the Princi pality of Sealand is not very influential," it concedes. "This is why the government of the Principality of Sealand founded the Sealand International Business Foundation (SIBF) as an instrument to efficiently safeguard the economic interests of the citizens organised in its network. "Irrespective of his/her origin, race and his/her religion, anyone can become a citizen of the Principality if he is prepared to make use of his/her talents to establish and boost the acceptance of an emerging state." In the Spanish-language version of the site, respondents are asked to say what they are interested in: citizenship, ID cards, passports or driving licences. According to investigators from the civil guard, Spain's paramilitary police force, yesterday, those privileges are on offer to anyone willing to pay between £5,500 and £35,000 for a range of documents that includes titles, academic degrees and full Principality of Sealand diplomatic passports. They allege that a Spaniard from the southern province of Almeria, Francisco Trujillo Ruiz, is presenting himself as the "Prince Regent of Sealand". He drives around Madrid with diplomatic number plates and refers to his office, in a luxury building on Calle Serrano, one of the smartest streets in Madrid, as Sealand's embassy. The Spanish foreign ministry, like the British government, takes quite a different view. It does not recognise passports issued by the Principality of Sealand and says they do not comply with criteria laid down by the Schengen Treaty for international documents. But according to the investigation, several countries have been taken in by "ambassadors" who claim to represent Sealand and use their prestige in business deals. The embassies of Gabon, Paraguay, Nepal, Syria, Haiti, Liberia, Honduras, Jamaica, Pakistan, Cyprus, Ethiopia, Jordan and Turkey all responded to requests for information from Sealand representatives who claim to be preparing lucrative investments in those countries. Access to other Sealand privileges does not come cheap. There is a basic "goodwill" charge of £300 for the first contact. Membership of "Mare Libertas", described as Sealand's exclusive international business foundation, costs £25,000. Its main project was described as the construction of a micro-city in Sealand, with ports, sports com plexes, a medical centre, a cathedral, heliports and universities. Trujillo Ruiz's team all hold "official" titles. His legal adviser is described as the "secretary general of the state", and there is a "foreign affairs minister" and a "chief political adviser". The civil guard is investigating the group, which appears to be "an organised crime ring" concentrating its activities on falsification and swindling. Documents supposedly issued by Sealand have been passed to investigating magistrates, who will decide whether to order arrests. This is not the first time that passports from Sealand have found their way into the news. One was found on the killer of Gianni Versace, Andrew Cunanan, and he was said to have a car with Sealand diplomatic plates. In 1997 forged Sealand passports were used to launder drug money in Slovenia, and there were reports that 4,000 forged passports were sold at £1,000 a head before China's takeover of Hong Kong. People involved in an illegal pyramid-selling scheme in eastern Europe had Sealand papers; one had border stamps from Libya, Iraq and Iran. This hardly seems to be Prince Roy's fault, but it is easy to see how it happens. Official-looking, plausible papers from the Principality of Sealand may raise eyebrows in Britain but, reckon the authorities, it might not attract so much suspicion in new or faraway countries that, while aware that there are tax havens off the British coast, don't necessarily know the details. Michael Bates says he wrote to the Spanish website, asking them to leave his father's principality alone. Someone replied, citing connections with the good name of King Juan Carlos and paying tribute to the Sealanders. "He said he'd written a book on Sealand," says Bates, which may explain the pictures on the site, "but I'm thinking, what the hell is this all about. If you want, I'll go to Spain to confront them. I'd be only too happy to. They are doing us a dreadful disservice." Meanwhile, back on Sealand, people are doing very nicely, thank you. It has electricity, television, double-glazing in the 75ft towers. "It's not a palace, but it's not too bad," says Michael Bates. There are ongoing talks about annexing more land, maybe within the next couple of years, and even setting up a casino. Though Sealand is not recognised by the British government, the authorities don't make life too difficult, he says. Ashore, he runs a shellfish business in Leigh-on-Sea, and says he has one of only 14 licences in the Thames estuary to farm cockles. He plans to keep Sealand going, even when his parents die. The principality has seen its way through other crises and it will see its way through this one. There have been worse moments. In 1967, when the Ministry of Defence tried to evict them, sending out navy helicopters and the Royal Maritime auxiliary vessel Golden Eye for what Prince Roy liked to call the Battle of Roughs Tower, gunshots and molotov cocktails were fired back - as a "warning". Prince Roy was hauled to court, but a judge ruled that the platform was outside the three-mile limit of territorial waters, making the prince immune from his order. In 1978, German and Dutch raiders - businessmen - took over the tower in a KLM helicopter in a wrangle with Prince Roy involving several million deutschmarks. They kidnapped Michael and took him to the Netherlands. But within days Prince Roy had recaptured the island, sliding down 100ft ropes from a helicopter, fighting the invaders and capturing one of the raiders in turn. Gernot Putz, a 34-year-old German lawyer who had been a Sealand passport holder, was charged with treason and held for seven weeks. He received a "pardon". But Michael Bates and his family are sanguine about such things. The trouble with independent states, he says, is that they are always at risk from a coup d'état. "If you are your own defence, you have got nobody to bleat to."  Additional reporting by Adela Gooch

fields.headline: No: 1603 Tennent's
fields.body:
Yeah, yeah. Scottish brewers, makers of Tennent's Super, or Vitamin T as it's known on park benches throughout Britain - you can't tell me anything new about it. So you know all about T-pai then?

T'pau don't you mean? Had a hit in the 80s with China in Your Hand. No, this is T-pai, it's the noughties, and the problem is that China isn't in their hand.

Perhaps you'd better explain. Bass, Britain's second-biggest brewer, has failed to convince the Chinese to drink Tennent's. They're pulling out of a joint brewing venture that has seen them spend £25m since launching the T-pai brand over there in 1996.

Quite a lot T-pai then. What went wrong? Local beer is cheaper, and they like it better. And just as Bass was setting out, growth in the beer market, which had been on the up for years, started to decline. With the market literally saturated, local protectionism grew to the extent that they were putting up road blocks to stop delivery of beer from other parts of the country. So you can imagine how they felt about a lager which originally came from Glasgow.

So China was not destined to turn into a country of T-pai louts? The signs were bad right from the start, with the Chinese trying to eat haggis with chopsticks at the launch party.

Too much of a cultural revolution then? They just weren't ready for the little blue tin.

Is there a town near the T-pai factory in the remote north-east of the country with a name that, in retrospect, could be seen as a bad omen? Funny you should ask, it is near Siping...

Should have set up in Gul Ping then. Or Dau Ni Nwan.

Not to be confused with: The aforementioned T'pau, Taipei, a toupee, Stella Tennant.

Funny how both her first and second names are well-known lagers, isn't it? She's spelt differently. And it's not of any relevance to this particular pass notes.

fields.headline: A brush with the mafia
fields.standfirst: Has artist Peter Howson been forced to sell his paintings to Glasgow's gangsters on the quiet? If so, says  Jonathan Jones, it will be yet another case of the magnetic attraction between art and the criminal underworld
fields.trailText: Has artist Peter Howson been forced to sell his paintings to Glasgow's gangsters on the quiet? If so, says Jonathan Jones, it will be yet another case of the magnetic attraction between art and the criminal underworld
fields.body:
There's an episode in the hit Mafia television series The Sopranos when mobster Tony Soprano asks his girlfriend what the painting of a swimming-pool in their hotel room makes her think of. "It makes me think of David Hockey [sic]." Tony is troubled, thoughtful. He started seeing a therapist because of dreams about the ducks leaving his swimming-pool, dreams that looked like a Hockney painting.

The image of the gangster with a feeling for art is one that goes to the divided heart of our culture. Is art just for an elite, or can it be for everyone - even Tony Soprano? It's a question raised by a story in the Scotland on Sunday newspaper, which claimed that the Scottish painter Peter Howson has had to deal with the Glasgow underworld for the past 15 years. Howson, internationally known for his macho figurative paintings, is quoted in the newspaper telling how his strange relationship with the world of crime began when he was visited in the 1980s by the kingpin of the Glasgow crime scene, the late Arthur Thompson Sr, who offered cash on the spot for a canvas. Howson found himself supplying paintings to the city's criminals for a fraction of the price charged by his London dealer. When he tried to renegotiate, he got death threats. Gangsters like art, it seems, but they like it cheap.

Howson's dealer in London, Matthew Flowers, now says that the story contains so many inaccuracies the artist is planning legal action. Howson will not comment until he issues a statement later this week. One thing you can say about Howson is that his bombastic, heavy breathing paintings revelling in a world of male violence are the kind of art you can easily picture in a hard man's mansion, next to the one of the dogs playing snooker.

Personally, I hope there is nothing to the story, because I would like to think gangsters have better taste, like Tony Soprano. In the 1960s the Kray twins were familiar figures on the London art scene. The actress Anita Pallenberg remembers being in Morocco with the art dealer Robert Fraser, who represented the pop artists Peter Blake and Richard Hamilton, and meeting the Krays on the beach in Tangier. Fraser was a friend of theirs.

In 1980, Francis Bacon painted a portrait of the Krays - a romantic, anti-heroic celebration of male sexuality and violence in which one of the twins aims a phallic shotgun straight out of the painting at the viewer. Bacon's lover George Dyer was an ineffectual hanger-on from the Krays' circles; no wonder Bacon's painting of the Krays has a personal and darkly loving quality. Bacon wasn't the only artist to be seduced by the world of violent crime. In 1964, Andy Warhol painted huge portraits of America's Most Wanted Men on the New York State Pavilion at the New York World's Fair. They were painted over, reportedly because the governor was worried about offending New York's Italian community. But Warhol's paintings, based on police mugshots, were celebratory and openly sexual: these were his most wanted men.

These strange magnetic connections between art and organised crime go against everything we believe about art and sensitivity. Art is supposed to be good. Yet not only are artists drawn to crime, criminals are drawn to art. The police believe that stolen and forged paintings are used as gifts and sweeteners in the underworld. Police experts insist that this is solely because of their perceived monetary value - they are not valued as art. But how can they be so sure? You can see why the police want to believe the criminal has no finer feelings. The way we imagine the gangster's world is fixated on this question - can a killer have a soul? Can you have style and taste and still be wicked? In The Godfather films, Marlon Brando is a man of natural good taste, and when Martin Scorsese came to refute this benign vision of the mob in Goodfellas he does it through a critique of aesthetics. His gangsters have style but no culture.

Yet the Italian mob, in particular, has good evidence for claiming art and culture on its side. In the Italian Renaissance, the artist was widely seen as prone to violence and brutality. The 16th century sculptor Cellini talks frankly in his autobiography about committing brutal assaults and murders. The Renaissance artists Leone Leoni and Francesco "Torbido" of Venice were notoriously violent men. Recently a spate of biographies have argued over whether Carravaggio was a murderer - but he has certainly been remembered as such. Art and violence seemed indistinguishable in the sweaty, physical world of Renaissance Italy.

Today, art is seen in the home of the Sicilian Mafia as an antidote to mob law. One of the reforms introduced by the anti-Mafia mayor of Palermo, Leoluca Orlando, is an annual cultural festival that invites avant-garde artists to Sicily to beat ancient traditions with modernism. In 1997, the British artist Richard Long walked across Sicily, through the Mafia stronghold of Corleone, in what locals saw as a therapeutic rejection of the Mafia's rule.

But does art heal? Or does it look good in a gangland front room? The most intense relationship between a modern artist and a real-life hardman was the friendship that developed in the 1970s between the German sculptor Joseph Beuys, famous for his shamanistic art that used felt and fat and ritual gestures, and the violent criminal Jimmy Boyle. Boyle was on an art therapy course in Barlinnie Prison in Glasgow when he saw photographs of Beuys living in a cage with a coyote and wrote to the artist, claiming to be a coyote. They had discussions about art and freedom, and Boyle - who has since written books, has art exhibitions and is an icon of reformsees Beuys as his mentor.

But have you ever seen a sculpture by Jimmy Boyle? Francis Bacon's painting of the Krays is a dark masterpiece. Cellini's sculpture has an erotic violence that makes it unsurprising that he killed people. In art, there is no right and wrong. Jimmy Boyle makes bronze figurative art that is a better use of his time than beating people up, but that's the best you can say about it.

webTitle: I've only had one affair. Am I abnormal?

fields.headline: I've only had one affair. Am I abnormal?
fields.standfirst: The psychiatrist  Oliver James  investigates Britain's strange obsession with monogamy
fields.trailText: The psychiatrist,  Oliver James,  investigates Britain's strange obsession with monogamy
fields.body:
Although I am 46 years old and have had many long-term relationships with women, only once have I been sexually unfaithful. That I still recall it with horror years later makes me wonder if I am not a trifle neurotic about the issue.

We had known each other for some time when we met up for a drink at a pub with no lust aforethought on my part. She invited me back for a coffee and we drunkenly ended up in bed.

There was a bare minimum of preliminaries. The act itself cannot have lasted more than a couple of minutes. Immediately it was over I leapt under the shower to wash away my "crime" and gracelessly slunk straight off.

That is the sum total of my infidelities. In June I will be married for the first and, hopefully, only time and I am as sure as any man can be that I shall never again have sex with anyone other than my wife-to-be.

It would be nice to be able to feel virtuous and even a bit smug about this. But having recently investigated infidelity in making a TV programme and having interviewed all manner of people about it, I have been forced to question my faithful tendencies.

Were we born to be faithful or is there something wrong with me that I am prepared to sacrifice my sex instinct on the altar of fidelity? Perhaps Peter Stringfellow was right when, in the course of my research, he told me that I am missing out and that it is he who is the healthy one - if I had all his opportunities would I not also want as many different women, as nubile and as often as possible?

Pathologising Stringfellow's promiscuous and, on occasion, self-avowedly duplicitous behaviour is easy. But much of what I have to say about him goes for all sexual betrayers.

He is the first to admit that he has simply "not grown up" in wanting so many different partners. Taken literally, rather than as a value judgement, this is certainly true because we do not start life faithful. As small children all of us have a fairly indiscriminate sensuality (Freud's "polymorphous perversity") that shifts between the mouth, the anus and the genitalia. Both sexes are capable of orgasm from a young age. Although boys cannot ejaculate, as early as five months they have been observed to achieve a striking duplicate of adult orgasm. Girls are capable of real orgasms from the age of three.

There is a decrease in overt sexual behaviour during later childhood, but with the onset of puberty, snogging and heavy petting of large numbers of partners becomes normal. In mid-teens a theoretical commitment to the principle of monogamy grows, although it is often contradicted by promiscuous practice. Only in the later teens are longer term monogamous bonds usually forged. After that, rates of infidelity plummet with each succeeding decade, levelling off around retirement. Given the strong connection between youth and promiscuity, there is no doubt that Stringfellow is not grown up.

How uncommon is his pattern of sexual behaviour? Very few of the studies about sex can be trusted, but there is one that is as reliable as can be. This was the survey of nearly 20,000 Britons' sexual behaviour that Baroness Thatcher tried to ban in the early 1990s.

Unprecedented care was taken by the researchers to overcome the usual shortcomings of such surveys, and the results are probably as accurate as is possible. Only 15% of the men and 8% of the women reported having had an affair in the previous five years. Among the married, the figures were even lower: 8% of husbands, 4% of wives. While the lifetime figures would be higher than this, if they are even twice as great that would still make infidelity pretty rare.

The British Sexual Survey revealed that, in general, we don't have nearly as much sex as you might think. For instance, fully 52% of women and 38% of men had had only two or fewer partners in their lifetime. This suggests that Stringfellow is unusual if not grossly abnormal: only 24% of all men have slept with more than 10 partners in their lives. For the pathology of infidelity we must turn to the psychiatrists. Promiscuity is used as one of the defining features of a person with antisocial personality disorder (a psychopath). The psychopath's lack of empathy with others and minimal conscience about selfish actions make it easier to betray lovers. But Stringfellow is not mentally ill or a psychopath.

A new book (The Dangerous Passion, Bloomsbury) by the American sex psychologist David Buss provides evidence that some of Stringfellow's characteristics are associated with infidelity in the normal population. In a sample of 107 married couples, three personality traits predicted who would be unfaithful: narcissism, lack of conscience and impulsiveness. Elements of all these are to be found in Stringfellow.

Stringfellow's statistical unusualness and immaturity encourage me to feel that he is the one with the problem, not me. But the most convincing case for being like me was anecdotal, supplied when I interviewed Jonathan Ross, the TV presenter.

Having known Ross since the mid- 80s, I can vouch for the truth of his claim that he has always been both advocate and practitioner of fidelity. His fame, appearance and undoubted wit have furnished him with innumerable opportunities to stray but he has always resisted. His basic argument was that it was sufficient to enjoy looking at attractive women other than his wife without having to do anything about it. To put his marriage and children at risk by an affair was to place too high a premium on the sexual act and to ignore the fact that we are sentient beings, not animals.

Acting as devil's advocate, I countered as follows: "Your average baboon's dream ticket is to get a whole load of female baboons who are fascinated and excited by him. He beats up the other males so that they don't try and have sex with his 'women' and that is basically it: he's sorted. Isn't that what life's all about?"

He replied: "Where you are going horribly and somewhat embarrassingly wrong is the idea that baboons have a choice in the matter. They wake up and they scratch, they fart and they fight, they eat and they sleep. That's pretty much a baboon day.

"Now that's not a good day for a baboon, nor is that a bad day for a baboon, that's just a day because they don't have the choices. They don't think 'I rather like her, and yet I'm promised to fleabag over there.' They don't think.

"We're an evolved, intelligent interesting species and we're not just driven by instinct. If Stringfellow doesn't realize that then I do feel somewhat sorry for him, because he has a choice."

With Ross's help I could now see myself as someone who exercises choice. With the help of the scientific evidence I could also see fidelity as a sign that I am not narcissistic, have a conscience and am among the average, normal majority who do not have affairs.

Alas, the truth is nowhere near that simple. It may be normal to be faithful in sexually inhibited Britain, but that isn't true of many other countries or past societies. While only 5-10% of men in societies where more than one wife is permitted actually achieve it, the tendency for men to want to have more than one sexual outlet is strongly suggested by the fact that 84% of the 853 cultures in the world today are polygamous. Leaving aside the issues this raises about the differences between men and women, it certainly implies that my desire to be faithful to one person is not normal in the wider scheme of things.

In all patriarchal agricultural societies, such as traditional Hindu or Chinese cultures, there is not even a word for male adultery because it is so taken for granted. While romantic love is found in nearly all societies and the tendency to form intense attachments and to marry are equally widespread, infidelity or multiple partnering are also the norm, not the exception.

What's more, the British are abnormally faithful compared to much of the developed world. If the studies are to be believed, between 40-50% of married Americans and more than half of the men in much of Europe have been unfaithful. Adultery is the rule across the central and southern Adriatic coast and an accepted tradition in most of southern Europe.

The fact is that Stringfellow's promiscuity is abnormal for a modern Briton but, as an aspiration, it is the norm for a man in most of the societies there have ever been.

Psychiatrically speaking, his infidelity would appear to make him more pathological than I. But it could be argued that he is actually a courageous dissident from a repressive and unnatural status quo. That would make me the craven, compliant product of a particular society at a particular time in history.

My heart and mind reject this conclusion. I have met the woman with whom I want to share the rest of my life. Stringfellow is incapable of sustained intimacy and is immature - so there. He and all the versions of him who betray their loved ones should be more like me because, in the end, it causes less harm to all concerned.

That is my conviction. But then to what extent is morality ever anything more than the excuse the majority use to put themselves in the right?

 Oliver James presents Affairs of the Heart on Channel 4 tonight at 10.30pm.
fields.bodyText: Although I am 46 years old and have had many long-term relationships with women, only once have I been sexually unfaithful. That I still recall it with horror years later makes me wonder if I am not a trifle neurotic about the issue. We had known each other for some time when we met up for a drink at a pub with no lust aforethought on my part. She invited me back for a coffee and we drunkenly ended up in bed. There was a bare minimum of preliminaries. The act itself cannot have lasted more than a couple of minutes. Immediately it was over I leapt under the shower to wash away my "crime" and gracelessly slunk straight off. That is the sum total of my infidelities. In June I will be married for the first and, hopefully, only time and I am as sure as any man can be that I shall never again have sex with anyone other than my wife-to-be. It would be nice to be able to feel virtuous and even a bit smug about this. But having recently investigated infidelity in making a TV programme and having interviewed all manner of people about it, I have been forced to question my faithful tendencies. Were we born to be faithful or is there something wrong with me that I am prepared to sacrifice my sex instinct on the altar of fidelity? Perhaps Peter Stringfellow was right when, in the course of my research, he told me that I am missing out and that it is he who is the healthy one - if I had all his opportunities would I not also want as many different women, as nubile and as often as possible? Pathologising Stringfellow's promiscuous and, on occasion, self-avowedly duplicitous behaviour is easy. But much of what I have to say about him goes for all sexual betrayers. He is the first to admit that he has simply "not grown up" in wanting so many different partners. Taken literally, rather than as a value judgement, this is certainly true because we do not start life faithful. As small children all of us have a fairly indiscriminate sensuality (Freud's "polymorphous perversity") that shifts between the mouth, the anus and the genitalia. Both sexes are capable of orgasm from a young age. Although boys cannot ejaculate, as early as five months they have been observed to achieve a striking duplicate of adult orgasm. Girls are capable of real orgasms from the age of three. There is a decrease in overt sexual behaviour during later childhood, but with the onset of puberty, snogging and heavy petting of large numbers of partners becomes normal. In mid-teens a theoretical commitment to the principle of monogamy grows, although it is often contradicted by promiscuous practice. Only in the later teens are longer term monogamous bonds usually forged. After that, rates of infidelity plummet with each succeeding decade, levelling off around retirement. Given the strong connection between youth and promiscuity, there is no doubt that Stringfellow is not grown up. How uncommon is his pattern of sexual behaviour? Very few of the studies about sex can be trusted, but there is one that is as reliable as can be. This was the survey of nearly 20,000 Britons' sexual behaviour that Baroness Thatcher tried to ban in the early 1990s. Unprecedented care was taken by the researchers to overcome the usual shortcomings of such surveys, and the results are probably as accurate as is possible. Only 15% of the men and 8% of the women reported having had an affair in the previous five years. Among the married, the figures were even lower: 8% of husbands, 4% of wives. While the lifetime figures would be higher than this, if they are even twice as great that would still make infidelity pretty rare. The British Sexual Survey revealed that, in general, we don't have nearly as much sex as you might think. For instance, fully 52% of women and 38% of men had had only two or fewer partners in their lifetime. This suggests that Stringfellow is unusual if not grossly abnormal: only 24% of all men have slept with more than 10 partners in their lives. For the pathology of infidelity we must turn to the psychiatrists. Promiscuity is used as one of the defining features of a person with antisocial personality disorder (a psychopath). The psychopath's lack of empathy with others and minimal conscience about selfish actions make it easier to betray lovers. But Stringfellow is not mentally ill or a psychopath. A new book (The Dangerous Passion, Bloomsbury) by the American sex psychologist David Buss provides evidence that some of Stringfellow's characteristics are associated with infidelity in the normal population. In a sample of 107 married couples, three personality traits predicted who would be unfaithful: narcissism, lack of conscience and impulsiveness. Elements of all these are to be found in Stringfellow. Stringfellow's statistical unusualness and immaturity encourage me to feel that he is the one with the problem, not me. But the most convincing case for being like me was anecdotal, supplied when I interviewed Jonathan Ross, the TV presenter. Having known Ross since the mid- 80s, I can vouch for the truth of his claim that he has always been both advocate and practitioner of fidelity. His fame, appearance and undoubted wit have furnished him with innumerable opportunities to stray but he has always resisted. His basic argument was that it was sufficient to enjoy looking at attractive women other than his wife without having to do anything about it. To put his marriage and children at risk by an affair was to place too high a premium on the sexual act and to ignore the fact that we are sentient beings, not animals. Acting as devil's advocate, I countered as follows: "Your average baboon's dream ticket is to get a whole load of female baboons who are fascinated and excited by him. He beats up the other males so that they don't try and have sex with his 'women' and that is basically it: he's sorted. Isn't that what life's all about?" He replied: "Where you are going horribly and somewhat embarrassingly wrong is the idea that baboons have a choice in the matter. They wake up and they scratch, they fart and they fight, they eat and they sleep. That's pretty much a baboon day. "Now that's not a good day for a baboon, nor is that a bad day for a baboon, that's just a day because they don't have the choices. They don't think 'I rather like her, and yet I'm promised to fleabag over there.' They don't think. "We're an evolved, intelligent interesting species and we're not just driven by instinct. If Stringfellow doesn't realize that then I do feel somewhat sorry for him, because he has a choice." With Ross's help I could now see myself as someone who exercises choice. With the help of the scientific evidence I could also see fidelity as a sign that I am not narcissistic, have a conscience and am among the average, normal majority who do not have affairs. Alas, the truth is nowhere near that simple. It may be normal to be faithful in sexually inhibited Britain, but that isn't true of many other countries or past societies. While only 5-10% of men in societies where more than one wife is permitted actually achieve it, the tendency for men to want to have more than one sexual outlet is strongly suggested by the fact that 84% of the 853 cultures in the world today are polygamous. Leaving aside the issues this raises about the differences between men and women, it certainly implies that my desire to be faithful to one person is not normal in the wider scheme of things. In all patriarchal agricultural societies, such as traditional Hindu or Chinese cultures, there is not even a word for male adultery because it is so taken for granted. While romantic love is found in nearly all societies and the tendency to form intense attachments and to marry are equally widespread, infidelity or multiple partnering are also the norm, not the exception. What's more, the British are abnormally faithful compared to much of the developed world. If the studies are to be believed, between 40-50% of married Americans and more than half of the men in much of Europe have been unfaithful. Adultery is the rule across the central and southern Adriatic coast and an accepted tradition in most of southern Europe. The fact is that Stringfellow's promiscuity is abnormal for a modern Briton but, as an aspiration, it is the norm for a man in most of the societies there have ever been. Psychiatrically speaking, his infidelity would appear to make him more pathological than I. But it could be argued that he is actually a courageous dissident from a repressive and unnatural status quo. That would make me the craven, compliant product of a particular society at a particular time in history. My heart and mind reject this conclusion. I have met the woman with whom I want to share the rest of my life. Stringfellow is incapable of sustained intimacy and is immature - so there. He and all the versions of him who betray their loved ones should be more like me because, in the end, it causes less harm to all concerned. That is my conviction. But then to what extent is morality ever anything more than the excuse the majority use to put themselves in the right?  Oliver James presents Affairs of the Heart on Channel 4 tonight at 10.30pm.

fields.headline: I was helping women
fields.standfirst:
I'm accused of politicising health service appointments

The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: The commissioner for public appointments has heard of several instances of good candidates being rejected places on NHS boards in order to meet equal opportunity targets. I plead guilty. In any process of selection, some applicants will inevitably be rejected even though they are good candidates. The process would only be wrong if an inferior applicant got the job.
fields.body:
Under the Tory government the boards of NHS trusts and health authorities were dominated by men and didn't reflect the make up of the local community. Many didn't live locally and some showed little commitment to the principles of the NHS. Most trade unionists were banned by law from membership.

Labour pledged we would make NHS boards more representative of the communities they serve. As health secretary I upheld that pledge. Half of those I appointed are women, and the proportion of black and Asian appointees has almost doubled to 12%. In London, where a quarter of the adult population is black or Asian, a quarter of board members are black or Asian. I also increased the proportion drawn from carers, users, or voluntary bodies to 20%. Most live in their areas. I can't see much wrong with that. But the commissioner for public appointments and the scrutiny panel aren't at all happy - and their unhappiness isn't confined to party affiliations.

The panel rather condescendingly admits that "it may indeed be the case that the inclusion of community service has tapped a pool of non-traditional suitable candidates". It is really big of them to concede that being a carer, or a member of a local voluntary group, or coming from a particular ethnic group, may bring to NHS decision-making insights and understanding which will benefit patients and staff.

But they go on to quote "one contributor to the scrutiny" as remarking "ministers will have to choose between able and effective (management) boards or an expression of equality". If such a statement were to be made by someone in the Metropolitan police it would be used as evidence of institutionalised racism. But the scrutiny panel doesn't include this quotation to illustrate the attitudes I was up against. Far from it.

Instead, they say they have heard of several instances of good candidates being rejected in order to meet equal opportunity targets.

I plead guilty. In any process of selection, some applicants will inevitably be rejected even though they are good candidates. The process would only be wrong if an inferior applicant got the job.

Why did the scrutiny panel conclude that the women or blacks or Asians who were appointed were inferior? After all, we are talking about the NHS where 75% of the staff are women and 21% of hospital doctors are black or Asian. I can't accept that some groups are fit to make up the workforce but are not capable of being decision-makers.

I told officials I found it hard to believe there wasn't more than one woman in say, Hertfordshire, or one black person in say, Birmingham, or one Asian in say, Southall, who was up to the job.

Of course some people got appointed who turned out to be below par. In a few cases it was necessary to get them to agree quietly to resign. As far as I can recall every one of these was a white man whose original appointment had very strong backing from the establishment.

The other main charge is that I appointed a lot of Labour supporters. I disappointed an awful lot more. At a Labour local government conference I was "given the bird" when I stated that I had no intention of "appointing Labour dead-heads in place of Tory dead-heads". Labour people are keen to serve the NHS under a Labour government while Tories are less so - particularly when the Tory party leadership have denounced most of the reforms we have introduced in the NHS, despite the fact that they have generally been welcomed by the professionals. In any case, three-quarters of the NHS appointees have no political affiliation, and the report concedes "no candidate has been appointed without going through the full appointments process".

The commissioner concluded appointments have been systematically politicised by:

a) asking MPs to comment on shortlists for people to chair boards; and

b) inviting nominations from MPs and local councils (of all parties).

The first practice was introduced by the Tories, presumably with the approval of the previous commissioner for public appointments, Sir Len Peach. Nominations from MPs and local councils were part of my effort to make boards more representative of the communities they serve. I thought local elected representatives would come up with some useful names.

What Dame Rennie Fritchie's report didn't mention was that I only introduced that after discussions with Sir Len Peach. He saw me as following his own approach to increasing the number of women and ethnic minority candidates - by increasing the number of good applications. Far from being embarrassed, I am proud of the way I carried out our pledge to make NHS boards more representative - even if some of them are Labour supporters.

I have asked Dame Rennie Fritchie to advise me on appointment procedures to be followed by the Mayor of London. My invitation still stands. But I make one thing clear, I want to appoint talented people and people who reflect the population of the city. Lots of people fit both requirements.

 Frank Dobson is Labour's candidate for mayor of London.

fields.headline: Corrections and clarifications
fields.trailText: In an item contributed to a diary, page 9, Media, yesterday, we referred to the fact that the London Evening Standard had made clear its support for the author and journalist Tom Bower who is being sued by Richard Branson over an article in the Standard which questioned Branson's motives in seeking to run the lottery. Our item said that any reference to the fact that Bower's wife, Veronica Wadley, worked for Associated as the features editor of the Daily Mail was "strangely missing" from the editorial run by the "Associated-owned" Standard. We neglected to point out that the relationship between Veronica Wadley and Associated was made completely clear on page 9 of the same issue of the Standard (and she is, in fact, deputy editor of the Mail, not features editor). We regret any suggestion that the Standard was supporting Bower because of his wife's connection with Associated. Apologies to Tom Bower, Veronica Wadley and    the editor of the Standard, Max Hastings.

Dorothy Squires appeared posthumously in the birthdays, March 25, page 22. She died in April, 1998. Apologies.

In a piece headed Back from the brink (etc), page 1, Sport, March 25, we may have given the impression that English football clubs did not do very well in any of the Europe competitions in the 90s before 1997. Perhaps we should have mentioned that Arsenal won the European Cup Winners Cup in 1994 and were runners-up in the same contest the following year.

The person shown on page 11 of today's (pre-printed) Guardian Education is not James Wright, vice-chancellor of Newcastle University, but John Midwinter, vice-provost of University College London. Apologies to both.

In recommending the Jesus 2000 award exhibition, page 19, the Scotland edition of the Guide, yesterday, we got the name of the gallery and the name of the winner wrong. The entries may be seen at the Gallery of Modern Art, Queen Street, Glasgow. The winner was Kenny Hunter, and not Nicola Hicks, who was among the runners-up (a note of confusion introduced in the editing for which we apologise).

The women's a cappella group to which we intended to refer on page 13 of the Guide (North edition), March 25, under Liverpool-Merseyside Festival, is Soul Purpose, not Foul Purpose.

fields.headline: Car-sharing trend takes off
fields.standfirst: Another Monday, another mega merger... DaimlerChrysler 'footprint' lands on Mitsubishi
fields.trailText: Another Monday, another mega motor merger. Last week it was General Motors and Fiat with news of the huge industrial alliance. Yesterday it was the turn of DaimlerChrysler, announcing that it is taking effective control of Japan's Mitsubishi Motors through a 34% holding. Almost as an aperitif to the much anticipated main course, Volkswagen took a one-third stake in truck maker Scania.
fields.byline: Mark Milner, Nicholas Bannister and Jonathan Watts  in Tokyo
fields.body:
Another Monday, another mega motor merger. Last week it was General Motors and Fiat with news of the huge industrial alliance. Yesterday it was the turn of DaimlerChrysler, announcing that it is taking effective control of Japan's Mitsubishi Motors through a 34% holding. Almost as an aperitif to the much anticipated main course, Volkswagen took a one-third stake in truck maker Scania.

The latest deals form an intriguing pattern. GM is not taking overall control in Fiat's car business; it is settling for 20% - with first refusal, however, on the rest. Fiat will become the US car group's biggest shareholder, albeit with only a 5% holding.

The DaimlerChrysler/Mitsubishi deal mirrors the earlier tie-up between Renault and Nissan: a less than majority stake but a clear understanding about which side will be running the business.

The German-American group is paying just under £1.3bn for its stake in Mitsubishi, a move which will dramatically increase its presence in Asia while providing a much needed cash injection for its indebted Japanese partner.

As DaimlerChrysler chairman Jürgen Schrempp put it: "With the giant footprint of this group in the worldwide automotive market we're now where we always wanted to be."

The new allies, which between them will build about 6.5m cars a year, appear to be a good fit. Although Mitsubishi is poorly represented in the European market, its manufacturing base in the Netherlands will become a 50/50 joint venture with its new partner and be the bridgehead for developing and making new small cars for the European market, solving DaimerChrysler's problem about a partner for its Smart car. It will also give DaimlerChrysler a valuable entry port into the Japanese market and elsewhere in Asia where what has of late been sluggish growth is expected to take off rapidly.

The rationale behind the latest deal, as with the others, is familiar enough. In a fiercely competitive global automotive business, manufacturers want to be able to offer consumers more choice, more cheaply, more often and to do that they know they have to take cost out of the business. The chosen route is to share those things which do not give a marque or model its individuality. Who cares who made the starter motor, the headlights, the power train or the platform, provided they all work efficiently?

But the way the deals are being structured suggests that, for all the global nature of the business, national sensitivities still count.

There is no way the Agnelli family could have ceded control of what is an icon of Italian manufacturing industry without a huge row in Italy.

Nor, despite Nissan's travails at the time, could Renault have taken over the Japanese automotive group - even if it had wanted to put up extra cash. This time round DaimlerChrysler looks to be showing a consideration towards national sensitivities.

'Independently managed'

Although DaimlerChrysler will have a decisive say in Mitsubishi's affairs, with its representatives holding three of the 10 board seats the Japanese car group's president, Katsuhiko Kawasoe, was still able to maintain yesterday that his company would remain "an independently managed business".

Nor does the agreement include any arrangements for DaimlerChrysler to increase its stake.

The Scania/VW deal is more complex. VW, which had been talking to Scania for some time, got its opportunity because the European Commission blocked the acquisition of the Swedish truck maker by rival manufacturer Volvo. What it has done is buy - at a pretty stiff price - a large slice of the shareholding in Scania owned by the Swedish investment group Investor. However, Investor remains a shareholder, at least for the time being, as does Volvo, which built up a 45.6% holding as part of its campaign to acquire Scania.

Nevertheless, national sensitivities do exist. Although Volvo recently sold its car business to Ford it is worth remembering that a previous attempt by Renault to acquire the whole of Volvo was blocked by shareholders whose motivation was not entirely financial.

Ahead of yesterday's deal some Swedish commentators had expressed concern that if Volvo and Scania were kept apart and one or other was taken over a by a foreign firm it could provide a fillip to the country's eurosceptics.

Is there any comfort in this for the UK car industry where sensibilities have been badly ruffled, to say the least, by BMW's decision to dismember Rover? Probably not. Japan in particular is a country where, even though some of the car makers may be having troubles, they are still an attractive investment because of their proximity to Asia's emerging markets.

By contrast, the British car makers are struggling in a mature market where there is too much capacity and new car sales are generated by replacement not by an expansion of the overall demand.

Against that background BMW decided Rover was expendable and never mind national sensibilities. It is hard to see another car maker taking a different view and challenging Alchemy Partners' plans for turning the company into a niche player, manufacturing MG sports cars.

Making their marques

Who manufactures what among the biggest carmakers:

General Motors: Chevrolet, Pontiac, Oldsmobile, Buick, Cadillac, Saturn, Vauxhall, Opel, Saab (cars), Holden, Isuzu. 20% stake in Fiat Auto

Ford: Ford, Jaguar, Volvo, Aston Martin, Lincoln, Mercury. 33% stake in Mazda; negotiating £1.8bn takeover of Land-Rover

DaimlerChrysler: Mercedes, Chrysler, Plymouth, Dodge, Jeep, Smart. 34% stake in Mitsubishi

Toyota: Toyota, Lexus. 51% stake in Daihatsu

Volkswagen: Volkswagen, Audi, Seat, Skoda, Bugatti, Bentley, Rolls-Royce (until 2003), Lamborghini, Cosworth

VW, which had been talking to Scania for some time, got its opportunity because the European Commission blocked the acquisition of the Swedish truck maker by rival manufacturer Volvo. What it has done is buy - at a pretty stiff price - a large slice of the shareholding in Scania owned by the Swedish investment group Investor. However, Investor remains a shareholder, at least for the time being, as does Volvo, which built up a 45.6% holding as part of its campaign to acquire Scania. Nevertheless, national sensitivities do exist. Although Volvo recently sold its car business to Ford it is worth remembering that a previous attempt by Renault to acquire the whole of Volvo was blocked by shareholders whose motivation was not entirely financial. Ahead of yesterday's deal some Swedish commentators had expressed concern that if Volvo and Scania were kept apart and one or other was taken over a by a foreign firm it could provide a fillip to the country's eurosceptics. Is there any comfort in this for the UK car industry where sensibilities have been badly ruffled, to say the least, by BMW's decision to dismember Rover? Probably not. Japan in particular is a country where, even though some of the car makers may be having troubles, they are still an attractive investment because of their proximity to Asia's emerging markets. By contrast, the British car makers are struggling in a mature market where there is too much capacity and new car sales are generated by replacement not by an expansion of the overall demand. Against that background BMW decided Rover was expendable and never mind national sensibilities. It is hard to see another car maker taking a different view and challenging Alchemy Partners' plans for turning the company into a niche player, manufacturing MG sports cars. webTitle: Thus drops the cost of US calls

fields.headline: Thus drops the cost of US calls
fields.trailText: Phone users will be able to call California for the same price as calling Croydon, under a new tariff launched yesterday by Thus, the telecoms group.
fields.body:
Phone users will be able to call California for the same price as calling Croydon, under a new tariff launched yesterday by Thus, the telecoms group.

The company is offering business customers a rate of 2.55p a minute for calls within Britain or to the US, in a deal branded as TransCall.

Thus chief executive Bill Allan said the "innovative pricing initiative" was designed to provide greater choice and flexibility to our customers.

News of the initiative sent Thus shares up 12p to 681p.

A company spokesman said it could afford to offer cheap rates because of the high volume of international calls its customers made and because of the competitive nature of transatlantic telecoms traffic. He said: "Thus has negotiated excellent terms with third party phone companies in the US."

Originally part of Scottish Power, Thus was floated on the stock market last year. It has more than 500 corporate customers including the BBC and Royal Bank of Scotland.

Analysts said other phone companies would be forced to come up with similar deals. One said: "They're showing they can deliver. They're more advanced than some of the other operators, but they've not yet got the same profile."

Thus has also launched FlexiCall, which offers a daytime rate for British business calls starting at 1.9p a minute. Those spending a lot of time on the phone can claim discounts of up to 20%.

fields.headline: Allied Domecq
fields.trailText: Though Vivendi, Seagram and Cox Communications have shrugged off reports of a three way tie-up, the speculation serves to highlight the belief that at some point Seagram will seek partners for its media interests - leaving the drinks business free to do the same.
fields.body:
Though Vivendi, Seagram and Cox Communications have shrugged off reports of a three way tie-up, the speculation serves to highlight the belief that at some point Seagram will seek partners for its media interests - leaving the drinks business free to do the same.

Such talk may infuriate Seagram chief executive Edgar Bronfman but the rest of the drinks industry must be raising a glass of something or other at the thought of such an alliance. Not least among them will be Allied Domecq, the Ballantine's whiskey to Beefeater gin group.

Earlier this month Allied lost its place in the FTSE 100 and saw its shares fall to below 250p - though they have since recovered to above £3.

No doubt it would like to see itself restored to the upper echelons of corporate society, especially on the back of a deal with Seagram. Certainly it has made no secret of its desire to see further consolidation within the drinks industry with itself in the vanguard.

But, assuming the chance came along, would the group have the firepower to clinch the deal? Allied is a big player in the spirits business yet analysts believe it might be stretched to stump up the $7bn (£4.4bn) Seagram's drinks business might be expected to command. After all, its own market capitalisation is only about £3.3bn.

It could opt for a "no premium" merger along the lines of the Guinness-GrandMet merger. Certainly its range of brands would sit nicely alongside Seagram's Chivas Regal whisky and Martell cognac.

But others would have exactly the same idea too. One group which is hotly tipped to rival Allied if Seagram does go looking for a partner is Bacardi. Its brands - the white rum that carries the company's name and Dewar's scotch - would sit just as nicely in a combined drinks cabinet. Brown-Forman from the US would not want to be left behind either.

Is there scope for Allied to expand without waiting to see if all the speculation about Seagram comes true? Maybe. The creation of Diageo raised the stakes. Other drinks groups such as France's Pernod-Ricard have been linked with Allied in the past and no doubt will be again. The industry is not going to stand still.

webTitle: TT profits dive but outlook brightens

fields.headline: TT profits dive but outlook brightens
fields.trailText: Now is not a good time to be a British automotive supplier. Export markets are hard to penetrate because of the strength of sterling, and the City does not favour engineering firms (if not manufacturing generally).
fields.body:
Now is not a good time to be a British automotive supplier. Export markets are hard to penetrate because of the strength of sterling, and the City does not favour engineering firms (if not manufacturing generally).

TT Group has all these problems and more with a number of its start-up businesses in Germany and the US suffering birth pains over the last 12 months.

Analysts would be forgiven for steering clear of the shares yesterday given confirmation that annual pre-tax profits tumbled to £38m from £65m.

Instead the share price climbed by 7%. Why? Partly relief that the financial position had not got any worse after a profits warning, coupled with reassurances that the future trading environment looks a bit brighter.

But the main impetus was a commitment to ditch its £60m turnover packaging business and get out of some other non-core activities.

TT is promising also to switch more manufacturing capability from the UK to low-cost countries such as Mexico and Malaysia where it has established plants.

Executive chairman John Newman never shied away from tough decisions and has drastically pruned down a company once regarded as a conglomerate.

But Mr Newman has good reason to be keen on shareholder value. He does, after all, own nearly 10% of the company and is extremely unhappy about a share price which has fallen dramatically in the past two years - from a high of 380p in May 1998 to close at 92p yesterday.

He gave strong hints that if TT remains in the stock market doghouse for much more than the next 12 months, he will consider following the example of Hall Engineering and take TT private via a management buy out.

Such a move might seem attractive but Mr Newman would not like to lose the flexibility to make share-based acquisitions which remain part of his current strategy.

Analysts are cautiously confident that the company, which enjoyed 19% compound growth over 10 years, is now on the mend. They are pencilling in pre-tax profits of £41m for the coming 12 months heartened by Mr Newman's talks of a "limited recovery" in key markets.

fields.headline: Pouring oil on troubled waters
fields.standfirst: Back to the 70s in Vienna and Oslo
fields.trailText: Just for a moment it felt like the 1970s. Opec leaders were in conclave in Vienna with the financial markets hanging on oil ministers' every word. Would there be a deal? When? Meanwhile, in Germany the country's biggest union was squaring up to the employers over an inflation-busting pay increase. In Paris the prime minister, Lionel Jospin, was reshuffling his cabinet pack, including replacing a finance minister whose standing had been damaged by union opposition to tax reform proposals. Even Norway's normally moderate unions were sounding militant.
fields.body:
Just for a moment it felt like the 1970s. Opec leaders were in conclave in Vienna with the financial markets hanging on oil ministers' every word. Would there be a deal? When? Meanwhile, in Germany the country's biggest union was squaring up to the employers over an inflation-busting pay increase. In Paris the prime minister, Lionel Jospin, was reshuffling his cabinet pack, including replacing a finance minister whose standing had been damaged by union opposition to tax reform proposals. Even Norway's normally moderate unions were sounding militant.

Thoughts that the free market mechanism was suddenly under attack on two fronts - an oil producers' cartel on the one hand and organised labour on the other - were short lived, however.

Despite disagreements, Opec looks on course for a deal somewhere between the 1m barrels a day sought by the hawks and the 1.7m recommended by the moderates.

The producers know it is in their interests as much as the oil consumers' that output is set at a rate which is sustainable - sufficient, that is, to keep the price at a low enough level to keep global growth on track. They know, too, that the restraint which drove the price up from $10 to more than $30 a barrel would be fragile without a deal this week. Kuwait, for example, has already said it does not see a $30 plus price as a good idea.

Elsewhere, obstreperous of Oslo is merely engaging in ritual brinkmanship. Paris is playing politics, though the return of a heavyweight like Laurent Fabius is not without risk to Mr Jospin's personal ambitions. Even IG Metall, for long the standard-bearer of a social market economy rather than a market economy, must be wondering just how good its prospects for a big victory really are - even if warnings of the consequences of "excessive" pay demands came from a somewhat unusual source. IG Metall's Klaus Zwickel must have had a wigging or two over the years from the Bundesbank but this must have been his first from the governor of the Bank of Portugal.

But the identity of the messenger is hardly relevant. The European Central Bank knows the engineering union is a crucial test of its mettle and it will have seen that others, notably in the chemical industry, have already settled for less.

It is worth noting, too, that the early industrial action - as a sign of things to come - is being taken at a DaimlerChrysler factory near Stuttgart. That is close to the car company's home but, on a day when Daimler effectively took control of Mitsubishi, is it really that close to its heart?

The 1970s are history. Just ask the workers at Longbridge.

Closing on a deal

Microsoft's long-running battle with the US justice department could be nudging towards a close. The group is reported to have made an offer including allowing personal computer and software makers to add competitors' products such as internet browsers or media players to Microsoft's Windows.

On the face of it the move looks an important one, not least because it signals that Microsoft is serious about reaching a settlement. Whether it goes far enough remains to be seen. The indications are that some government officials are prepared to accept the deal while others are prepared to soldier on in the search for further concessions.

It will not be an easy call. The political climate is changing. It will not have escaped the justice department that, in the run-up to the presidential elections, there is bound to be fall-out from anything which might be seen to weaken Microsoft too much. Certainly the much talked about break-up of Bill Gates' empire might be hard to shrug off for anyone with his sights on the White House

But justice officials and in particular Judge Thomas Penfield Jackson will need to consider very carefully not just where Microsoft is coming from but where it is going. The computer industry is a fast-changing beast. One of Microsoft's great strengths in the past has been not so much its inventiveness but its ability to spot a new development sufficiently early and then to move into the new area. There are signs that it has spotted several new areas. It has, for example, strengthened its alliance with internet navigation firm RealNames by taking a 20% stake in the group in what has been seen as a direct challenge to America Online' s browser technology.

The $3bn (£1.8bn) games console market is another area where Microsoft looks likely to expand. It already dominates the PC games market by vacuuming up exclusive licensing agreements.

Now its X-Box is its secret weapon in the battle for pre-eminence in games technology - an area it once looked down on.

The regulators need to keep all this firmly in mind. When the a deal is finally done, whether it is agreed or imposed, they need to be sure they are not just settling past disputes but laying down a marker or two for the future.

fields.headline: Going live
fields.standfirst: MacKenzie plans to float Wireless Group
fields.trailText: Kelvin MacKenzie, the larger-than-life former editor of the Sun newspaper, yesterday announced plans to float his radio business, the Wireless Group, in a move likely to value the company at up to £200m.
fields.body:
Kelvin MacKenzie, the larger-than-life former editor of the Sun newspaper, yesterday announced plans to float his radio business, the Wireless Group, in a move likely to value the company at up to £200m.

Mr MacKenzie said he planned to float 25% of the group to raise funds for growing existing franchises including TalkSport and to develop new media opportunities. A listing will also provide the company, which claims to be the fourth-biggest radio group in Britain, with the "currency" of shares to make further acquisitions.

Mr MacKenzie, a veteran of the then Mirror Group's infamous cable channel Live TV, formed the Wireless Group in November 1998 when he led the buyout of Talk Radio. His 7% stake in the business will be worth up to £14m.

"It's unreasonable to expect the shareholders to keep bearing the burden," he said. "We need money for acquisitions in radio, and new media opportunities generally. Anything that fits with radio."

The Wireless Group's first acquisition came in July last year when it paid £47m for the eight wholly owned and three partly owned stations of the Radio Partnership.
