webTitle: Share prices hit as Opec dithers

fields.headline: Share prices hit as Opec dithers
fields.trailText: The world's biggest oil exporters last night inched towards agreement over increasing crude output at a crunch meeting in Vienna.
fields.body:
The world's biggest oil exporters last night inched towards agreement over increasing crude output at a crunch meeting in Vienna.

Signs that a deal was imminent sent oil shares rattling down. BP Amoco lost 5% of its paper value to close at 512.5p.

But as the talks adjourned last night the west remained anxious for a decisive move by the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries. This would ease fears about the effect of higher oil prices on global inflation and growth.

Opec members agreed a year ago to remove 4.32m barrels of oil per day from the market in an attempt to raise prices from historically low levels. Since then the Brent blend price has risen from $10 per barrel to $32, the highest level for nine years. But the quota deal comes to an end this month and western nations hope to see the price drop to $25 as a result of a significant increase in output.

Yesterday Opec oil ministers met in Vienna to try to overcome tactical disagreements about the way forward. They want to reduce oil prices slightly without sending them crashing down again.

Saudi Arabia, the group's most influential member, argued for an increase of about 1.7m barrels. But Iran said that an increase should be capped at just over 1m barrels.

Iran's Bijan Zanganeh pointed out that Iraq would soon be able to export a lot more crude under agreements with the United Nations.

But a compromise was being hammered out. Non-Opec Omani minister Mohammad al-Rahmi, a close ally of of the big Gulf producers, said he expected the Saudis to secure the full 1.7m increase.

Expectations that the Opec countries would ease their output restrictions has already driven down the price of oil by 20% over the past two weeks. The price has also been affected by widespread breaking of official quota limits.

Crude oil futures were trading slightly lower in New York yesterday with US crude for May at $27.60, down 42 cents.

fields.headline: Movers
fields.trailText: It was a day when the old economy watchers waited for Opec and new economy investors went bargain hunting. The meeting of oil ministers in Vienna kept the oil stocks in nervous mood while BP Amoco suffered an additional burden in the shape of Friday night's court move by ExxonMobil aimed at thwarting the former's takeover of Atlantic Richfield.
fields.body:
It was a day when the old economy watchers waited for Opec and new economy investors went bargain hunting. The meeting of oil ministers in Vienna kept the oil stocks in nervous mood while BP Amoco suffered an additional burden in the shape of Friday night's court move by ExxonMobil aimed at thwarting the former's takeover of Atlantic Richfield.

BP Amoco shares lost 30p to 513p and accounted for almost half of the overall 51.3 point decline in the FTSE 100 index to 6,687.2.

Shell was down just 7p at 471p.

Much of the rest of the fall in the index came from losses at three pharmaceutical stocks with GlaxoWellcome down 78p to £17.70, SmithKline losing 34p to 827p and AstraZeneca shedding 56p to £27.34.

Biotech group Nycomed Amersham suffered from the generally gloomy tone from the health sector, losing 45p to 545p.

Great Universal Stores was out of favour after the recent run on buy-out speculation. The shares closed down 28p at 391p.

Indeed positive news was hard to find among the leading stocks. However, internet security firm Baltimore Technology managed to add 787p to £97.72 on the back of a recent positive broker's comment and a better showing from Nasdaq.

Entrepreneur Philip Green's move for Bhs helped out the stores sector, though Storehouse shares themselves lost 6p to 43p - in part because investors had been looking for a bid for the whole group, rather than one part.

Selfridges gained 6p to 234p and Debenhams added 5p to 145p on hopes of more consolidation in the sector.

Telecoms provider Thus was in the spotlight, climbing 13p to 691p as it revealed new pricing plans. Analysts are now looking to BT, up 23p to £12.87, and to Colt Telecom, down 161p to £33.20, for a response to the Thus initiative.

While the FTSE 100 index lost ground, TechMark, though still way below its best, picked up modestly as did the FTSE Midcap index as investors went shopping for good buys among smaller biotech and high technology listings.

"It is partly a year-end rush for technology ISAs," according to one trader. "But the Nasdaq was also strong on Friday and today."

Trading volume in the leading stocks was thinner than of late with dealers blaming fund manager reluctance to change their asset allocations at this stage in the financial year for the relatively modest turnover of 1.3bn shares.

Great Universal Stores was out of favour after the recent run on buy-out speculation. The shares closed down 28p at 391p. Indeed positive news was hard to find among the leading stocks. However, internet security firm Baltimore Technology managed to add 787p to £97.72 on the back of a recent positive broker's comment and a better showing from Nasdaq. Entrepreneur Philip Green's move for Bhs helped out the stores sector, though Storehouse shares themselves lost 6p to 43p - in part because investors had been looking for a bid for the whole group, rather than one part. Selfridges gained 6p to 234p and Debenhams added 5p to 145p on hopes of more consolidation in the sector. Telecoms provider Thus was in the spotlight, climbing 13p to 691p as it revealed new pricing plans. Analysts are now looking to BT, up 23p to £12.87, and to Colt Telecom, down 161p to £33.20, for a response to the Thus initiative. While the FTSE 100 index lost ground, TechMark, though still way below its best, picked up modestly as did the FTSE Midcap index as investors went shopping for good buys among smaller biotech and high technology listings. "It is partly a year-end rush for technology ISAs," according to one trader. "But the Nasdaq was also strong on Friday and today." Trading volume in the leading stocks was thinner than of late with dealers blaming fund manager reluctance to change their asset allocations at this stage in the financial year for the relatively modest turnover of 1.3bn shares.

webTitle: Scottish Radio turns up takeover heat

fields.headline: Scottish Radio turns up takeover heat
fields.trailText: Scottish Radio Holdings yesterday turned up the heat in its hostile takeover bid for rival Border Television when it questioned the management of the company's key radio assets.
fields.body:
Scottish Radio Holdings yesterday turned up the heat in its hostile takeover bid for rival Border Television when it questioned the management of the company's key radio assets.

Richard Findlay, Scottish Radio chief executive, accused Border of obscuring listener figures for its two biggest stations as he launched the company's offer document. Scottish Radio failed to secure an agreed takeover two weeks ago.

Mr Findlay pointed to a 15% drop in hours spent tuned in to Border's north-west and north-east franchises in the last three months of 1999 and underlined the departure of the managing director of the group's radio division in the summer.

"Independence is no longer a realistic option for Border. They have taken an extraordinary position by not talking to their shareholders about this offer. The directors of the company are not acting in the proper interests of their owners."

The size of the bid has fallen slightly to around £114m as Scottish Radio shares have given up a little of their value. The paper offer is now worth around £10.54 a share.

Border repeated its earlier line that the offer represents a "significant undervaluation" of the company and will publish its defence document in the next two weeks.

Paul Corley, Border chief executive said he was astonished that Scottish Radio had chosen to attack on the number of hours listened to the stations during a given quarter, which he said is always volatile. A better indication, he suggested, was reach - the percentage of people in an area tuning in over a given month - which was growing.

"I can't see much new in their offer document," he said. "Our stance is the same."

The publication of Scottish Radio's offer document could be the trigger for a bidding war to break out over Border. Capital Radio, Chrysalis, Scottish Media Group and Kelvin MacKenzie's Wireless Group are all thought to be circling. A first round of talks between Scottish Radio and Border fell apart two years ago.

Scottish Radio shares closed 7.5p lower at £17.85 and Border was 7.5p down at £11.55.

At the same time, Scottish Radio sought to calm fears among local MPs in the Border Television region that the proposed acquisition would dilute the franchises commitment to local programming.

webTitle: Railtrack blow to Virgin west coast plans

fields.headline: Railtrack blow to Virgin west coast plans
fields.standfirst: Regulator threatens legal action over 'promises made and not kept' as £5bn upgrade falls behind
fields.trailText: Railtrack is likely to fail to deliver the much-vaunted west coast mainline upgrade, scuppering Sir Richard Branson's plans to start high-speed Virgin Trains services between London and Glasgow by May 2002, the rail regulator warned last night.
fields.body:
Railtrack is likely to fail to deliver the much-vaunted west coast mainline upgrade, scuppering Sir Richard Branson's plans to start high-speed Virgin Trains services between London and Glasgow by May 2002, the rail regulator warned last night.

Tom Winsor, the regulator, is threatening legal action against Railtrack for falling behind on the £5.3bn upgrade of the west coast main line, and suggested that it might not be in a position to complete the project by the agreed date for Virgin's 125mph service. He said Railtrack was running into difficulty - although the job could "still be done".

Mike Grant, chief executive of the shadow Strategic Rail Authority, later joined Mr Winsor in expressing doubts about Railtrack's ability to deliver the project, the most crucial improvement in Britain's railways this decade. Mr Grant said: "It is important that we are given the confidence that the first stage of the operation will be delivered on time."

Upgrading track and signals is crucial to Sir Richard's plans for high-speed tilting trains, cutting the journey time between Manchester and London to less than two hours. Virgin said that Railtrack was confident of meeting its target, but if it failed Virgin would be entitled to compensation.

The new trains ordered by Virgin are on schedule. They will start to appear in the summer of 2001. All the fleet will be in place by October 2002.

Robin Gisby, Railtrack's director of network development, said he was "obviously disappointed" by Mr Winsor's action. He said that the company was "on schedule" to allow Virgin to run 125mph trains in 2002.

Mr Winsor said that exposing Railtrack through the courts would be a sufficient deterrent and there would be no fine. He agreed that he had a deteriorating relationship with Railtrack and that "it has been a history of promises made and not kept". The west coast project was two years behind schedule and its cost had climbed from £2.1bn to £5.3bn.

Mr Winsor said he was disappointed by Railtrack: "Like me, the travelling public simply will not understand or accept Railtrack's behaviour."

The company suffered another blow last night when an employment tribunal upheld an order by the railways inspectorate requiring it to improve 22 signals which had been passed when indicating danger.

The order was issued after the Paddington crash last October, but Railtrack appealed against it. The order does not affect the infamous signal 109, which was taken out of commission.

 Chris Leah, formerly Railtrack's operations director, has been appointed director of safety and environment.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.body:
BP Amoco in Alaska move
BP Amoco is planning to ring fence Atlantic Richfield's Alaskan Prudhoe Bay assets, after a legal challenge from ExxonMobil, in an attempt to get its acquisition of Arco approved by the US federal trade commission.

On Friday, ExxonMobil issued a legal challenge to try to stop BP Amoco selling Arco's share in the Prudhoe Bay oil field to Phillips Petroleum.

XS Leisure to post loss
British XS Leisure said yesterday that it expected to make a pre-tax loss in the year to March 31 after discovering "certain accounting errors within the company".

"The monthly management accounts appear to have overstated the company's profitability by a considerable margin," it said, adding that finance director Philip Bunt had resigned and his share options had been cancelled.

EC clears way for BT deal
The European Commission has cleared BT's acquisition of Irish telecom operator Esat subject to conditions on distribution agreements in Ireland.

The commission found that the proposed acquisition raised serious doubts for competition on the Irish market for distribution of global telecommunications services.

In the market for global telecom services, the BT-Esat deal would have controlled 50%-60% of the Irish market for these services, mostly supplied to multinationals, it said.

The combined entity would have distributed the Concert service of BT and AT&T Corp, Global One services via its exclusive distribution agreement with Esat, and Infonet products via a non-exclusive deal with Esat, it said.

Ofgem looks at Scotland
Ofgem said it will launch a thorough review of electricity arrangements in Scotland, as it believes a number of these arrangements "may be stifling the successful development of competition".

It said the review was due by May. It will review potential barriers to competition and will look at the allocation, pricing and trading arrangements over the interconnector.

Ofgem also said it intended to refuse Scottish Power's application to reserve 75% of the upgraded capacity on the Scotland-England interconnector.

Shuffle in store for FXF Trust
Shares in FXF Trust soared yesterday after Kerry Packer's Consolidated Press said it would restructure the company into an investment vehicle that would share in the Australian media baron's market savvy.

Other companies linked to Mr Packer such as television and magazine group Publishing and Broadcasting and internet service provider Ecorp also rose.

webTitle: Imports and pound add weight to deficit

fields.headline: Imports and pound add weight to deficit
fields.trailText: Surging consumer demand for imports and the impact of the strong pound on exports left Britain with its biggest current account deficit for almost a decade last year, according to official figures released yesterday.
fields.body:
Surging consumer demand for imports and the impact of the strong pound on exports left Britain with its biggest current account deficit for almost a decade last year, according to official figures released yesterday.

Despite the strength of the service sector and the country's sizeable earnings from its overseas assets, a £700m deficit in 1998 was turned into a £12.8bn shortfall last year - the highest since 1990.

With data from the Office for National Statistics showing that rising household spending was the driving force behind robust growth in the final three months of last year, City analysts warned that the figures shortened the odds on further rises in interest rates from the Bank of England.

The ONS said the economy expanded 0.8% in the fourth quarter of the year, while the annual growth rate nudged up from 2.9% to 3%. Final domestic demand - which the Bank has already cited as a cause for concern - in the year to the fourth quarter was revised upwards from 4% to 4.4%.

However, there were some hints that the economy may be starting to cool off, with higher interest rates in the autumn prompting individuals to push up the proportion of their disposable incomes saved rather than spent, and corporate profits falling slightly.

On the trade front, the ONS reported that Britain's deficit in goods stood at £26.6bn last year, its highest on record. The shortfall was offset, however, by traditional strength in in visible trade, where the surplus on services was worth more than £13bn and the surplus on investment income almost £8bn. Transfers to international institutions - mainly the European Union - added nearly £5bn to the current account deficit.

An unexpectedly hefty £3bn surplus on investment income in the final few months of the year meant that the overall deficit of £2.8bn in the fourth quarter was £1bn less than the City had been braced for, but analysts stressed that the flows were very erratic and could not be relied upon to continue at the current rate.

Dharshini David, of HSBC, said that even if the investment account continued to improve in 2000, the current account was poised to deteriorate and would be a significant drag on growth.

"The shortfall could easily widen towards the £20bn mark this year, a fairly dramatic widening given that the current account was broadly in balance in 1998", she said.

fields.headline: Green wins Bhs chain for £200m
fields.trailText: Storehouse, the embattled retail group, yesterday accepted a £200m offer for Bhs, the clothing and homewares chain, from entrepreneur Philip Green in a move which leaves its Mothercare children's shops to soldier on alone.
fields.body:
Storehouse, the embattled retail group, yesterday accepted a £200m offer for Bhs, the clothing and homewares chain, from entrepreneur Philip Green in a move which leaves its Mothercare children's shops to soldier on alone.

Shares in the group, which had run up strongly in hopes that a bidding contest would produce a better price, declined sharply as the market accepted that Mr Green's "take it or leave it" bid represented the best deal on offer.

Shares in Storehouse ended the session yesterday 8p lower at 42p.

A rival consortium - including Stephen Tucker, the Monaco-based financier, Nigel Whittaker, a former Kingfisher director, and Lord MacLaurin, the ex-Tesco boss - said yesterday it would let shareholders decide on its offer to parachute in a management team to turn round the business.

Other potential bidders such as Iceland, which recently cemented a deal to open food halls in Bhs shops, and the discount retailer Brown & Jackson have ruled themselves out of the bidding process.

Analysts said long suffering Storehouse investors were more likely to take Mr Green's money and then hope that the rump of the group, which will be left with debts of £70m to £80m, would provide a cash windfall of about £100m.

Mr Green, who has bounced back with the Storehouse bid after his takeover approaches to Marks & Spencer were rejected, said yesterday that he had no fixed plans to overhaul Bhs. But he won considerable investor support when he acquired and profitably broke up the Sears retail empire.

"At the moment I haven't got a fixed plan. Let's get it [the deal] completed. This season is pretty much in stone, they've got all the product committed so we need to work our way through that."

Mr Green said he would spend the next two months evaluating Bhs before deciding on an action plan.

He had made no decisions about the Bhs management - now headed by Stephen Tague. He added: "I need to interview the people, meet the people and evaluate where we are. I never have preconceived plans.

"I haven't met the management yet and I need to get the management on side." Meetings would take place in the next "two to three days" but before then he thought it important not to worry staff and executives by putting about ideas for change.

Mr Green said he had been prepared to bid for the whole group if the Storehouse board had turned down his offer for Bhs, although he admitted the management was "down the road to sorting out Mothercare and I'd rather focus on sorting out Bhs".

Mothercare accounted for £472m of the group's sales of £856.2m last year.

However, the company expects better returns following a decision to concentrate on the pre-school age group and the addition of 40 large Mothercare World stores, which have been performing better than the average in the portfolio. More than 80 Mothercare stores have been targeted for closure.

A Storehouse official said the January trading statement showed that the Mothercare business was improving and she said the group now intended to invest in its internet business.

Clive Vaughan, director of consultancy at Retail Intelligence, said Mr Green should be able to help Bhs take advantage of a period in which M&S has been trading poorly. Bhs had a number of potential strengths - more than 4m sq ft of well located retail space, customer familiarity and a good logistics infrastructure - of which Mr Green could take advantage.

fields.headline: British shipyards snubbed
fields.standfirst: MoD says UK lacks expertise to win £300m order for ro-ro ferries
fields.trailText: The Ministry of Defence is ready to order £300m of ferries from continental European shipbuilders while British yards such as Harland & Wolff and Govan are on the brink of collapse.
fields.body:
The Ministry of Defence is ready to order £300m of ferries from continental European shipbuilders while British yards such as Harland & Wolff and Govan are on the brink of collapse.

A contract for six roll-on roll-off ships will be placed early next month and the total deal, which also includes a 20-year management contract, is said to be worth a total of £1bn.

Only one of the four bidding consortiums includes a British shipyard - the Sealion grouping is lead by BAE Systems which owns the Govan yard in Scotland. Although all the groups vying to win the lucrative deal have to include a quote for work to be carried out by a British shipbuilder, this does involve any commitment to use a UK yard.

A spokesman for the MoD, who admitted that this was the first time the government had decided to build ships under the private finance initiative, said: "There are considerable savings to be had and we have to get the best value for money- we have to justify the money we spend as part of the defence budget."

But the failure by the government to support hard-pressed British shipbuilding is bound to increase criticism of its attitude towards traditional industry, particularly as it follows the loss of a cruise ship contract by the Northern Ireland yard Harland & Wolff, which now has only the slimmest prospects of survival.

The government's difficulties have worsened with accusations in the maritime industry that the MoD will seek to offset this disappointment by placing a £350m contract for troop ships - which qualify as military vessels to be built in a British yard - with the Belfast shipbuilder.

Jaap Kroese, the owner of Swan Hunter - which is based in the Wallsend constituency of trade and industry secretary Stephen Byers - has already threatened to sue if the troop ship contract is awarded to Harland &Wolff on political grounds. Mr Byers has been criticised for his handling of BMW's decision to sell Rover in a move which is expected to cost 6,000 jobs, and will not welcome fresh anger from shipbuilders.

Mr Kroese was quoted in the shipping newspaper Lloyd's List as saying: "When 5,000 jobs go in Birmingham [at Rover] there is a minister there the next day promising them support. When 30,000 jobs go in the north-east nobody bothers about it."

A 1,000-strong protest march took place on the Newcastle quayside at the weekend and another demonstration, converging on the Houses of Parliament, is planned for April 12.

The MoD spokesman declined to detail the potential savings from paying for support ships through the private finance initiative but appeared to admit that the chances of a British shipyard winning in the process would be limited. "Yards in the UK haven't built roll-on roll-off ferries for 20 years. Some yards don't even have the design capability to build them. It would be potentially high risk for a project manager to use a British yard."

The government has made a concession to British shipbuilders: it gave the Sealion consortium extra time to submit a bid after the ailing Scottish shipyard Govan was sold to BAE Systems late last year.

The MoD spokesman was adamant, however, that the government would not favour national shipbuilders with the huge contract. "We cannot subsidise ... It does not make sense to use yards which don't have the capability, which are not competitive, to produce a certain type of vessel. This is strictly commercial and completely different from warships where we have a UK-build policy."

webTitle: Do Sarah Lucas's pictures make you think of sex?

fields.headline: Do Sarah Lucas's pictures make you think of sex?
fields.standfirst: Chairs in Y-fronts, light bulbs that look like breasts... Sarah Lucas has let her subconscious run wild at the Freud Museum. By  Adrian Searle
fields.trailText: Chairs in Y-fronts, light bulbs that look like breasts... Sarah Lucas has let her subconscious run wild at the Freud Museum. By Adrian Searle
fields.body:
The thought of Sarah Lucas on the rampage in Sigmund Freud's house feels unlikely and alarming, but also disgracefully inevitable. Somehow, I don't see Lucas spending her evenings in with Freud's Collected Works and an apple. It isn't her style even if in some quarters, reading psycho-analytic literature has become almost mandatory for the theoretically inclined artist and critic. Her works, currently installed at the Freud Museum in Hampstead, do not give you the feeling that she is either paying homage to Freud and Freudian thought, or contesting or illustrating Freud's ideas - even if there are works here with titles like Hysterical Attack and Beyond the Pleasure Principle.

As much as her titles lead us to Freud, they lead us to thoughts of sex and death, to the self and its images. For Lucas, this is nothing new. But it must be said that the Freud Museum show is, in almost every respect, an advance on works that she recently presented in the Fag Show at the London gallery Sadie Coles HQ.

Art relates to art as much as it does to the person who makes it. I look at Lucas's objects in the Freud Museum and, as much as I'm led back to Freud and the years I spent on someone's couch, I'm reminded of Hans Bellmer's terrifying dolls, of Louise Bourgeois's contorted torsos and a whole gamut of artists who, like Lucas, use and reuse commonplace objects. Looking at her work, you can be stultified by its obviousness. But then it hangs around in your head. Look again, and it gets more complex, more rich, less funny and more tart and painful. Lucas's work has, at its best, a terrible pathos, cloaked in a crass, knockabout, very English humour.

There is something unmentionable in the room on the right at the top of the stairs. A cabinet of curios and Freudian mementos stands against one wall. There's a sofa and a desk in the room, and in the middle of the carpet a horrendous agglomeration of things: a strip light piercing a half-suspended red mattress. Globe lights dangle from the fluorescent tube, like cartoon testicles. The glowing strip-light rears up at an equally schematic woman, sketched in by a bucket (a red light illuminating its interior) and light-bulb breasts. Everything is held precariously in place, as if put together in a great hurry. Down on the floor, the mattress flops over a cardboard coffin. This ghastly arrangement would be puerile, if it weren't so hilarious, if it weren't so lively.

Down in the dining room, two of the chairs have been turned into human surrogates. One chair sits on the oak table, a bra and panties stretched over the back and the seat, big globe light bulbs filling the bra. The second chair wears vest and Y-fronts, from which emerges another strip light, angled up and under the chair on the table. Let's do it on the table, one half of the work seems to say. Don't put me on a pedestal, says the other half. It is all very rumbustious and absurd: all that striving, all that posing, all that getting it up and getting it down. The language of sex and the language of sculpture aren't so very different - it is all about mistaking one object for another, being alert to the rightness and wrongness of things.

In the inner sanctum of Freud's consulting room Lucas has placed two extruded figures, made from papier-mache and covered in pictures of mouths and eyes snipped from newspapers and magazines. They grow out of two kitchen chairs. They're hopeless, headless creatures, but great sculptures. They make me want to shriek - look how sensitively they grow from the chair-backs, how nastily elegant they are as forms. "It's a Vagina Dentata!" I remember Brian Sewell yelling when he was on Derek Jameson's couch with Michael Winner in the early days of Sky TV.

Behind Freud's famous couch, with its covering of old brocade and the inviting, plumped-up cushions, Lucas has installed a huge blown-up photograph of herself. Like the two figures in the room, she is headless, and the photo is a close-up of her T-shirt. There's a ragged hole in the shirt, near the neck. Another, neatly hemmed peep-hole reveals her nipple. Imagine lying on the couch, mumbling on to the good doctor, while staring at the wall, and finding there images of breasts, gaping holes, rended fabric, maternal and masturbatory fantasy images. And all the while drivelling on for the full 50 minutes, the doctor going "Hmmmn" behind the serried ranks of figurines perched on his desk.

You can't analyse the artist through the things they make, although it is often amusing to try. Artists are sly. Artists tell lies, artists are self-mythologists. The things they make inevitably have a bearing on their inner lives - and vice versa - but the relationship is a slippery one. What leads us to look, and to look again, you might ask, if not our our own desires? Lucas's exhibition is both highly theatrical and very much a sculpture show. She really does have a feel for materials, for placement, for throwing ideas in the air and keeping them suspended. She might be running amok in this dead Viennese household, but at least she's keeping things alive - like a hysteric, like a child.

 Beyond the Pleasure Principle: Sarah Lucas is at the Freud Museum, London NW3, till April 12. Details: 0171-435 2002.

fields.headline: Crackdown may mean 15 new jails
fields.trailText: Fifteen new jails must be built to house the thousands of extra offenders who will be imprisoned each year under tough sentencing to be brought in by the Home Office, probation officers will warn today.
fields.body:
Fifteen new jails must be built to house the thousands of extra offenders who will be imprisoned each year under tough sentencing to be brought in by the Home Office, probation officers will warn today.

There could be about 60,000 additional offenders each year as a result of the legislation, the National Association of Probation Officers warned.

The criminal justice and court services bill, which received its second reading yesterday, aims to tighten penalties for offenders breaching community sentences and to crack down on drug offenders.

But probation officers predicted the legislation would require 15 new jails and cost £210m a year. Napo said that up to 40,000 offenders who breached community sentences, as well as 10,000 offenders denied bail because they tested positive for class A drugs on arrest, would be jailed. And the prison population could be increased by up to 7,500 offenders each year who breached curfews and orders to attend drug treatment centres.

Napo's assistant general secretary, Harry Fletcher, said: "The majority of this group need treatment and assistance, not punishment."

The Home Office dismissed Napo's figures as "nonsense", estimating that 15,000 people breaching orders under the new rules would be jailed.

A spokeswoman said: "We have calculated that, as a result of the enforcement proposals, around 2,000 extra prison places will be required."
